required for these Final Specifications after 1st July 2022.

1 Introductory Material 1 
1.1 Foreword 2 
This Technical Specification has been produced by the O-RAN Alliance. 3 
The contents of the present document are subject to continuing work within O-RAN and may change following formal 4 
O-RAN approval. Should the O-RAN Alliance modify the contents of the present document, it will be re-released by O-5 
RAN with an identifying change of release date and an increase in version number as follows: 6 
Release x.y.z 7 
where: 8 
x the first digit is incremented for all changes of substance, i.e. technical enhancements, corrections, updates, 9 
etc. (the initial approved document will have x=01). 10 
y the second digit is incremented when editorial only changes have been incorporated in the document. 11 
z the third digit included only in working versions of the document indicating incremental changes during the 12 
editing process. 13 
1.2 Scope 14 
1.2.1 General 15 
The present document defines tests that validate the conformance to the protocols defined in [2] for the Lower Layer 16 
Split Option 7.2x interface between the O-RU and the O-DU.  A guiding principle for these conformance tests is to use 17 
only standard interfaces that are defined by the specification [2] or relevant 3GPP specifications.  The construction of 18 
these tests avoids the requirement for a device to include any special interfaces used solely for the purpose of these 19 
tests. 20 
While these tests are not written to evaluate the performance of an O-DU or O-RU device, some tests require obtaining 21 
measurements and evaluating the success or failure of the device to process sample data correctly based on portion of 22 
the protocol being tested at the time.     23 
In general, unless otherwise stated, the tests cover LTE (Stand-Alone), NR Non-Stand-Alone (NSA) and NR Stand-24 
Alone (SA).  25 
In the main body of this specification (in any “chapter”) the information contained therein is normative meaning 26 
binding on any compliant system, unless explicitly described as informative (a capability described as “optional” may 27 
or may not be included in a compliant system but if it is included it must comply with the optional capability 28 
description).  Information contained in an “Annex” to this specification is always informative. 29 
1.2.2 U-Plane and C-Plane Scope 30 
This version of the Conformance Test specification defines tests which validate the conformance of an O-RU and O-31 
DU.  The tests are designed to cover a large number of optional functionalities defined in [2].  Therefore, for any given 32 
O-RU implementation, a subset of these tests may not be applicable.  It is the responsibility of the tester to understand 33 
the applicability of each test to the feature provided by a particular O-RU.    34 
1.2.3 S-Plane  35 
This version of the Conformance Test specification defines tests for time synchronization of the O-RU and O-DU.  The 36 
tests defined in this version include both functional and performance tests.  Functional tests validate the ability of the O-37 
RU and O-DU to achieve the proper synchronization management state based on a variety of PTP, and optionally 38 
SyncE input conditions.  Performance tests validate the conformance of the recovered clock for the O-DU or O-RU.   39 
Concerning the scope of the S-Plane, various synchronization options have been defined in the ORAN CUS 40 
Specification [2] for distributing synchronization to the O-RU (LLS-C1, LLS-C2, LLS-C3 and LLS-C4). Depending on 41 
the specific ORAN deployment being considered not all of them may be relevant. When testing the S-Plane, the tester 42 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       7 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
shall identify which of the test cases are relevant depending on the specific deployment scenarios addressed. As a 1 
general guideline the following applies: 2 
1) Direct connection between O-DU and O-RU:  3 
 LLS-C1 is generally the main sync option to be validated.  4 
 LLS-C4 may be considered as alternative or as a complement to C1 5 
2) Synchronization network between O-DU and O-RU 6 
 LLS-C2 for cases where the synchronization is delivered to the O-RU via the O-DU and over the bridged 7 
network. In this topology the PRTC synchronizing the O-DU may be local or remote.  8 
 LLS-C3 for cases when the synchronization is distributed to the O-RU without involving the O-DU. In 9 
this case one or more PRTC may be remote and may also be local. 10 
 LLS-C4 may be considered as alternative or as a complement to LLS-C2/C3 11 
For LLS-C1 and LLS-C2, a local PRTC is either embedded in or co-located with the O-DU. A remote PRTC is 12 
located anywhere in the network (backhaul or fronthaul).    13 
 14 
 15 
1.2.4 Test Requirement Status 16 
The following table is a list of each test in this conformance specification and status of the test as REQUIRED or 17 
CONDITIONAL MANDATORY.  Note that tests that are REQUIRED are for those functions of the DUT that by 18 
specification are required to be supported.  Optional functionality in a DUT implies that the corresponding conformance 19 
test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY and is mandatory only if the DUT supports the optional functionality.  20 
The M-Plane conformance tests are applicable to both the O-RU and the O-DU.  Some of the M-Plane tests are 21 
specifically targeting the protocol conformance of the O-RU and are not necessary for conformance testing of a O-DU.  22 
Therefore, for M-Plane tests, the table below has two “Test Requirement” columns describing if the test is mandatory, 23 
conditional mandatory or optional for testing an O-RU or a O-DU.   If a test is OPTIONAL, it does not need to be 24 
included in a conformance test of the device but could be included if desired.  25 
Test 
Number O-RU Test Requirement O-DU Test Requirement Test Description 
M-Plane

1.3 References 3 
The following documents contain provisions which, through reference in this text, constitute provisions of the present 4 
document. 5 
- References are either specific (identified by date of publication, edition number, version number, etc.) or 6 
non-specific. 7 
- For a specific reference, subsequent revisions do not apply. 8 
- For a non-specific reference, the latest version applies. In the case of a reference to a 3GPP document (including 9 
a GSM document), a non-specific reference implicitly refers to the latest version of that document. 10 
 11 
[1] 3GPP TR 21.905, “Vocabulary for 3GPP Specifications” 12 
[2] O-RAN WG4 Control, User and Synchronization Specification version 08.00 13 
[3] O-RAN WG4 Management Plane Specification version 08.00 14 
[4] O-RAN Management Plane Yang Models version 08.00 15 
[5] ITU-T G.8275.1 (Amendment 2), Precision time protocol telecom profile for phase/time synchronization with 16 
full timing support from the network, ITU, March 2018 17 
[6] ITU-T G.8275.2 (Amendment 2), Precision time protocol telecom profile for phase/time synchronization with 18 
partial timing support from the network, ITU, March 2018 19 
[7] ITU-T G.8271.1 (Amendment 1), “Network limits for time synchronization in packet networks”, ITU, March 20 
2018 21 
[8] ITU-T G.8271.2 (Amendment 1), “Network limits for time synchronization in packet networks with partial 22 
timing support from the network”, ITU, March 2018 23 
[9] ITU-T G.8273, “Framework of phase and time clocks”, ITU, March 2018 24 
[10] ITU-T G.8261, “Timing and synchronization aspects in packet networks”, ITU, August 2013 25

transmission and reception” 28

1.3.1 Definitions 18 
For the purposes of the present document, the terms and definitions given in 3GPP TR 21.905, “Vocabulary for 3GPP 19 
Specifications”[1]and the following apply. A term defined in the present document takes precedence over the definition 20 
of the same term, if any, in [1] 21 
C-Plane Control Plane: refers specifically to real-time control between O-DU and O-RU, and should not be 22 
confused with the UE’s control plane 23 
DL DownLink: data flow towards the radiating antenna 24 
eNB eNodeB (applies to LTE) <E-UTRAN NodeB / Evolved NodeB> 25 
EVM Error Vector Magnitude – see section 6.5.2 Modulation quality in 3GPP TS 38.104 26 
fm-pm Fault Management, Performance Management role 27 
gNB gNodeB (applies to NR) <Next Generation NodeB> 28 
M-Plane Management Plane: refers to non-real-time management operations between the O-DU and the O-29 
RU 30 
NETCONF Network Configuration Protocol. For details see: RFC 6241, “Network Configuration Protocol 31 
(NETCONF)”, IETF, June 2011 32 
NSA Non-Stand-Alone network mode that supports operation of SgNB attached to MeNB 33 
O-CU O-RAN Central Unit – a logical node hosting PDCP, RRC, SDAP and other control functions 34 
O-DU O-RAN Distributed Unit: a logical node hosting RLC/MAC/High-PHY layers based on a lower 35 
layer functional split. O-DU in addition hosts an M-Plane instance. 36 
O-RU O-RAN Radio Unit <O-RAN Radio Unit: a logical node hosting Low-PHY layer and RF 37 
processing based on a lower layer functional split. This is similar to 3GPP’s “TRP” or “RRH” but 38 
more specific in including the Low-PHY layer (FFT/iFFT, PRACH extraction).>. O-RU in 39 
addition hosts M-Plane instance. 40 
PTP Precision Time Protocol (PTP) is a protocol for distributing precise time and frequency over 41 
packet networks. PTP is defined in the IEEE Standard 1588. 42 
PDCCH Physical Downlink Control Channel applies for LTE and NR air interface 43 
PBCH Physical Broadcast Channel applies for LTE and NR air interface 44 
SA Stand-Alone network mode that supports operation of gNB attached to a 5G Core Network 45 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       20 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
SCS OFDM Sub Carrier Spacing 1 
SSB Synchronization Signal Block, in 5G PBCH and synchronization signal are packaged as a single 2 
block 3 
subordinate The term “subordinate” is used as a replacement for “slave” and is consistent with its use in CUS 4 
specification. When consensus emerges on how to eliminate the use of the term “slave” in the 5 
referenced standards organization, that approach will be applied to this specification 6 
sudo Super-User Do role 7 
S-Plane Synchronization Plane: Data flow for synchronization and timing information between nodes 8 
SyncE Synchronous Ethernet, is an ITU-T standard for computer networking that facilitates distribution 9 
of clock signals over the Ethernet physical layer 10 
T-BC Telecom Boundary Clock 11 
TWAMP Two-Way Active Measurement Protocol 12 
UDP User Datagram Protocol 13 
UE User Equipment terminology for a mobile device in LTE and NR 14 
UL UpLink: data flow from the UE towards the core network, that is from the O-RU towards in the O-15 
DU in a Fronthaul context. 16 
1.3.2 Abbreviations 17 
For the purposes of the present document, the following abbreviations apply.  18 
 19 
C-Plane Control Plane: refers specifically to real-time control between O-DU and O-RU, and should not be 20 
confused with the UE’s control plane 21 
CUSM-E C-Plane, U-Plane, S-Plane and M-plane emulator – test equipment capable of sending and 22 
receiving required messages for all of these protocol planes when the Radio Unit is the device 23 
under test 24 
DL DownLink: data flow towards the radiating antenna 25 
DUT Device Under Test 26 
eNB e NodeB (applies to LTE)  <E-UTRAN NodeB / Evolved NodeB> 27 
gNB g NodeB (applies to NR)  <Next Generation NodeB> 28 
M-Plane Management Plane: refers to non-real-time management operations between the O-DU and the O-29 
RU 30 
NETCONF Network Configuration Protocol. For details see RFC 6241, “Network Configuration Protocol 31 
(NETCONF)”, IETF, June 2011 32 
SMO Service Management and Orchestration  33 
O-DU O-RAN Distributed Unit  <O-RAN Distributed Unit: a logical node hosting 34 
PDCP/RLC/MAC/High-PHY layers based on a lower layer functional split.> 35 
O-RU O-RAN Radio Unit  <O-RAN Radio Unit: a logical node hosting Low-PHY layer and RF 36 
processing based on a lower layer functional split.  This is similar to 3GPP’s “TRP” or “RRH” but 37 
more specific in including the Low-PHY layer (FFT/iFFT, PRACH extraction).> 38 
S-Plane Synchronization Plane: refers to traffic between the O-RU or O-DU to a synchronization controller 39 
which is generally an IEEE-1588 Grand Master (however, Grand Master functionality may be 40 
embedded in the O-DU). 41 
TED Test Equipment, O-DU – test equipment used to validate the O-DU 42 
TER Test Equipment, O-RU – test equipment used to validate the O-RU 43 
UL UpLink: data flow away from the radiating antenna 44 
U-Plane User Plane: refers to IQ sample data transferred between O-DU and O-RU  45

Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
2 Test Configuration 1 
The conformance tests described in this document require test equipment with specific capabilities to support the testing 2 
of each protocol including the M-Plane, U-Plane, C-Plane and S-Plane. In addition, the tests define a specific 3 
connectivity between the test equipment and the device under test.  This section describes the test equipment 4 
requirements at a high level.  Details are included in each test.   5 
As noted in the introduction in the Scope paragraphs, the initial focus of the M-Plane, C-Plane and U-Plane 6 
conformance tests is the O-RU.  Version 2.00 and later include S-Plane tests for the O-DU in addition to the S-Plane 7 
tests for the O-RU.  The initial test configuration description below is focused on the test equipment and configuration 8 
required to test the O-RU. O-DU test configuration descriptions for the S-Plane are covered in the S-Plane section of 9 
this document. 10 
2.1 Test Configuration for O-RU as the Device Under Test 11 
When testing the O-RU, it is connected to test equipment called Test Equipment O-RU (TER).  The TER is shown in  12 
Figure 2.1-1 below.   TER surrounds the DUT and connects to both the fronthaul interface itself and the radio interface. 13 
At the radio interface, the TER collects RF signals from the DUT (downlink) and sends RF signals to the DUT receiver 14 
(uplink).  Thus, the TER is made up of three main components, a CUSM-Plane Emulator (CUSM-E), a signal analyzer 15 
and a signal generator as shown in Figure 2.1-1. The RF test interface is described in TS 36.141 for LTE, TS 38.141-1 16 
for NR conducted, and TS 38.141-2 for non-conducted tests.  The fronthaul interface is standard Ethernet as described 17 
above.  In this case, the DL data flow is evaluated based on what is received by the signal analyzer in the RF domain as 18 
radiated by the O-RU, and the UL data flow is evaluated based on what is emitted by the signal generator in the RF 19 
domain and received by the CUSM-E.   20 
When the O-RU is the Device Under Test (DUT), there is Test Equipment, RU (“TER”) that is used to connect to the DUT, run the test and evaluate the test result.fronthaul connectionDUT = O-RURF connection orantenna array(s)Test Equipment, RU(TER)CUSM-Plane EmulatorSignal GeneratorThe Test Equipment, RU (“TER”) provides everything needed to operate the test, including:M-Plane commands to collect O-RU capabilities and configure the O-RUSynchronization via G.8275.1 (Mandatory for O-RU)C-Plane and U-Plane data flow to the O-RUCollection of RF energy to determine if the O-RU reacted correctly to the DL C-Plane and U-Plane dataRadiation of RF energy to be received by the O-RU (note: this could be actually radiated, or conveyed through multiple RF cabled connections)Collection of O-RU UL fronthaul data flows and evaluating it for correctness based on the supplied RF energy to the O-RU antennas or RF connectorsSignal Analyser
 21 
Figure 2.1-1 Test Setup, DUT = O-RU 22 
While M-Plane conformance tests do not generally require all the functions shown for a TER in Figure 2.1-1, the intent 23 
of this description is to show the general capabilities required for all tests on the O-RU as the DUT including U-Plane, 24 
C-Plane and S-Plane tests.  If tests are restricted to only the M-Plane, the required test equipment configuration may 25 
also refer to Note: The M-Plane test equipment functions for supplementary circuitry and RS-485 sniffer/injector shown 26 
as CONDITIONAL MANDATORY in the figure above are only needed if the DUT supports. 3.1.9.1 External Input / 27 
Output Ports, 3.1.9.2 External Output Port State Control or 3.1.11.1 ALD Communications Test. 28 
Figure 2.1-2. 29

Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       22 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
When the O-RU is the Device Under T est (DUT), there is T est Equipment, RU (“TER”) that is used to connect to the DUT , run the test and evaluate the test result.Fronthaul connectionDUT = O-RUM-Plane Conformance TestEquipment, RU(TER)MS-Plane EmulatorSupplementary circuitryThe M-Plane Conformance T est Equipment, RU (“TER”) provides everything needed to operate the test, including:M-Plane commands to collect O-RU capabilities and configure the O-RUSynchronization via G.8275.1 (Mandatory for O-RU) is required to generate an “No external sync source” alarm.RS-485 sniffer / injector is required to validate the ALD communications protocol and operation of the O-RU for ALD Communications T est. (This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY : only needed if the DUT supports ALD port) Supplementary circuitry is required to force a change of logical state of input lines and confirm voltage of an output lines for External Input / Output Port T est. (This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY : only needed if the DUT supports External Input / Output Port)ALDExternal I/OCONDITIONAL MANDATORYRS-485sniffer / injector

CONDITIONAL MANDATORY in the figure above are only needed if the DUT supports. 3.1.9.1 External Input / 3 
Output Ports, 3.1.9.2 External Output Port State Control or 3.1.11.1 ALD Communications Test. 4 
Figure 2.1-2 M-Plane Test Setup, DUT = O-RU 5 
2.2 Test Configuration for O-DU as the Device Under Test 6 
When testing the open fronthaul interface of the O-DU, it is connected to test equipment called Test Equipment O-DU 7 
(TED).  The TED is shown below with the following two cases:  8 
1. Stand-alone O-DU as the DUT – In this case the TED wraps around the O-DU DUT via its F1 interface 9 
towards the Core + O-CU Emulator (and additionally X2 signalling emulator in NSA), the front haul interface 10 
towards the O-RU+UE Emulator, and the O1 or EMS interface towards the test configuration entity. 11 
2. Combined O-CU+O-DU (from the same vendor) as the DUT - In this case the TED wraps around the 12 
combined O-CU + O-DU DUT via the NG (SA) or S1 and X2 (NSA) interfaces towards the Core Emulator 13 
(additionally the X2 signalling emulator in NSA), the front haul interface towards the O-RU+UE Emulator, 14 
and the O1 or EMS interface towards the test configuration entity.   15 
 16 
 17  18 
Figure 2.2-2 Test Setup, DUT = O-DU 19 
 20 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       23 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
It is important to note that the tests assume production grade DUTs which should not be placed into any special test 1 
modes nor require any special test ports.  At the front haul interface, the O-RU+UE Emulator is expected to perform the 2 
following functions: 3 
1. Exchange of front haul data as required to exercise the feature under test.  This entails emulating the necessary 4 
front haul signals as seen by the O-DU DUT as if it were connected to an actual O-RU with an actual UE (or 5 
multiple UEs in the case of beamforming tests) performing an actual connection with the base station.   6 
2. Detailed observation and analysis of the front haul data stream of the O-DU DUT in order to ascertain 7 
compliance to the specifications.    8 
Note that in addition to the C-, U-, and M-plane signals in the fronthaul, this also includes the necessary S-plane for 9 
synchronizing the O-DU DUT with the O-RU+UE Emulator.   10 
Since the O-DU is meant to support various classes of O-RU with different feature sets, e.g. CAT-A or CAT-B, FR1 or 11 
FR2, different beamforming methods to multiple UEs, different compression schemes, etc.., it is important that the O-12 
RU+UE Emulator has the flexibility to effectively emulate the various scenarios in a robust and repeatable manner in 13 
order to test the various features.   Similarly, the Core+O-CU emulator (with the addition of an X2 signalling emulator 14 
for NSA mode) shall likewise emulate and observe the appropriate signals at the F1 or NG (or S1 and X2 for NSA) 15 
interfaces to effectively wrap-around the O-DU or O-CU+O-DU DUT.  Note that the Core, O-CU, eNB, O-RU, and UE 16 
emulator functionalities required in the TED are those that place the O-DU or O-CU+O-DU DUT into a state that 17 
allows it to perform an actual connection(s) to a UE(s) to exercise the various open fronthaul features under test, and are 18 
thus not required to fully emulate the full functionality of their commercial equivalents.  Conversely, this specification 19 
does not preclude the use of the commercial equivalent elements instead of emulators, but must support a level of 20 
configurability and repeatability to ensure that the required features in the O-DU front-haul are effectively and 21 
repeatably exercised.  With use of either node emulators or commercial equivalents, the required test outcomes and 22 
reports must be effectively and repeatably reproduced.         23 
In order to cover the various potential optional features, section types, and section extensions for the O-DU DUT, the 24 
TED should use the O1 (if available) or EMS interface to provision the O-DU or O-CU+O-DU DUT in order to place it 25 
into the appropriate modes to exercise the specific features to test, which is then coordinated with the O-RU+UE 26 
Emulator in order to elicit the appropriate front-haul interface behavior.   27 
While M-Plane conformance tests do not generally require all the functions shown for a TED in Note: The M-Plane test 28 
equipment functions for supplementary circuitry and RS-485 sniffer/injector shown as CONDITIONAL 29 
MANDATORY in the figure above are only needed if the DUT supports. 3.1.9.1 External Input / Output Ports, 3.1.9.2 30 
External Output Port State Control or 3.1.11.1 ALD Communications Test. 31 
Figure 2.1-2, the intent of this description is to show the general capabilities required for all tests on the O-DU as the 32 
DUT including U-Plane, C-Plane and S-Plane tests.  If tests are restricted to only the M-Plane, the required test 33 
equipment configuration may be simplified. 34 
3 Conformance Measurements 35 
3.1 M-Plane Measurements 36 
The O-RAN Fronthaul management plane (M-Plane) protocol conformance tests are described in this section.   The M-37 
Plane is based on the NETCONF network element management protocol and YANG data modeling language.  The 38 
NETCONF protocol uses a client and server model for all exchanges of information and execution of RPCs.  Every 39 
NETCONF transaction is a 2-way exchange involving the client and the server.  The O-DU must support a NETCONF 40 
client and the O-RU must support a NETCONF server.  Any test written to exercise either the O-DU (client) or O-RU 41 
(server) is therefore applicable to both the O-DU and the O-RU.   42 
The following sections describe Conformance Tests for the M-Plane.   While all of these M-Plane conformance tests 43 
could apply to both the O-DU and the O-RU, some tests are focused primarily on the O-RU NETCONF server 44 
capabilities and functions.   Therefore, each test below is identified as a conformance test for the O-DU, the O-RU or 45 
both.  Table 1.2.4-1  lists all M-Plane test cases and whether they are applicable to one or both of the O-DU and O-RU 46 
for conformance testing. 47 
 48 
 49 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       24 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
3.1.1 Transport and Handshake Test Scenarios 1 
 Transport and Handshake in IPv4/SSH Environment (positive case) 2 
 3 
A. Test Description and Applicability 4 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY for a O-RU or O-DU that declares support for IPv4. 5 
This scenario validates that the O-RU properly executes the session establishment procedure with VLANs and a 6 
DHCPv4 server.  This test is applicable to IPv4 environments. 7 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 8 
 6,2 Management Plane Transport aspects  9 
 6.3 NETCONF Call Home to O-RU Controller(s) 10 
 11 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 12 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 13 
configured and connected to the O-RU 14 
 15 
C. Test Methodology 16 
a. Initial Conditions 17 
1. The O-RU is powered on and has an ethernet connection to the DHCP-server 18 
2. The configured DHCPv4 server is reachable by the O-RU NETCONF Server through the VLAN 19 
configured for M-Plane. 20 
3. Default SSH credentials (sudo) are used by both the O-RU NETCONF Server and the TER NETCONF 21 
Client 22 
4. IP details for test purposes are pre-defined and fixed (applies to the DHCP server). 23 
 24 
b. Procedure 25 
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server can be preconfigured with no VLAN (known in 802.1Q as native ethernet 26 
or an untagged VLAN), a VLAN ID or may optionally perform a VLAN scan by issuing DHCP Discover 27 
trying to reach the DHCP Server 28 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server continues the DHCPv4 procedure on the preconfigured VLAN or first 29 
VLAN where the Offer from DHCP Server / Relay is received if the scan method is used 30 
3. O-RU NETCONF Server retrieves IP details and the IP address of the controlling TER NETCONF Client 31 
from the DHCP Server.  Note: RFC 2131 is followed for DHCPv4 32 
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server establishes TCP connection and performs a Call Home procedure towards 33 
the NETCONF Client using the IP details obtained in step 3 34 
5. The TER NETCONF Client establishes a SSH session with the O-RU NETCONF Server.  Proper 35 
credentials are used. 36 
6. The O-RU NETCONF Server accepts the SSH session establishment from the TER NETCONF Client 37 
7. The TER NETCONF Client and O-RU NETCONF Server exchange capabilities through NETCONF 38 
<hello> messages.  The following is an abbreviated example of the capabilities exchange.  A typical 39 
capabilities exchange will have far more parameters included. 40 
Note: RFC 6241 is followed for NETCONF communication. 41 
Server (O-RU) initiates Hello message . 42 
<hello xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 43 
  <capabilities> 44 
    <capability>urn:ietf:params:netconf:base:1.0</capability> 45 
    <capability>urn:ietf:params:netconf:base:1.1</capability> 46 
    <capability>urn:ietf:params:netconf:capability:writable-47 
running:1.0</capability> 48 
    49 
<capability>urn:ietf:params:netconf:capability:notification:1.0</capabilit50 
y> 51 
    52 
<capability>urn:ietf:params:netconf:capability:interleave:1.0</capability> 53 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       25 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
    <capability>http://org/openroadm/user-mgmt?module=org-openroadm-user-1 
mgmt&amp;amp;amp;revision=2017-12-15</capability> 2 
…… 3 
  </capabilities> 4 
  <session-id>1</session-id> 5 
</hello>  6 
 7 
Client (DU) responds with Hello message … 8 
<hello xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 9 
  <capabilities> 10 
    <capability>urn:ietf:params:netconf:base:1.0</capability> 11 
    <capability>urn:ietf:params:netconf:base:1.1</capability> 12 
  </capabilities> 13 
</hello> 14 
 15 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  16 
Test scenario step 7 is performed successfully. 17 
 Transport and Handshake in IPv4/SSH Environment (negative case) 18 
A. Test Description and Applicability 19 
This scenario is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 20 
This scenario validates that the O-RU properly executes the session establishment procedure with VLANs and a 21 
DHCPv4 server.  This test is applicable to IPv4 environments.  Two negative flows are included in this test: 22 
 The TER NETCONF Client does not trigger a SSH session establishment in reaction to Call Home 23 
initiated by THE O-RU NETCONF Server. 24 
 The TER NETCONF Client uses improper credentials when trying to establish a SSH session with the O-25 
RU NETCONF Server. 26 
 27 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 28 
 6.2 Management Plane Transport aspects 29 
 6.3 NETCONF Call Home to O-RU Controller(s) 30 
 31 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 32 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 33 
configured and connected to the O-RU. 34 
 35 
C. Test Methodology 36 
a. Initial Conditions 37 
a. O-RU is powered on and has an ethernet connection to the DHCP-server 38 
b. Configured DHCPv4 server is reachable for O-RU NETCONF Server through the VLAN configured for 39 
M-Plane. 40 
c. Default SSH credentials (sudo) are used by both O-RU NETCONF Server and NETCONF Client 41 
d. IP details for test purposes are pre-defined and fixed (applies to DHCP server). 42 
b. Procedure 43 
i. Flow 1 44 
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server can be preconfigured with no VLAN (known in 802.1Q as native 45 
ethernet or an untagged VLAN), a VLAN ID or may optionally perform a VLAN scan by issuing a 46 
DHCP Discover trying to reach DHCP Server 47 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server continues the DHCPv4 procedure on the preconfigured VLAN or first 48 
VLAN where the Offer from the DHCP Server / Relay is received if the scan method is used 49 
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server retrieves IP details and the IP address of controlling TER NETCONF 50 
Client from the DHCP Server.  Note: RFC 2131 is followed for DHCPv4 51 
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server establishes TCP connection and performs Call Home procedure with 52 
the TER NETCONF Client using IP details obtained in step 3 53 
5. The TER NETCONF Client does not initiate the SSH session establishment procedure. 54 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       26 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
6. The O-RU NETCONF Server periodically repeats the Call Home towards TER NETCONF Client.  1 
 2 
ii. Flow 2 3 
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server can be preconfigured with a VLAN ID or may optionally perform a 4 
VLAN scan by issuing a DHCP Discover trying to reach the DHCP Server 5 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server continues the DHCPv4 procedure on the preconfigured VLAN or first 6 
VLAN where the Offer from the DHCP Server / Relay is received if the scan method is used 7 
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server retrieves IP details and the IP address of the controlling TER 8 
NETCONF Client from DHCP Server.  Note: RFC 2131 is followed for DHCPv4 9 
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server establishes a TCP connection and performs the Call Home procedure 10 
with the TER NETCONF Client using IP details obtained in step 3 11 
5. The TER NETCONF Client initiates the SSH session establishment procedure with improper 12 
credentials. 13 
6. Due to the incorrect SSH credentials, the O-RU NETCONF Server rejects the SSH session 14 
establishment from the TER NETCONF Client. 15 
7. The O-RU NETCONF Server starts periodic Call Home procedure towards the TER NETCONF 16 
Client. 17 
 18 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  19 
1. Flow 1: Scenario reaches step 6.  The O-RU NETCONF Server falls into Call Home procedure loop. 20 
2. Flow 2: Scenario reaches step 7.  The O-RU NETCONF Server falls into Call Home procedure loop. 21 
 22

Client 43

 45

Discover trying to reach DHCP Server 49 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server continues DHCPv6 procedure on the preconfigured VLAN or first VLAN 50

b.    Procedure 38

ethernet or an untagged VLAN), a VLAN ID or may optionally perform a VLAN scan by issuing 41 
DHCP Discover trying to reach DHCP Server 42 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server continues the DHCPv6 procedure on the preconfigured VLAN or first 43 
VLAN where the Offer from DHCP Server / Relay is received if the scan method is used 44

4. The O-RU NETCONF Server establishes a TCP connection and performs the Call Home procedure to 47 
the TER NETCONF Client using IP details obtained in step 3 48 
5. NETCONF Client does not initiate a SSH session establishment procedure. 49 
6. The O-RU NETCONF Server periodically repeats Call Home to the NETCONF Client.  50 
 51 
ii. Flow 2 52 
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server can be preconfigured with a VLAN ID or may optionally perform a 53 
VLAN scan by issuing DHCP Discover trying to reach DHCP Server 54

7. The O-RU NETCONF Server starts periodic Call Home procedure to the TER NETCONF Client. 11

 6.3 NETCONF Call Home to O-RU Controller(s) 14 
 15 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 16 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 17 
configured and connected to the O-RU. 18 
 19 
C. Test Methodology 20 
a. Initial Conditions 21 
1. The O-RU is powered on and has an ethernet connection to the DHCP-server 22 
2. The previously configured DHCPv6 server is reachable by the O-RU NETCONF Server through the 23 
VLAN configured for M-Plane. 24 
3. Default TLS credentials (sudo) are used by both the O-RU NETCONF Server and the TER NETCONF 25 
Client 26 
4. IP details for test purposes are pre-defined and fixed (applies to the DHCPv6 server) 27 
 28 
b.    Procedure 29 
i. Flow 1 30 
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server can be preconfigured with no VLAN (known in 802.1Q as native 31 
ethernet or an untagged VLAN), a VLAN ID or may optionally perform a VLAN scan by issuing 32 
DHCP Discover trying to reach DHCP Server 33 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server continues the DHCPv6 procedure on the preconfigured VLAN or first 34 
VLAN where the Offer from DHCP Server / Relay is received if the scan method is used 35 
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server retrieves IP details and the IP address of the controlling TER 36 
NETCONF Client from the DHCP Server.  Note: RFC 3315 is followed for DHCPv6 37 
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server establishes a TCP connection and performs the Call Home procedure to 38 
the TER NETCONF Client using IP details obtained in step 3 39 
5. NETCONF Client does not initiate a TLS connection establishment procedure. 40 
6. The O-RU NETCONF Server periodically repeats Call Home to the NETCONF Client.  41 
 42 
ii. Flow 2 43 
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server can be preconfigured with a VLAN ID or may optionally perform a 44 
VLAN scan by issuing DHCP Discover trying to reach DHCP Server 45 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server continues DHCPv6 procedure on the preconfigured VLAN or first 46 
VLAN where the Offer from the DHCP Server / Relay is received if the scan method is used 47 
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server retrieves IP details and the IP address of the controlling TER 48 
NETCONF Client from the DHCP Server.  Note: RFC 3315 is followed for DHCPv6 49 
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server establishes TCP connection and performs a Call Home procedure to the 50 
TER NETCONF Client using IP details obtained in step 3 51 
5. The TER NETCONF Client initiates a TLS connection establishment procedure with improper 52 
credentials.   53 
6. Due to the incorrect TLS credentials, the O-RU NETCONF Server rejects the TLS connection 54 
establishment from the TER NETCONF Client. 55 
7. The O-RU NETCONF Server starts periodic Call Home procedure to the TER NETCONF Client. 56 
 57 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       32 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  1 
1. Flow 1: Scenario reaches step 6.  The O-RU NETCONF Server falls into Call Home procedure loop. 2 
2. Flow 2: Scenario reaches step 7.  The O-RU NETCONF Server falls into Call Home procedure loop. 3 
 4 
3.1.2 Manage Alarm Requests 5 
 Subscription to Notifications 6 
A. Test Description and Applicability 7 
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 8 
This test validates that the O-RU properly handles a NETCONF subscription to notifications. 9 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 10 
11.3 Manage Alarms Request to NETCONF Clients 11 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 12 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 13 
operational, configured and connected to the O-RU 14 
 15 
C. Test Methodology 16 
a. Initial Conditions 17 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.1.1 (IPv4/SSH) or 3.1.1.3 (IPv6/SSH) or 3.1.1.5 (IPv4/TLS) 18 
or 3.1.1.7 (IPv6/TLS)  is successfully completed. 19 
 20 
b. Procedure 21 
1. The TER NETCONF Client triggers the subscription:  22  23 
<rpc><create-subscription><stream>NETCONF</stream></create-24 
subscription></rpc>   25 
to the O-RU NETCONF Server to subscribe to notifications related to the supervision process. Note: 26 
<stream>NETCONF</stream> is intentional, meaning that the TER NETCONF Client subscribes to all 27 
notifications that the O-RU NETCONF Server can generate (including alarm notifications). 28 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with   29  30 
<rpc-reply><ok/></rpc-reply>   31 
 32 
to the TER NETCONF Client. 33 
 34 
Note: RFC 6241 is followed for NETCONF communication. 35 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  36 
Test scenario step 2 is performed successfully. 37 
 38 
3.1.3 M-Plane Connection Supervision 39 
 M-Plane connection supervision (positive case) 40 
A. Test Description and Applicability 41 
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 42 
This test validates that the O-RU manages the connection supervision process correctly. 43 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 44 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       33 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 6.7 Monitoring NETCONF connectivity 1 
 2 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 3 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 4 
configured and connected to the O-RU 5 
 6 
C. Test Methodology 7 
a. Initial Conditions 8 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.1.1 (IPv4/SSH) or 3.1.1.3 (IPv6/SSH) or 3.1.1.5 (IPv4/TLS) or 9 
3.1.1.7 (IPv6/TLS)  is successfully completed. 10 
 11 
b. Procedure 12 
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server supervision timer expires 13 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server sends a supervision notification message to the TER NETCONF Client.  14 
Note that the time in this example is shown generically and will be the current time during this test.  15 
 16 <notification xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:notification:1.0"> 17 
  <eventTime>YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ</eventTime> 18 
  <supervision-notification xmlns="urn:o-ran:supervision:1.0"/> 19 
</notification> 20 
 21 
3. The TER NETCONF Client responds with  22 
<rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-23 
id="20"> 24 
  <supervision-watchdog-reset xmlns="urn:o-ran:supervision:1.0"> 25 
        <supervision-notification-interval>60</supervision-26 
notification-interval> 27 
        <guard-timer-overhead>10</guard-timer-overhead> 28 
    </supervision-watchdog-reset> 29 
</rpc> 30 
 31 
to the O-RU NETCONF Server. 32 
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server sends a reply to the TER NETCONF Client 33 <rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-34 
id="20"> 35 
  <next-update-at xmlns="urn:o-ran:supervision:1.0">2020-10- YYYY-MM-36 
DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </next-update-at> 37 
</rpc-reply> 38 
 39 
5. Note that the TER NETCONF Client can change the value of the supervision timer in the supervision 40 
watchdog reset message. The O-RU NETCONF server must adjust the timer accordingly if this optional 41 
test is performed. 42 
6. The O-RU NETCONF Server sends a supervision notification towards the TER NETCONF Client with 43 
respect to time-date sent in rpc-reply in step 3. 44 
7. Steps 1 to 4 are looped for a total of 30 iterations including the first pass through steps 1 to 4. 45 
Note: RFC 6241 is followed for NETCONF communication. 46 
 47 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 48 
Test scenario step 5 is performed successfully in all iterations. 49 
 50 
 M-Plane Connection Supervision (negative case) 51 
A. Test Description and Applicability 52 
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 53 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       34 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
This test validates that the O-RU manages the connection supervision process correctly. 1 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 2 
 6.7 Monitoring NETCONF connectivity 3 
 4 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 5 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 6 
operational, configured and connected to the O-RU 7 
 8 
C. Test Methodology 9 
a. Initial Conditions 10 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.1.1 (IPv4/SSH) or 3.1.1.3 (IPv6/SSH) or 3.1.1.5 (IPv4/TLS) or 11 
3.1.1.7 (IPv6/TLS) is successfully completed. 12 
 13 
b. Procedure 14 
1. The O-RU NETCONF Server supervision timer expires 15 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server sends a supervision notification message to the TER NETCONF Client 16 
3. The TER NETCONF Client responds with  17 
 <rpc supervision-watchdog-reset></rpc> 18 
to the O-RU NETCONF Server. 19 
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server sends a reply to the TER NETCONF Client 20 
<rpc-reply><next-update-at>date-time</next-update-at></rpc-reply> 21 
5. Note that the TER NETCONF Client can change the value of the supervision timer in the supervision 22 
watchdog reset message. The O-RU NETCONF server must adjust the timer accordingly if this optional 23 
test is performed. 24 
6. The O-RU NETCONF Server sends a supervision notification towards the TER NETCONF Client with 25 
respect to time-date sent in rpc-reply in step 3. 26 
7. The TER NETCONF Client does not issue <rpc supervision-watchdog-reset></rpc> to the O-RU 27 
NETCONF Server and causes the watchdog timer to expire on the O-RU. 28 
8. The O-RU NETCONF Server enters the Supervision failure scenario. For details, please see O-RAN M-29 
Plane Specification [3], chapter 14.1. 30 
 31 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 32 
Test scenario step 7 is performed successfully. 33 
 34 
 35 
3.1.4 Retrieval of O-RU's information elements 36 
 Retrieval without Filter Applied 37 
 38 
A. Test Description and Applicability 39 
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 40 
This scenario validates that the O-RU NETCONF Server properly executes a general get command. 41 
This is a general-purpose high-level test related to NETCONF implementation.  There is no direct relationship to a 42 
specific chapter in [3]: 43 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 44 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 45 
configured and connected to the O-RU. 46 
C. Test Methodology 47 
a. Initial Conditions 48 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       35 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.1.1 (IPv4/SSH) or 3.1.1.3 (IPv6/SSH) or 3.1.1.5 (IPv4/TLS) or 1 
3.1.1.7 (IPv6/TLS)  is successfully completed. 2 
 3 
b. Procedure 4 
1. The TER NETCONF Client triggers <rpc><get> towards the O-RU NETCONF Server. 5 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with <rpc-reply><data> where <data> contains all information 6 
elements that the O-RU NETCONF Server is able to expose 7 
 8 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 9 
Test step 2 is performed successfully. 10 
 Retrieval with filter applied 11 
 12 
A. Test Description and Applicability 13 
This scenario is MANDATORY 14 
This scenario validates that the O-RU NETCONF Server properly executes a get command with a filter applied. 15 
This is a general-purpose high-level test related to NETCONF implementation.  There is no direct relationship to a 16 
specific chapter in [3]: 17 
B. Minimum Requirements 18 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 19 
configured and connected to the O-RU. 20 
C. Test Methodology 21 
a. Initial Conditions 22 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.1.1 (IPv4/SSH) or 3.1.1.3 (IPv6/SSH) or 3.1.1.5 (IPv4/TLS) or 23 
3.1.1.7 (IPv6/TLS)  respectively is successfully completed. 24 
 25 
b. Procedure 26 
1. The TER NETCONF Client triggers <rpc><get><filter> towards NETCONF Server.  The <filter> 27 
argument contains a regular expression that the O-RU NETCONF Server shall apply as a filter. For 28 
example, a filter that filters all low-level-rx-endpoints:  29 
  <rpc message-id="101" xmlns="urn:o-ran:uplane-conf:1.0" > 30 
      <get> 31 
          <source>running</source> 32 
          <filter type = ”subtree”> 33 
              <top xmlns="urn:o-ran:uplane-conf:1.0/”> 34 
                  <user-plane-configuration> 35 
                      <low-level-rx-endpoints> 36 
                      </low-level-rx-endpoints> 37 
                  </user-plane-configuration> 38 
              </top> 39 
          </filter> 40 
      </get> 41 
   </rpc> 42 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with <rpc-reply><data> where <data> contains details for objects 43 
as conforming to the <filter> (as per the above example filter: all low-level-rx-endpoints) 44 
 45 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 46 
Test step 2 is performed successfully. 47 
 48 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       36 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
3.1.5 Fault Management 1 
 O-RU Alarm Notification Generation  2 
 3 
A. Test Description and Applicability 4 
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 5 
This scenario validates that the O-RU NETCONF Server properly sends and alarm notification. 6 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 7 
 11.2 Alarm Notification 8 
 9 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 10 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 11 
configured and connected to the O-RU. 12 
C. Test Methodology 13 
a. Initial Conditions 14 
The test procedure described in section 3.1.2.1 for Subscription to Notifications is successfully completed. 15 
 16 
b. Procedure 17 
1. The TER NETCONF Client periodically tests O-RU’s sync-status until the LOCKED state is reached. 18   <rpc message-id="101" xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 19 
      <get> 20 
            <filter type = ”subtree”> 21 
              <top xmlns="urn:o-ran:sync:1.0/”> 22 
                  <sync><sync-status></sync-status></sync> 23 
              </top> 24 
          </filter> 25 
      </get> 26 
   </rpc> 27 
2. Disable the Sync signal on the TER. 28 
3. After a while (time depends on implementation) the O-RU NETCONF SERVER sends a notification for 29 
an alarm related to synchronization failure, e.g. alarm 17: No external sync source” or another vendor 30 
specific alarm.  The format of alarm notification follows RFC5277.   Note that the time in this example is 31 
shown generically and will be the current time during this test. 32 
 33 
<notification xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:notification:1.0"> 34 
  <eventTime> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </eventTime> 35 
  <alarm-notif xmlns="urn:o-ran:fm:1.0"> 36 
    <fault-id>17</fault-id> 37 
    <fault-source>sync</fault-source> 38 
    <affected-objects> 39 
      <name>syncE</name> 40 
    </affected-objects> 41 
    <fault-severity>MAJOR</fault-severity> 42 
    <is-cleared>false</is-cleared> 43 
    <fault-text>No external sync source</fault-text> 44 
    <event-time> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </event-time> 45 
  </alarm-notif> 46 
</notification> 47 
 48 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 49 
Test step 3 is performed successfully. 50 
 51 
 Retrieval of Active Alarm List 52 
 53 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       37 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
A. Test Description and Applicability 1 
This scenario is MANDATORY for O-RU tests and OPTIONAL for O-DU tests. 2 
This scenario validates that the O-RU NETCONF Server can send an active alarms list to the TER NETCONF 3 
Client. 4 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 5 
 11.  Fault Management 6 
 7 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 8 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 9 
configured and connected to the O-RU. 10 
C. Test Methodology 11 
a. Initial Conditions 12 
The test procedure described in section 3.1.2.1 for Subscription to Notifications is successfully completed. 13 
 14 
b. Procedure 15 
1. The TER NETCONF Client sends the O-RU NETCONF Server a command to get the active-alarm-list. 16   <rpc message-id="101" xmlns=" urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" 17 
> 18 
      <get> 19 
          <filter type = ”subtree”> 20 
              <top xmlns="urn:o-ran:fm:1.0/”> 21 
                  <active-alarm-list></active-alarm-list> 22 
              </top> 23 
          </filter> 24 
      </get> 25 
   </rpc> 26 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with <rpc-reply><data> where <data> contains at least the same 27 
alarm as reported in measurement 3.1.5.1 28 <rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-29 
id="11"> 30 
  <data xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 31 
    <active-alarm-list xmlns="urn:o-ran:fm:1.0"> 32 
      <active-alarms> 33 
        <fault-id>17</fault-id> 34 
        <fault-source>sync</fault-source> 35 
        <affected-objects> 36 
          <name>syncE</name> 37 
        </affected-objects> 38 
        <fault-severity>MAJOR</fault-severity> 39 
        <is-cleared>false</is-cleared> 40 
        <fault-text>No external sync source</fault-text> 41 
        <event-time> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </event-time> 42 
      </active-alarms> 43 
    </active-alarm-list> 44 
  </data> 45 
</rpc-reply> 46 
 47 
Note – There can be more than one Active Alarm in the reply from O-RU.  48 
 49 
 50 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 51 
Test step 2 is performed successfully. 52 
 53 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       38 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
3.1.6 O-RU Software Update 1 
 O-RU Software Update and Install (positive case) 2 
A. Test Description and Applicability 3 
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 4 
This test validates that the O-RU can successfully perform a software download and software install procedure. 5 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 6 
 8. Software Management 7 
 8 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 9 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 10 
configured and connected to the O-RU. 11 
C. Test Methodology 12 
a. Initial Conditions 13 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 14 
2. A correct and internally consistent SW package is available for test purposes. 15 
3. The O-RU provides at least one slot available for SW update procedure.  The status of this slot is assumed 16 
to be {active = False, running = False, access = READ-WRITE} 17 
4. A sFTP server is available with an account for the SW update procedure on the TER 18 
 19 
b. Procedure 20 
1. The TER NETCONF Client triggers <rpc><software-download>.  The O-RU NETCONF Server responds 21 
with <rpc-reply><software-download> 22 <rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="13"> 23 
  <software-download xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 24 
         <remote-file-25 
path>sftp://oranuser@192.168.3.13:22/Trace.zip</remote-file-path> 26 
    </software-download> 27 
</rpc> 28 
 29 
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-30 
id="13"> 31 
  <status xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0">STARTED</status> 32 
</rpc-reply> 33 
 34 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server performs a software download procedure.  When the download is 35 
completed, the O-RU NETCONF Server sends <notification><download-event> with status 36 
COMPLETED to TER NETCONF Client 37 <notification xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:notification:1.0"> 38 
  <eventTime> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </eventTime> 39 
  <download-event xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 40 
    <file-name>sftp://oranuser@192.168.3.13:22/Trace.zip</file-name> 41 
    <status>COMPLETED</status> 42 
  </download-event> 43 
</notification> 44 
 45 
 46 
3. The TER NETCONF Client triggers <rpc><software-install> informing the O-RU NETCONF Client 47 
about the desired slot for installation.  This slot must have the attributes active = FALSE, running = 48 
FALSE, access = READ-WRITE.  The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with <rpc-reply><software-49 
install> with status STARTED. 50 <rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="14"> 51 
  <software-install xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 52 
         <slot-name>"SLOT0"</slot-name> 53 
   <file-names>"testpkg"</file-names> 54 
    </software-install> 55 
</rpc> 56 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       39 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-2 
id="14"> 3 
  <status xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0">STARTED</status> 4 
</rpc-reply> 5 
 6 
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server examines the downloaded software.  The files are error free by design in 7 
this test.  The O-RU NETCONF Server installs the new software files to the desired slot.  8 
 9 
5. The O-RU NETCONF Server sends <notification><install-event><status> to the TER NETCONF Client. 10 
Field <status> contains the value COMPLETED to indicate the successful installation of software to the 11 
desired slot. 12 <notification xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:notification:1.0"> 13 
  <eventTime> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </eventTime> 14 
  <install-event xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 15 
    <slot-name>"SLOT0"</slot-name> 16 
    <status>COMPLETED</status> 17 
  </install-event> 18 
</notification> 19 
 20 
 21 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 22 
1. Test step 5 completed with notification that indicates successful installation of the downloaded software. 23 
2. Status of SW slot used for SW installation is set to VALID.  Other parameters of software slot shall not be 24 
changed. 25 
 26 
 O-RU Software Update (negative case) 27 
A. Test Description and Applicability 28 
This scenario is MANDATORY for O-RU tests and OPTIONAL for O-DU tests. 29 
This scenario corresponds the following chapters in [3]: 30 
 8. Software Management 31 
B. Test Entrance Criterea 32 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 33 
configured and connected to the O-RU. 34 
C. Test Methodology 35 
a. Initial Conditions 36 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 37 
2. A modified software package is available for test purposes (proper content of manifest.xml, but 38 
fake/invalid content of software files) 39 
3. The O-RU provides at least one slot available for the software update procedure (status != INVALID, 40 
active = False, running = False, access = READ-WRITE) 41 
4. A sFTP server is available with an account dedicated for the software update procedure 42 
 43 
b. Procedure 44 
1. The TER NETCONF Client triggers <rpc><software-download>.  The O-RU NETCONF Server responds 45 
with <rpc-reply><software-download> 46 <rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-47 
id="13"> 48 
  <software-download xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 49 
         <remote-file-50 
path>sftp://oranuser@192.168.3.13:22/Trace.zip</remote-file-path> 51 
    </software-download> 52 
</rpc> 53 
 54 
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-55 
id="13"> 56 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       40 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
  <status xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0">STARTED</status> 1 
</rpc-reply> 2 
 3 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server performs the software download procedure.  When the download is 4 
complete, the O-RU NETCONF Server sends <notification><download-event> with status COMPLETED 5 
to the TER NETCONF Client 6 <rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-7 
id="13"> 8 
  <software-download xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 9 
         <remote-file-10 
path>sftp://oranuser@192.168.3.13:22/Trace.zip</remote-file-path> 11 
    </software-download> 12 
</rpc> 13 
 14 
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-15 
id="13"> 16 
  <status xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-17 
management:1.0">COMPLETED</status> 18 
</rpc-reply> 19 
 20 
3. The TER NETCONF Client triggers <rpc><software-install> informing the O-RU NETCONF Server 21 
about desired slot the software shall be installed to.  The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with <rpc-22 
reply><software-install> with status STARTED. 23 <rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="14"> 24 
  <software-install xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 25 
         <slot-name>"SLOT0"</slot-name> 26 
   <file-names>"testpkg"</file-names> 27 
    </software-install> 28 
</rpc> 29 
 30 
<rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-31 
id="14"> 32 
  <status xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0">STARTED</status> 33 
</rpc-reply> 34 
 35 
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server determines that the software file is invalid and sends <notification><install-36 
event><status> to the TER NETCONF Client.  The Field <status> is correctly updated with one of the 37 
following status: FILE_ERROR or INTEGRITY_ERROR or APPLICATION_ERROR. 38 <notification xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:notification:1.0"> 39 
  <eventTime> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </eventTime> 40 
  <install-event xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 41 
    <slot-name>"SLOT0"</slot-name> 42 
    <status> FILE_ERROR </status> 43 
  </install-event> 44 
</notification> 45 
 46 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 47 
1. Test step 4 completed a described. 48 
2. Status of SW slot used for SW installation is set to INVALID.  Other parameters of software slot shall not be 49 
changed. 50 
 51 
3.1.7 O-RU Software Activation 52 
 Software Activation without Reset 53 
 54 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       41 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
A. Test Description and Applicability 1 
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 2 
This test validates that the O-RU can successfully activate software in a specific slot on the O-RU. 3 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 4 
 8. Software Management 5 
 6 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 7 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 8 
configured and connected to the O-RU. 9 
C. Test Methodology 10 
a. Initial Conditions 11 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.6.1 is successfully completed. 12 
 13 
b. Procedure 14 
1. The TER NETCONF Client triggers <rpc><software-activate> towards the O-RU NETCONF Server.  15 
The name of a slot containing a valid software installation to be activated is provided as a parameter in the 16 
RPC.  17 <rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="15"> 18 
  <software-activate xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 19 
         <slot-name>"SLOT0"</slot-name> 20 
 </software-activate> 21 
</rpc> 22 
 23 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with <rpc-reply><software-activate><status>.  The parameter 24 
"status" is set to STARTED. 25 <rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-26 
id="15"> 27 
  <status xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0">STARTED</status> 28 
</rpc-reply> 29 
 30 
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server performs a software activation procedure. When the procedure is 31 
completed, the O-RU NETCONF Server sends <notification><activation-event> with a status 32 
COMPLETED and the slot-name in the activation event corresponds to the slot-name used in the 33 
software-activate RPC to the TER NETCONF Client. 34 <notification xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:notification:1.0"> 35 
  <eventTime> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </eventTime> 36 
  <activation-event xmlns="urn:o-ran:software-management:1.0"> 37 
    <slot-name>"SLOT0"</slot-name> 38 
    <status>COMPLETED</status> 39 
  </activation-event> 40 
</notification> 41 
 42 
 43 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 44 
1. In step 3 of this test, the status of the software slot used for software activation is set to VALID and the 45 
parameter "active" is set to "True".  The parameter "running" remains "False". 46 
2. Status of the software slot containing the software still used by device remains VALID, the parameter 47 
"active" is set to False. The parameter "running" is True. 48 
Note: O-RU reset is required to complete SW activation sequence - meaning: to force device to start with the 49 
software just activated.  50 
 Supplemental Reset after Software Activation 51 
 52 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       42 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
A. Test Description and Applicability 1 
This scenario is MANDATORY for  O-RU tests and OPTIONAL for O-DU tests. 2 
This test validates that the O-RU can successfully start up with activated software. 3 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 4 
 8. Software Management 5 
 6 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 7 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 8 
configured and connected to the O-RU. 9 
C. Test Methodology 10 
a. Initial Conditions 11 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.6.1 is successfully completed. 12 
 13 
b. Procedure 14 
1. The TER NETCONF Client sends <rpc><reset></rpc> to the O-RU NETCONF Server.  15 <reset xmlns=”urn:o-ran:operations:1.0”> </reset> 16 
 17 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with rpc-reply. 18 3. <reset xmlns=”urn:o-ran:operations:1.0”> ok</reset> 19 
 20 
4. The O-RU restarts with a new software version running matching the version activated in test 3.1.7.1. 21 
 22 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 23 
1. In step 3 of this test, the status of the software slot used for software activation remains VALID (it is 24 
unchanged) and the parameter "active" remains "True".  The parameter "running" is set to True. 25 
2. Status of the software slot containing the previous version of software used by device remains VALID, the 26 
parameter "active" remains False. The parameter "running" is set to False. 27

3.1.8 Access Control 29 
 Sudo on Hybrid M-plane Architecture (positive case) 30 
 31 
A. Test Description and Applicability 32 
This scenario is MANDATORY for an O-RU and O-DU supporting the Hybrid M-plane architecture model. 33 
This test validates that user management model can be used to add users to the O-RU 34 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 35 
 6.4 NETCONF Connection Establishment 6.5 NETCONF Access Control 36 
 37 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 38 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 39 
configured and connected to the O-RU. 40 
C. Test Methodology 41 
a. Initial Conditions 42 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.6.1 is successfully completed. 43 
 44 
b. Procedure 45 
1. The TER NETCONF Client establishes a connection with the O-RU NETCONF Server 46 
2. The TER NETCONF Client configures three new user accounts in addition to the default sudo account 47 
already present and passwords for these three accounts using o-ran-user.mgmt.yang 48 <rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="16"> 49 
  <edit-config xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 50 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       43 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
  <target> 1 
            <running/> 2 
        </target> 3 
        <default-operation>merge</default-operation> 4 
        <config> 5 
   <users xmlns="urn:o-ran:user-mgmt:1.0"> 6 
   <user> 7 
    <name>MPLANEUSER1</name> 8 
    <password>1234</password> 9 
    <enabled>true</enabled> 10 
   </user> 11 
   <user> 12 
    <name>MPLANEUSER2</name> 13 
    <password>1234</password> 14 
    <enabled>true</enabled> 15 
   </user> 16 
   <user> 17 
    <name>MPLANEUSER3</name> 18 
    <password>1234</password> 19 
    <enabled>true</enabled> 20 
   </user> 21 
   </users> 22 
  </config> 23 
    </edit-config> 24 
</rpc> 25 
 26 <rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-27 
id="16"> 28 
  <ok/> 29 
</rpc-reply> 30 
 31 
3. The TER NETCONF Client configures user account to group mappings for the three new accounts using 32 
ietf-netconf-acm.yang respectively one with “nms”, one with “fm-pm” and one with “swm” privilege. 33 <rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="15"> 34 
  <edit-config xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 35 
  <target> 36 
            <running/> 37 
        </target> 38 
        <default-operation>merge</default-operation> 39 
        <config> 40 
 <nacm xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:yang:ietf-netconf-acm"> 41 
     <groups> 42 
        <group> 43 
          <name>swm</name> 44 
          <user-name>MPLANEUSER1</user-name> 45 
        </group> 46 
  <group> 47 
          <name>nms</name> 48 
          <user-name>MPLANEUSER2</user-name> 49 
        </group> 50 
  <group> 51 
          <name>fm-pm</name> 52 
          <user-name>MPLANEUSER3</user-name> 53 
        </group> 54 
      </groups> 55 
    </nacm> 56 
 </config> 57 
    </edit-config> 58 
</rpc> 59 
 60 
4. The O-RU NETCONF Server confirms the operations for the above transactions 61 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       44 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
5. The TER NETCONF Client retrieves a list of users from O-RU NETCONF Server. The newly created 1 
user accounts and mappings are validated. 2 <rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="17"> 3 
  <get xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 4 
        <filter xmlns:o-ran-usermgmt="urn:o-ran:user-mgmt:1.0" 5 
type="xpath" select="/o-ran-usermgmt:*//."/> 6 
        <with-defaults xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:yang:ietf-netconf-7 
with-defaults">report-all</with-defaults> 8 
    </get> 9 
</rpc> 10

id="17"> 13

    <users xmlns="urn:o-ran:user-mgmt:1.0"> 15 
      <user> 16 
        <name>oranuser</name> 17 
        <password>userdefined</password> 18 
        <enabled>true</enabled> 19 
      </user> 20 
      <user> 21 
        <name>xranuser</name> 22 
        <password>userdefined</password> 23 
        <enabled>true</enabled> 24 
      </user> 25 
      <user> 26 
        <name>MPLANEUSER1</name> 27 
        <password>1234</password>  28 
        <enabled>true</enabled> 29 
      </user> 30 
      <user> 31 
        <name>MPLANEUSER2</name> 32 
        <password>1234</password> 33 
        <enabled>true</enabled> 34 
      </user> 35 
      <user> 36 
        <name>MPLANEUSER3</name> 37 
        <password>1234</password> 38 
        <enabled>true</enabled> 39 
      </user> 40 
    </users> 41 
  </data> 42 
</rpc-reply> 43

C. Test Methodology 3 
a. Initial Conditions 4 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.8.1 is successfully completed. 5 
2. Four user accounts are provisioned on the O-RU NETCONF server with the following groupings: sudo, 6 
nms, fm-pm, swm. 7 
 8 
b. Procedure 9 
1. The TER NETCONF client establishes a connection using a user account with sudo privileges. 10 
2. The TER NETCONF client gets the password leaves from the user-mgmt.yang model. 11 <rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="17"> 12 
  <get xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 13 
        <filter xmlns:o-ran-usermgmt="urn:o-ran:user-mgmt:1.0" 14 
type="xpath" select="/o-ran-usermgmt:*//."/> 15 
        <with-defaults xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:yang:ietf-netconf-16 
with-defaults">report-all</with-defaults> 17 
    </get> 18 
</rpc> 19 
 20 
3. The O-RU NETCONF server replies by silently omitting data nodes and their descendants to which the 21 
client does not have read access from the <rpc-reply> message 22 <rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-23 
id="17"> 24 
  <data xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 25 
    <users xmlns="urn:o-ran:user-mgmt:1.0"> 26 
        <name>MPLANEUSER1</name> 27 
        <password>1234</password> 28 
        <enabled>true</enabled> 29 
      </user> 30 
      <user> 31 
        <name>MPLANEUSER2</name> 32 
        <password>1234</password> 33 
        <enabled>true</enabled> 34 
      </user> 35 
      <user> 36 
        <name>MPLANEUSER3</name> 37 
        <password>1234</password> 38 
        <enabled>true</enabled> 39 
      </user> 40 
    </users> 41 
  </data> 42 
</rpc-reply> 43

Test step 3 is performed successfully. 46

a. Initial Conditions 4

nms, fm-pm, swm. 7 
b. Procedure 8 
1. The TER NETCONF Client establishes a connection.  Instead of using the default SUDO account, the 9 
NETCONF Client uses a user account with NMS privileges. 10 
2. The TER NETCONF client attempts to configure a new user/password account on the NETCONF server 11 
using the user-mgmt.yang model 12 <rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="16"> 13 
  <edit-config xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 14 
  <target> 15 
            <running/> 16 
        </target> 17 
        <default-operation>merge</default-operation> 18 
        <config> 19 
   <users xmlns="urn:o-ran:user-mgmt:1.0"> 20 
   <user> 21 
    <name>MPLANEUSER4</name> 22 
    <password>1234</password> 23 
    <enabled>true</enabled> 24 
   </user> 25 
   </config> 26 
    </edit-config> 27 
</rpc> 28 
 29 
3. The NETCONF server replies rejecting the protocol operation with an "access-denied" error. 30 <rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-31 
id="16"> 32 
  <rpc-error> 33 
    <error-type>protocol</error-type> 34 
    <error-tag>access-denied</error-tag> 35 
    <error-severity>error</error-severity> 36 
  </rpc-error> 37 
</rpc-reply> 38 
 39

________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       47 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
C. Test Methodology 1 
a. Initial Conditions 2 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.8.1 is successfully completed. 3 
2. Four user accounts are provisioned on the O-RU NETCONF server with the following groupings: sudo, 4 
nms, fm-pm, swm. 5 
b. Procedure 6 
1. The TER NETCONF Client establishes a connection.  Instead of using the default SUDO account, the 7 
NETCONF Client uses a user account with fm-pm privileges. 8 
2. The TER NETCONF client attempts to configure a new processing-element on the NETCONF server 9 
using the o-ran-processing-element yang model 10 <rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="19"> 11 
  <edit-config xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 12 
    <target> 13 
      <running/> 14 
    </target> 15 
    <default-operation>merge</default-operation> 16 
    <config><processing-elements xmlns="urn:o-ran:processing-17 
element:1.0"> 18 
  <transport-session-type>ETH-INTERFACE</transport-session-type> 19 
  <ru-elements> 20 
    <name>HD-BDE_00000600_processing-element01</name> 21 
    <transport-flow> 22 
      <interface-name>HD-BDE_00000600_uc-vlan0</interface-name> 23 
      <eth-flow> 24 
        <ru-mac-address>00:03:A2:0A:00:00</ru-mac-address> 25 
        <vlan-id>2</vlan-id> 26 
        <o-du-mac-address>38:AF:D7:D5:CE:9B</o-du-mac-address> 27 
      </eth-flow> 28 
    </transport-flow> 29 
  </ru-elements> 30 
</processing-elements> 31 
</config> 32 
  </edit-config> 33 
</rpc> 34 
 35 
3. The NETCONF server replies rejecting the protocol operation with an "access-denied" error. 36 <rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-37 
id="19"> 38 
  <rpc-error> 39 
    <error-type>protocol</error-type> 40 
    <error-tag>access-denied</error-tag> 41 
    <error-severity>error</error-severity> 42 
  </rpc-error> 43 
</rpc-reply> 44 
 45 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 46 
Test step 3 is performed successfully. 47

with-defaults">report-all</with-defaults> 18 
    </get> 19 
</rpc> 20

id="11"> 24

    <error-type>protocol</error-type> 26

  </rpc-error> 29 
</rpc-reply> 30

id="37"> 36

</rpc> 38 
5. The O-RU NETCONF Server establishes a TCP connection and performs the Call Home procedure to the 39 
TER NETCONF Client using the same IP and VLAN. 40 
6. The TER NETCONF Client establishes a SSH session / TLS connection towards the NETCONF Server.  41 
The user account created in step 1 is used. 42 
7. The O-RU NETCONF Server accepts the SSH session / TLS connection establishment from TER 43 
NETCONF Client 44 
8. The TER NETCONF Client and O-RU NETCONF Server exchange capabilities through the NETCONF 45 
<hello> messages. 46
