3.1.9  External Input / Output Ports 1 
 External Input Port State Detection 2 
A. Test Description and Applicability 3 
This scenario is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. The test is applicable only for O-RUs supporting logical input 4 
ports.  This test is OPTIONAL for O-DU tests. 5 
This test validates proper handling of logical input ports. 6 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 7 
 14.5.2 External input 8 
 9 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 10 
 The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 11 
operational, configured and connected to the O-RU. 12 
 Supplementary circuitry is required to force a change of logical state of input lines belonging to an input port. 13 
It is assumed that logical input ports are internally pulled to logical high state by O-RU, therefore 14 
supplementary circuitry shall only allow to change the input port to a logical low. To determine a physical 15 
input line for this test, one shall read the customer documentation applicable for the O-RU being tested. 16 
 17 
C. Test Methodology 18 
a. Initial Conditions 19 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 20 
 21 
b. Procedure 22 
1. The External Input Ports are left in their normal, default state.  For the purposes of this test, these input 23 
ports are assumed to be a logical high.  24 
2. The TER NETCONF Client retrieves state of chosen input port by issuing <rpc><get><filter 25 
type="subtree"><external-io xml...><input><port-in></port-in></input></external-26 
io></filter></get></rpc> 27 <rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="7"> 28 
    <get xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 29 
    <filter type="subtree"> 30 
              <external-io xmlns:o-ran-io="urn:o-ran:external-io:1.0"> 31 
       <input>   <port-in/> </input> 32 
          </external-io> 33 
         </filter> 34 
           <with-defaults xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:yang:ietf-35 
netconf-with-defaults">report-all</with-defaults> 36 
     </get> 37 
</rpc> 38 
 39 
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server provides the state of every line-in belonging to the input port under test to 40 
the TER NETCONF Client. For all input lines, the state is TRUE, indicating open circuit (no shortage to 41 
ground is detected by input lines) 42 <rpc-reply xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-43 
id="7"> 44 
  <data xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 45 
    <external-io xmlns="urn:o-ran:external-io:1.0"> 46 
      <input> 47 
        <name>PORT0</name> 48 
        <port-in>0</port-in> 49 
        <line-in>TRUE</line-in> 50 
      </input> 51 
    </external-io> 52 
  </data> 53 
</rpc-reply> 54 
 55 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       52 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
4. The TER supplementary circuitry randomly shorts one or more input lines to the ground. Changes shall 1 
occur with a periodicity greater than 30 seconds. 2 
5. For every change the O-RU NETCONF Server sends notification <external-input-change> to the TER 3 
NETCONF Client.   The notification contains updated states of input lines belonging to the port under test. 4 
A state FALSE indicates shortage to ground detected by particular input line. 5 notification xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:notification:1.0"> 6 
  <eventTime> YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.FZ </eventTime> 7 
<external-input-change xmlns="urn:o-ran:external-io:1.0" > 8 
      <current-input-notification > 9 
        <external-input > 10 
          <name > PORT0</name> 11 
            <line-in >FALSE</line-in> 12 
        </external-input> 13 
      </current-input-notification> 14 
    </external-input-change> 15 
</notification> 16 
 17 
6. This test scenario is looped to step 4 for a total of 10 iterations including the first pass through steps 1 to 4. 18 
 19 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 20 
Step 5 is correctly validated for each of the total of 10 iterations of the test.  21 
 22 
 External Output Port State Control 23 
A. Test Description and Applicability 24 
This scenario is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. The test is applicable only for O-RUs supporting logical output 25 
ports.  This test is OPTIONAL for O-DU tests. 26 
This test validates proper handling of logical output ports. 27 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 28 
 14.5.3 External output 29 
 30 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 31 
 The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 32 
operational, configured and connected to the O-RU. 33 
 Supplementary circuitry is required to measure voltage of an output port signal.  To determine the mapping of 34 
physical output lines to ports, one shall read customer documentation for the O-RU being tested.  The 35 
definition of voltage levels served by output lines of output ports and the maximum allowed current sourced by 36 
single an output line shall be validated against the TER capabilities. 37 
 38 
C. Test Methodology 39 
a. Initial Conditions 40 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 41 
 42 
b. Procedure 43 
1. The TER NETCONF Client issues :<rpc><edit-config> to the O-RU NETCONF Server requesting all 44 
output lines belonging to output port to be set to FALSE. 45 <rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-46 
id="56"> 47 
  <edit-config xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 48 
  <target><running/></target> 49 
  <default-operation>merge</default-operation> 50 
    <config> 51 
      <external-io xmlns="urn:o-ran:external-io:1.0"> 52 
        <output-setting> 53 
          <name>External-Output-0</name> 54 
          <line-out>false</line-out> 55 
        </output-setting> 56 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       53 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
      </external-io> 1 
    </config> 2 
  </edit-config> 3 
</rpc> 4 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Server sets logical LOW state to output lines corresponding to step 1 and responds 5 
to TER NETCONF Client with <rpc-reply> 6 <rpc-reply message-id="56" 7 
 xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 8 
  <ok/> 9 
</rpc-reply> 10 
3. The TER supplementary circuitry shows that all output lines of the target output port are set to logical 11 
LOW state. 12 
4. The TER NETCONF Client issues :<rpc><edit-config> towards NETCONF Server requesting a random 13 
change of states of output lines belonging to target output port.  Changes shall occur with a periodicity 14 
greater than 30 seconds. 15 <rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-16 
id="58"> 17 
  <edit-config xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 18 
  <target><running/></target> 19 
  <default-operation>merge</default-operation> 20 
    <config> 21 
      <external-io xmlns="urn:o-ran:external-io:1.0"> 22 
        <output-setting> 23 
          <name>External-Output-0</name> 24 
          <line-out>true</line-out> 25 
        </output-setting> 26 
      </external-io> 27 
    </config> 28 
  </edit-config> 29 
</rpc> 30 
5. The O-RU NETCONF Server sets the requested states of output lines for the states defined by step 4 and 31 
responds to NETCONF Client with <rpc-reply>.  The TER supplementary circuitry validates the change. 32 <rpc-reply message-id="58" 33 
  xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 34 
  <ok/> 35 
</rpc-reply> 36 
6. This test scenario is looped to step 5 for a total of 10 iterations including the first pass through steps 1 to 4. 37 
 38 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 39 
Step 5 is correctly validated for each of the total of 10 iterations of the test.  40 
  41 
3.1.10   O-RU Configurability 42 
 O-RU Configurability Test (positive case) 43 
 44 
A. Test Description and Applicability 45 
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests.  46 
This test validates eAxC configuration and validation.  The test scenario is intentionally limited in scope to be 47 
applicable to any O-RU hardware design. 48 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 49 
 9 Configuration Management 50 
 15.2 User plane message routing 51 
 52 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 53 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane is operational, 54 
configured and connected to the O-RU. 55

 1 
C. Test Methodology 2 
a. Initial Conditions 3 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 4 
 5 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       55 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
b. Procedure 1 
1. The TER NETCONF Client assigns unique eAxC_IDs to low-level-rx-endpoints. The same set of 2 
eAxC_IDs is also assigned to low-level-tx-endpoints.  The TER NETCONF Client uses <rpc><edit-3 
config>.  Note: The following is an example and is expected to vary for different equipment or 4 
configurations. 5 
 6 <rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-id="23"> 7 
  <edit-config xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 8 
        <target> 9 
            <running/> 10 
        </target> 11 
        <default-operation>merge</default-operation> 12 
        <config> 13 
            <user-plane-configuration xmlns="urn:o-ran:uplane-14 
conf:1.0"> 15 
            <low-level-tx-endpoints> 16 
    <name>Low-Level-Tx-Endpoint-0</name> 17 
    <compression> 18 
      <compression-type>STATIC</compression-type> 19 
      <iq-bitwidth>14</iq-bitwidth> 20 
      <exponent>4</exponent> 21 
    </compression> 22 
    <frame-structure>193</frame-structure> 23 
    <cp-type>NORMAL</cp-type> 24 
    <cp-length>88</cp-length> 25 
    <cp-length-other>72</cp-length-other> 26 
    <offset-to-absolute-frequency-center>-3276</offset-to-absolute-27 
frequency-center> 28 
    <number-of-prb-per-scs> 29 
      <scs>KHZ_30</scs> 30 
      <number-of-prb>273</number-of-prb> 31 
    </number-of-prb-per-scs> 32 
    <e-axcid> 33 
      <o-du-port-bitmask>49152</o-du-port-bitmask> 34 
      <band-sector-bitmask>16128</band-sector-bitmask> 35 
      <ccid-bitmask>240</ccid-bitmask> 36 
      <ru-port-bitmask>15</ru-port-bitmask> 37 
      <eaxc-id>0</eaxc-id> 38 
    </e-axcid> 39 
…. 40 
    <name>Low-Level-Rx-Endpoint-0</name> 41 
    <compression> 42 
      <compression-type>STATIC</compression-type> 43 
      <bitwidth>14</bitwidth> 44 
      <exponent>4</exponent> 45 
    </compression> 46 
    <frame-structure>193</frame-structure> 47 
    <cp-type>NORMAL</cp-type> 48 
    <cp-length>88</cp-length> 49 
    <cp-length-other>72</cp-length-other> 50 
    <offset-to-absolute-frequency-center>-3276</offset-to-absolute-51 
frequency-center> 52

      <scs>KHZ_30</scs> 58 
      <ul-fft-sampling-offset>21</ul-fft-sampling-offset> 59 
    </ul-fft-sampling-offsets> 60 
    <e-axcid> 61 
      <o-du-port-bitmask>49152</o-du-port-bitmask> 62

  O-RU Configurability Test (negative case) 44 
A. Test Description and Applicability 45 
This scenario is MANDATORY for O-RU tests and OPTIONAL for O-DU tests.  46 
The test scenario is intentionally limited to scope that shall be testable without a need to modify test scenario 47 
according O-RU's hardware design. 48 
This test verifies that the O-RU NETCONF Server supports configurability with validation. 49 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 50 
 9 Configuration Management 51 
 15.2 User plane message routing 52 
 53

B. Test Entrance Criteria 1 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 2 
configured and connected to the O-RU. 3 
 4 
C. Test Methodology 5 
a. Initial Conditions 6 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 7 
 8 
b. Procedure 9 
1. The TER NETCONF Client assigns eAxC_IDs to low-level-rx-endpoints.  The same eAxC_ID is assigned 10 
to more than one low-level-tx-endpoint or/and more than one low-level-rx-endpoint.  The NETCONF 11 
Client uses <rpc><edit-config>. 12 
2. The O-RU NETCONF Sever responds with the <rpc-reply> message indicating rejection of the requested 13 
procedure. 14 
 15 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 16 
Test step 2 is performed successfully. 17 
 18 
3.1.11 ALD Communications 19 
 ALD Communications Test 20 
A. Test Description and Applicability 21 
This scenario is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY for a O-RU equipped with a RET port (regardless of whether 22 
this is a raw RS-485 port or OOK modem coupled internally to antenna connector(s)).  This scenario shall be 23 
performed against each ALD port exposed by the O-RU.  This test is OPTIONAL for O-DU tests. 24 
The purpose of the test is to validate the ALD communications protocol and operation of the O-RU. The following 25 
functions are validated in this test. 26 
 Proper transmission of the content if RPC <ald-communication> towards desired ALD port 27 
 Proper calculation of FCS 28 
 Proper application of basic transparency to content to be transmitted 29 
 Proper addition of start / stop flags 30 
 Proper reception of payload injected to ALD port 31 
 Proper removal of start / stop flags 32 
 Proper application of basic transparency to content received from ALD port 33 
 Proper validation of FCS in data received from ALD port. 34 
 35 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 36 
 14.4 Operational aspects of Antenna Line Devices 37 
 38 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 39 
 The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 40 
operational, configured and connected to the O-RU. 41 
 It is assumed, that O-RU being a subject of this conformance test scenario is proven to be compliant to the 42 
following specifications: 43 
1. ISO/IEC 13239:2002 “High-level data link control (HDLC) procedures” 44 
2. 3GPP TS 25.460 “UTRAN Iuant Interface: General aspects and principles” 45 
3. 3GPP TS 25.461 ”UTRAN Iuant Interface: Layer 1” 46 
4. 3GPP TS 25.462 ”UTRAN Iuant Interface: Signalling Transport” 47 
5. 3GPP TS 25.466 “UTRAN Iuant Interface: Application Part” 48 
 The O-RU uses a 9.6 kbps data rate on its ALD port(s) for transmission and reception, regardless of connector 49 
supported by particular ALD port. 50 
 51 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       58 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
C. Test Methodology 2 
As O-RU does not verify correctness of the payload that is exchanged between NETCONF Client and ALD (except 3 
FCS for traffic coming from ALD) - any payload can be used in test vector, under condition, that test vectors are 4 
compliant to referenced above set of specification documents (e.g. length is not smaller than minimum size of real 5 
message). 6 
RS-485 sniffer / injector is needed for this test. Such a device shall be connected either to O-RU’s RS-485 port or 7 
to RS-485 port of Smart BiasT connected to O-RU with coaxial cable (depending on O-RU construction) 8 
Unless not specified otherwise – RS-485 sniffer / injector shall be connected to ALD port corresponding to record 9 
“port-id” used in RPC <ald-communication>. 10 
In case O-RU exposes ALD port as antenna port, test environment should utilize Smart BiasT for conversion 11 
between OOK modulation at antenna port and RS-485 signaling that RS-485 sniffer / injector can handle. DC 12 
voltage for Smart BiasT device shall be provided by O-RU through antenna feeder. 13 
If not specified otherwise, for test purposes RS-485 sniffer / injector is connected to ALD port which will be 14 
addressed in RPC <ald-communication> within the scenario. 15 
As this test is intended to verify O-RU functions and there will be no real ALD connected – compliance to the 16 
required HDLC message structure is required, whilst the AISG payload can be artificial (unless otherwise specified 17 
in test case). The O-RU does not verify if messaging is correct, hence, for test simplicity and ease of test result 18 
verification, artificial test vectors can be used. 19 
a. Initial Conditions 20 
a. The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 21 
 22 
b. Procedure 23 
i. Test Case 1: Transmission towards ALD (positive scenario) 24 
Scope: CRC calculation, transparency algorithm application, start / stop flag addition, datagram 25 
transmission using desired ALD port  26 
1) NETCONF Client sends regular RPC <ald-communication> message containing bytes 0x7D and 27 
0x7E in “ald-req-msg” record. 28 
2) O-RU calculates FCS, adds it to datagram provided in record “ald-req-msg”, applies basic 29 
transparency (replaces every occurrence of byte “0x7E” with two bytes “0x7D 0x5E”, respectively, 30 
replace byte “0x7D” with two bytes “0x7D 0x5D”) and add start/stop flags 0x7E. 31 
3) O-RU sends payload calculated in step 2 through ALD port mentioned in record “port-id” of RPC. 32 
4) RS-485 sniffer / injector receives payload sent by O-RU. Received payload is subject of analysis for 33 
scenario success / failure classification 34 
 35 
ii. Test Case 1 Test Requirement (expected result) 36 
Content received by RS-485 listener / injector is compared with content of RPC <ald-communication>. 37 
a) payload shall be sent by desired ALD port of O-RU 38 
b) FCS shall be properly calculated 39 
c) basic transparency shall be properly applied 40 
d) start / stop flags shall be added to payload that has been received by RS-485 sniffer / injector 41 
Test scenario is considered as completed with success in case all mentioned above conditions are satisfied. 42 
Any deviation means test scenario is failed. 43 
 44 
iii. Test Case 2: Reception from ALD (positive case) 45 
Scope: datagram reception, start / stop flag detection and removal, transparency algorithm applications, 46 
CRC verification  47 
Note: Test case 2 shall be performed just after Test case 1 so that content injected by RS-485 sniffer / 48 
injector is considered by O-RU as ALD’s response to message sent towards ALD in Test case 1. Timing 49 
between Test case 1 and Test case 2 shall follow 3GPP specifications mentioned above. 50 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       59 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
1) RS485 sniffer / injector sends properly formatted (start / stop flags, FCS and min / max payload size) 1 
message containing strings “0x7D 0x5E” and “0x7D 0x5D” towards O-RU’s ALD port used in Test 2 
case 1. 3 
2) O-RU receives the content. 4 
3) O-RU removes start / stop flags, performs basic transparency (replaces “0x7D 0x5E” with “0x7E” 5 
and “0x7D 0x5D” with “0x7D”), makes sure if FCS is correct according content of datagram.  6 
4) O-RU sends “ald-resp-msg” towards NETCONF Client.  In the response parameter “status” contains 7 
value “ACCEPTED”. 8 
 9 
iv. Test Case 2 Requirement (expected result) 10 
Content received by NETCONF Client is compared with content injected by RS-485 sniffer / injector. 11 
a) record “ald-port” shall indicate proper O-RU’s ALD port as source of the payload 12 
b) basic transparency is properly applied 13 
b) counter of received octets is properly incremented 14 
d) counters of frames with wrong FCS (CRC) and frames without stop flags are not incremented 15 
Test scenario is considered as completed with success in case all mentioned above conditions are satisfied. 16 
Any deviation means test scenario is failed. 17 
v. Test Case 3: Reception from ALD (negative case – wrong FCS) 18 
Scope: datagram reception, start / stop flag detection and removal, transparency algorithm application, 19 
CRC verification  20 
Note: Test case 3 shall be performed just after Test case 1 so that content injected by RS-485 sniffer / 21 
injector is considered by O-RU as ALD’s response to message sent towards ALD in Test case 1. Timing 22 
between Test case 1 and Test case 3 shall follow 3GPP specifications mentioned above. 23 
1) RS-485 sniffer / injector sends message containing wrong FCS towards O-RU’s ALD port used in Test 24 
case 1. 25 
2) O-RU receives the content. 26 
3) O-RU removes start / stop flags, performs basic transparency (replaces “0x7D 0x5E” with “0x7E” and 27 
“0x7D 0x5D” with “0x7D”) and detects, that FCS is incorrect according content of received datagram. 28 
4) O-RU sends “ald-resp-msg” towards NETCONF Client.  In the response parameter “status” contains 29 
value “ACCEPTED”. 30 
 31 
vi. Test Case 3 Requirement (expected result) 32 
Content received by NETCONF Client is compared with content injected by RS-485 sniffer / injector. 33 
a) record “ald-port” shall indicate proper O-RU’s ALD port as source of the payload 34 
b) record “ald-resp-msg” is empty 35 
b) counter of frames without stop flags is not incremented 36 
d) counter of received octet and counter of frames with wrong FCS (CRC) are incremented 37 
Test scenario is considered as completed with success in case all mentioned above conditions are satisfied. 38 
Any deviation means test scenario is failed. 39 
 40 
vii. Test Case 4: Reception from ALD (negative case – no stop flag) 41 
Scope: datagram reception, start / stop flag detection 42 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       60 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
Note: Test case 4 shall be performed just after Test case 1 so that content injected by RS-485 sniffer / 1 
injector is considered by O-RU as ALD’s response to message sent towards ALD in Test case 1. Timing 2 
between Test case 1 and Test case 4 shall follow 3GPP specifications mentioned above. 3 
1) RS-485 sniffer / injector sends message not terminated by stop flag “0x7E” towards O-RU’s ALD port 4 
used in Test case 1. 5 
2) O-RU receives the content. 6 
3) O-RU reaches the end of reception window without receiving stop flag that would terminate the 7 
datagram. 8 
4) O-RU sends “ald-resp-msg” towards NETCONF Client. In the response parameter “status” contains 9 
value “ACCEPTED”. 10 
 11 
viii. Test Case 4 Requirement (expected result) 12 
Content received by NETCONF Client is compared with content injected by RS-485 sniffer / injector. 13 
a) record “ald-port” shall indicate proper O-RU’s ALD port as source of the payload 14 
b) record “ald-resp-msg” is empty 15 
b) counter of frames with wrong FCS (CRC) is not incremented 16 
d) counter of received octets and counter of frames without stop flags are incremented 17 
Test scenario is considered as completed with success in case all mentioned above conditions are satisfied. 18 
Any deviation means test scenario is failed. 19 
 20 
ix. Test case 5: Transmission towards ALD (negative scenario – wrong ALD port) 21 
Scope: CRC calculation, transparency algorithm application, start / stop flag addition, datagram 22 
transmission using desired ALD port (ports are not used by the same HDLC Primary Device) 23 
Scenario is applicable only in case O-RU supports more than one ALD port and under condition that ALD 24 
ports do not share single modem. 25 
IMPORTANT: In this scenario RS-485 sniffer / injector shall be connected to ALD port different from 26 
than the one indicated in record “port-id” of RPC <ald-communication>. 27 
1) NETCONF Client sends regular RPC <ald-communication> message. 28 
2) O-RU performs the content processing and sends the content towards ALD port that corresponds to 29 
content of record “port-id” of RPC 30 
3) RS-485 sniffer / injector does not receive payload sent by O-RU.  31 
 32 
x. Test Requirement (expected result) 33 
Test scenario is considered as completed with success in case RS-485 sniffer / injector does not receive 34 
payload in step 3. Any deviation is considered as failed test case. 35 
 36 
xi. Test case 6: Transmission towards ALD (negative scenario – non-existing ALD port) 37 
Scope: datagram reception 38 
1) NETCONF Client sends regular RPC <ald-communication> message. Parameter <port-id> used in 39 
RPC does not point to existing ALD port. 40 
2) O-RU sends <rpc-error> to NETCONF Client. In the response parameter “error-tag” contains value 41 
“data-missing”. 42 
3) NETCONF Client receives the <rpc-error> message as described above. 43 
 44

Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       61 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
xii. Test Requirement (expected result) 1 
Test scenario is considered as completed with success in case step 3) is reached. 2 
 3 
3.1.12   Log Management 4 
  Troubleshooting Test 5 
A. Test Description and Applicability 6 
This scenario is MANDATORY for both O-RU and O-DU Tests. 7 
This test validates the capability of the O-RU to upload troubleshooting logs including alarm information. 8 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 9 
 14.2.2 Troubleshooting Log Management 10 
 11 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 12 
The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are operational, 13 
configured and connected to the O-RU. 14 
 15 
C. Test Methodology 16 
a. Initial Conditions 17 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 18 
 19 
b. Procedure 20 
1. The TER NETCONF Client sends <rpc><start-troubleshooting-logs> to the O-RU NETCONF Server.  21 
The O-RU NETCONF Server responds with <rpc-reply>< troubleshooting-status-grouping >. 22 <rpc xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0" message-23

</rpc> 27

3.1.13 Connectivity Check 13 
 Ethernet Connectivity Monitoring 14 
A. Test Description and Applicability 15 
This scenario is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY if the O-RU or O-DU supports C-Plane and U-Plane 16 
connectivity over Ethernet.   17 
This test validates the proper operation of LBM on the O-RU. 18 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 19 
 7.3 C/U Plane VLAN configuration 20 
 7.5 Definition of processing elements 21 
 7.6 Verification of C/U Plane Transport Connectivity 22 
 23 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 24 
1. The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 25 
operational, configured and connected to the O-RU. 26 
2. Result validation of this test requires TER capabilities such as a network sniffer that allows for traffic analysis 27 
over ETH frames between O-RU and O-DU. 28 
 29 
C. Test Methodology 30 
a. Initial Conditions 31 
The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 32 
 33 
b. Procedure 34 
1. The TER NETCONF Client configures the O-RU NETCONF Server with a vlan-id for the C-Plane and 35 
U-Plane interfaces. 36 
2. The TER NETCONF Client configures a transport-flow in the O-RU processing element:  a combination 37 
of VLAN identity, O-DU MAC address and O-RU MAC address.  38 
3. The TER sends loopback message to the O-RU MAC address configured for the processing element. 39 
4. The O-RU sends loopback responses to the O-DU MAC Address of the loopback message. 40 
 41 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 42 
Packets are sent correctly in step 3 and 4, as validated via the TER. 43 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       66 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 UDP Echo Test 1 
A. Test Description and Applicability 2 
This scenario is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY.  The test is applicable only if the O-RU or O-DU supports C-3 
Plane and U-Plane sessions over IP. 4 
This test validates the proper operation UDP Echo on the O-RU for continuous verification of connectivity. 5 
This scenario corresponds to the following chapters in [3]: 6 
 7.4 O-RU C/U Plane IP Address Assignment  7 
 7.5 Definition of processing elements 8 
 7.6 O-DU Verification of C/U Plane Transport Connectivity 9 
 10 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 11 
1. The minimum functions of the TER described in section 2.1 that support validation of the M-Plane are 12 
operational, configured and connected to the O-RU. 13 
2. Result validation of this test requires TER capabilities such as a network sniffer that allows for traffic analysis 14 
over ETH frames between O-RU and O-DU. 15 
 16 
C. Test Methodology 17 
a. Initial Conditions 18 
1. The test procedure described in section 3.1.4.1 is successfully completed. 19 
 20 
b. Procedure 21 
1. The TER NETCONF Client configures IP information and udpip-flow in the O-RU processing element 22 
for the C-Plane and U-Plane communications.  23 
2. The TER NETCONF Client sends a UDP datagram to UDP port number:7 of the O-RU NETCONF 24 
Server. 25 
3. The O-RU NETCONF Server sends back the UDP datagram to the TER NETCONF Client. 26 
 27 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 28 
Packets are sent correctly in step 2 and 3 as validated by the TER with sniffer capability.  29 
  30 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       67 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
3.2 UC-Plane Measurements O-RU 2 
3.2.1 UC-Plane Standard Test Definitions 3 
The following sections describe test scenarios for equipment implementing the U-Plane and C-Plane O-RAN option 4 
7.2x protocols.    5 
 UC-Plane Measurements, O-RU TEST SCENARIO 6 
In these sets of tests, the Device Under Test (DUT) is the O-RU.   7 
This document describes conformance tests for 4 scenarios: 8 
1. Conducted FDD tests for FR1 radios 9 
2. Non-conducted (OTA) FDD tests for FR1 radios 10 
3. Conducted TDD tests for FR1 radios 11 
4. Non-conducted tests for TDD FR1 and FR2 radios 12 
 13 
The O-RU must only be tested for the scenarios that apply to the O-RU capabilities. The fact that there are 4 scenarios 14 
defined does not imply that every O-RU must be tested for all scenarios in order to be O-RAN compliant and 15 
consequently the O-RU does not have to support all the capabilities required to test all 4 scenarios (i.e. support of FR1, 16 
FR2, TDD, FDD, conducted and non-conducted). In other words, depending on whether the O-RU supports capabilities 17 
such as FDD, TDD, FR1 and or FR2, only the corresponding scenarios that match the O-RU capabilities will apply. For 18 
example, an O-RU that does not have or cannot provide access to antenna ports (or TAB connectors), supports TDD 19 
and operates at FR2 bands, the corresponding scenario that the O-RU will need to be tested to be O-RAN conformant is 20 
scenario #4 only. Another example, for an O-RU that supports FDD, operates at FR1 bands and has or can provide 21 
access to antenna ports (or TAB connectors), scenario #1 or #2 can apply but only one of the two possible scenarios will 22 
be selected to test the O-RU for O-RAN conformance.   23 
For scenario #1 and #3 above the RF test setup is as described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE].  For 24 
scenarios #2 and #4 the RF test setup is as described in TS 38.141-2. Note that O-RAN conformance testing is expected 25 
to be “off-line” and not to be run while an O-DU and/or O-RU is operating and serving actual users.  The O-RU 26 
manufacturer must also make available the same declarations described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1, TS 38.141-2 [NR] and 27 
TS 36.141 [LTE] Section 4.6.  This will determine the radio’s support for multi-carrier operation (e.g., if multi-carrier 28 
operation is supported on different connectors) 29 
Since the purpose of this document is to test O-RAN Fronthaul conformance and not to duplicate 3GPP RF tests, only 30 
selected parts of TS 38.141-1, TS 38.141-2 [NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE] will be used for RF testing.  These selected test 31 
features are only necessary to test whether the O-RU correctly interpreted and generated the O-RAN C-Plane and U-32 
Plane messages correctly. Several testcases require a bandwidth that may not be supported by the O-RU. In such 33 
situation, the testcase should be executed by adjusting to a bandwidth that is supported by the O-RU and complies with 34 
the channel bandwidth listed in either TS 38.104 section 5.3.2 for NR or TS 36.104 section 5.6 for LTE. The adjustment 35 
of the bandwidth can be done by reducing the number of physical resource blocks or by selecting another FRC. The 36 
bandwidth adjustment may select the minimum bandwidth defined by 3GPP. The adjustment of the bandwidth does not 37 
require the execution of the same testcase again with a larger bandwidth. 38 
There will also be some additions to the test waveforms used in TS 38.141-1, TS 38.141-2 [NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE] 39 
to fully exercise the features of the O-RAN Fronthaul protocol.  These selected parts and additions are summarized 40 
below: 41 
 For scenario #1 (Conducted FDD tests for FR1 radios) 42 
 For downlink tests for type 1-C radios (radios with antenna port connectors and passive antennas) the test 43 
configuration described in TS 38.141-1 D.1.1 will be used.  Only a single antenna port will be used unless the 44 
test explicitly requires more than one port and the radio supports more than one port.  RF test equipment will 45 
be connected at the point described in TS 38.141-1 section 4.2.1. Note that an antenna port is an electrical 46 
conducting port that is connected to an array element. 47 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       68 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 For uplink tests for type 1-C radios (radios with antenna port connectors and passive antennas) the test 1 
configuration described in TS 38.141-1 D.2.1 will be used.  Only a single antenna port will be used unless the 2 
test explicitly requires more than one port and the radio supports more than one port.  RF test equipment will 3 
be connected at the point described in TS 38.141-1 section 4.2.1. Note that an antenna port is an electrical 4 
conducting port that is connected to an array element. 5 
 For downlink tests for type 1-H radios (radios with TAB connectors and active antenna systems) the test 6 
configuration described in TS 38.14138.141-1 D.3.1 will be used for conducted tests.  Only a single TAB 7 
connector will be used unless the test explicitly requires more than one connector.  RF test equipment will be 8 
connected at the point described in TS 38.141-1 section 4.2.2. Note that a transceiver array boundary (TAB) 9 
connector is an electrical conducting port that is connected to an array element via a radio distribution network 10 
(RDN). 11 
 For uplink tests for type 1-H radios (radios with TAB connectors and active antenna systems) the test 12 
configuration described in TS 38.14138.141-1 D.4.1 will be used for conducted tests.  Only a single TAB 13 
connector will be used unless the test explicitly requires more than one connector.  RF test equipment will be 14 
connected at the point described in TS 38.141-1 section 4.2.2. Note that a transceiver array boundary (TAB) 15 
connector is an electrical conducting port that is connected to an array element via a radio distribution network 16 
(RDN). 17 
 The basic downlink test will start with the Test model described in NR-FR1-TM1.1 and E-TM1.1.  Subsequent 18 
tests will adapt this model to test additional features of the O-RAN interface (e.g., Modifying the payload data, 19 
blanking some symbols, etc.).  Note this test model describes the IQ data contained in the O-RAN packets not 20 
the O-RAN specific parameters.  This test model will also be augmented with the following O-RAN specific 21 
parameters: 22 
Includes “stock” eAxC values as configured via M-Plane: 23 
 DU_Port_ID: two bits, nominal value 00b 24 
 BandSector: nominal 6 bits, nominal value 000000b 25 
 CC_ID: nominal 4 bits, nominal value 0000b (most tests invoke only one component carrier) 26 
 RU_port_ID: 4 bits, nominal values 0000b through 0011b or to whatever max value needed for a 27 
specific test 28 
 If the radio manufacturer declares support for multi-carrier a different eAxC will be assigned for each carrier. 29 
Note that most tests described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE]  require testing at the bottom, 30 
middle and top of the supported bands of the radio.  This specification relaxes that requirement because the 31 
purpose is to test the fronthaul compliance and not the radio performance. 32 
 Compression: Static 16-bit fixed point IQ bitwidth in both DL and UL 33 
 Beamforming: no beamforming (beamId = 0x0000), assumed to mean boresight radiation (normal to the 34 
antenna surface) at some undetermined beamwidth (recall that beam weight magnitudes must be equal to 35 
unity) 36 
 Transport: L2 Ethernet, eCPRI with no fragmentation and no QOS 37 
 Delay Parameters: The test will be executed with a direct fiber connection to the O-RU and the network delay 38 
is considered negligible for the purpose of delay management.  Therefore, T12_min = T12_max = 0 and 39 
T34_min = T34_max = 0. 40 
The radio will report its supported values for: 41 
o T2a_min/max_up 42 
o Ta3_min/max_up 43 
o T2a_min/max_cp_ul 44 
o Tcp_adv_dl 45 
These parameters will be used to calculate the delay windows needed for the delay management tests below.  46 
Note that T1a_min_up = T2a_min_up and T1a_max_up = T2a_max_up due to the fixed, zero network delay.  47 
Similarly, Ta4_min_up = Ta3_min_up and Ta4_max_up = Ta3_max_up.  Similarly, T1a_min_cp_ul = 48 
T2a_min_cp_ul and T1a_max_cp_ul = T2a_max_cp_ul.   49 
 50 
 Uplink tests will start with the basic 3GPP test signal for Fixed Reference Channels for receiver sensitivity and 51 
in-channel selectivity as described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE].  All O-RAN specific 52 
parameters will be the same as described above for downlink testing.  As with downlink testing subsequent 53 
tests will build on this basic waveform modifying parameters as needed to exercise O-RAN specific features. 54 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       69 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Uplink tests will be conducted using power levels at least 30dB higher than the power levels used to test 3GPP 1 
Receiver sensitivity described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1 Table 7.2.5-1[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE]. This is to ensure 2 
a clear signal is received by the O-RU so it can be accurately decoded and demodulated to ensure the correct 3 
data was received by the O-DU as was sent by the signal source.  Again, the purpose of these tests is to ensure 4 
correct operation of the O-RAN fronthaul not to test receiver sensitivity. 5 
 6 
 For scenario #2 (Non-conducted OTA FDD tests for FR1 radios) 7 
 For downlink tests for type 1-H radios that elect to be tested over the air (OTA) rather than conducted, the test 8 
configuration is described in TS 38.141-2 E.1.2 where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber 9 
and measurements are referenced to the radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated 10 
Interface Boundary (RIB) defined in TS 38.141-2 4.2-1. The RF analyzer test equipment is connected to the 11 
Test Antenna and is located outside of the OTA chamber.  12 
 For downlink test for 1-O or 2-O radios (radios with no physical antenna or TAB connectors and consequently 13 
only over the air – OTA – measurements are possible) the test configuration is described in TS 38.141-2 E.1.2 14 
where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber and measurements are referenced to the 15 
radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated Interface Boundary (RIB) defined in TS 16 
38.141-2 4.2-2. The RF analyzer test equipment is connected to the Test Antenna and is located outside of the 17 
OTA chamber. 18 
 For uplink tests for type 1-H radios that elect to be tested over the air (OTA) rather than conducted, the test 19 
configuration is described in TS 38.141-2 E.2.1 where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber 20 
and measurements are referenced to the radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated 21 
Interface Boundary (RIB) defined in TS 38.141-2 4.2-1. The RF generator test equipment is connected to the 22 
Test Antenna and is located outside of the OTA chamber. 23 
 For uplink test for 1-O or 2-O radios (radios with no physical antenna or TAB connectors and consequently 24 
only over the air (OTA) measurements are possible) the test configuration is described in TS 38.141-2 E.2.1 25 
where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber and measurements are referenced to the 26 
radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated Interface Boundary (RIB) defined in TS 27 
38.141-2 4.2-2. The RF generator test equipment is connected to the Test Antenna and is located outside of the 28 
OTA chamber.  29 
 For downlink tests for LTE radios that elect to be tested over the air (OTA), the test configuration is described 30 
in TS 38.141-2 E.1.2 where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber and measurements are 31 
referenced to the radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated Interface Boundary (RIB) 32 
defined in TS 38.141-2 4.2-1. The RF analyzer test equipment is connected to the Test Antenna and is located 33 
out of the OTA chamber. 34 
 For uplink tests for LTE radios that elect to be tested over the air (OTA), the test configuration is described in 35 
TS 38.141-2 E.2.1 where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber and measurements are 36 
referenced to the radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated Interface Boundary (RIB) 37 
defined in TS 38.141-2 4.2-1. The RF generator test equipment is connected to the Test Antenna and is located 38 
out of the OTA chamber. 39 
 Note that the chamber shown in TS 38.141-2 E1.2. and E.2.1. are generic and consequently any OTA chamber 40 
could be used, i.e. far field, CATR, near field, reverberation, etc. 41 
 Likewise, depending on the beamforming measurement technology the positioner in TS 38.141-2 E.1.2 and 42 
E.2.1. may or may not be needed. 43 
 Furthermore, depending on the beamforming method to be measured more than one test antenna with more 44 
than one RF analyzer and/or generator ports may also be needed. 45 
 The basic downlink test will start with the Test model described in NR-FR1-TM1.1 and E-TM1.1 in TS 46 
38.141-1 and 36.141 for NR FR1 and LTE radios respectively.  Subsequent tests will adapt this model to test 47 
additional features of the O-RAN interface (e.g., Modifying the payload data, blanking some symbols, etc.).  48 
Note this test model describes the IQ data contained in the O-RAN packets not the O-RAN specific 49 
parameters.  This test model will also be augmented with the following O-RAN specific parameters: 50 
Includes “stock” eAxC values as configured via M-Plane: 51 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       70 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 DU_Port_ID: two bits, nominal value 00b 1 
 BandSector: nominal 6 bits, nominal value 000000b 2 
 CC_ID: nominal 4 bits, nominal value 0000b (most tests invoke only one component carrier) 3 
 RU_port_ID: 4 bits, nominal values 0000b through 0011b or to whatever max value needed for a 4 
specific test 5 
 If the radio manufacturer declares support for multi-carrier a different eAxC will be assigned for each carrier. 6 
Note that most tests described in 3GPP TS 38.141-2[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE]  require testing at the bottom, 7 
middle and top of the supported bands of the radio.  This specification relaxes that requirement because the 8 
purpose is to test the fronthaul compliance and not the radio performance. 9 
 Compression: Static 16-bit fixed point IQ bitwidth in both DL and UL 10 
 Beamforming: no beamforming (beamId = 0x0000), assumed to mean boresight radiation (normal to the 11 
antenna surface) at some undetermined beamwidth (recall that beam weight magnitudes must be equal to 12 
unity) 13 
 Transport: L2 Ethernet, eCPRI with no fragmentation and no QOS 14 
 Delay Parameters: The test will be executed with a direct fiber connection to the O-RU and the network delay 15 
is considered negligible for the purpose of delay management.  Therefore, T12_min = T12_max = 0 and 16 
T34_min = T34_max = 0. 17 
The radio will report its supported values for: 18 
o T2a_min/max_up 19 
o Ta3_min/max_up 20 
o T2a_min/max_cp_ul 21 
o Tcp_adv_dl 22 
These parameters will be used to calculate the delay windows needed for the delay management tests below.  23 
Note that T1a_min_up = T2a_min_up and T1a_max_up = T2a_max_up due to the fixed, zero network delay.  24 
Similarly, Ta4_min_up = Ta3_min_up and Ta4_max_up = Ta3_max_up.  Similarly, T1a_min_cp_ul = 25 
T2a_min_cp_ul and T1a_max_cp_ul = T2a_max_cp_ul.   26 
 Uplink tests will start with the basic 3GPP test signal for Fixed Reference Channels for receiver sensitivity and 27 
in-channel selectivity as described in 3GPP TS 38.141-2[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE]. All O-RAN specific 28 
parameters will be the same as described above for downlink testing. As with downlink testing subsequent 29 
tests will build on this basic waveform modifying parameters as needed to exercise O-RAN specific features. 30 
 Uplink tests will be radiated using power levels at least 30dB higher than the reference sensitivity power levels 31 
used to test 3GPP Receiver sensitivity described in 3GPP TS 38.141-2 Table 7.3.5.2-1, Table 7.3.5.2-2 and 32 
Table 7.3.5.2-3[NR FR1], Table 7.3.5.3-1 [NR FR2]  and TS 36.141 Table 7.2-1 to Table 7.2-12 [LTE]. This 33 
is to ensure a clear signal is received by the O-RU so it can be accurately decoded and demodulated to ensure 34 
the correct data was received by the O-DU as was sent by the signal source.  Again, the purpose of these tests 35 
is to ensure correct operation of the O-RAN fronthaul not to test receiver sensitivity. 36 
 37 
 For scenario #3 (Conducted TDD Tests for FR1 Radios) 38 
 All provisions of section 3.2.1.1.1 will apply to FR1 TDD tests however the default test waveform will be a TDD 39 
waveform as described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1. It will be NR-FR1-TM1.1 (TDD) and G-FR1-A1-5 (SCS30k_51RB) in 40 
the uplink.  If the O-RU does not support the UL bandwidth of 51 RB, another FRC test model can be selected.   The 41 
TDD test model is derived based on the uplink/downlink configurations described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1 Table 4.9.2.2.1 42 
using information element TDD-UL-DL-ConfigCommon as defined in TS 38.331 for 30 kHz SCS as shown below: 43

Table 3.2.1.1-1 Configuration Parameters for TDD FR1 Conducted Tests 1 
This waveform is shown below: 2 
 3 
Figure 3.2.1.1-1 NR-FR1-TM1.1 TDD Test Signal 4 
 5 
As an alternative to the default test waveform shown in Figure 3.2.1.1-1, it is optional to flexibly use other test 6 
waveforms with any TDD configurations allowed by the information element TDD-UL-DL-ConfigCommon as defined 7 
in TS 38.331 for 30 kHz SCS. The tester should use the 3GPP prescribed waveform as the recommended waveform but 8 
has the option to use any TDD configuration in the IOT profiles defined in [25] with the above constraints. 9 
This test frame consists of a PDCCH in the first two symbols of every downlink slot consisting of 3 PRBs.  All the 10 
remaining PRBs in the frame consist of Physical Downlink Shared Channel data. This configuration corresponds to 11 
stock data section A (Section 3.2.1.1.5 below) in all symbols that do not contain PDCCH channels. Individual tests may 12 
call out other stock data sections as needed. If the radio does not support the numerology described in section 3.2.3.1 13 
the stock test frames can be adapted for smaller numbers of PRBs and should still be used. Symbols number two and 14 
eleven contain DMRS signals which are not used to test O-RAN Front Haul capabilities but should be sent to help test 15 
equipment synchronize.  In the standard test frame, all PDSCH data is set to zeros if not otherwise described in the 16 
testcase and PUSCH is set to PN23 sequences.  For all tests in this document (except the most basic resource allocation 17 
test) the PN23 sequence will be used in both uplink and downlink to allow the test to determine whether test data was 18 
put in the correct PRBs and whether the test data was accurately transmitted (or received) by the O-RU under test. 19 
 For tests for type 1-C and 1-H the test configuration described in TS 38.141-1 for TDD testing will be used.  Only a 20 
single antenna port will be used unless the test explicitly requires more than one port and the radio supports more 21 
than one port.  RF test equipment will be connected at the point described in TS 38.141-1. Note that an antenna 22 
port is an electrical conducting port that is connected to an array element. 23 
 The test will start with the Test model described above.  Subsequent tests will adapt this model to test additional 24 
features of the O-RAN interface (e.g., Modifying the payload data, blanking some symbols, etc.).  Note this test 25

specific parameters will be the same as described above for downlink testing.  As with downlink testing subsequent 30 
tests will build on this basic waveform modifying parameters as needed to exercise O-RAN specific features. 31 
 Uplink tests will be conducted using power levels at least 30dB higher than the power levels used to test 3GPP 32 
Receiver sensitivity described in 3GPP TS 38.141-1 Table 7.2.5-1[NR] and TS 36.141 [LTE]. This is to ensure a 33 
clear signal is received by the O-RU so it can be accurately decoded and demodulated to ensure the correct data 34 
was received by the O-DU as was sent by the signal source.  Again, the purpose of these tests is to ensure correct 35 
operation of the O-RAN fronthaul not to test receiver sensitivity. 36

 For Scenario #4 (Non-conducted OTA TDD Tests for FR1 and FR2 Radios) 38 
All provisions of section 3.2.1.1.2 with respect to OTA methodology will apply to this scenario, except applied to TDD 39 
FR1 (1-H, 1-O) and FR2 (2-O) radios.  The default test waveform for FR1 will be a TDD waveform as described in 40 
Sec. 3.2.1.1.3.  The default test waveform for FR2 will be a 100 MHz bandwidth TDD waveform based on NR-FR2-41 
TM1.1 for the downlink, and G-FR2-A1-3 for 120 kHz subcarrier spacing with 66 RBs in the uplink.  The TDD test 42 
model is derived based on the uplink/downlink configurations described in 3GPP TS 38.141-2 Table 4.9.2.2-1 using 43 
information element TDD-UL-DL-ConfigCommon as defined in TS 38.331 as shown below: 44

Table 3.2.1.1-2 Configuration Parameters for FR2 Radio Testing 1 
As an alternative to the default test waveform shown in Figure 3.2.1.1-2, it is optional to flexibly use other test 2 
waveforms with any TDD configurations allowed by the information element TDD-UL-DL-ConfigCommon as defined 3 
in TS 38.331. The tester should use the 3GPP prescribed waveform as the recommended waveform but has the option to 4 
use any TDD configuration in the IOT profiles defined in [25] with the above constraints. 5 
This test frame consists of a PDCCH in the first two symbols of every downlink slot consisting of 3 PRBs.  All the 6 
remaining PRBs in the frame consist of Physical Downlink Shared Channel data. This configuration corresponds to 7 
stock data section A (Section 3.2.1.1.5 below) in all symbols that do not contain PDCCH channels. Individual tests may 8 
call out other stock data sections as needed. If the radio does not support the numerology described the stock test frames 9 
can be adapted for smaller numbers of PRBs and should still be used. Symbols number two and eleven contain DMRS 10 
signals which are not used to test O-RAN Front Haul capabilities but should be sent to help test equipment synchronize.  11 
In the standard test frame, all PDSCH data is set to zeros if not otherwise mentioned in the testcase  and PUSCH is set 12 
to PN23 sequences.  For all tests in this document (except the most basic resource allocation test) the PN23 sequence 13 
will be used in both uplink and downlink to allow the test to determine whether test data was put in the correct PRBs 14 
and whether the test data was accurately transmitted (or received) by the O-RU under test. 15 
 For downlink tests for type 1-H radios that elect to be tested over the air (OTA) rather than conducted, the test 16 
configuration is described in TS 38.141-2 E.1.2 where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber 17 
and measurements are referenced to the radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated 18 
Interface Boundary (RIB) defined in TS 38.141-2 4.2-1. The RF analyzer test equipment is connected to the 19 
Test Antenna and is located outside of the OTA chamber.  20 
 For downlink test for 1-O or 2-O radios (radios with no physical antenna or TAB connectors and consequently 21 
only over the air – OTA – measurements are possible) the test configuration is described in TS 38.141-2 E.1.2 22 
where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber and measurements are referenced to the 23 
radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated Interface Boundary (RIB) defined in TS 24 
38.141-2 4.2-2. The RF analyzer test equipment is connected to the Test Antenna and is located outside of the 25 
OTA chamber. 26 
 For uplink tests for type 1-H radios that elect to be tested over the air (OTA) rather than conducted, the test 27 
configuration is described in TS 38.141-2 E.2.1 where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber 28 
and measurements are referenced to the radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated 29 
Interface Boundary (RIB) defined in TS 38.141-2 4.2-1. The RF generator test equipment is connected to the 30 
Test Antenna and is located outside of the OTA chamber. 31 
 For uplink test for 1-O or 2-O radios (radios with no physical antenna or TAB connectors and consequently 32 
only over the air (OTA) measurements are possible) the test configuration is described in TS 38.141-2 E.2.1 33 
where the Test Antenna will be placed inside an OTA chamber and measurements are referenced to the 34 
radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated Interface Boundary (RIB) defined in TS 35 
38.141-2 4.2-2. The RF generator test equipment is connected to the Test Antenna and is located outside of the 36 
OTA chamber.  37

referenced to the radiated characteristics defined over the air (OTA) at the Radiated Interface Boundary (RIB) 40 
defined in TS 38.141-2 4.2-1. The RF analyzer test equipment is connected to the Test Antenna and is located 41
