 1 Figure 3.2.3.1-13 G-FR1-A5-1 UL FDD Test Signal 2 
 3 
Using an RF source, the test equipment will generate a 3GPP test signal as shown in Figure 3.2.3.1-13 above.  4 
The radio will demodulate and decode this signal and send frequency domain IQ to the O-DU-Emulator as 5 
instructed by the O-DU-emulator using uplink C-Plane messages containing section extension 10.  Note this 6 
signal has 20 slots with all symbols populated with only uplink shared channel data in the only first 51 RBs.  The 7 
symbols are populated with PN23 data. 8 
 9 
The TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) generates an uplink signal on the antenna connectors or TAB connectors, 10 
together with the corresponding C-Plane messages on the Fronthaul interface. 11 
 12 
The TER will capture the U-Plane messages generated by the DUT and validate if the payload matches with the 13 
uplink signal.  14 
 15 
It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections 16 
 Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 17 
 Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 18 
 Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 19 
 20 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 21 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.1 of this document.  The test numerology will be 22 
30 kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section 3GPP TS 38.141-1 section G-FR1-A1-23 
5.  It will be for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. The 24 
radio must report that it supports section extension type 10, multiple port groupings.  Note this signal may be 25 
changed to any of the 3GPP sensitivity test signals in table A.1-1 in 3GPP TS 38.141-1 if the radio does not 26 
support the numerology and bandwidth used in this test.  The test signal described in this section will be used if the 27 
radio supports that numerology and bandwidth. Manufacturers’ must provide their defined list of beam indices and 28 
their associated magnitude and phase relation between antenna ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions 29 
with antenna array characteristics. 30 
 31 
 32 
C. Test Methodology 33 
Leverage from the well-known payload (Pseudo Random sequence) of the uplink signal to compare it with the 34 
payload of the signal communicated on the O-RAN interface. The IQ information is extracted from the U-Plane 35 
message and demodulated to retrieve payload. Signals will be applied to connector ports emulating the phase and 36 
amplitude corresponding to the associated beam ID direction or phase relationship provided by the manufacturer. 37 
  38 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       104 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
c. Initial Conditions 1 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-2 
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 3 
ports that belong to the beam under test and configure the source to transmit the required 3GPP test signal upon 4 
receiving a trigger signal from the CUSM-E.  Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is 5 
phase coherence between the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.  The signal source 6 
power level should be adjusted to at least 30 dB above the setting used in the 3GPP receiver sensitivity test. Let 7 
the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range 8 
 9 
d. Procedure 10 
 Load uplink test waveform (G-FR1-A1-5 : SCS130k_51RB) on the RF Signal Source.  Note this signal 11 
should contain a new PN23 sequence as user data in PRBs 0 through 51 for symbols 6 and 7.  The remainder 12 
of the test waveform is as described in 3GPP. 13 
 Configure Signal Source to play test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it receives a trigger 14 
signal from the O-DU emulator that C-Plane messages have been sent. 15 
 Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 16 
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) 17 
to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test. For example, 18 
initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).   19 
 Load C-Plane message sequence on Test Equipment O-RU (TER) – Use the O-DU emulator control 20 
interface to build the appropriate C-Plane message (Single C-Plane message) that describes the signal. For 21 
this test symbols number 6 and 7 will be used in each slot.   22 
Every symbol should be described by a single type 1 section (DL-SCH and DCI) except symbols #6 and #7 23 
which will be used as the payload data. The data in symbol #6 is expected to be a new PN23 sequence 24 
starting in the first PRB and continuing to PRB 51.  Symbol #7 should be identical to symbol #6. No section 25 
type zero messages will be used for this test.  The C-Plane message should include section extension 10 with 26 
numPortc equal to what was received on the M-Plane at startup.  The eAxC ID should be the group eAxC ID 27 
also received from the M-Plane.  Run the test three times using: 28 
Test Case #1 (beamGroupType = 00b, Common Beam): All layers should have the same beam ID.  The 29 
signal sent by the source should correspond to the same beam ID.  It is expected that the source is connected 30 
to at least two port groups to ensure the same beam is being used. 31 
Test Case #2 (beamGroupType = 01b, beam matrix indication): All layers should have consecutive beam IDs 32 
starting with the beam ID in the C-Plane message.  The signal sent by the source should correspond to the 33 
consecutive beam IDs.  It is expected that the source is connected to at least two port groups to ensure the 34 
consecutive beams are being used 35 
Test Case #3 (beamGroupType = 10b, beam vector listing): All layers will be assigned beam IDs based on the list 36 
of beam IDs contained in the section extension.  The number of beam IDs must be equal to numPortc.  The signal 37 
sent by the source should correspond to the signalled beam IDs.  It is expected that the source is connected to at 38 
least two port groups to ensure that the correct beams are being used 39 
 Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  40 
 Launch test to play the C-Plane message and trigger the source to play the RF signal on a frame boundary. 41 
Respect all timing windows. 42 
 Signal the signal source that C-Plane messages have been sent to allow it to start sending RF.  Respect all 43 
timing windows. 44 
 Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the Antenna port  45 
 Extract IQ information  46 
 Extract Payload 47 
 Compare payload binary sequences  48 
  49 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  50 
1. The test frame received by the signal analyzer must contain the same PN23 signals that were sent in the U-51 
Plane. 52 
The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 53 
that achieves the best performance (i.e., highest EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match the manufacturer’s 54 
declaration of the beam under test.  If this is also true, the test passes. 55 
 56 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       105 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP DL – Resource allocation – Coupling 1 
C and U plane via Frequency and Time 2 
A. Test Description and Applicability 3 
This test is CONDITIONAL  MANDATORY. 4 
 5 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can accurately interpret C-Plane resource allocation messages, 6 
transfer U-Plane data into the correct resource blocks and transmit this data accurately in the downlink when the 7 
radio reports it supports the option feature of coupling C and U plane messages via frequency and time.  This test is 8 
applicable for Category A and Category B radios (No precoding is required).  The test will be conducted therefore 9 
there will be no channel distortion or interference.  It is mandatory the radio pass this test if it reports it supports 10 
coupling C and U plane via time and frequency. 11 
 12 
Using a standard 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 test frame for FDD the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER 13 
described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on the 14 
downlink the standard NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal.  This signal is shown below in Figure 3.2.3.1-14. 15 
 16 
 17 
 18 Figure 3.2.3.1-14  NR-FR1-TM1.1 FDD Test Signal 19 
 20 
This test frame consists of a PDCCH in the first two symbols of every slot consisting of 3 PRBs.  All the remaining 21 
PRBs in the frame consist of Physical Downlink Shared Channel data. This test requires non-zero data (PN23 22 
Sequence)  to populate all allocated resource blocks.  This configuration corresponds to stock data section A in all 23 
symbols that do not contain PDCCH channels. 24 
 25 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 26 
The test numerology will be 30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section NR-FR1-27 
TM1.1.  It will be for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. 28 
 29 
 30 
C. Test Methodology 31 
 32 
a. Initial Conditions 33 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       106 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 1 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU 2 
antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 3 
demodulate the transmitted signal.  This test is only applicable if the radio reports it supports coupling C and U 4 
plane via time and frequency. 5 
b. Procedure 6 
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU emulator.  7 
Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal. 8 
Every symbol should be described by a single section (DL-SCH and DCI) using section type 1 messages. The 9 
data in the sections must be a PN23 sequence using an initial seed of all ones. No section type zero messages 10 
will be used for this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU 11 
respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times 12 
required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame. 13 
 14 
In this test the C-Plane messages will contain valid values in the following fields: 15 
 EAxC ID 16 
 Datadirection bit (Downlink) 17 
 Frame ID, subframeID, slotID, startsymbolID, and NumSymbol 18 
 SectionID must have a value 4095 19 
 SymInc, rb reMask and section extension #6 are not used in this test 20 
The U-Plane messages generated by the TER must match those values used in the C-Plane corresponding o 21 
the section described in the C-plane but the value of sectionID will be 4095. 22 
 23 
 24 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  25 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 26 
radio category (i.e., EVM). 27 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above.  If it contains 28 
all the same PRB assignments and data, the test passes. 29 
 30 
 31 
 UC-Plane O-RU Base Class FDD Test UL – Coupling C and U plane via time and 32 
frequency 33 
A. Test Description and Applicability 34 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 35 
 36 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can meet the most basic uplink requirements for O-RAN fronthaul 37 
correctly interpreting C-Plane messages and correctly constructing uplink U-Plane messages from an RF signal 38 
when the radio reports it supports C and U plane coupling via time and frequency. 39 
 40 
The test validates that correct uplink operation of the O-RU using 3GPP Reference Sensitivity level definition 41 
(Section 7.2 TS 38.141-1) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 38.141) and power 42 
Levels at least 30 dB above Reference Sensitivity power Level described in TS 38.141-1 Table 7.2.5-1.  This is to 43 
improve the likelihood that all data will be received by the radio correctly since we are not interested in testing 44 
receiver sensitivity but only the O-RAN protocol compliance.  45 
 46 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       107 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1  2 
Figure 3.2.3.1-15  G-FR1-A5-1 Uplink FDD Test Signal 3 
 4 
This signal is described by table A.1-1 in 3GPP 38.141-1 and is referred to as G-FR1-A1-5 with the power increased 5 
to up to 30 dB above that described in Table 7.2.5-1.  Under those conditions, a 3GPP compliant O-RU should 6 
deliver uplink U-Plane information that matches the uplink signal.  7 
 8 
The TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) generates an uplink signal on the antenna connector or TAB connector, together 9 
with the corresponding C-Plane messages on the Fronthaul interface. 10 
 11 
The TER will capture the U-Plane messages generated by the DUT and validate whether the payload matches the 12 
uplink signal.  13 
 14 
It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections 15 
 Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 16 
 Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 17 
 Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 18 
 19 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 20 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.1 of this document.  The O-RU must indicate it 21 
supports coupling C and U plane via time and frequency. The test numerology will be 30 kHz subcarrier spacing 22 
and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section 3GPP TS 38.141-1 section G-FR1-A-5.  It will be for 5G New 23 
Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. Note this signal may be 24 
changed to any of the 3GPP sensitivity test signals in table A.1-1 in 3GPP TS 38.141-1 if the radio does not 25 
support the numerology and bandwidth used in this test.  The test signal described in this section will be used if the 26 
radio supports that numerology and bandwidth. 27 
C. Test Methodology 28 
Leverage from the well-known payload (PN23 sequence) of the uplink signal to compare it with the payload of the 29 
signal communicated on the O-RAN interface. The IQ information is extracted from the U-Plane message and 30 
demodulated to retrieve payload.  31 
  32 
a: Initial Conditions 33 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-34 
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 35 
port and configure the source to transmit the required 3GPP test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from the 36 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       108 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
CUSM-E.  The signal source power level should be adjusted to at least 30 dB above the setting used in the 3GPP 1 
receiver sensitivity test. 2 
b: Procedure 3 
 Load uplink test waveform (G-FR1-A1-5 : SCS30k_51RB) on the RF Signal Source  4 
 Configure Signal Source to play test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it receives a 5 
trigger signal from the O-DU emulator that C-Plane messages have been sent. 6 
 Load C-Plane message sequence on Test Equipment O-RU (TER) C-Plane messages will contain valid 7 
values in the following fields: 8 
 EAxC ID 9 
 Datadirection bit (Uplink) 10 
 Frame ID, subframeID, slotID, startsymbolID, and NumSymbol 11 
 SectionID must have a value 4095 12 
 SymInc, rb reMask and section extension #6 are not used in this test 13 
 Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  14 
 Launch test to play the RF uplink frame after the C-Plane messages have been sent honoring timing 15 
windows  16 
 Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the Antenna port  17 
 TER will arrange U-Plane messages according to time and frequency 18 
 Extract IQ information  19 
 Extract Payload 20 
 Compare payload binary sequences  21 
  22 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  23 
1. The verdict is “Test pass” if the payload binary sequences match between the uplink test frame sent to the 24 
DUT and the received U-Plane data from the DUT 25 
2. If any of the test conditions are not true, the verdict for the whole test is "Fail" 26 
 27 
 28 
 UC- Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP DL – Resource allocation – Section 29 
Description Priorities  30 
A. Test Description and Applicability 31 
This test is CONDITIONAL  MANDATORY. 32 
 33 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can accurately interpret C-Plane resource allocation messages, 34 
transfer U-Plane data into the correct resource blocks and transmit this data accurately in the downlink when the 35 
radio reports it supports the option feature of coupling C and U plane messages via frequency and time and Section 36 
Description Priorities.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios (No precoding is required).  37 
The test will be conducted therefore there will be no channel distortion or interference.  It is mandatory the radio 38 
pass this test if it reports it supports coupling C and U plane via time and frequency.  Note, there are two versions 39 
of this feature: coupling C and U plane messages via frequency and time and Section Description Priorities and 40 
coupling C and U plane messages via frequency and time and Section Description Priorities (optimized).  This test 41 
requires both tests to be performed if the radio supports both methods otherwise only one test is to be performed if 42 
the radio only supports one of these methods.  These methods are listed under test methodology below. 43 
 44 
 45 
Using a standard 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 test frame for FDD the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER 46 
described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on the 47 
downlink the standard NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal with exceptions noted in the test procedure.  This signal is shown 48 
below in Figure 3.2.3.1-16 . 49 
 50 
 51 
 52 
 53 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       109 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
 2 Figure 3.2.3.1-16  NR-FR1-TM1.1 FDD Test Signal 3 
 4 
This test frame consists of a PDCCH in the first two symbols of every slot consisting of 3 PRBs.  All the remaining 5 
PRBs in the frame consist of Physical Downlink Shared Channel data. This test requires non-zero data (PN23 6 
Sequence)  to populate all allocated resource blocks.  This configuration corresponds to stock data section A in all 7 
symbols that do not contain PDCCH channels. 8 
 9 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 10 
The test numerology will be 30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section NR-FR1-11 
TM1.1.  It will be for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. 12 
 13 
 14 
C. Test Methodology 15 
 16 
a. Initial Conditions 17 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 18 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU 19 
antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 20 
demodulate the transmitted signal.  This test is only applicable if the radio reports it supports coupling C and U 21 
plane via time and frequency and Section Description Priority (including the optimized version). 22 
b. Procedure for Coupling C and U plane messages via frequency and time with section priorities 23 
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above and below in the O-DU 24 
emulator.  Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe 25 
the signal. Every symbol should be described by a single section (DL-SCH and DCI) using section type 1 26 
messages. The data in the sections must be a PN23 sequence using an initial seed of all ones. No section type 27 
zero messages will be used for this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to 28 
the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of 29 
times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame. 30 
 31

ext 6 
priority symbolMask startPrbc numPrbc reMask rbgMask beamId numSymbol Note

Table 3.2.3.1-3 Section Description Priorities 1 
In this test the section configuration will be as shown in Table 3.2.3.1-3 above.  The 6 sections will comprise 2 
one slot and this slot will be repeated continuously to synchronize the TER signal analyzer.  The six sections 3 
will be sent on one C-Plane message using C and U plane coupling via time and frequency.  The 4 
configuration above follows the example given in the CUSM specification. 5 
The section numbers in the above table do not represent SectionID numbers but individual sections. Sections 6 
#1 and #2 describe hypothetical DMRS signals sent in symbols #2 and #11 in each slot.  These signals have 7 
every other subcarrier masked by reMask. This is the same as shown above in the standard NR-FR1-TM1.1 8 
test signal shown above. The DMRS signals in symbol #2 have beam ID 1 and symbol #11 have beam ID 2.  9 
These sections use section extension 6 and contain a higher priority than all other sections.  10 
Section #3 describes PN23 data sent to hypothetical UE #1 it overlaps REs in sections #1 and #2 but has a 11 
lower priority so sections #1 and #2 are valid.  Since section #3 has contiguous symbols section extension 6 12 
is not needed. 13 
Section #4 is for hypothetical UE #2. It occupies the same symbols as the DMRS signals but uses a different 14 
reMask.  Since the symbols are not contiguous it uses sections extension 6 but the priority is set to the default 15 
0. 16 
Section #5 is for hypothetical UE #3 and uses a contiguous set of symbols so section extension 6 is not 17 
needed.  It does not overlap any other signals.  This section is optional because it does not test Section 18 
Description Priority. 19 
Section #6 is a hypothetical special channel using only one symbol and does not require section extension 6.  20 
This section is also optional. 21 
U-Plane messages will contain: 22 
 DMRS signals for every odd resource element as described by section #1 for symbol #11 23 
 DMRS signals for every odd resource element as described by section #2 for symbol #2 24 
 A new PN23 sequence in each of the first 5 symbols as described in section #3.  Note that for 25 
symbol #2 the PN sequence will be pierced by the DMRS signals. 26 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       111 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 A new PN23 sequence for symbol #5 as described by section #4 as well as a new PN sequence for 1 
symbol #11.  These sequences are only 32 PRBs long and start in PRB 15. The sequence in symbol 2 
#11 will be pierced by DMRS signals. 3 
 The user data for sections number #5 and #6 are standard PN23 sequences only for these symbols 4 
and PRBs described in the table above. 5 
c. Procedure for Coupling C and U plane messages via frequency and time with section priorities 6 
(optimized) 7 
This test will be identical to the above test with the following exceptions: 8 
 There will be two C-Plane messages describing the downlink signal to be sent. 9 
 The first two sections listed in the table above (those with higher priorities) will be repeated in both 10 
C-Plane messages and will have a section ID equal to a value between 0 and “max-highest-priority-11 
sections-per-slot” as sent on the M-Plane. 12 
 The other sections will be divided between the two C-Plane messages and not repeated. 13 
 The repeated C-plane message will have the “repetition” bit set to one. 14 
 15 
 16 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  17 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 18 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 19 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same PRB assignment and data as the signal 20 
described above.   21 
3. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 22 
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 23 
declaration of the beam under test that has been assigned to each section described above.  The procedure for 24 
this beamforming test is the same as test 3.2.3.2.3 (UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – 25 
Predefined-beam Beamforming).  This result is applicable for either or both forms of this test. 26 
 27 
 UC-Plane O-RU Base Class FDD Test UL – Section Description Priorities 28 
A. Test Description and Applicability 29 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 30 
 31 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can meet the uplink requirements for O-RAN fronthaul correctly 32 
interpreting C-Plane messages and correctly constructing uplink U-Plane messages from an RF signal when the 33 
radio reports it supports Section Description Priorities as well as Coupling C and U plane via time and frequency. 34 
Note, there are two versions of this feature: coupling C and U plane messages via frequency and time and Section 35 
Description Priorities and coupling C and U plane messages via frequency and time and Section Description 36 
Priorities (optimized).  This test requires both tests to be performed if the radio supports both methods otherwise 37 
only one test is to be performed in the radio only supports one of these methods.  These methods are listed under test 38 
methodology below.  39 
 40 
The test validates that correct uplink operation of the O-RU using 3GPP Reference Sensitivity level definition 41 
(Section 7.2 TS 38.141-1) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 38.141) and power 42 
Levels at least 30 dB above Reference Sensitivity power Level described in TS 38.141-1 Table 7.2.5-1.  This is to 43 
improve the likelihood that all data will be received by the radio correctly since we are not interested in testing 44 
receiver sensitivity but only the O-RAN protocol compliance.  45 
 46

 4 
This signal is described by table A.1-1 in 3GPP 38.141-1 and is referred to as G-FR1-A1-5 with the power increased 5 
to up to 30 dB above that described in Table 7.2.5-1.  Under those conditions, a 3GPP compliant O-RU should 6 
deliver uplink U-Plane information that matches the uplink signal. Note this is the starting signal however it will be 7 
modified as described below to accommodate this test. 8 
 9 
The TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) generates an uplink signal on the antenna connector or TAB connector, together 10 
with the corresponding C-Plane messages on the Fronthaul interface. 11 
 12 
The TER will capture the U-Plane messages generated by the DUT and validate whether the payload matches the 13 
uplink signal as well as beam characteristics signals in the C-Plane.  14 
 15 
It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections 16 
 Section 5.4.7.6 Section Extension 6 17 
 Section 5.5.7 Coupling via time and frequency with priorities as well as the optimized version of this 18 
feature 19 
 Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 20 
 21 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 22 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.1 of this document.  The O-RU must indicate is 23 
supports coupling C and U plane via time and frequency as well a Section Description Priorities either optimized or 24 
regular. The test numerology will be 30 kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section 25 
3GPP TS 38.141-1 section G-FR1-A-5.  It will be for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna 26 
ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. Note this signal may be changed to any of the 3GPP sensitivity test signals in table 27 
A.1-1 in 3GPP TS 38.141-1 if the radio does not support the numerology and bandwidth used in this test.  The test 28 
signal described in this section will be used if the radio supports that numerology and bandwidth. 29 
C. Test Methodology 30 
Leverage from the well-known payload (PN23 sequence) of the uplink signal to compare it with the payload of the 31 
signal communicated on the O-RAN interface. The IQ information is extracted from the U-Plane message and 32 
demodulated to retrieve payload.  33

a: Initial Conditions 1

port and configure the source to transmit the required 3GPP test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from the 4 
CUSM-E.  The signal source power level should be adjusted to at least 30 dB above the setting used in the 3GPP 5 
receiver sensitivity test. 6 
b: Procedure for Coupling C and U plane messages via frequency and time with section priorities 7 
 Build the following Uplink C-Plane message. 8 
Start with a standard as G-FR1-A1-5 waveform.  Define the sections shown in tableTable 3.2.3.1-4.  These 9

Table 3.2.3.1-4  Section Description Priorities UL 12 
 13 
In this test the section configuration will be as shown in Table 3.2.3.1-4 above.  The 6 sections will comprise 14 
one slot and this slot will be repeated to fill the entire frame (i.e., 20 times).  The six sections will be sent on 15 
one C-Plane message using C and U plane coupling via time and frequency.  The configuration above 16 
follows the example given in the CUSM specification. 17 
o The section numbers in the above table do not represent SectionID numbers but individual sections. 18 
Sections #1 and #2 describe hypothetical DMRS signals sent in symbols #2 and #11 in each slot.  19 
These signals have every other subcarrier masked by reMask. This is the same as shown above in 20 
the standard G-FR1-A1-5 test signal shown above with the exception that the DMRS signals 21 
continue for all 273 RBs. The DMRS signals in symbol #2 have beam ID 1 and symbol #11 have 22 
beam ID 2.  These sections use section extension 6 and contain a higher priority than all other 23 
sections.  24 
o Section #3 describes PN23 data sent to hypothetical UE #1 it overlaps REs in sections #1 and #2 25 
but has a lower priority so sections #1 and #2 are valid.  Since section #3 has contiguous symbols 26 
section extension 6 is not needed.  Note it starts in PRM 64 (RBG 4) and continues for the 27 
remainder of the 273 RBs. 28 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       114 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
o Section #4 is for hypothetical UE #2. It occupies the same symbols as the DMRS signals but uses a 1 
different reMask.  Since the symbols are not contiguous it uses sections extension 6 but the priority 2 
is set to the default 0.  It also starts in RBG 4 (RB 64) and continues to the rest of the 273 RBs. 3 
o Section #5 is for hypothetical UE #3 and uses a contiguous set of symbols so section extension 6 is 4 
not needed.  It does not overlap any other signals.  This section is optional because it does not test 5 
Section Description Priority. 6 
o Section #6 is a hypothetical special channel using only one symbol and does not require section 7 
extension 6.  This section is also optional. 8 
 Load the following waveform into the signal source: 9 
o DMRS signals for every odd resource element as described by section #1 for symbol #11 10 
o DMRS signals for every odd resource element as described by section #2 for symbol #2 11 
o A new PN23 sequence in each of the first 5 symbols as described in section #3.  Note that for 12 
symbol #2 the PN sequence will be pierced by the DMRS signals. 13 
o A new PN23 sequence for symbol #5 as described by section #4 as well as a new PN sequence for 14 
symbol #11.  These sequences start in PRB 64 and continue to PRB 273. The sequence in symbol 15 
#11 will be pierced by DMRS signals. 16 
o The user data for sections number #5 and #6 are standard PN23 sequences only for these symbols 17 
and PRBs described in the table above. 18 
 19 
 Configure Signal Source to play test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it receives a 20 
trigger signal from the O-DU emulator that C-Plane messages have been sent. 21 
 Load C-Plane message described above on Test Equipment O-RU (TER). The C-Plane message will contain 22 
valid values in the following fields: 23 
 EAxC ID 24 
 Datadirection bit (Uplink) 25 
 Frame ID, subframeID, slotID, startsymbolID, and NumSymbol 26 
 SectionID must have a value 4095 27 
 Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  28 
 Launch test to play the RF uplink frame after the C-Plane messages have been sent honoring timing 29 
windows  30 
 Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the Antenna port  31 
 TER will arrange U-Plane messages according to time and frequency 32 
 Extract IQ information  33 
 Extract Payload 34 
 Compare payload binary sequences  35 
c. Procedure for Coupling C and U plane messages via frequency and time with section priorities 36 
(optimized) 37 
This test will be identical to the above test with the following exceptions: 38 
o There will be two C-Plane messages describing the uplink signal to be sent. 39 
o The first two sections listed in the table above (those with higher priorities) will be repeated in both C-Plane 40 
messages and will have a section ID equal to a value between 0 and “max-highest-priority-sections-per-slot” 41 
as sent on the M-Plane. 42 
o The other sections will be divided between the two C-Plane messages and not repeated. 43 
o The repeated C-plane message will have the “repetition” bit set to one. 44 
 45 
  46 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  47 
1. The verdict is “Test pass” if the payload binary sequences match between the uplink test frame sent to the 48 
DUT and the received U-Plane data from the DUT and the beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the 49 
antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, 50 
power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s declaration of the beam under test.  The procedures 51 
for test case 3.2.3.2.4 (UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Predefined-beam 52 
Beamforming) should be used.  This result is applicable for either or both forms of this test. 53 
2. If any of the test conditions are not true, the verdict for the whole test is "Fail" 54 
 55 
 56

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended using Non-contiguous PRB Allocation 1 
Section Extension 12 3GPP DL – Resource Allocation 2 
A. Test Description and Applicability 3 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 4 
 5 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can correctly decode and interpret C-Plane and U-Plane messages 6 
putting resource block in the correct place in the transmitted signal using the extension type 12. In this test stock 7 
data section definition C will be used to exercise the non-contiguous RB allocation, all 273 PRBs (or the maximum 8 
number of PRBs per symbol for the highest numerology the radio supports) will be used in this test. 9 
 10 
Using a standard 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 test frame for FDD the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER 11 
described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on the 12 
downlink the standard NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal with the modifications described below (supporting non-contiguous 13 
PRB allocation)..  The standard 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 is shown in Figure 3.2.3.1-18 below: 14 
 15  16 
Figure 3.2.3.1-18 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 Test Signal 17 
This generic NR-FR1-TM1.1 test frame consists of a PDCCH in the first two symbols of every slot consisting of 18 
3 PRBs.  All the remaining PRBs in the frame consist of Physical Downlink Shared Channel data. 19 
 20 
This test requires non-zero data to populate all allocated resource blocks.  This data will be a PN23 sequence 21 
with a seed value of all ones as described below. 22 
 23 
This test will utilize stock data section definition C described above with the following exception.  This data 24 
section will include user data in the first RB group, the second group will be blank and the remainder of the 25 
RBGs contain user data.  This stock data section will be repeated over two symbols to test the SymMask 26 
parameter. 27 
 28 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 29 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.1  of this document.  The default test 30 
numerology will be 30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section NR-FR1-31 
TM1.1.  It will be for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB 32 
connectors.  The Radio must support the extension type 12 as notified by the M-Plane.  The signal analyzer must 33 
have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 34 
 35 
C. Test Methodology 36 
a. Initial Conditions 37 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 38 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU 39

antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 1 
demodulate the transmitted signal.   2 
b. Procedure 3

including reference signals to ensure test equipment can synchronize with the signal.  The starting PRB will 5 
be zero and number of PRBs will be chosen from one or more columns in Table 3.2.3.1-6 Stock Data 6 
Sections below.  The resource block group size will be 16 based on 3GPP 38.214 Table 5.1.2.2.1-1 as shown 7 
in Table 3.2.3.1-5 below using configuration 2.   8

Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU emulator.  21 
Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal. 22

The O-DU emulator will build a U-Plane message containing the PN23 IQ data for the first 16 PRBs (RBG 0), 3 
this message will have the section ID used in the C-Plane message described above.  Another U-Plane message 4 
will be created using the same section ID but with the PN23 data for RBGs 2-17 in it.  The same U-Plane 5 
messages will be used for symbol #7. 6 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  7 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 8 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 9 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should only contain the same PN23 signals that were sent in the 10 
U-Plane, that is the PN23 sequence in the first 16 PRBs, nothing in the next 16 PRBs and the remainder of the 11 
PN23 sequence in RBGs 2-17, or the pattern appropriate for the numerology if a different numerology is 12 
chosen as noted above.  13

 UC Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended using Non-contiguous PRB Allocation 15 
Section Extension 3GPP UL – Resource Allocation 16 
A. Test Description and Applicability 17 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 18 
 19 
The purpose of this test is to validate the capability of interpreting the section extension 12, non-contiguous PRB 20 
allocation to the basic uplink test. 21 
 22 
Validate correct uplink operation of the O-RU using 3GPP Reference Sensitivity level definition (Section 7.2 TS 23 
38.141-1) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 38.141) and power Levels at least 24 
30 dB above Reference Sensitivity power Level described in TS 38.141-1 table 7.2.5-1.  This is to improve the 25 
likelihood that all data will be received by the radio correctly since we are not interested in testing receiver 26 
sensitivity but only the O-RAN protocol compliance. C-Plane messages will contain 2 symbols with the same set of 27 
non-contiguous PRBs referenced to test both the symMask and the offStartPrb parameters. 28 
 29 
 30 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       118 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1  2 
Figure 3.2.3.1-19 G-FR1-A5-1 UL FDD Test Signal 3 
 4 
Using an RF source, the test equipment will generate a 3GPP test signal as shown in Figure 3.2.3.1-19 above.  5 
The radio will demodulate and decode this signal and send frequency domain IQ to the O-DU-Emulator as 6 
instructed by the O-DU-emulator using uplink C-Plane messages containing section extension 12.  Note this 7 
signal has 20 slots with all symbols populated with only uplink shared data in the only first 48 RBs.  The 8 
symbols are populated with PN23 data. 9 
 10 
The TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) generates an uplink signal on the antenna connector or TAB connector, 11 
together with the corresponding C-Plane messages on the Fronthaul interface. 12 
 13 
The TER will capture the U-Plane messages generated by the DUT and validate if the payload matches with the 14 
uplink signal.  15 
 16 
It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections 17 
 Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 18 
 Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 19 
 Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 20 
 21 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 22 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.1 of this document.  The test numerology will be 23 
30 kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section 3GPP TS 38.141-1 section G-FR1-A1-5.  24 
It will be for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. The 25 
radio must report that it supports section extension type 12, non-contiguous PRB allocations.  Note this signal may 26 
be changed to any of the 3GPP sensitivity test signals in table A.1-1 in 3GPP TS 38.141-1 if the radio does not 27 
support the numerology and bandwidth used in this test.  The test signal described in this section will be used if the 28 
radio supports that numerology and bandwidth. 29 
 30 
C. Test Methodology 31 
Leverage from the well-known payload (Pseudo Random sequence) of the uplink signal to compare it with the 32 
payload of the signal communicated on the O-RAN interface. The IQ information is extracted from the U-Plane 33 
message and demodulated to retrieve payload.  34 
  35 
a. Initial Conditions 36

receiver sensitivity test. 5

signal from the O-DU emulator that C-Plane messages have been sent. 12

and 7 will be used in each slot.  The starting PRB will be zero and number of used PRBs will be 48.  The 15 
resource block group size will be 16.  Using the calculations in the O-RAN fronthaul specification section 16

 UC Plane O-RU Base Class FDD Test UL – Static SRS allocation 17 
A. Test Description and Applicability 18 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 19 
 20 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the O-RU can support static SRS configuration through the M-Plane.  This is an 21 
uplink only test so there is no corresponding downlink test for FDD.  The O-RU must report through the M-Plane 22 
that it supports static configuration of SRS. 23 
 24 
The test will have the CUSM emulator configure the O-RU, through the M-Plane, with a section of time/frequency 25 
resources reserved for static uplink SRS.  The signal source will be programmed to send simulated SRS signals in a 26 
subset of those resources.  The O-RU should receive this SRS signals and pass them through to the CUSM emulator 27 
using U-Plane messages.  Note, there will be no C-Plane messages sent from the CUSM emulator and the O-RU.  28 
The signal generator will signal power levels at least 30 dB above Reference Sensitivity power Level described in 29 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       121 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
TS 138.141-1 Table 7.2.5-1.  This is to improve the likelihood that all data will be received by the radio correctly 1 
since we are not interested in testing receiver sensitivity but only the O-RAN protocol compliance. 2 
 3 
The placement of the time frequency resources is not specified in this test so it may be placed anywhere in the 4 
frame. 5 
 6 
 7 
The TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) generates an uplink SRS signal on the antenna connector or TAB connector. The 8 
TER will capture the U-Plane messages generated by the DUT and validate whether the payload matches the uplink 9 
signal as well as beam characteristics. The metric used to validate that the signal received by the CUSM emulator 10 
matches the signal sent by the signal generator will be EVM as described in Annex H.7 of 3GPP 38.141.  While 11 
some 3GPP test documents (e.g., TS 38.521 section 6.4.2.1.3) suggest treating the EVM requirements for physical 12 
Zadoff-Chu sequences such as PRACH the same as QPSK for EVM requirements, this document will decrease the 13 
required EVM to the level specified for 64 QAM.  The purpose of this is to ensure that there is no chance of false 14 
positives where a random, mistaken signal sent by the O-RU closely mimics the test signal used by the TER.  Since 15 
there are no impairments made to the uplink SRS signal this should be well within the capabilities of the O-RU. 16 
 17 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 18 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.1 of this document.  The O-RU must indicate it 19 
supports static SRS allocation. The test numerology will be 30 kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as 20 
described in section 3GPP TS 138.141-1 section G-FR1-A-5.  It will be for 5G New Radio only. The radio must 21 
have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. Note this signal may be changed to any of the 3GPP 22 
sensitivity test signals in table A.1-1 in 3GPP TS 138.141-1 if the radio does not support the numerology and 23 
bandwidth used in this test.  The test signal described in this section will be used if the radio supports that 24 
numerology and bandwidth. 25 
C. Test Methodology 26 
  27 
a: Initial Conditions 28 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-29 
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 30 
port and configure the source to transmit the required SRS test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from the 31 
CUSM-E.  The signal source power level should be adjusted to at least 30 dB above the setting used in the 3GPP 32 
receiver sensitivity test. 33 
Implicit in this Initial set up is statically configuring O-RU with a section of time/frequency resources for static 34 
SRS signals. 35 
b: Procedure 36 
 Build an SRS signal in the signal generator that fits in the preconfigured time frequency resources set in the 37 
initial configuration. 38 
 Load the waveform into the signal source: 39 
 Configure Signal Source to play test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it receives a 40 
trigger signal from the O-DU emulator that signals the start of a frame boundary. 41 
 Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  42 
 Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the Antenna port 43 
connected 44 
 TER will arrange U-Plane messages according to time and frequency 45 
 Extract IQ information  46 
 Calculate EVM of the SRS signal received by the CUSM emulator to the ideal signal generated by the 47 
signal source. Use the method described in TS 38.141 Annex H.7 to perform the calculation. 48 
  49 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  50 
1. The verdict is “Test pass” if the calculated EVM is less than 8%. 51 
2. If any of the test conditions are not true, the verdict for the whole test is "Fail" 52 
 53 
 54 
 UC Plane O-RU Base Class FDD Test UL – Static PRACH allocation 55 
A. Test Description and Applicability 56 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       122 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 1 
 2 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the O-RU can support static PRACH configuration through the M-Plane.  This 3 
is an uplink only test so there is no corresponding downlink test for FDD.  The O-RU must report through the M-4 
Plane capabilities that it supports static configuration of PRACH.  The concept is to repeat test 3.2.3.8.1 (5GNR  5 
PRACH test) without sending any C-Plane type 3 messages and configuring the O-RU using only the M-Plane. 6 
 7 
TER will setup the signal generator with a PRACH test waveform according to TS 38.141-1 section 8.4.1 and A.6. 8 
The test waveform will contain the same preamble ID repeated by following the timing offset scheme specified in 9 
the figures 8.4.1.4.2-2 or 8.4.1.4.2-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected PRACH format. 10 
This is an example for FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3, at each occasion the time offset of the 11 
same preamble index (selected according to table A.6-1 TS 38.141.1) is incremented by 100nsec starting from 0 up 12 
to 800nsec (9 occasions per frame). Each PRACH occasion is at the beginning of the first nine used sub-frames. The 13 
scheme is repeated every frame. 14 
 15 
 16 
Figure 3.2.3.1-20 FR1 SCS 30Kz 100MHz Format A3 17 
 18 
According to the PRACH waveform setting, the TER will generate a corresponding sequence of M-Plane messages 19 
which include the following parameters (According to the M-Plane specification): 20 
grouping static-prach-configuration  21 
• leaf pattern-period - "Period after which static PRACH patterns are repeated. Unit: number of 22 
frames." 23 
• leaf guard-tone-low-re - "Number of REs occupied by the low guard tones." 24 
• leaf num-prach-re - "Number of contiguous PRBs per data section description“ 25 
• leaf guard-tone-high-re - "Number of REs occupied by the high guard tones.“ 26 
• leaf sequence-duration - "Duration of single sequence of the PRACH. Sequence may be considered as 27 
'single PRACH symbol’” 28 
• list prach-patterns - key prach-pattern-id - "Provides a PRACH pattern. Each record in the list 29 
represents a single PRACH occasion. Number of list entries cannot exceed max-prach-patterns“ 30 
• leaf prach-pattern-id - "Supplementary parameter acting as key for prach-pattern list.“ 31 
• leaf number-of-repetitions - "This parameter defines number of PRACH repetitions in 32 
PRACH occasion, to which the section control is applicable 33 
• leaf number-of-occasions - "This parameter informs how many consecutive PRACH 34 
occasions is described by the PRACH Pattern” 35 
• leaf re-offset – “Offset between the start of the lowest-frequency RE of the lowest frequency 36 
PRB and the start of the lowest frequency RE belonging to the PRACH occasion.  The re-37 
offset is configured as number of PRACH REs. 38 
• list occasion-parameters – “list of cp-lengths, gp-lengths and beam-ids applicable per each 39 
PRACH occasion in PRACH pattern. Note: the number of records in this list MUST be equal 40 
to value of parameter number-of-occasions.“ 41 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       123 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
• leaf occasion-id - "Supplementary parameter acting as key in 'occasion-parameters' 1 
list“ 2 
• leaf cp-length - "Cyclic prefix length. See CUS-plane specification for detailed 3 
description.“ 4 
• leaf gp-length - "Guard period length.“ 5 
• leaf beam-id  - "This parameter defines the beam pattern to be applied to the U-6 
Plane data. beamId = 0 means no beamforming operation will be performed." 7 
• leaf frame-number - "This parameter is an index inside the pattern-length, such that PRACH 8 
occasion is happening for SFN which fulfills following equation: [SFN mod pattern-length = 9 
frame-id]“ 10 
• leaf sub-frame-id - "Identifier of sub-frame of the PRACH occasion. Value is interpreted in 11 
the same way as subframeId field in a section description of a C-Plane message.“ 12 
• leaf time-offset - "This parameter defines the time-offset from the start of the sub-frame to 13 
the start of the first Cyclic Prefix of PRACH pattern" 14 
 15 
By the corresponding U-Plane messages in the uplink direction, the TER will try to detect the presence of the 16 
corresponding preamble at the expected timing offset and calculate the probability of detection Pd according to the 17 
definition in TS38.141-1 section 8.4.1.1.  18 
The signal will be exercised at only one O-RU port without adding any external AWGN power level or multipath 19 
fading profile and at a power level avoiding detection errors due to poor SNR (rule described in the sub-section C of 20 
this scenario class). 21 
The test will have the CUSM emulator configure the O-RU, through the M-Plane, with a section of time/frequency 22 
resources reserved for static uplink PRACH.  The default is the PRACH configuration described in 3GPP above but the 23 
test may be conducted with changes if the radio does not support those exact configurations.  The signal source will be 24 
programmed to send simulated PRACH signals in those resources.  The O-RU should receive this PRACH signal and 25 
pass them through to the CUSM emulator using U-Plane messages.  Note, there will be no C-Plane messages sent from 26 
the CUSM emulator and the O-RU. 27 
 28 
 29 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 30 
O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (FR1) or TAB connector. 31 
By the M-plane, TER will detect all the supported SCSs, FFT sizes and carrier bandwidths by the O-RU. It is assumed 32 
that only one combination of the three above parameters supported by the O-RU is enough to validate the test. TER 33 
shall generate M-Plane messages according to one of the PRACH formats in table A.6-1 TS 38.141. TER will choose 34 
the format either according to the manufacturer declaration item D.103 “PRACH format and SCS” in TS 38.141-1 or 35 
according to the format information obtained by the M-plane in case O-RU implements this feature. If more formats are 36 
claimed, only one shall be selected to reduce the test time, preference will be given to a format specified in Table A.6.1 37 
TS 38.141. It is assumed that the O-RU manufacturer will support at least one in that table. For the case of long 38 
preambles, it is assumed format 0 is always supported since this is the only one shown in the table A.6-1 TS 38.141. 39 
 40 
C. Test Methodology 41 
  42 
a: Initial Conditions 43 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-44 
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 45 
port and configure the source to transmit the required PRACH test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from 46 
the CUSM-E.   47 
Implicit in this Initial set up is statically configuring O-RU with a section of time/frequency resources for static 48 
PRACH signals. 49 
b: Procedure 50 
 Set signal generator power by the following method: 51 
a. Select SNR from the scenario with two RX antennas and AWGN propagation condition in table 8.4.1.5-52 
1, 8.4.1.5-2 or 8.4.1.5-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected SCS and PRACH format. 53 
b. Select the AWGN power level according to the configured SCS and channel bandwidth in table 54 
8.4.1.4.2-1 TS 38.141-1 and 38.141-1and multiply by the PRACH signal bandwidth.  55 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       124 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
c. The output power will be given by the formula (SNR+Noise power – 3dB) rounded to the first decimal 1 
digit. Extra 3dB are to compensate that SNR and noise power are selected from the two RX ports test 2 
case and this test procedure requires only one O-RU port. 3 
 4 
For example, for the FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3 SNR is -13.5dB and noise level 5 
is -70.1dBm/98.28MHz. signal generator power = -13.5dB -70.1dBm/98.28MHz*(139*30 KHz)-3dB 6 
=-19.5dBm.  7 
 Set signal generator frequency offset to the central carrier frequency. PRACH will be mapped over 8 
frequency according to msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter equal to 0. PRACH format is set according 9 
to what TER has selected from the manufacturer declarations. 10 
 Start PRACH waveform generation on the signal generator. Ensure the test frame is repeated enough times 11 
to generate a statistically significant number of PRACH occasions. That is at least 10 occasions. 12 
 TER will perform PRACH detection per each PRACH occasion in each frame sent and compare the result 13 
with the expected preamble ID and the expected timing offset. Since the external AWGN and fading 14 
generator are not present the time error tolerance should be low, TER will use the time error tolerance in 15 
table 8.4.1.1-1 for AWGN case according to the corresponding PRACH format and PRACH SCS. A counter 16 
of successful detections is incremented at every matching. The probability of detection is given by the ratio 17 
between that counter and the number of the expected received PRACH occasions within the test time. 18 
 Repeat the test procedure by setting msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter to the right edge of the 19 
configured carrier bandwidth in order to exercise a different frequency offset number 20 
  21 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  22 
1. Test is pass if the probability of detection is 100%. 23 
 24 
 25 
 26 
 UC Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended using section extension 13 for frequency 27 
hopping UL – Resource Allocation 28 
A. Test Description and Applicability 29 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 30 
 31 
The purpose of this test is to validate the capability of the O-RU to correctly interpret section extension 13, 32 
frequency hopping, for the uplink. 33 
 34 
This test will validate correct uplink operation of the O-RU using 3GPP Reference Sensitivity level definition 35 
(Section 7.2 TS 38.141-1) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 38.141) and power 36 
Levels at least 30 dB above Reference Sensitivity power Level described in TS 38.141-1 table 7.2.5-1.  This is to 37 
improve the likelihood that all data will be received by the radio correctly since we are not interested in testing 38 
receiver sensitivity but only the O-RAN protocol compliance. C-Plane message will reference 2 symbols using 39 
section extension 13. 40 
 41 
 42 
startRAn
startRAn

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       125 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1  2 
Figure 3.2.3.1-21 G-FR1-A5-1 UL FDD Test Signal 3 
 4 
Using an RF source, the test equipment will generate a 3GPP test signal as shown in Figure 3.2.3.1-21 above.  5 
The radio will demodulate and decode this signal and send frequency domain IQ to the O-DU-Emulator as 6 
instructed by the O-DU-emulator using uplink C-Plane messages containing section extension 13.  Note this 7 
signal has 20 slots with all symbols populated with only uplink shared data in the only first 51 RBs.  The 8 
symbols are populated with PN23 data. 9 
 10 
The TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) generates an uplink signal on the antenna connector or TAB connector, 11 
together with the corresponding C-Plane messages on the Fronthaul interface. 12 
 13 
The TER will capture the U-Plane messages generated by the DUT and validate if the payload matches with the 14 
uplink signal.  15 
 16 
It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections 17 
 Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 18 
 Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 19 
 Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 20 
 21 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 22 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.1 of this document.  The test numerology will be 23 
30 kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section 3GPP TS 38.141-1 section G-FR1-A1-5.  24 
It will be for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. The 25 
radio must report that it supports section extension type 13, frequency hopping.  Note this signal may be changed to 26 
any of the 3GPP sensitivity test signals in table A.1-1 in 3GPP TS 38.141-1 if the radio does not support the 27 
numerology and bandwidth used in this test.  The test signal described in this section will be used if the radio 28 
supports that numerology and bandwidth. 29 
 30 
C. Test Methodology 31 
Leverage from the well-known payload (Pseudo Random sequence) of the uplink signal to compare it with the 32 
payload of the signal communicated on the O-RAN interface. The IQ information is extracted from the U-Plane 33 
message and demodulated to retrieve payload.  34 
  35 
a. Initial Conditions 36 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       126 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-1 
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 2 
port and configure the source to transmit the required 3GPP test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from the 3 
CUSM-E.  The signal source power level should be adjusted to at least 30 dB above the setting used in the 3GPP 4 
receiver sensitivity test. 5 
 6 
b. Procedure 7 
 Load uplink test waveform (G-FR1-A1-5 : SCS130k_51RB) on the RF Signal Source.  Note this signal 8 
should contain a new PN23 sequence as user data in PRBs 0 through 50 for symbol 6 and PRBs 100 through 9 
151 for symbol 7.  This will be copied for all 20 slots. The remainder of the test waveform is as described in 10 
3GPP. 11 
 Configure Signal Source to play test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it receives a trigger 12 
signal from the O-DU emulator that C-Plane messages have been sent. 13 
 Load a C-Plane message on Test Equipment O-RU (TER) – Use the O-DU emulator control interface to 14 
build the appropriate C-Plane message that describes this uplink signal. This section should have  15 
startSymbolId = 6, numPrbc = 51, and section extension 13 attached.  The section extension should have 16 
nextSymbolId = 7 and nextStartPrbc = 100. 17 
 Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  18 
 Launch test to play the C-Plane messages and trigger the source to play the RF signal on a frame boundary.  19 
 Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the Antenna port  20 
 Extract IQ information  21 
 Extract Payload 22 
 Compare payload binary sequences  23 
  24 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  25 
1. The verdict is “Test pass” if the test frame received by the signal analyzer contains two U-Plane messages for 26 
this section ID one containing the PN23 sequence for the first 51 PRBs in symbol 6 and PRBs 100 through 27 
151 for symbol #7 containing the PN23 sequence sent by the signal source for those PRBs. 28
