 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming (BFM)  1 
This section describes the beamforming conformance testing for ORAN fronthaul interface. The tests do not aim to test 2 
the O-RU beamforming performance or capabilities but to test that the O-RU under test focuses the RF energy or 3 
sensitivity into a specific direction and with a specific granularity following the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface 4 
of the TER described in section 2.1) C-Plane messages.  5 
Unless stated otherwise in a test case, the following statements apply to all the test cases defined in this section: 6 
 It is based on conducted testing with a setup such as described in Section 2.1 and it only applies to O-RU DUTs 7 
that have conducted antenna ports or TAB connectors. 8 
 9 
 It applies to  Category A and  Category B O-RU DUTs. 10 
 11 
 It applies to LTE and/or 5G New Radio O-RU DUTs.  In both cases, precoding is not required in any test case.   12 
 13 
 If O-RU DUT supports Analog Beamforming (i.e. time domain beamforming), all the U-Plane test frames are 14 
defined by segmenting the Stock Test A: 1 section per symbol.  The definition of this Stock Test A can be 15 
found in Figure 3.2.1.1-2 and the description accompanying this figure.  Each slot shall include multiple 16 
sections (one per symbol within the slot) and only one beam at a time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore 17 
only one beam can be tested per slot. 18 
 19 
 If O-RU DUT supports Digital Beamforming (i.e. frequency domain beamforming), all the U-Plane test frames 20 
are defined by segmenting the Stock Test B: 2 sections per symbol definition as shown in Figure 3.2.1.1-2.  21 
Each slot shall include multiple sections (two per symbol within the slot) and only one beam per section at a 22 
time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore up to two different beams can be tested per slot. 23 
 24 
 If O-RU DUT supports multiple polarizations, it is up to the TER to determine if the testing is carried out for 25 
each polarization separately or multiple polarizations at the same time. In any case, it is important to guarantee 26 
that the correct eAxC_ID for the correct polarization (or polarizations) is exercised.  27 
 28 
 For O-RU DUT that support LTE:  29 
o Downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP E-TM1.1 test frame for FDD (Section 6.1.1.1 TS 36.141-1) with 30 
20MHz bandwidth (100 RB) as shown in Figure 3.2.3.2-1. 31 
 32 
Figure 3.2.3.2-1 E-TM1.1 FDD 20 MHz 100RB 33 
If 20MHz is not supported by the O-RU DUT, then it will use the highest bandwidth supported by the O-34 
RU DUT. 35 
o Uplink test will use a standard 3GPP UL RMC Configuration definition for FDD (TS36.521-1) and 36 
power levels 30dB above Reference Sensitivity power level with 10MHz bandwidth (100 RB) as shown 37 
in Figure 3.2.3.2-2. 38 
 39 Figure 3.2.3.2-2 UL RMC FDD 20 MHz 100 RB 40 
If 20MHz is not supported by the O-RU DUT, then it will use the highest bandwidth supported by the O-41 
RU DUT. 42 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       128 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
 For O-RU DUT that support 5G NR:  2 
o Downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 test frame for FDD in [19] (Section 4.9.2 3 
TS138.141-1) of the Conducted Transmitter Characteristic Test section (Section 6 TS138.141-1) as 4 
described in section 3.2.1.1. The test numerology will be preferably 30KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 5 
MHz Bandwidth. If not supported, then it will use any other supported subcarrier spacing and the 6 
highest bandwidth of the O-RU DUT. 7 
  8 
o Uplink tests will use a standard 3GPP Reference Sensitivity level definition (Section 7.2 and Annex A 9 
TS138.141-1) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 38.141) and power 10 
levels 30dB above Reference Sensitivity power level as described in section 3.2.1.1.  The test 11 
numerology will be preferably 30kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth, if supported. 12 
Otherwise, it will use any available subcarrier space and the highest bandwidth supported by the O-RU 13 
DUT. 14 
  15 
 The O-RU DUT must: 16 
o support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.1 of this document. 17 
o have installed current release of shipping software.  18 
o have at least two conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be connected to a signal analyzer. 19 
Likewise, it must have at least two conducted antenna ports or TAB connectors to be connected to a signal 20 
generator. 21 
o be fully calibrated up to the antenna ports or (TAB connectors) (if needed). It is expected to be calibrated 22 
by O-RU vendor prior to testing.  23 
 24 
 25 
 The TER must: 26 
o be capable of carrying out any signal processing required to generate and demodulate 3GPP compliant 27 
waveforms. 28 
o be able to calculate or extract beamweights (or magnitude and phase relations) between antenna ports or 29 
TAB connectors. Alternatively, and if the O-RU DUT manufacturer provides the list of beam directions 30 
supported by the O-RU DUT, TER might calculate or extract the beam direction instead of the 31 
beamweights. 32 
o be able to generate and deliver signals with the required beamweights (or magnitude and phase relations) at 33 
the antenna ports or TAB connectors.  34 
o be fully calibrated up to the interfaces where is connected to the O-RU DUT antenna ports (or TAB 35 
connectors). For that, a known test signal might be either injected by the TER into the O-RU DUT, or 36 
internally generated by the O-RU DUT, and the O-RU DUT must not apply any digital or analog 37 
beamweights to the known test signal.  One possible method to perform calibration uses injected C-Plane 38 
and U-Plane signals from TER into the O-RU and using C-Plane messages with beamID=0.   39 
 40 
 41 
 The O-DU emulator of the TER must: 42 
o be capable of generating and sending U-Plane messages containing 3GPP test frames following the 43 
corresponding Stock sectioning defined above, as well as be capable of capturing U-Plane messages and 44 
extracting 3GPP test frames (i.e. IQ data) from the captured U-Plane messages. 45 
o be capable of generating the C-Plane messages for, receiving, extracting and demodulating the 3GPP test 46 
frames following the corresponding Stock sectioning defined above. 47 
 48 
 The TER might have less testing ports than the O-RU DUT conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) if 49 
testing is carried out sequentially; or as many antenna ports as the number of conducted antenna ports (or TAB 50 
connectors) under test if testing is carried out simultaneously. 51 
 52 
 It is up to the TER on how to extract the beamweights (or magnitude and phase relation) between the 53 
antenna ports or TAB connectors, or the beam direction / properties, in order to match it with the 54 
manufacturer’s declaration. 55 
 56 
 The user payload will be generated as PN23 with a seed of all ones. 57 
 58 
 It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections: 59 
 Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 60 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       129 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 1 
 Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 2 
 Section 10 for beamforming guidelines. 3 
 Annex J for beamforming methods description.  4 
 5 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – No Beamforming 6 
A. Test Description and Applicability 7 
This test is MANDATORY. 8 
 9 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 10 
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 11 
 12 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 13 
 Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of magnitude and phase relation (or beamweights) between 14 
antenna ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics when O-RU DUT 15 
is operating with no beamforming.  16 
 17 
C. Test Methodology 18 
 19 
a. Initial Conditions 20 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 21 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  22 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 23 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.  24 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 25 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 26 
transmitted signal.  27 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  28 
 29 
b. Procedure 30 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 31 
emulator.   32 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 33 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-SCH 34 
and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 35 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 36 
windows described in section3.2.1.1.1.   37 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 38 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 39 
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam direction from the measured 40 
signal. 41 
 42 
 43 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  44 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 45 
radio category (i.e., EVM). 46 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 47 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 48 
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 49 
connectors, or the extracted beam direction, should match the expected relation, or beam direction, for the 50 
expected no beamforming within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  51 
 52 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – No Beamforming 53 
A. Test Description and Applicability 54 
This test is MANDATORY. 55 
 56 
 57 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       130 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 1 
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 2 
 3 
 4 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 5 
 Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of magnitude and phase relation (or beamweights) between antenna 6 
ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics when O-RU DUT is 7 
operating with no beamforming.  8 
 9 
C. Test Methodology 10 
 11 
a. Initial Conditions 12 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 13 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 14 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 15 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.  16 
 Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 17 
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 18 
signal.  19 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   20 
 21 
b. Procedure 22 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  23 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 24 
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 25 
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test. For 26 
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming). 27 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 28 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-29 
SCH) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 30 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 31 
also triggering the signal source.   32 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 33 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 34 
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or phase relation between 35 
all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O-RU. For example, 36 
repeating the process for a number of different beamweights will simulate the reception of the test signal 37 
from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the sensitivity to 38 
the correct beam direction. 39 
 40 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  41 
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain 42 
all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 43 
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 44 
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 45 
declaration of the phase relation expected for no beamforming. 46 
 47 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam 48 
Beamforming 49 
A. Test Description and Applicability 50 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 51 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with predefined-beams 52 
beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 53 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each indexed beam required in this measurement, see below. The 54 
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction could be 55 
defined by the phase relation between the antenna ports or TAB connectors under test, or directly by extracting the 56 
beam direction. 57 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       131 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 2 
 3 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam Beamforming conformance test 4 
might include multiple tests that the O-RU must comply: 5 
The test should include the following beams: 6 
1. A beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 7 
2. A beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 8 
3. A beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 9 
4. A beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 10 
5. A beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 11 
 12 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured. 13 
 14 
 15 
 16 
 17 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 18 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of beam indices and their associated magnitude and phase relation between antenna 19 
ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics. 20 
 21 
C. Test Methodology 22 
 23 
a. Initial Conditions 24 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 25 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  26 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 27 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   28 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 29 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 30 
transmitted signal.  31 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range. 32 
   33 
b. Procedure 34 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU emulator.   35 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 36 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-SCH and 37 
DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 38 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 39 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   40 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate 41 
and decode the test frame. 42 
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam direction from the measured 43 
signal. 44 
 45 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  46 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 47 
radio category (i.e., EVM). 48 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 49 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 50 
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 51 
connectors, or the extracted beam direction, should match the expected relation, or beam direction, 52 
corresponding to the beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  53 
 54 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Predefined-beam 55 
Beamforming 56 
A. Test Description and Applicability 57 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       132 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 1 
 2 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with predefined-beams 3 
beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  4 
 5 
The same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.3 applies, but 6 
instead it is related to the uplink direction.  7 
 8 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 9 
 10 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of beam indices and their associated magnitude and phase relation between antenna 11 
ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics. 12 
  13 
C. Test Methodology 14 
 15 
a. Initial Conditions 16 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 17 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 18 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 19 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.    20 
 Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 21 
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 22 
signal.  23 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   24 
 25 
b. Procedure 26 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER. 27 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 28 
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 29 
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test. For 30 
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).   31 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 32 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-33 
SCH) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 34 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 35 
also triggering the signal source.   36 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 37 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 38 
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or phase relation between 39 
all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O-RU. For example, 40 
repeating the process for a number of different beamweights will simulate the reception of the test signal 41 
from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the sensitivity to 42 
the correct beam direction. 43 
 44 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  45 
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain 46 
all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 47 
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 48 
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 49 
declaration of the beam under test. 50 
 51 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic 52 
Beamforming 53 
A. Test Description and Applicability 54 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 55 
 56 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       133 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with weight-based dynamic 1 
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  2 
 3 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each weighted beam required in this measurement, see below. The 4 
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction could be 5 
defined by the phase relation between the antenna ports or TAB connectors under test, or by directly extracting the 6 
beam direction. 7 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 8 
 9 
 10 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic Beamforming conformance 11 
test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 12 
a. A weight-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 13 
b. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 14 
(θ). 15 
c. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 16 
(θ). 17 
d. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 18 
(θ). 19 
e. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 20 
(θ). 21 
 22 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured. 23 
 24 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight—based Dynamic Beamforming 25 
conformance test should also evaluate the following compression methods for each of the supported beams 26 
described above (a. to e.) for the O-RU to comply: 27 
a. No compression method applied to the beamforming weights.  28 
b. Block floating point compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit mantissa. 29 
c. Block scaling compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit scaler. 30 
d. μ-law compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit fixed width. 31 
e. Depending on what type of Beamspace compression the DUT supports, either BBeamspace compression 32 
method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit scaler or Beamspace compression method applied to 33 
the beamforming weights with 14-bit mantissa..  34 
 35 
If the O-RU does not support all the compression methods described above, fewer than 5 compression methods will 36 
be measured. 37 
 38 
 39 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 40 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of frequency domain (ϕ) and or time domain (θ) weights for each supported beam, 41 
or alternatively, list of gain and phase relation, or complex beam weights, between antenna ports or TAB 42 
connectors for each supported beam . Also, the O-RU needs to report to the O-DU the antenna array 43 
characteristics. 44 
 45 
C. Test Methodology 46 
 47 
a. Initial Conditions 48 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 49 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 50 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 51 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.    52 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 53 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 54 
transmitted signal.  55 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   56 
 57 
b. Procedure 58 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU emulator.   59 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       134 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 1 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (DL-SCH and DCI) 2 
using section type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension 3 
extType=0x01 to convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 1 4 
since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 5 
should be 0x0. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 6 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 7 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   8 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate 9 
and decode the test frame. 10 
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam direction from the measured 11 
signal. 12 
 13 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  14 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 15 
radio category (i.e., EVM). 16 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 17 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 18 
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 19 
connectors, or the extracted beam direction, should match the expected relation, or beam direction, 20 
corresponding to the beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  21 
 22 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Weight-based Dynamic 23 
Beamforming 24 
A. Test Description and Applicability 25 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 26 
 27 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with weight-based beamforming 28 
and with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  29 
 30 
The same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.5 but applies to 31 
the uplink direction.  32 
 33 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 34 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of frequency domain (ϕ) and or time domain (θ) weights for each supported beam, 35 
or alternatively, list of gain and phase relation, or complex beam weights, between antenna ports or TAB 36 
connectors for each supported beam . Also, the O-RU needs to report to the O-DU the antenna array 37 
characteristics 38 
 39 
C. Test Methodology 40 
 41 
a. Initial Conditions 42 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 43 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  44 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 45 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   46 
 Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 47 
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 48 
signal.  49 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   50 
 51 
b. Procedure 52 
 53 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  54 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 55 
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 56 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       135 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test. For 1 
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).   2 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 3 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (UL-SCH) using section 4 
type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension extType=0x01 to 5 
convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 1 since the same 6 
beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0. No 7 
section type zero messages will be used for this test. 8 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 9 
also triggering the signal source.   10 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 11 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 12 
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or phase relation between 13 
all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O-RU. For example, 14 
repeating the process for a number of different beamweights will simulate the reception of the test signal 15 
from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the sensitivity to the 16 
correct beam direction. 17 
 18 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  19 
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain 20 
all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 21 
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 22 
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 23 
declaration of the beam under test. 24

 26 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Attribute-based Dynamic 27 
Beamforming 28 
A. Test Description and Applicability 29 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 30 
 31 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with attributed-based dynamic 32 
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  33 
 34 
If the O-RU DUT supports Attribute based Dynamic Beamforming, this test is mandatory for the O-RU DUT to be 35 
O-RAN conformant.   36 
The transmitted beam direction and attributes are measured for each attributed beam required in this measurement, 37 
see below. The measured transmitted direction and attributes, i.e. pointing azimuth and elevation angles, 38 
beamwidths and sidelobe suppression, is compared to manufacturer-designated direction and attributes. 39 
Transmitted direction and beam attributes are defined by the magnitude and phase relation between the antenna 40 
ports or TAB connectors under test, or by directly extracting the beam properties. 41 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in Section 10.4.1.1 of [2]. 42 
 43 
 44 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Attribute-based Dynamic Beamforming 45 
conformance test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 46 
a. An attribute-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles with any beamwidth and sidelobe 47 
suppression supported by the O-RU under this beam direction. 48 
b. An attribute-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 49 
(θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction. 50 
c. An attribute-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 51 
(θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction. 52 
d. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 53 
(θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction. 54 
e. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 55 
(θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction. 56 
 57 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       136 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles and attribute 1 
configurations will be measured. 2 
 3 
 4 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 5 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of supported beam directions (azimuth ϕ and elevation θ angles) attributes that are 6 
supported by the O-RU and their associated gain and phase relation, or complex weight, between antenna ports 7 
or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics. 8 
 9 
C. Test Methodology 10 
 11 
a. Initial Conditions 12 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 13 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  14 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 15 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   16 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 17 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 18 
transmitted signal.  19 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   20 
 21 
b. Procedure 22 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 23 
emulator.   24 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 25 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (DL-SCH and DCI) 26 
using section type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension 27 
extType=0x02 to convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 2 28 
since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot.  If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 29 
should be 0x0. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 30 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 31 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   32 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 33 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 34 
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam properties from the measured 35 
signal. 36 
 37 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  38 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 39 
radio category (i.e., EVM). 40 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 41 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 42 
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 43 
connectors, or the extracted beam properties, should match the expected beam properties corresponding to the 44 
beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  45 
 46 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Attribute-based Dynamic 47 
Beamforming 48 
A. Test Description and Applicability 49 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 50 
 51 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with attribute-based 52 
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 53 
 54

uplink direction.  56

B. Test Entrance Criteria 1 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of supported beam directions (azimuth ϕ and elevation θ angles) attributes that are 2 
supported by the O-RU and their associated gain and phase relation, or complex weight, between antenna ports 3 
or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics 4 
 5 
C. Test Methodology 6 
 7 
a. Initial Conditions 8 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 9 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 10 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 11 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.    12 
 Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 13 
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 14 
signal.  15 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   16 
 17 
b. Procedure 18 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  19 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 20 
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 21 
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test. For 22 
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).   23 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 24 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (UL-SCH) using section 25 
type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension extType=0x02 to 26 
convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 2 since the same 27 
beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0. No 28 
section type zero messages will be used for this test. 29 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while also 30 
triggering the signal source.   31 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 32 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 33 
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or magnitude and phase 34 
relation between all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O-RU. For 35 
example, repeating the process for a number of different sets of beamweights will simulate the reception of 36 
the test signal from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the 37 
sensitivity to the correct beam properties. 38 
 39 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  40 
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should 41 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 42 
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 43 
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the 44 
manufacturer’s declaration of the beam under test. 45 
 46 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based 47 
Beamforming 48 
A. Test Description and Applicability 49 
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 50 
 51 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with channel-information-based 52 
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU-MIMO). 53 
 54 
For Category A radios, the test is for each polarization separately and consequently either different or same channel 55 
models can be defined for each of the polarization. For Category B, same channel might be used for both 56 
polarizations and the test might measure each polarization separately. 57 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       138 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each scenario required in this measurement.  The measured 1 
transmitted direction is extracted from the decoded received signal in the TER. Transmitted direction is defined by 2 
properly receiving a data transmission between the O-RU and the target User Equipment while destroying or 3 
heavily attenuating the data transmission between the O-RU and the other User Equipment. 4 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based Beamforming 5 
conformance test should evaluate the following scenarios for the O-RU to comply and will rely on TER Channel 6 
Emulation capabilities as shown in Figure 3.2.3.2-3.  7 
 8 
 9 Figure 3.2.3.2-3 TER with Channel Emulation Capability 10 
 11 
a. A scenario where two spatial streams, or eAxC flows, are generated for two users (one layer each) with M 12 
antenna ports or TAB connectors. The O-DU will report to the O-RU via C plane messages an emulated 13 
channel estimate 𝐻 ≜  [ℎଵଵ, . . . , ℎଵெ, ℎଶଵ, . . . , ℎଶெ] ∈ ℂଶ௫ெ. The emulated channel  𝐻  shall model a static channel, 14 
with rank not lower than the number of spatial streams, and it shall not be a block-diagonal channel. As an 15 
example, a Butler channel model could be implemented as emulated channel. The O-RU will calculate and 16 
apply the beamweight matrix 𝐺 ≜  [𝑔ଵଵ, . . . , 𝑔ଵெ, 𝑔ଶଵ, . . . , 𝑔ଶெ] ∈ ℂெ௫ଶ in such that the received signal at the 17 
users is the same as the generated in the O-DU. It is up to the O-RU on how to calculate the beamforming 18 
weights, for example Zero-forcing, regularized zero-forcing / MMSE, etc.   19 
 20 
If O-RU supports Analog Beamforming (Time Domain Beamforming), the test should not apply any analog 21 
beamforming or time domain beamforming. In this case, M is not the number of antenna ports or TAB connectors 22 
but the number of TRX channels supported by the O-RU. 23 
 24 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 25 
 26 
 The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be 27 
connected to a signal analyzer. 28 
 The TER equipment must either include a channel emulator between the O-RU antenna ports and the signal 29 
analyzer or the signal analyzer be capable of applying the required channel matrix being emulated between the 30 
O-RU and the users.  31 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antenna ports or TAB connectors are 32 
connected to each TRX chain.  33 
 34 
C. Test Methodology 35 
 36 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       139 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
a. Initial Conditions 1 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 2 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  3 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 4 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   5 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the scenario under 6 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 7 
transmitted signal.  8 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   9 
 10 
b. Procedure 11 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 12 
emulator.   13 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 14 
and the scenario under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-SCH and 15 
DCI) using section type 5 and 6 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 16 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 17 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1. 18 
d. Capture the test signals and pass them through a channel emulator or apply the signal processing required 19 
to emulate the channel under test.   20 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 21 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 22 
 23 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  24 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 25 
radio category (i.e., EVM). 26 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 27 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 28 
 29 
 30 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Channel-Information-based 31 
Beamforming 32 
A. Test Description and Applicability 33 
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 34 
 35 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with channel-information-based 36 
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU-MIMO).  37 
 38 
Same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.10 but considering 39 
uplink direction.  40 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 41 
 42 
 The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be 43 
connected to a signal generator. 44 
 The TER equipment must either include a channel emulator between the O-RU antenna ports and the signal 45 
generator or the signal generator be capable of applying the required channel matrix being emulated between 46 
the users and the O-RU.  47 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antenna ports or TAB connectors are 48 
connected to each TRX chain. 49 
 50 
C. Test Methodology 51 
 52 
a. Initial Conditions 53 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 54 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  55 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 56 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   57 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       140 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 1 
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 2 
signal.  3 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  4 
  5 
b. Procedure 6 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER. 7 
b. Inject the test signals through a channel emulator or apply the required signal processing to emulate the 8 
channel under test.  9 
c. Inject the resulting test signals into the antenna ports (or TAB connectors). 10 
d. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 11 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-SCH) using 12 
section type 5 and 6. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 13 
e. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 2.4. while also 14 
triggering the signal source.   15 
f. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 16 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 17 
 18 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  19 
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should 20 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 21 
 22 
 23 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Flexible Predefined-beam 24 
Beamforming 25 
A. Test Description and Applicability 26 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 27 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with predefined-beams 28 
beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC) using section extension 11. 29 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each indexed beam required in this measurement, see below. The 30 
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction could be 31 
defined by the phase relation between the antenna ports or TAB connectors under test, or directly by extracting the 32 
beam direction. 33 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 34 
 35 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Flexible Predefined-beam Beamforming 36 
conformance test might include multiple tests that the O-RU must comply. The test should include any two of the 37 
following beams: 38 
1. A beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 39 
2. A beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 40 
3. A beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 41 
4. A beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 42 
 43 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 44 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of beam indices and their associated magnitude and phase relation between antenna 45 
ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics. 46 
 47 
C. Test Methodology 48 
 49 
a. Initial Conditions 50 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 51 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  52 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 53 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   54 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       141 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 1 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 2 
transmitted signal.  3 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range. 4 
   5 
b. Procedure 6 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU emulator.   7 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 8 
and the beam under test. Every slot should be described by one section (DL-SCH and DCI) using section 9 
type 1 and will contain section extension extType=0x0B to convey the beamIDs for Beam1 and Beam2, i.e. 10 
BeamID1 and BeamID2.  11 
The fields in Section Extension 11 should contain the following values: 12 
disableBFWs RAD numBundPrb bfwCompHdr 
1 0 floor(allocPRBsymbol /2) (depends on method) 
 13 
 14 
 15 
 16 
 17 
 18 
 19 
Where allocPRBsymbol is the number of allocated PRBs per symbol for the Downlink test waveform under 20 
a certain Bandwidth and Subcarrier spacing configuration. For example, for a 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 with 21 
100MHz bandwidth and 30KHz subcarrier spacing, the allocPRBsymbol is 273. 22 
If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0. No section type zero messages will be used 23 
for this test. 24 
No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 25 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 26 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   27 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate 28 
and decode the test frame. 29 
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam direction from the measured 30 
signal. 31 
 32 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  33 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 34 
radio category (i.e., EVM). 35 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 36 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 37 
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 38 
connectors, or the extracted beam direction, should match the expected relation, or beam direction, 39 
corresponding to the beams under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer. 40 
 41 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Flexible Predefined-beam 42 
Beamforming 43 
A. Test Description and Applicability 44 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 45 
 46 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with predefined-beams 47 
beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC) using section extension 11.  48 
 49 
The same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.11 applies, but 50 
instead it is related to the uplink direction.  51 
 52 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 53 
Bundle bfwCompParam beamId 
PRB bundle 0 (depends on Compression method) beamID1 
PRB bundle 1 (depends on Compression method) beamID2 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       142 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of beam indices and their associated magnitude and phase relation between antenna 2 
ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics. 3 
  4 
C. Test Methodology 5 
 6 
a. Initial Conditions 7 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 8 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 9 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 10 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.    11 
 Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 12 
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 13 
signal.  14 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   15 
 16 
b. Procedure 17 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER. 18 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 19 
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 20 
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test. For 21 
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).   22 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 23 
and the beam under test. Every slot should be described by one section (UL-SCH) using section type 1 24 
messages and will contain section extension extType=0x0B to convey the beamIDs for Beam1 and Beam2, 25 
i.e. BeamID1 and BeamID2.  26 
The fields in Section Extension 11 should contain the following values: 27 
disableBFWs RAD numBundPrb bfwCompHdr 
1 0 floor(allocPRBsymbol/2) (depends on method) 
 28 
 29 
 30 
 31 
 32 
 33 
 34 
Where allocPRBsymbol is the number of allocated PRBs per symbol for the Uplink test waveform under a 35 
certain Bandwidth and Subcarrier spacing configuration. For example, for a 3GPP G-FR1-A1-5 test 36 
waveform with 100MHz bandwidth and 30KHz subcarrier spacing, the allocPRBsymbol is 51. 37 
If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0. No section type zero messages will be used 38 
for this test. 39 
No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 40 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 41 
also triggering the signal source.   42 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 43 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 44 
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or phase relation between 45 
all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O-RU. For example, 46 
repeating the process for a number of different beamweights will simulate the reception of the test signal 47 
from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the sensitivity to 48 
the correct beam direction. 49 
 50 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  51 
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain 52 
all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 53 
2. The beamweights or equivalently the magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of 54 
the test signal that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the 55 
manufacturer’s declaration of the beams under test. 56 
 57 
Bundle bfwCompParam beamId 
PRB bundle 0 (depends on Compression method) beamID1 
PRB bundle 1 (depends on Compression method) beamID2

 1 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Flexible Real Time Weights 2 
Beamforming  3 
A. Test Description and Applicability 4 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 5 
 6 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with flexible weight-based 7 
dynamic beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC) using section extension 11.  8 
 9 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each weighted beam required in this measurement, see below. The 10 
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction could be 11 
defined by the phase relation between the antenna ports or TAB connectors under test, or by directly extracting the 12 
beam direction. 13 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 14 
 15 
 16 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Flexible Real Time Weights Beamforming 17 
conformance test should evaluate any two of following beams (called henceforth Beam1 and Beam2) for the O-RU 18 
to comply: 19 
1. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation 20 
angle (θ). 21 
2. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation 22 
angle (θ). 23 
3. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation 24 
angle (θ). 25 
4. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation 26 
angle (θ). 27 
 28 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Flexible Real Time Weights Beamforming 29 
conformance test should also evaluate the following compression methods for each of the supported beams 30 
described above (a. to e.) for the O-RU to comply: 31 
1. No compression method applied to the beamforming weights.  32 
2. Block floating point compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit mantissa. 33 
3. Block scaling compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit scaler. 34 
4. μ-law compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit fixed width. 35 
5. Depending on what type of Beamspace compression the DUT supports, either BBeamspace compression 36 
method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit scaler or Beamspace compression method applied 37 
to the beamforming weights with 14-bit mantissa..  38 
 39 
If the O-RU does not support all the compression methods described above, fewer than 5 compression methods will 40 
be measured. 41 
 42 
 43 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 44 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of frequency domain (ϕ) and or time domain (θ) weights for each supported beam, 45 
or alternatively, list of gain and phase relation, or complex beam weights, between antenna ports or TAB 46 
connectors for each supported beam. Also, the O-RU needs to report to the O-DU the antenna array 47 
characteristics. 48 
 49

M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 54 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 55 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.    56

________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.
