                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Layer nulling Beamforming 1 
A. Test Description and Applicability 2 
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 3 
 4 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with channel-information-based 5 
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU-MIMO) with section extension 14. 6 
 7 
For Category A radios, the test is for each polarization separately and consequently either different or same channel 8 
models can be defined for each of the polarization. For Category B, same channel might be used for both 9 
polarizations and the test might measure each polarization separately. 10 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each scenario required in this measurement.  The measured 11 
transmitted direction is extracted from the decoded received signal in the TER. Transmitted direction is defined by 12 
properly receiving a data transmission between the O-RU and the target User Equipment while destroying or 13 
heavily attenuating the data transmission between the O-RU and the other User Equipment. 14 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Layer nulling Beamforming conformance test 15 
should evaluate the following scenarios for the O-RU to comply and will rely on TER Channel Emulation 16 
capabilities as shown in Figure 3.2.3.2-3.  17 
 18 
 19 
 20 
a. The conformance test will contain two test runs where in each of the test runs, the O-DU will indicate to 21 
the O-RU that one of the users/layers to be null at a time. For example, first test run will indicate only UE 22 
0 Layer 0 to be null (i.e. null eAxC 0) while the second test run will indicate only UE 1 layer 0 to be null 23 
(i.e. null eAxC 1), see figure Figure 3.2.3.2-4. 24 
 25 
 26 
 27 Figure 3.2.3.2-4 Layer Nulling Beamforming Tests 28 
 29 
b. A scenario where two spatial streams, or eAxC flows, are generated for two users (one layer each) with M 30 
antenna ports or TAB connectors. The O-DU will report to the O-RU via C plane messages using section 31 
types 5 and section types 6 an emulated channel estimate 𝐻 ≜  [ℎଵଵ, . . . , ℎଵெ, ℎଶଵ, . . . , ℎଶெ] ∈ ℂଶ௫ெ. The 32 
emulated channel  𝐻  shall model a static channel, with rank not lower than the number of spatial streams, 33 
and it shall not be a block-diagonal channel. As an example, a Butler channel model could be 34 
implemented as emulated channel. The O-RU will calculate the beamweight matrix 𝐺 ≜35 
 [𝑔ଵଵ, . . . , 𝑔ଵெ, 𝑔ଶଵ, . . . , 𝑔ଶெ] ∈ ℂெ௫ଶ for all layers/users but it will only apply the beamweights to the 36 
users/layers that have not been indicated as null by the O-DU emulator. The TER should only receive the 37 
non-null user/layers for each of the test runs. It is up to the O-RU on how to calculate the beamforming 38 
weights, for example Zero-forcing, regularized zero-forcing / MMSE, etc.   39 
 40 
If O-RU supports Analog Beamforming (Time Domain Beamforming), the test should not apply any analog 41 
beamforming or time domain beamforming. In this case, M is not the number of antenna ports or TAB connectors 42 
but the number of TRX channels supported by the O-RU. 43 
 44 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       147 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 1 
 2 
 The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be 3 
connected to a signal analyzer. 4 
 The TER equipment must either include a channel emulator between the O-RU antenna ports and the signal 5 
analyzer or the signal analyzer be capable of applying the required channel matrix being emulated between the 6 
O-RU and the users.  7 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antenna ports or TAB connectors are 8 
connected to each TRX chain.  9 
 10 
C. Test Methodology 11 
 12 
a. Initial Conditions 13 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 14 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  15 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 16 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   17 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the scenario under 18 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 19 
transmitted signal.  20 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   21 
 22 
b. Procedure 23 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 24 
emulator.   25 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 26 
and the scenario under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-SCH and 27 
DCI) using section type 5 and 6 messages. Section type 5 messages will contain section extension 14 28 
indicating the nulling of the eAxC to be nulled under this test run. No section type zero messages will be 29 
used for this test. 30 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 31 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1. 32 
d. Capture the test signals and pass them through a channel emulator or apply the signal processing required 33 
to emulate the channel under test.   34 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 35 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 36 
f. Repeat procedure a. to e. for the other eAxC to be nulled (i.e. the remining eAxC not tested yet). 37 
 38 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  39 
1. For each of the test runs, the expected signal (i.e. the expected User containing non-nulled eAxC data) is 40 
measured by the signal analyzer and should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this radio 41 
category (i.e., EVM) 42 
2. For each of the test runs, the non-expected signal (i.e. the non-expected User containing nulled eAxC data) 43 
should be measured but no data should be detected (or heavily attenuated) by the signal analyzer. 44 
3. For each of the test runs, the expected test frame to be received for each test run by the signal analyzer should 45 
be the same as the signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original 46 
PN23 data. 47 
 48 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Layer nulling Beamforming 49 
A. Test Description and Applicability 50 
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 51 
 52 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with channel-information-based 53 
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU-MIMO) with section extension 14.  54 
 55 
Same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.15 but considering 56 
uplink direction.  57 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 58 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       148 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
 The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be 2 
connected to a signal generator. 3 
 The TER equipment must either include a channel emulator between the O-RU antenna ports and the signal 4 
generator or the signal generator be capable of applying the required channel matrix being emulated between 5 
the users and the O-RU.  6 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antenna ports or TAB connectors are 7 
connected to each TRX chain. 8 
 9 
C. Test Methodology 10 
 11 
a. Initial Conditions 12 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 13 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  14 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 15 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   16 
 Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 17 
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 18 
signal.  19 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  20 
  21 
b. Procedure 22 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER. 23 
b. Inject both test signals, for both Users, through a channel emulator or apply the required signal processing 24 
to emulate the channel under test.  25 
c. Inject the resulting test signals into the antenna ports (or TAB connectors). 26 
d. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 27 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-SCH) using 28 
section type 5 and 6. Section type 5 messages will contain section extension 14 indicating the nulling of the 29 
eAxC to be nulled under this test run. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 30 
e. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 2.4. while also 31 
triggering the signal source.   32 
f. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 33 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 34 
g. Repeat procedure a. to f. but now null other eAxC to be nulled (i.e. the remining eAxC not tested yet). 35 
 36 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  37 
1. For each of the test runs, the expected test frame (i.e. the non-nulled eAxC) received by the TER/O-DU should 38 
be the same as the signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original 39 
PN23 data. 40 
2. For each of the test runs, the non-expected test frame (i.e. the nulled eAxC) received by the TER/O-DU should 41 
be measured and confirm that no data or heavily attenuated data is measured. 42 
 43 
 44 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based 45 
Beamforming with mixed numerology 46 
A. Test Description and Applicability 47 
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 48 
 49 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with channel-information-based 50 
beamforming and mixed numerology in combination with a beam-ID-based beamforming and mixed numerology. 51 
 52 
For Category A radios, the test is for each polarization separately and consequently either different or same channel 53 
models can be defined for each of the polarization. For Category B, same channel might be used for both 54 
polarizations and the test might measure each polarization separately. 55 
The two beams share the spectrum equally and the transmitted beam directions for UE-based and beam-ID-based 56 
beamforming are either sufficiently separated in space or a guard band can be signaled in between to avoid 57 
interference. On each beam, i.e. the beam signaled via beam ID and the beam signaled via UE-ID the testcase 58 
emulates a change of the numerology.  59 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       149 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based Beamforming with 1 
mixed numerologies conformance test should evaluate the following scenarios for the O-RU to comply and will 2 
rely on TER capabilities as shown in Figure 3.2.3.2-5. 3 
 4 
 5 Figure 3.2.3.2-5 Test setup for channel information based beamforming with mixed numerologies 6 
a. A scenario where two spatial streams, or eAxC flows, are generated for two users (one layer each) with M 7 
antenna ports or TAB connectors. The O-DU will signal to the O-RU via C plane messages a beam ID based 8 
beam and a UE ID based beam that are either sufficiently separated in the spatial domain to avoid interference 9 
or a guard band is configured between the frequency domain resources. The two beams share the channel 10 
bandwidth in equal parts, depending on the applied numerology. The beam ID beam direction is based on 11 
manufacturer declaration and the O-DU may report to the O-RU via C plane messages an emulated channel 12 
estimate 𝐻 ≜  [ℎଶଵ, . . . , ℎଶெ] ∈ ℂଶ௫ெ allowing the computing of the beamweight matrix 𝐺 ≜  [𝑔ଶଵ, . . . , 𝑔ଶெ] ∈13 
ℂெ௫ଶ in such that the received signal at the UE ID based beam is the same as the generated in the O-DU. It is 14 
up to the O-RU on how to calculate the beamforming weights, for example Zero-forcing, regularized zero-15 
forcing / MMSE, etc.   16 
 17 
If O-RU supports Analog Beamforming (Time Domain Beamforming), the test should not apply any analog 18 
beamforming or time domain beamforming. In this case, M is not the number of antenna ports or TAB connectors 19 
but the number of TRX channels supported by the O-RU. 20 
 21 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 22 
 23 
 The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be 24 
connected to a signal analyzer. 25 
 The TER equipment must be able to receive the two beams via an RF connection stage. This can for example  26 
include a channel emulator between the O-RU antenna ports and the signal analyzer or a switch matrix with 27 
sufficient decoupling between its connectors.  28 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antenna ports or TAB connectors are 29 
connected to each TRX chain.  30 
 Manufacturer provides information about beam ID based beamforming to allow the signaling of the channel 31 
information allowing the UE-based beam in a sufficiently separated spatial direction to avoid interference. 32 
Alternatively, a guard band can be signaled between the two frequency allocations on each beam.  33 
 34 
C. Test Methodology 35 
 36 
a. Initial Conditions 37 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 38 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  39 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 40 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   41 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       150 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the scenario under 1 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 2 
transmitted signal.  3 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   4 
 5 
b. Procedure 6 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 7 
emulator.   8 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 9 
and the scenario under test. Due to the symbol duration dependency on the subcarrier spacing, the section 10 
corresponding to 15 kHz SCS covers 2 OFDMA symbols duration, the section corresponding to 30 kHz 11 
SCS covers 4 OFDMA symbols and the section corresponding to 60 kHz SCS covers 8 OFDMA symbol 12 
duration to have a common measurement time of 1 ms for each numerology.   13 
c. The C-Plane message schedules two sections separated in the frequency domain at the same time, the 14 
channel bandwidth is divided in two sections of equal size. A guard band between the two frequency 15 
sections can be configured. One section presents beam ID based beamforming and the simultaneous section 16 
presents the UE ID based beamforming.  17 
d. The O-DU emulator signals section type 1 corresponding to beam ID specific beamforming for the 18 
measurement duration of 4 OFDMA symbols and 30 kHz SCS. The user plane data is a new PN23 19 
sequence. After the measurement duration of 4 OFDMA symbols, the O-DU emulator signals section type 20 
3 with mixed numerology and schedules an SCS of 15 kHz. The scheduling and measurement duration is 2 21 
OFDMA symbols. The user plane data is a new PN23 sequence. The beam ID value is the same in section 22 
type 1 and section type 3 and the occupied bandwidth for both numerologies should match as much as 23 
possible.  24 
e. The O-DU emulator signals section type 5 corresponding to the UE ID based beamforming for the 25 
measurement duration of 4 OFDMA symbols and 30 kHz SCS. The user plane data is a new PN23 26 
sequence. After the measurement duration of 4 OFDMA symbols, the O-DU emulator signals section type 27 
5 with section extension 15 mixed numerology and schedules an SCS of 60 kHz. The scheduling and 28 
measurement duration is 8 OFDMA symbols. The user plane data is a new PN23 sequence. The UE ID 29 
value is different for the section type 5 and section type 5 with section extension 15 case, emulating a 30 
situation of time domain beamforming to two separate UE IDs. The occupied bandwidth for both 31 
consecutive UE ID beams should match as much as possible.  32 
f. The O-DU emulator may schedule after the two scheduling periods of 1 ms each (4 OFDMA symbols 33 
followed by 2 OFDMA for 15 kHz SCS / 8 OFDMA symbols for 60 kHz SCS) another two sections with 34 
30 kHz SCS and section type 1 / section type 5 scheduling, see Figure 3.2.3.2-6 35 
g. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. As described, there will be 4 user plane data section, each 36 
one containing a new PN23 sequence. 37 
h. Capture the test signals and pass them through a channel emulator or apply the signal processing required 38 
to receive the two beams generated by the DUT.   39 
i. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 40 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 41 
 42 
Section type 5 + Section 
extension type 15 
 Optional guard band

Figure 3.2.3.2-6 Test execution details 1

D. Test Requirement (expected result)  3 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 4 
radio category (i.e., EVM). 5 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 6 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 7

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Bit masking for antenna 10 
mapping in Channel-Information-based Beamforming in uplink direction 11 
A. Test Description and Applicability 12 
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 13 
 14 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive properly a basic 3GPP test frame with bit masking 15 
signaling an antenna mapping for channel-information-based beamforming in uplink direction. 16 
 17 
The O-DU emulator shall signal antenna port combinations via section extension type 16 as declared by the 18 
manufacturer. An uplink signal is fed into the O-RU antenna ports signaled as belonging to the antenna mapping 19 
and the received signal should indicate good reception by analysis of EVM and PN pattern matching. In a second 20 
analysis, the uplink signal is fed into the O-RU antenna ports that are not signaled as belonging to the antenna 21 
mapping and the received signal quality, e.g. EVM should be much worse compared to the proper reception case. 22 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – bit masking for antenna mapping in Channel-23 
Information-based Beamforming should evaluate the following scenarios for the O-RU to comply and will rely on 24 
TER capabilities as shown in Figure 3.2.3.2-7.  25 
 26 
 27 Figure 3.2.3.2-7 Test setup for channel information based beamforming with bit masking for antenna mapping 28 
in uplink direction 29 
 30 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 31 
 32 
 The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be 33 
connected to a signal generator. 34 
 The TER equipment must be able transmit two uplink signals that are fed into the antenna ports of the O-RU. 35 
The feeding of the uplink signal into the antenna ports can be done simultaneously or consecutively.  36 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       152 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 The TER may contain a channel emulation stage or a switch matrix to allow the proper connection of the 1 
uplink signal with the O-RU antenna port or a consecutive test with manual connection is possible 2 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antenna ports or TAB connectors are 3 
connected to each TRX chain.  4 
 Manufacturer provides information about antenna mapping to enable correct signaling via C-plane  5 
  6 
C. Test Methodology 7 
 8 
a. Initial Conditions 9 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 10 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  11 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 12 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   13 
 Connect the signal generator to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the scenario 14 
under test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 15 
demodulate the transmitted signal.  16 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   17 
 18 
b. Procedure 19 
a. The uplink signal is described by table A.1-1 in 3GPP 38.141-1 and is referred to as G-FR1-A1-5 with the 20 
power that is about 30 dB higher as the minimum sensitivity. The data content is a new PN23 sequence in 21 
each of the two test steps. 22 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 23 
and the scenario under test.  24 
c. The O-DU emulator signals via section extension type 16 without section extension 10 the antenna masking 25 
dependent on manufacturer declaration. The antenna elements belonging to the signaled antenna mask are 26 
identified by the first eAxC value in section extension type 16.  27 
d. Test step 1: The signal generator uplink signal containing a new PN23 sequence in the FRC G-FR1-A1-5 is 28 
connected to the antenna port identified as the first eAxC value corresponding to the situation where the 29 
uplink signal is properly connected to the receiving antenna port. The received signal should indicate a 30 
good EVM signal quality and the PN23 sequence matches between generator and analyzer 31 
e. Test step 2: A second uplink signal containing a new PN23 sequence in the FRC G-FR1-A1-5 is connected 32 
to the antenna port not identified as the first eAxC value in the section extension type 16 message 33 
corresponding to the situation where the uplink signal is wrongly connected to the receiving antenna port. 34 
The received signal quality should be much worse compared to the signal quality detected in paragraph (d) 35 
f. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 36 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 37 
 38 
 39 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  40 
1. For the situation of the uplink signal fed into the first eAxC antenna port signaled as belonging to the antenna 41 
mask, the signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement 42 
for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 43 
2. The test frame received in test step 1 by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above 44 
and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 45 
3. The received uplink signal in test step 2 should indicate a EVM not satisfying the 3GPP performance or indicate 46 
a PN pattern mismatch 47 
 48 
 49 
 50 
 51 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – User port grouping in 52 
Channel-Information-based Beamforming in downlink direction 53 
A. Test Description and Applicability 54 
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 55 
 56 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with UE based antenna port 57 
grouping and channel-information-based beamforming. The test emulates a downlink signal with 2 layers 58 
belonging to the same UE. Via section extension type 17, the O-DU emulator signals the same UE ID for the two 59 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
downlink layer signal and the analyzer shall indicate a good signal quality. In a second test step, the signal analyzer 1 
is connected to an antenna port of the O-RU that is not signaled as belonging to the user port group and the 2 
received signal quality should be much worse compared to test step 1.  3 
 4 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – user port grouping for antenna mapping in 5 
Channel-Information-based Beamforming should evaluate the following scenarios for the O-RU to comply and will 6 
rely on TER capabilities as shown in Figure 3.2.3.2-8 7 
 8 
 9 Figure 3.2.3.2-8 Test setup for channel information based beamforming with user port grouping antenna 10 
mapping in downlink direction 11 
 12 
a. A scenario where two spatial streams, or eAxC flows, are generated for one user. The antenna configuration 13 
of the O-RU has M antenna element rows as of manufacturer declaration and R<M antenna elements will be 14 
used to transmit the two layers to the user. The O-DU will signal to the O-RU via C plane messages a UE ID 15 
based beam and a user port grouping. The O-DU may report to the O-RU via C plane messages an emulated 16 
channel estimate 𝐻 ≜  [ℎଵଵ, . . . , ℎଵெ] ∈ ℂଵ௫ெ allowing the computing of the beamweight matrix 𝐺 ≜17 
 [𝑔ଵଵ, . . . , 𝑔ଵோ, … , 𝑔ଵெ] ∈ ℂெ௫ଵ in such that the  received signal at the UE ID based beam is the same as the 18 
generated in the O-DU. It is up to the O-RU on how do the antenna port grouping and the selection of the 19 
number of R antenna element rows and to calculate the beamforming weights, for example Zero-forcing, 20 
regularized zero-forcing / MMSE, etc.   21 
 22 
 23

 25 
 The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be 26 
connected to a signal analyzer. 27 
 The TER equipment must be able to receive the two layers via an RF connection stage. This can for example  28

C. Test Methodology 34

a. Initial Conditions 36

 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 1 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   2 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the scenario under 3 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 4 
transmitted signal.  5

 7 
b. Procedure 8 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 9 
emulator.  The user plane data content is a new PN23 for each of the two layers.  10 
b. The O-DU emulator signals section type 5 with section extension type 10 and section extension type 17 11 
corresponding to the UE ID based beamforming.  Section extension type 17 indicates the value numUeID 12 
for the first user on the two layers dedicated to this user 13 
c. Test step 1: The O-DU emulator provides a user plane data signal representing two layers with a new PN23 14 
sequence on each layer. The C-Plane signals an antenna port grouping using the section extension type 17. 15 
The received signal should indicate a good EVM signal quality and the PN23 sequence matches between 16 
generator and analyzer on both layers dedicated to the user.  17 
d. Test step 2: The signal analyzer is connected to an antenna port that is not signaled as belonging to the user 18 
port group via section extension type 17. This can be done simultaneously to test step 1 or consecutively. 19 
The received signal quality should be much worse compared to the signal quality detected in test step1. 20 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 21 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 22 
 23 
 24

basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 27 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 28 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 29 
3. The received downlink signal in test step 2 should indicate a EVM not satisfying the 3GPP performance or 30 
indicate a PN pattern mismatch 31

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression (CMP) 1 
Validate the correct implementation and interpretation of mandatory and optional IQ data compression formats 2 
described in [2]. Also, evaluate the consistency in U-Plane signaling. 3 
It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections in [2]: 4 
 Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 5 
 Section 5.4.4.10 for applicability of "udCompHdr" and "reserved" fields 6 
 Section 6.3.3.13 udCompHdr (user data compression header) 7 
 Section 6.3.3.15/16/17 for applicability of udCompParam 8 
 Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 9 
 Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 10 
 Table 8-2 for mandatory/optional capabilities. 11 
 Annex A 12 
 Annex A.6 Selective RE sending Compression 13 
 14 
The objective is primarily to test the protocol, prior to the compression algorithms performance. 15 
Signalling: IQ Compression related fields in UC-Plane messages include:  16 
 U-Plane IQ data field  17 
 C-Plane udCompHdr (per section 5.4.4.10 of [2]) 18 
 U-Plane udComphdr (per section 6.3.3.13 of [2]) 19 
 U-Plane udCompParam (per section 6.3.3.15 of [2]) 20 
 21 
Compression: The current specification [2] includes 7 compression modes, including uncompressed mode (fixed 22 
point).  Tests should cover each one of these modes   23 
 fixed-point 24 
 block floating-point 25 
 block scaling 26 
 mu-law 27 
 modulation compression (modulation compression not included in this document) 28 
 Block Floating Point + selective RE sending 29 
 Modulation Compression + selective RE sending 30 
 31 
IQ Bit Width: IQ information can be represented using different bit width (1-16 bits). To optimize test time, tests 32 
should be performed on a subset of bit widths  33 
 9 bits 34 
 14 bits  35 
 Overview of Compression Test Methodology 36 
A common test methodology and structure will be used across all compression test cases. Each one of the test cases will 37 
be defined with specific input parameters and expected output values.  38 
To minimize influence of the Radio’s RF performance to the test results, the test methodology will be based on a 39 
relative comparison between modulated signal measurements performed on a test frame with uncompressed IQ (fixed 40 
16 bits) and measurements on the same test frame using compressed IQ. The test will verify that the difference between 41 
measurements fits within an acceptable range for the test to pass. 42 
For downlink test, the modulated signal measurement is performed by a signal analyzer on the antenna port of the O-43 
RU.  44 
For uplink measurement, the modulated signal measurement is performed with the IQ extracted from the Uplink U-45 
Plane data sent by the O-RU on the O-RAN interface.  46 
The following paragraphs in this overview section outline the details of these common test methodologies.  47 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       156 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
3.2.3.3.1.1 Test Frame 1 
The test frames used for compression conformance test will be referred in this document as “NR-FR1-CMP-TST-2 
FRAME-DL” Downlink Standard Compression Test frame and “NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL” Uplink Standard 3 
Compression Test frame. They are 5G NR frames based on the description in section 3.2.1.1.5 with specific attributes 4 
described below. 5 
The Downlink UC-Plane test stimulus file includes the C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to 6 
transmit on the downlink the NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-DL test frame.  7 
The Uplink C-Plane test stimulus file includes the C-Plane messages that require the O-RU to provide the uplink U-8 
Plane messages according to the NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL test frame received by the O-RU on its antenna port. 9 
Signalling and IQ information will be based on various compression schemes 10 
Stimulus File Name Description 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-UNC-16B Static Downlink Uncompressed (CU-plane) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-UNC-16B Static Uplink Uncompressed (C-plane only) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-FPF-9B Static Downlink Fixed Point 9 Bits (CU-plane) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-FPF-14B Static Downlink Fixed Point 14 Bits (CU-plane) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-FPF-9B Static Uplink Fixed Point 9 Bits (C-plane only) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-FPF-14B Static Uplink Fixed Point 14 Bits (C-plane only) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-BFP-9B Static Downlink Block Floating Point 9 Bits (CU-plane) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-BFP-14B Static Downlink Block Floating Point 14 Bits (CU-plane) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-BFP-9B Static Uplink Block Floating Point 9 Bits (C-plane only) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-BFP-14B Static Uplink Block Floating Point 14 Bits (C-plane only) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-BSC-9B Static Downlink Block Scaling 9 Bits (CU-plane) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-BSC-14B Static Downlink Block Scaling 14 Bits (CU-plane) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-BSC-9B Static Uplink Block Scaling 9 Bits (C-plane only) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-BSC-14B Static Uplink Block Scaling 14 Bits (C-plane only) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-MLW-9B Static Downlink Mu-Law 9 Bits (CU-plane) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-MLW-14B Static Downlink Mu-Law 14 Bits (CU-plane) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-MLW-9B Static Uplink Mu-Law 9 Bits (C-plane only) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-MLW-14B Static Uplink Mu-Law 14 Bits (C-plane only) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-MC Static Downlink Modulation Compression  
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-UNC-BRE-
16B 
Static Downlink Uncompressed (CU-plane) with both empty 
and allocated RE in the same symbol   
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-UNC-BRE-
16B 
Static Uplink Uncompressed (C-plane only) with both empty 
and allocated RE in the same symbol

(CU-plane)

(CU-plane)

 4 
3.2.3.3.1.2 Test Frame Power  5 
To ensure that the compressed IQ exponent value is properly tested, each symbol of the test frame will include 3 6 
sections with different power levels.  The Power levels are relative powers to the first group of PRBs transmitted.  Any 7 
valid 3GPP power level may be used for the first set of PRBs as long as the power levels of the remaining PRBs are 8 
also valid.  Figure 3.2.3.3-1 below shows PRB power relative to the first set of PRBs. 9 
    0 dB for the bottom third of total PRBs in the symbol (referred as PDSCH0) 10 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       158 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 -10 dB for the middle third of total PRBs in the symbol (referred as PDSCH1) 1 
 -20 dB for the upper third of total PRBs in the symbol (referred as PDSCH2) 2 
 3 
The spectrum representation of the frame shown in Figure 3.2.3.3-1 below highlights the various power levels for each 4 
group of PRBS within a symbol.  5 
 6 
Figure 3.2.3.3-1 PRB Spectrum Power Visualization 7 
 8 
3.2.3.3.1.3 Test Frame User data  9 
To validate that user data has not been impacted by compression, the test payload for the 3 sections is each based on an 10 
individual PN23 sequence that will be measured and compared by the test apparatus.   11 
3.2.3.3.1.4 Test Frame Modulation Scheme 12 
To maximise coverage on the compressed IQ mantissa value, the test frame will use the highest possible modulation 13 
(256 QAM modulation for downlink).  An example measurement is show in Figure 3.2.3.3-2. 14 
 15 
Figure 3.2.3.3-2 Example User Data Modulation Validation 16 
3.2.3.3.1.5 Summary of Required Measurements for Compression Tests 17 
3 measurements types will be required for downlink tests and 4 measurements will be required for uplink tests.  18 
 Power level:  Using the test frames (NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-DL and NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL) 19 
sent twice with both compressed and uncompressed IQ data, power level measurements are performed to 20 
validate compression algorithms influence on Exponent (udCompParam).  21 
The Power level measurements are called: 22 
 23 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 24 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 25 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 26 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 27 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 28 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 29 
 30 
For the test to pass, the difference between measurements should be within an acceptable range, called 31 
o ACC_PWR_PDSCH0 = ± 1dB 32 
o ACC_PWR_PDSCH1 = ± 1dB 33 
o ACC_PWR_PDSCH2 = ± 1dB 34 
o  35 
 EVM:  Using a common test frame sent twice with both compressed and uncompressed IQ data, EVM 36 
measurements comparisons between uncompressed IQ and compressed IQ will help validate acceptable 37 
compression influence on signal quality.  38 
 39 
These 6 EVM measurements required: 40 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       159 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 in % 1 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0  in % 2 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1  in % 3 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1  in % 4 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2  in % 5 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2  in % 6 
 7 
For the test to pass, the difference between the compressed and uncompressed measurements for the same 8 
PDSCH signal must be within the following range: 9 
o ACC_EVM_PDSCH0 ≤ 4 percentage points 10 
o ACC_EVM_PDSCH1 ≤ 4 percentage points 11 
o ACC_EVM_PDSCH2 ≤ 4 percentage points 12 
 13 
An example measurement showing both power and EVM is shown below in Figure 3.2.3.3-3. 14 
  
Figure 3.2.3.3-3 Example Compression EVM Measurement 15 
 16 
 Payload Data Integrity:  comparing user data between the O-RAN test frame and the RF measurement to 17 
validate that compression does not influence user data.  The User data measurements are called: 18 
 19 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH0  20 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH1  21 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH2  22 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH0  23 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH1  24 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH2  25 
 26 
For the data integrity test to pass, the comparison between stimulus payload and the measured payload should 27 
be free of any errors (i.e. BER=0).  28 
 29 
 Presence/Absence of U-Plane Header measurements (uplink only): to validate that in the U-Plane PRB 30 
header, the udCompHeader, “reserved” and udCompParam fields are correctly absent for Static compression 31 
mode or present for other compression modes.  32 
 33 
Table 3.2.3.3-3 describes the measurements required for each compression option in the downlink. 34 
 35

3.2.3.3.1.7 Results Analysis 2 
In general, for each specific Compression Test in this conformance test document, the test will pass if the following 3 
conditions are met: 4 
 Power measurement differences between Uncompressed and Compressed are within acceptable range  5 
 EVM measurement difference between Uncompressed and Compressed are within acceptable range  6 
 Data integrity measurements show no data corruption 7 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       162 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Uplink U-Plane Header measurements exclude fields for static compression 1 
 2 
These test criteria and expected results are summarized below in 3.2.3.3-6.   3

Table 3.2.3.3-5  Compression Test Acceptance Threshold Criteria 1 
 2 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Static Format (SF) Fixed-Point (FP)  3 
A. Test Description and Applicability 4 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY and shall be performed if the O-RU supports this compression 5 
format. 6 
 7 
The purpose of this test is to: 8 
 Validate correct encoding of IQ data under the following conditions.  9 
o RU Static compression configurations 10 
o Fixed point IQ data format 11 
o Selection of 2 supported bit width: 9 bits, 14 bits  12 
o Uplink / downlink 13 
 Validate that in the U-Plane PRB header, the udCompHeader, “reserved” and udCompParam fields are 14 
not present  15 
 16 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 17 
 The test uses the setup and methodology described in section 3.2.1.1. 18 
 19 
 20 
C. Test Methodology 21 
a.  Initial Conditions 22 
 The O-RU is started 23 
 Fronthaul Ethernet interface configured for communication between TER and the DUT. 24 
 O-RU synchronized with TER using S-Plane 25 
 Communication established between TER and the DUT such that it is possible to exchange U-Plane and 26 
C-Plane messages  27 
 Signal Analyzer connected to DUT’s antenna port and setup according to DUT RF output configuration 28 
 Signal Source connected to DUT’s antenna port and setup according to DUT RF input configuration 29 
 30 
b.  Procedure 31 
For each supported bit width (9 bits, 14 bits), the following tests need to be performed: 32 
  33 
1. Downlink test 34 
 Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, put the O-RU into a static configuration with the 35 
downlink configured as follows: no compression, (16 bits) 36 
 Arm Signal Analyzer to capture the next Frame  37 
 Send the “uncompressed” NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-UNC-16B test stimulus file to the 38 
DUT 39 
 With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 power measurements  40 
 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 41 
 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 42 
 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 43 
 With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 EVM measurements  44 
 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 in % 45 
 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 in % 46 
 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 in % 47 
 With the Signal Analyzer, check Data integrity measurements  48 
 CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH0  49 
 CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH1  50 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       165 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH2  1 
 Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, put the O-RU into a static configuration with the 2 
downlink configured as follows: Fixed point, 9-bit (then 14 bits)  3 
 Send the “Compressed” NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-FPF-9B (then 14B) test stimulus 4 
file to the DUT 5 
 With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 power measurements  6 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 7 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 8 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 9 
 With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 EVM measurements  10 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 in % 11 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 in % 12 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 in % 13 
 With the Signal Analyzer, check Data integrity measurements  14 
 CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH0  15 
 CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH1  16 
 CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH2  17 
 Verify the following conditions  18 
 Power measurements within acceptable range  19 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 and CMP-20 
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH0 range 21 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 and CMP-22 
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH1 range 23 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 and CMP-24 
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH2 range 25 
  26 
 27 
 EVM  measurements within acceptable range  28 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 and CMP-29 
Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH0 30 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 and CMP-31 
Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH1 32 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 and CMP-33 
Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH2 34 
 35 
 BER Measurements show no errors  36 
 CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH0 =0 37 
 CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH1  =0 38 
 CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH2 =0 39 
 CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH0 =0 40 
 CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH1 =0 41 
 CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH2 =0 42 
  43 
2. Uplink test 44 
 Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, put the O-RU into a static configuration with the 45 
uplink configured as follows: no compression, 16-bit 46 
 Arm Signal Source to generate the Frame NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL 47 
 Arm CUSM-E to send the “uncompressed” NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-UNC-16B test 48 
stimulus file to the DUT 49 
 ARM CUSM-E to capture the Uplink U-Plane Data from the DUT 50 
 Launch the test 51 
 Extract IQ information from Capture U-Plane trace 52 
 Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 power measurements  53 
 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 54 
 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 55 
 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 56 
 57 
 Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 EVM measurements  58 
 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 in % 59 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       166 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 in % 1 
 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 in % 2 
 3 
 Using the Signal Analyzer software, check Data integrity measurements  4 
 CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH0  5 
 CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH1  6 
 CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH2  7 
 8 
 Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, put the O-RU into a static configuration with the 9 
uplink configured as follows: Fixed point, 9-bit (then 14 bits)  10 
 Arm Signal Source to generate the Frame NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL 11 
 Arm CUSM-E to send the “Compressed” NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-FPF-9B test stimulus 12 
file to the DUT 13 
 Arm CUSM-E to capture the Uplink U-Plane Data from the DUT 14 
 Launch the test 15 
 Extract IQ information from Capture U-Plane trace 16 
 Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 power measurements  17 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 18 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 19 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 20 
 21 
 Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 EVM measurements  22 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 in % 23 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 in % 24 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 in % 25 
 26 
 Using the Signal Analyzer software, check Data integrity measurements  27 
 CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH0  28 
 CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH1  29 
 CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH2  30 
 31 
 Validate correct U-Plane PRB header structure  32 
 U-Plane udComphdr (per section 6.3.3.13 of [2]) 33 
 U-Plane udCompParam (per section 6.3.3.15 of [2]) 34 
 35 
 Validate that the power measurements within acceptable range  36 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 and CMP-37 
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 is withinACC_PWR_PDSCH0 range 38 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 and CMP-39 
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 is withinACC_PWR_PDSCH1 range 40 
  41 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 and CMP-42 
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 is withinACC_PWR_PDSCH2 range 43 
 EVM measurements within acceptable range  44 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 and CMP-Compressed-45 
Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH0 46 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 and CMP-Compressed-47 
Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH1 48 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 and CMP-Compressed-49 
Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH2 50 
 51 
 Validate that the BER Measurements show no errors  52 
 CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH0 = 0 53 
 CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH1 = 0 54 
 CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH2 = 0 55 
 CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH0 = 0 56 
 CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH1 = 0 57 
 CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH2 = 0 58

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Static Format (SF) Modulation-10 
Compressed Format 11 
A. Test Description and Applicability 12 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY and shall be performed if the O-RU supports this compression 13 
format. 14 
 15 
This modulation compression format scenario is a static format scenario, based on 3.2.3.3.2 with some important 16 
differences 17 
 The purpose is to validate Radio Unit’s correct interpretation of the Modulation compression parameters 18 
used in the Section Extension Type = 4 and Section Extension Type 5  19 
 When high level modulation is supported by the Device Under Test (DUT), Section Extension Type 5 20 
messages will be tested on the current compression test frame , that includes Mixed MCS test cases where 21 
high MCS user data REs and low MCS DMRS signaling data REs are in the same PRB. 22 
 The test will only verify DL correct encoding of IQ information, as the Modulation Compression model is 23 
not applicable for uplink 24 
 As the Modulation Compression model does not require IQ bit width to be setup, there is no need to run 25 
multiple compression tests for various IQ bit width.  26 
 27 
Stimulus File Name Description 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-UNC-16B Static Downlink Uncompressed (CU-plane) 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-MC Static Downlink Modulation Compression  
 28 
 29 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 30 
Same as 3.2.3.3.2. 31 
 32 
C. Test Methodology 33 
Same as 3.2.3.3.2 with Static Modulation Compression test patterns 34 
 NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-MC 35 
 36 
Note that this test is only applicable to the downlink and therefore should only follow the downlink steps of the 37 
referenced test case above.  Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, put the O-RU into a static 38 
configuration with the downlink configured as follows: Modulation Compression. 39 
 40 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  41 
All validation steps for the downlink referenced in 3.2.3.3.2 are within expected ranges or correctly match the 42 
expected outcome. 43

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Non-Static (NS) Fixed-Point (FPF)  45

format. 48

information for 2 supported bit widths: 9 bits or 14 bits. 50 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       169 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 2 
Same as 3.2.3.3.2. 3 
 4 
C. Test Methodology 5 
a. Initial Conditions 6 
 Same as 3.2.3.3.2  Non-Static Fixed-Point test patterns 7 
 Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, disable the O-RU Static IQ and compression format 8 
 9 
 10 
b. Procedure 11 
For each supported bit width (9 bits, 14 bits), the following tests need to be performed: 12 
1. Downlink test 13 
 Arm Signal Analyzer to capture the next Frame  14 
 Send the uncompressed” NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-NS-DL-UNC-16B test stimulus file to the 15 
DUT 16 
 With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 power measurements  17 
 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0in dBm 18 
 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 19 
 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 20 
 21 
 With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 EVM measurements  22 
 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 in % 23 
 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 in % 24 
 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 in % 25 
 26 
 With the Signal Analyzer, check Data integrity measurements  27 
 CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH0  28 
 CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH1  29 
 CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH2  30 
 31 
 Send the “Compressed” NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-NS-DL-FPF-9B (then 14B) test stimulus 32 
file to the DUT 33 
 34 
 With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 power measurements  35 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 36 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 37 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 38 
 39 
 With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 EVM measurements  40 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 in % 41 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 in % 42 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 in % 43 
 44 
 With the Signal Analyzer, check Data integrity measurements  45 
 CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH0  46 
 CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH1  47 
 CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH2  48 
 49 
 Validate that the power measurements within acceptable range  50 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 and CMP-51 
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH0 range 52 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 and CMP-53 
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH1 range 54 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 and CMP-55 
Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH2 range 56 
 57 
 Validate that the EVM  measurements within acceptable range  58 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 and CMP-59 
Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 is within ACC_EVM_PDSCH0 range 60

 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 and CMP-1 
Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 is within ACC_EVM_PDSCH1 range 2 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 and CMP-3 
Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 is within ACC_EVM_PDSCH2 range 4

2. Uplink test 15

test stimulus file to the DUT 18

 CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 in % 30

 36

configuration   38

 Arm CUSM-E to send the “Compressed” NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-NS-UL-CMP-9B 40 
(then 14B) test stimulus file to the DUT 41 
 ARM CUSM-E to capture the Uplink U-Plane Data from the DUT 42 
 Launch the test 43 
 Extract IQ information from Captured U-Plane trace 44 
 Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 power measurements  45 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH0 in dBm 46 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH1 in dBm 47 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-PDSCH2 in dBm 48 
 49

 CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 in % 52 
 CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 in % 53 
 54

 Validate correct U-Plane PRB header structure  1 
 U-Plane udComphdr (per section 6.3.3.13 of [2]specification) 2

Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH0 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH0 value. 13 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 and CMP-14 
Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH1 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH1 value. 15 
 Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 and CMP-16 
Compressed-Measured-EVM-PDSCH2 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH2 value. 17

 CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH0 = 0 19 
 CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH1 = 0 20 
 CMP-Uncompressed-BER-PDSCH2 = 0 21

 CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH1 = 0 23 
 CMP-Compressed-BER-PDSCH2 = 0 24

A. Test Description and Applicability 37

 40 
This modulation compression format scenario is a non-static format scenario, based on 3.2.3.3.2 with some 41 
important differences 42 
 The purpose is to validate Radio Unit’s correct interpretation of the Modulation compression parameters 43 
used in the Section Extension Type = 4 and Section Extension Type 5  44 
 When high level modulation is supported by the Device Under Test (DUT), Section Extension Type 5 45 
messages will be tested on the current compression test frame , that includes Mixed MCS test cases where 46 
high MCS user data REs and low MCS DMRS signaling data REs are in the same PRB. 47 
 The test will only verify DL correct encoding of IQ information, as the Modulation Compression model is 48 
not applicable for uplink 49 
 As the Modulation Compression model does not require IQ bit width to be setup, there is no need to run 50 
multiple compression tests for various IQ bit width.  51

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Static Format (SF) Block Floating Point 16 
+ Selective RE Format 17 
A. Test Description and Applicability 18 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY and shall be performed if the O-RU supports this compression 19 
format. 20 
 21 
The Block Floating-Point+ Selective RE Format scenario is a static format scenario that will verify DL and UL 22 
correct encoding of IQ information for 2 supported bit widths: 9 bits or 14 bits. 23 
 24 
For this test scenario, the compression test methodology will be based on the description in section 3.2.3.3.1.  25 
 26 
However, on top of the test frame requirements from section 3.2.3.3.1, this test scenario also requires a test frame 27 
that MUST include PRBs with a combination of allocated and empty Resource Elements in the same symbol, to 28 
verify if the O-RU properly interprets the ReMask value in the udCompParam field (user data compression 29 
parameter). The measurements must be performed on the symbols that include a combination of empty and 30 
allocated resource elements.  31 
 32 
The recommended DL test frame is based on Type 2 DMRS with 2 DMRS CDM groups without data. The 33 
resource mapping model for the Resource Blocks is shown Figure 3.2.3.3-4, where both symbols #2 and #11 34 
include a combination of empty and allocated Resources. 35 
 36 
 37 Figure 3.2.3.3-4  Frame Format Compression Test Selective RE 38 
 39 
The uncompressed and compressed test frames are listed in Table 3.2.3.3-6  Stimulus Files for Static Compression 40 
Test  41

Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       174 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
Stimulus File Name Description 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-UNC-RE-16B Static Downlink Uncompressed (CU-plane) with both 
empty and allocated RE in the same symbol   
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-UNC-RE-16B 
Static Uplink Uncompressed (C-plane only) with both 
empty and allocated RE in the same symbol   
 
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-BRE-9B Static Downlink Block Floating Point + Selective RE 9 
Bits (CU-plane)  
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-BRE-14B Static Downlink Block Floating Point + Selective 14 
Bits (CU-plane)  
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-BRE-9B 
Static Uplink Block Floating Point 9 Bits + Selective 
RE  
 (C-plane only)  
NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-BRE-14B Static Uplink Block Floating Point 14 Bits + Selective 
RE (C-plane only)  
Table 3.2.3.3-6  Stimulus Files for Static Compression Test 1 
 2 
 3

Same as 3.2.3.3.2 for static Block floating point + Selective RE formats. 5

C. Test Methodology 7 
 Same as 3.2.3.3.2 with Static Block Floating Point + Selective RE test patterns.  8 
 9 
The uncompressed test frames used for this test are 10 
 NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-UNC-RE-16B 11 
 NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-UNC-RE-16B 12 
 13 
The compressed test frames used for this test are  14 
 NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-BRE-9B 15 
 NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-DL-BRE-14B 16 
 NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-BRE-9B 17 
 NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-ST-UL-BRE-14B 18 
 19 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  20 
 Same as 3.2.3.3.2. 21

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Static Format (SF) mod-compr + 23 
Selective RE Format 24 
A. Test Description and Applicability 25 
This test is CONDITIONAL- MANDATORY and shall be performed if the O-RU supports this compression 26 
format. 27 
 28 
This modulation compression + Selective format scenario is a static format scenario, based on 3.2.3.3.2 with some 29 
important differences 30 
 The purpose is to validate Radio Unit’s correct interpretation of the Modulation compression parameters 31 
used in the Section Extension Type = 4 and Section Extension Type 5  32 
 When high level modulation is supported by the Device Under Test (DUT), Section Extension Type 5 33 
messages will be tested on the current compression test frame , that includes Mixed MCS test cases where 34 
high MCS user data REs and low MCS DMRS signaling data REs are in the same PRB. 35 
 The test will only verify Downlink correct encoding of IQ information, as the Modulation Compression 36 
model is not applicable for uplink 37 
 As the Modulation Compression model does not require IQ bit width to be setup, there is no need to run 38 
multiple compression tests for various IQ bit widths.  39 
 40 
On top of the test frame requirements described above , this test scenario requires a test frame that MUST include 41 
PRBs with a combination of allocated and empty Resource Elements in the same symbol, to verify if the O-RU 42 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       175 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
properly interprets the ReMask value in the udCompParam field (user data compression parameter).  The 1 
measurements must be performed on the symbols that include a combination of empty and allocated resource 2 
elements.  3 
 4 
The recommended DL test frame is based on Type 2 DMRS with 2 DMRS CDM groups without data. The 5 
resource mapping model for the Resource Blocks is shown on the diagram below, where both symbols #2 and #11 6 
include a combination of empty and allocated Resources. 7

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Non-Static Format (NS) Block Floating 1 
Point + Selective RE Format 2 
A. Test Description and Applicability 3 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY and shall be performed if the O-RU supports this compression format  4 
 5 
This Block Floating-Point+ Selective RE Format scenario is a non-static format scenario that will verify DL and 6 
UL correct encoding of IQ information for 2 supported bit widths: 9 bits or 14 bits. 7 
For this test scenario, the compression test methodology will be based on the description in section 3.2.3.3.1  8 
 9 
However, on top of the test frame requirements from section 3.2.3.3.1, this test scenario also requires a test frame 10 
that MUST include PRBs with a combination of allocated and empty Resource Elements in the same symbol, to 11 
verify if the O-RU properly interprets the sReMask value in the udCompParam field (user data compression 12 
parameter). The measurements must be performed on the symbols that include a combination of empty and 13 
allocated resource elements.  14 
 15 
The recommended DL test frame is based on Type 2 DMRS with 2 DMRS CDM groups without data. The 16 
resource mapping model for the Resource Blocks is shown on the diagram below, where both symbols #2 and #11 17 
include a combination of empty and allocated Resources. 18

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Delay Management (DLM) 3 
This section describes conformance test cases for O-RU Delay Management. 4 
The test setup for these test cases is shown in 2.1.  5 
When performing the conformance test cases for scenario class Delay Management it does not matter which timing 6 
method is used. The different timing methods are described in section 2.3.2, 2.3.3, 2.3.4 and 2.3.5 in the CUS 7 
Specification [2] 8 
Delay Management downlink tests will test whether the O-RU can accurately transmit data when C and U plane 9 
messages are received at the extreme ends of their respective reception windows. Uplink tests will test whether the O-10 
RU can accurately transmit received data to the CUSM-E when the CUSM-E transmits uplink C-Plane messages within 11 
the correct uplink reception window.  It also tests whether the O-RU sends its U-Plane messages within the correct 12 
reception window. 13 
Figure 3.2.3.4-1 shows a simplified timing relation for the C- and U-Plane messages for downlink. 14 
The size of the control plane reception window on the O-RU will be: (T2a_max_up +Tcp_adv_dl) – (T2a_min_up 15 
+Tcp_adv_dl) = C-Plane reception window.   The start-point (before t=0) will be: T2a_max_up + Tcp_adv_dl = start of 16 
C-Plane transmission window. 17 
The size of the reception window for the user plane will be: T2a_max_up - T2a_min_up. The start-point (before t=0) 18 
will be T2a_max_up. 19 
As an example, if the values are set such as T2a_max_up = 264 µs, Tcp_adv_dl = 63 µs and T2a_min_up = 53 µs, then 20 
the C-Plane reception window would be 211 µs, the start of C-plane transmission window would be 327 us, the U-plane 21 
reception window would 211 µs and the start of U-plane transmission window would be 264 µs. 22 
 23 
 24 
TERO-RUTERt=0symbol #0symbol #13symbol #12ccuuT2a_max_cp_dlT2a_min_cp_dlReception windowC-Plane DLT2a_max_up_dlT2a_min_up_dlReception windowU-Plane DLTcp_adv_dl
 25 
Figure 3.2.3.4-1 Simplified Timing for Downlink 26 
 27 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       179 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
The Delay Management uplink test cases for the O-RU will test that if the C-Plane fronthaul messages are received with 1 
respective reception window then the corresponding U-Plane messages will be sent in the O-RU’s transmission 2 
window. 3 
Figure 3.2.3.4-2 shows a simplified timing relation for the C-Plane and U-Plane messages for uplink. 4 
Similar to the downlink case, the size of the control plane reception window is T2a_max_cp_ul - T2a_min_cp_ul . The 5 
start-point of (before t=0) of the C-plane reception window is T2a_max_cp_ul. 6 
The size of the transmission window for the user plane will be: Ta3_max_up  - Ta3_min_up. The start-point (after t=0) 7 
will be Ta3_min_up. 8 
If we follow the same example values as the ones set in the downlink case, the C-plane reception window would be 211 9 
µs, the start-point of the C-plane reception window would be 274 µs, the U-plane transmission window would be 70 µs 10 
and the start-point of the U-plane transmission window would be 20 µs.  11 
 12 
TERO-RUTERt=0symbol #0symbol #13symbol #12cc uuT2a_max_cp_ulT2a_min_cp_ulReception windowC-Plane ULTa3_max_up_dlTa3_min_up_dlTransmission windowU-Plane ULt 13 
Figure 3.2.3.4-2 Simplified Timing for Uplink 14 
 15 
The test frame used for downlink tests will be (by default) will be the 3GPP G-FR1-A1-1 FDD signal shown below in 16 
Figure 3.2.3.4-3.   If the radio does not support this signal a 3GPP test wave form that the radio supports can be 17 
substituted provided there is at least one symbol in each slot available for test traffic.  This symbol will be a stock data 18 
section type “B” described in 3.2.1.1.1.  This symbol will contain a new PN23 sequence starting in PRB 0 and 19 
extending to all the PRBS in the test signal (274 PRBs in the example below). 20 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       180 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
Figure 3.2.3.4-3 FDD Downlink Test Signal for Delay Management Tests 2 
 3 
The test frame used for uplink tests will be (by default) the 3GPP G-FR1-A1-1 FDD signal shown below in Figure 4 
3.2.3.4-4.  If the radio does not support this signal a 3GPP test wave form that the radio supports can be substituted 5 
provided there is at least one symbol in each slot available for test traffic.  This symbol will be a stock data section type 6 
“B” described in 2.3.1.  This symbol will contain a new PN23 sequence starting in PRB 0 and extending to all the 7 
PRBS in the test signal (25 PRBs in the example below). 8 
 9 
Figure 3.2.3.4-4 Uplink FDD Test Signal for Delay Management Tests 10 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       181 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class DLM Test #1: Downlink – Positive testing 1 
A. Test Description and Applicability 2 
This test is MANDATORY. 3 
 4 
This test case will validate that the timing on the air interface is according to requirements specified in the 5 
CUS Specification when the C-Plane and the U-Plane messages are received within the O-RU’s reception 6 
windows. 7 
 8 
Four different test cases for downlink can be performed when the expected outcome is positive, i.e. the O-RU 9 
shall be able to transmit the received U-Plane-data on the air interface.  These are shown in Figure 3.2.3.4-5.  10 
Note that in these tests the C-Plane reception window may be applicable to the slot or symbol boundaries 11 
depending on the Radio’s capabilities.  That is, in some radios, the C-Plane reception window is at the 12 
beginning of each slot and all C-Plane messages will be sent at once within this window.  Other radios will 13 
require C-Plane messages to be sent in a reception window for each symbol, In all cases U-Plane messages 14 
will be sent during reception windows corresponding to each symbol regardless of whether the radio has large 15 
enough buffers to store U-Plane data for multiple symbols. 16 
 17 
1: Early - Earlyt=0T2a_max_cp_dlT2a_max_up_dlTcp_adv_dlO-RU rec. win. C-planeO-RU rec. win. U-planeT2a_min_up_dlT2a_min_cp_dlTcp_adv_dlt=0T2a_max_cp_dlT2a_max_up_dlTcp_adv_dlO-RU rec. win. C-planeO-RU rec. win. U-planeT2a_min_up_dlT2a_min_cp_dlTcp_adv_dl2: Early - Late3: Late - Earlyt=0T2a_max_cp_dlT2a_max_up_dlTcp_adv_dlO-RU rec. win. C-planeO-RU rec. win. U-planeT2a_min_up_dlT2a_min_cp_dlTcp_adv_dlt=0T2a_max_cp_dlT2a_max_up_dlTcp_adv_dlO-RU rec. win. C-planeO-RU rec. win. U-planeT2a_min_up_dlT2a_min_cp_dlTcp_adv_dl4: Late - Late
 18 
Figure 3.2.3.4-5 Downlink Positive Test Cases 19 
 20 
1st case “C-Plane Early – U-Plane Early”; the C-Plane message is received by the O-RU at the beginning of 21 
the reception window for the C-Plane messages (indicated with small green box in figure 2.5). The 22 
corresponding U-Plane data is received in the beginning of the reception window for the U-Plane messages 23 
(indicated with small blue box in figure), i.e. Tcp_adv_dl later. 24 
2nd case “C-Plane Early – U-Plane Late”; the C-Plane message is received by the O-RU at the beginning of 25 
the reception window for the C-Plane messages. The corresponding U-Plane data is received earliest Tcp_adv_dl 26 
after the C-Plane message i.e. in the end of the U-Plane reception window. 27 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       182 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
3rd case “C-Plane Late – U-Plane Early”; the C-Plane message is received by the O-RU at the end of the 1 
reception window for the C-Plane messages.  The corresponding U-Plane data is received earliest Tcp_adv_dl 2 
after the C-Plane message i.e. in the end of the reception window. 3 
4th case “C-Plane Late – U-Plane Late”; this case is greyed out in the figure since it will in practice be the 4 
same case as number 3, the U-Plane message cannot be received later than it is in case 3. 5 
 6 
 7 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 8 
The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (or TAB connector) to be connected to a signal analyzer.  The 9 
reception windows will be calculated and used by the CUSM-E based on the delay parameters reported by the 10 
radio on the M-Plane. 11 
 12 
C. Test Methodology 13 
 14 
a. Initial Conditions 15 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 16 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. Connect the RF Signal 17 
Analyzer to the O-RU antenna port. Determine the correct reception windows the radio claims to 18 
support using delay management parameters repowered by the radio, 19 
b. Procedure 20 
Configure the CUSM-ECUSM-E to send C-Plane and U-Plane messages so these messages are received 21 
within the reception windows for respective plane according to the three cases (1..3) described in Figure 22 
3.2.3.4-5 above. NOTE: Make sure that the C-Plane message is received at least Tcp_adv_dl earlier then 23 
the corresponding U-Plane message(s) by the O-RU. 24 
 25 
On the RF-signal-analyzer observe the received signal and compare the decoded data on the selected 26 
test symbol to the send PN23 sequence for that symbol. 27 
 28 
D. Pass/Fail Criteria (expected result) 29 
The test passes if the received data matches the transmitted data. 30 
 31 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class DLM Test #2: Uplink – Positive testing 32 
A. Purpose and Description  33 
This test is MANDATORY. 34 
 35 
This test case will validate that the transmission of the U-Plane data in uplink direction are transmitted correctly by 36 
the O-RU within its transmission window.  The CUSM-E will send C-Plane messages at both ends of the C-Plane 37 
reception window specified by the radio using the M-Plane (Two tests).  The C-Plane messages will describe a test 38 
frame as shown above.  The frame will have one designated symbol in each slot (not containing DMRS 39 
information).  The C-Plane message will ask the radio to send that symbol’s data from each slot. 40 
 41 
After the correct C-Plane messages are sent the CUSM-E will trigger the signal generator to send a valid test signal 42 
to the radio’s RF port.  This signal will contain a new, known PN23 sequence in the same symbol (per slot) 43 
designated by the C-Plane messages. 44 
 45 
The positive test outcome for these uplink test cases is that the corresponding U-Plane data for a specific C-Plane 46 
message is transmitted within the O-RU’s transmission window IF the C-Plane message was received within the O-47 
RU’s reception window as shown in Figure 3.2.3.4-6 48 
.  The data will be transmitted to the radio by an external signal generator and the uplink signal will be as described 49 
above.  The test data sent by the signal generator will contain a known, new PN23 sequence in one symbol of each 50 
slot.  The CUSM-E will expect to receive the same data for the correct symbol in each slot. 51 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       183 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00
