 1 
Figure 3.2.3.4-6 Relationship between C-Plane and U-Plane Message 2 
 3 
Two different test cases can be identified for the uplink case. The C-Plane message is received in the beginning 4 
of the reception window or at the end of the reception window.  These test cases are shown in Figure 3.2.3.4-7 5 
below.  6 
t=0O-RU rec. win. C-planeT2a_max_cp_ulT2a_min_cp_ult=0O-RU rec. win. C-planeT2a_max_cp_ulT2a_min_cp_ul1: Early2: Late
 7 
Figure 3.2.3.4-7 Early and Late C-Plane Message Test Cases 8 
 9 
1st case “Early”; the C-Plane message is received by the O-RU at the beginning of the reception window for the 10 
C-Plane messages (indicated with small green box in figure). 11 
2nd case “Late”; the C-Plane message is received by the O-RU at the end of the reception window for the C-12 
Plane messages. 13 
 14 
 15 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 16 
The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (or TAB connector) to be connected to a signal analyzer.   17 
 18 
C. Test Methodology 19 
a. Initial Conditions 20 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 21 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. Connect the RF Signal Generator to the O-22 
RU antenna port. 23 
b. Procedure 24 
Configure the CUSM-E to send C-Plane so these messages are received within the reception windows 25 
according to the two cases (1..2) described in Figure 3.2.3.4-7 above.  After these messages are sent a trigger 26 
signal will be sent to the signal generator instructing it to send the correct RF test frame at t=0. 27 
 28 
The CUSM-should receive U-Plane messages on the front haul interface during the uplink transmission 29 
window described by the radio over the M-Plane. 30 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       184 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
 2 
D. Pass/Fail Criteria (expected result) 3 
The test case is passed if the correct data is received at CUSM-E in the correct time window. 4 
 5 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class DLM Test #3: Downlink – Negative testing 6 
A. Test Description and Applicability 7 
This test is MANDATORY. 8 
 9 
This test case will validate that the O-RU will correctly increment relevant M-Plane counters if C-Plane and/or U-10 
Plane messages are not received within the respective O-RU reception windows. 11 
 12 
Negative testing for downlink traffic will verify that the O-RU will correctly increment relevant M-Plane counters 13 
if C-Plane and/or U-Plane messages are not received within the respective O-RU reception windows.  There are 14 
four test cases defined for this Downlink test and are shown in Figure 3.2.3.4-8.  The titles on each diagram show 15 
the message arrival time relative to the O-RU receive window for the C-Plane and the U-Plane in that order.  For 16 
instance, test 1: Too Early-OK means the C-Plane message arrived early, outside the O-RU C-Plane receive 17 
window and the corresponding U-Plane message arrived correctly within the O-RU U-Plane receive window.  18 
 19 
1: Too Early - OKt=0T2a_max_cp_dlT2a_max_up_dlTcp_adv_dlO-RU rec. win. C-planeO-RU rec. win. U-planeT2a_min_up_dlT2a_min_cp_dlTcp_adv_dlt=0T2a_max_cp_dlT2a_max_up_dlTcp_adv_dlO-RU rec. win. C-planeO-RU rec. win. U-planeT2a_min_up_dlT2a_min_cp_dlTcp_adv_dl2: OK – Too Early3: OK – Too Latet=0T2a_max_cp_dlT2a_max_up_dlTcp_adv_dlO-RU rec. win. C-planeO-RU rec. win. U-planeT2a_min_up_dlT2a_min_cp_dlTcp_adv_dlt=0T2a_max_cp_dlT2a_max_up_dlTcp_adv_dlO-RU rec. win. C-planeO-RU rec. win. U-planeT2a_min_up_dlT2a_min_cp_dlTcp_adv_dl4: Too Late - OK
 20 
Figure 3.2.3.4-8 Downlink Negative Test Cases 21 
 22 
 23 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 24 
The O-RU must support the default parameters defined in section 3.2.2 above, especially the parameters 25 
concerning delay management. 26 
 27 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       185 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
C. Test Methodology 1 
a. Initial Conditions 2 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 3 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  4 
b. Procedure 5 
Configure the CUSM-ECUSM-E to send C-Plane and U-Plane messages so these messages are received 6 
according to the four test cases shown in figure above. 7 
 8 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 9 
The test case is passed if the M-Plane performance measurement objects in the list “rx-window-measurement-10 
objects” for RX_EARLY are incremented properly for tests 1 and 2 and RX_LATE are incremented properly for 11 
tests 3 and 4.  12 
 13 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class DLM Test #4: Uplink – Negative Testing 14 
A. Test Description and Applicability 15 
This test is MANDATORY. 16 
 17 
This test case will validate that the O-RU will correctly increment relevant M-Plane counters if C-Plane and/or U-18 
Plane messages are not received within the respective O-DU reception windows. 19 
 20 
Negative testing for uplink traffic will verify that the O-RU will correctly increment relevant M-Plane counters if 21 
C-Plane and/or U-Plane messages are not received within the respective O-DU reception windows.  There are four 22 
test cases defined for this Downlink test and are shown in Figure 3.2.3.4-9.  The titles on each diagram show the 23 
message arrival time relative to the O-RU receive window for the C-Plane and the U-Plane in that order.  For 24 
instance, test 1: Too Early-OK means the C-Plane message arrived early, outside the O-RU C-Plane receive 25 
window and the corresponding U-Plane message arrived correctly within the O-RU U-Plane receive window. 26 
Negative testing for uplink traffic will verify that the O-RU will not transmit any U-Plane uplink data when C-27 
Plane messages are not received within the window on the O-RU. 28 
 29 
t=0O-RU rec. win. C-planeT2a_max_cp_ulT2a_min_cp_ult=0O-RU rec. win. C-planeT2a_max_cp_ulT2a_min_cp_ul1: Too Early2: Too Late
 30 
Figure 3.2.3.4-9 Uplink Negative Test Cases 31 
 32 
 33 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 34 
The O-RU must support the default parameters defined in section 3.2.2 above, especially the parameters 35 
concerning delay management. 36 
 37

C. Test Methodology 1 
a. Initial Conditions 2 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 3 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  4 
b. Procedure 5 
Configure the CUSM-E to send C-Plane messages so these messages are received according to the two test 6 
cases shown in figure above. 7 
 8 
D. Pass/Fail (expected result) 9 
The test case is passed if the M-Plane performance measurement objects in the list “rx-window-10 
measurement-objects” for RX_EARLY and RX_LATE are incremented properly for test 1 and test 2 11 
respectively. 12 
 13 
 14 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Transport (TRN) 15 
This test is for future study. 16 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class LAA (LAA) 17 
The purpose of this section is to specify LAA test cases to test the compliance of the O-RU to the O-RAN 18 
specifications. Although in LAA operation, regular C-Plane and U-Plane messages (used for operation over licensed 19 
spectrum as well) are transmitted over the fronthaul interface between the O-DU and O-RU, there exist additional C-20 
Plane messages that are required specifically for LAA operation over unlicensed spectrum. These additional C-Plane 21 
messages are based on Section type 7 and are communicated in both UL and DL directions between the O-DU and O-22 
RU.  23 
 24 
The LAA test cases only focus on LAA-related messages and operations. Other testing aspects that are applicable to 25 
LAA and non-LAA technologies (e.g., delay management, beamforming, compression, etc.) are not considered in this 26 
section; Please refer to other sections in the conformance test specification document. 27 
 28 
LAA considered in this section is based on 3GPP Rel. 13, which only considers downlink transmission on the 29 
unlicensed spectrum (i.e., uplink transmission goes on the licensed component carrier). Hence, all the test cases in this 30 
section will consider downlink operation only. This includes DL U-Plane messages and DL/UL C-Plane messages. 31 
Note also that UL C-Plane messages only exist in LAA technology. 32 
 33 
The LAA test cases for the O-RU test if the O-RU is capable of conforming with the CUSM-E instructions in terms of: 34 
1) Correctly performing the listen-before-talk (LBT) procedure (i.e., managing the congestion window). 35 
2) Timely data transmission based on the spectrum sensing outcome. 36 
3) Timely deferring from occupying the spectrum based on the messages received from the O-DU. 37 
 38 
On the other hand, testing O-RU capabilities (e.g., spectrum sensing) is out of scope of this specifications since it’s not 39 
directly related to the O-RAN fronthaul interface.  40 
 41 
 CU-DU-LAA-CWM Test #1: LBT PDSCH Configuration and Response  42 
A. Test Description and Applicability 43 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY.  The test must be executed if the O-RU supports LAA. 44 
This test validates that the O-RU is capable of the following functions 45 
 Correctly receiving and interpreting C-Plane messages (Section Type 7 and specifically laaMsgType 0) 46 
from the TER to correctly perform LBT.  47 
 Correctly receiving U-Plane data from the TER and correctly processes the data (i.e., drop it or transmit 48 
it) based on the LBT outcome.  49 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       187 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Correctly performing LBT and correctly generating C-Plane messages to inform the TER about the LBT 1 
outcomes using Section Type 7 and specifically laaMsgType 2. 2 
 3 
This test assumes that the O-RU is capable of processing Section Type 1 C-plane messages and its corresponding 4 
U-plane messages. 5 
It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections: 6 
 Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane messages, in particular Section Type 1 and Section Type 7. 7 
 Section 5.4.5.14 for applicability of “laaMsgType” (LAA message type) 8 
 Section 5.4.5.15 for applicability of “laaMsgLen” (LAA message length) 9 
 Section 5.4.5.16 for applicability of “lbtHandle” (LBT Handle) 10 
 Section 5.4.5.17 for applicability of “lbtDeferFactor” (listen-before-talk defer factor) 11 
 Section 5.4.5.18 for applicability of “lbtBackoffCounter” (listen-before-talk backoff counter) 12 
 Section 5.4.5.19 for applicability of “lbtOffset” (listen-before-talk offset) 13 
 Section 5.4.5.20 for applicability of “MCOT” (maximum channel occupancy time) 14 
 Section 5.4.5.21 for applicability of “lbtMode” (LBT Mode) 15 
 Section 5.4.5.22 for applicability of “lbtPdschRes” (LBT PDSCH Result) 16 
 Section 5.4.5.23 for applicability of “sfStatus” (subframe status) 17 
 Section 5.4.5.25 for applicability of “initialPartialSF” (Initial partial SF) 18 
 Section 5.4.5.27 for applicability of “sfnSf” (SFN/SF End) 19 
 Table 8-2 for mandatory capabilities 20 
 21 
The purpose of this test is to: 22 
 Validate that the O-RU can correctly interpret C-Plane messages by correctly performing LBT.  23 
 Validate that the O-RU can correctly construct the UL C-Plane message as specified in Section Type 7, 24 
laaMsgType 2 with the following specialized fields. Specifically,  25 
o Verify the laaMsgLen based on the message content. 26 
o Verify that the lbtHandle parameter in the DL C-Plane message with laaMsgType 0 matches the 27 
corresponding lbtHandle parameter in the UL C-Plane message with laaMsgType 2.  28 
o Verify the lbtPdschRes parameter value. Set: {0, 1, 2, 3}. 29 
o Verify the inParSF parameter value. Set: {0, 1} 30 
o Verify the sfStatus parameter value. Set: {0, 1}.  31 
o Verify the sfnSf value.  32 
 Validate that the O-RU can correctly interpret U-Plane data received from the TER. 33 
 Validate that the O-RU can correctly interpret C-Plane messages received from the TER.  34 
 35 
 36 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 37 
 The O-RU must support LAA 38 
 The O-RU has passed M-Plane conformance and S-Plane conformance testing. 39 
 The O-RU has antenna ports or TAB connectors for TER connections 40 
 41 
C. Test Methodology 42 
The test shall be executed by the TER issuing DL C-Plane messages to the O-RU DUT to cause the O-RU to 43 
execute LBT. Furthermore, the TER shall issue other U-Plane and C-Plane messages required for data 44 
transmission. The TER needs to emulate external interference to allow the O-RU to do LBT and send the LBT 45 
outcome to the TER based on the description in Section 5.3.4 in [2] 46 
 47 
a. Initial Conditions 48 
 TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) is initialized and configured. 49 
 The O-RU is initialized, synchronized, and configured as normal, except that it shall receive and interpret 50 
Test Commands. 51 
 The fronthaul Ethernet interface is up. 52 
  The O-RU is running its usual software, except that it is configured to accept and execute Test 53 
Commands to enable O-RU Conformance Testing. 54 
 The TER needs to emulate the external interference (e.g., Wi-Fi, other LAA cells) for the O-RU to execute 55 
LBT.  56 
 57 
b. Procedure 58

Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 DL C-Plane message (LBT_PDSCH_REQ): 1 
o The TER sends DL C-Plane message to configure the DUT (i.e., O-RU) to execute LBT for 2 
PDSCH transmission using the configuration parameters in Table 3.2.3.6-1 below.  3 
o The TER needs to run 4 consecutive LBT trials starting from run index 1 until run index 4.  4

 DL U-Plane data: 8 
o TER provides U-Plane DL data to the O-RU at the correct time based on Section 5.3.4 in [2] 9 
o TER evaluates the detected U-Plane data for correctness 10 
o Note that multiple U-Plane messages are needed for every “run” (i.e., for every MCOT). Some of 11 
these U-Plane messages should get dropped by the TER based on the outcome of the LBT 12 
process.  13

o TER sends DL C-Plane message to help the DUT interpret the U-Plane data.  16

o The TER generates RF signal to emulate that the channel is busy for the durations shown in 19

 30

the emulated external interference.  34

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class LTE (LTE) 5 
This section describes applicable LTE conformance test cases for O-RAN fronthaul interface. Since there are plenty of 6 
the commonalities between the NR and LTE test cases, this section makes suitable references to the NR specific test 7 
cases sections for the LTE scenarios whenever possible, as below.   8 
 LTE UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Beamforming (BFM) described in clause 3.2.3.2 9 
 LTE UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Compression (CMP) described in clause 3.2.3.3 10 
 LTE UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Delay Management (DLM) described in clause 3.2.3.4 11 
 LTE UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class LAA (LAA) described in clause 3.2.3.6 12 
 LTE UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Section Type 3 described in clause 3.2.3.8 13 
 14 
Subsequently, LTE-only specific generic test cases are explicitly covered in the subsections below.  One of the key 15 
differences applicable for LTE specific test cases as compared to NR is due to the explicit precoding behavior supported 16 
by some of the transmission modes for LTE.  17 
In particular, for a Category B O-RU to implement precoding for LTE TM2-TM4, specific C-Plane instructions need to 18 
be provided to the O-RU from the O-DU.  This specific aspect of the O-RAN fronthaul interface is enabled by the 19 
section extension = 0x3 described in the CUS Plane specification [2]. 20 
For all the test cases described in this section: 21 
 Downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP E-TM1.1 test frame for FDD (Section 6.1.1.1 TS 36.141-1) as shown in 22 
Figure 3.2.3.7-1. 23 
 24 Figure 3.2.3.7-1 3GPP E-TM1.1 Test Frame for FDD 25 
 26 
 Uplink tests will use a standard 3GPP UL FRC Configuration definition for FDD (TS36.521-1) and power levels 27 
30dB above Reference Sensitivity power level as shown in Figure 3.2.3.7-2. 28 
 29 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       190 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 Figure 3.2.3.7-2 UL FRC Configuration for FDD 2 
All the downlink tests in this section use a 3GPP test wave form LTE Test Model 1.1 (E-TM1.1) with 20 MHz 3 
Bandwidth as described in TS 36.141 section 6.1.1.1.   4 
There are several variations on this test signal depending on the capabilities of the radio.  If for example the radio does 5 
not support the bandwidth used in the example tests as reported in the M-plane it will be up to the test developer to 6 
modify their tests to adapt to the radio.  The test is expected to follow the same spirit as the tests in this document may 7 
have to be changed. 8 
Likewise, all uplink tests in this section use a 3GPP test waveform described in 36.141 section A1.  As with downlink 9 
tests if the radio does not support this signal, it is up to the test developer to modify the parameters of the test without 10 
changing the spirit of the test. 11 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Base 3GPP DL 12 
A. Test Description and Applicability 13 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 14 
  15 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame using the default parameters in 16 
section 3.2.1.1.1 of this document except for only one spatial stream on one antenna will be used.   17 
 18 
This test is applicable for  Category A and  Category B radios (No precoding is required).   19 
As per E-TM1.1 all user data in this test will be zeros.  The test will be conducted.   20 
 21 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 22 
 The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.5.3.1 of this document.  The test bandwidth is 20 23 
MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 24 
 The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port to be connected to a signal analyzer.   25 
 The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 26 
 27 
C. Procedure 28 
a. Initial Conditions 29 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 30 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.   31 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors under test and configure the 32 
analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted signal.  33 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range. 34 
 35 
b. Procedure 36 
 Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the E-TM1.1 signal described above in the CUSM-E.  37 
 Use the CUSM-E control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal. 38 
Every symbol should be described by a single section (DL-SCH and DCI) using section type 1 messages.  39 
 The data in the sections must be all zeros.  40 
 No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  41 
 Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 42 
windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the 43 
signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame. 44 
 45 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       191 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  1 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 2 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 3 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above.  If it contains 4 
all the same PRB assignments and all zero data, the test passes. 5 
 6 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP DL – Resource Allocation 7 
A. Test Description and Applicability 8 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 9 
 10 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can accurately interpret C-Plane resource allocation messages, 11 
transfer U-Plane data into the correct resource blocks and transmit this data accurately in the downlink.   12 
 13 
This test requires non-zero data to populate all allocated resource blocks.  This data will be a PN23 sequence with a 14 
seed value of all ones. 15 
 16 
This test is applicable for both  Category A and  Category B radios.  17 
 18 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 19 
 The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1 of this document.  The test bandwidth is 20 20 
MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 21 
 The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port to be connected to a signal analyzer.   22 
 The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 23 
 24 
C. Test Methodology 25 
 26 
a. Initial Conditions 27 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 28 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.   29 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors under test and configure the 30 
analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted signal.  31 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  32 
 33 
b. Procedure 34 
 Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the E-TM1.1 signal described above in the CUSM-E.  35 
 Use the CUSM-E control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal. 36 
Every symbol should be described by a single section (DL-SCH and DCI) using section type 1 messages.  37 
 The data in the sections must be a PN23 sequence using an initial seed of all ones.  38 
 No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  39 
 Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 40 
windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the 41 
signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame. 42 
 43 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  44 
A. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 45 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 46 
B. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above.  It contains all 47 
the same PRB assignments and data the test passes. 48 
 49 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP UL – Resource Allocation 50 
A. Test Description and Applicability 51 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 52 
 53 
The purpose of this test is to validate correct uplink operation of the O-RU using 3GPP Reference Sensitivity 54 
level definition (Section 7.2 TS 36.141) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 55 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       192 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
36.104) and power Levels at least 30 dB above Reference Sensitivity power Level described in E-TM1.1.  This 1 
is to improve the likelihood that all data will be received by the radio correctly since we are not interested in 2 
testing receiver sensitivity but only the O-RAN protocol compliance. The data section will be a PN23 sequence 3 
with a seed value of all ones. 4 
 5 
Under those conditions, 3GPP compliant O-RU should deliver uplink U-Plane information that matches with 6 
the uplink signal.  7 
 8 
The TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) generates an uplink signal on the antenna connector or TAB connector, 9 
together with the corresponding C-Plane messages on the Fronthaul interface. The TER will capture the U-10 
Plane messages generated by the DUT and validate if the payload matches with the uplink signal.  11 
 12 
This test is applicable for both  Category A and  Category B radios. 13 
 14 
It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections 15 
 Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 16 
 Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 17 
 Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 18 
 19 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 20 
 21 
 The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1 of this document.  The test bandwidth is 20 22 
MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 23 
 The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port to be connected to a signal analyzer.   24 
 The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 25 
 The Radio must support the reMask parameter as notified by the M-Plane.  26 
 27 
C. Test Methodology 28 
 29 
a. Initial Conditions 30 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for 31 
operation using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.   32 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors under test and configure 33 
the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 34 
transmitted signal.  35 
 Configure the source to transmit the required 3GPP test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from 36 
the CUSM-ECUSM-E.  The signal source power level should be adjusted to setting used in the 37 
3GPP receiver sensitivity test. 38 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  39 
 40 
b.  Procedure 41 
 Load uplink test waveform (A1-1) on the RF Signal Source  42 
 Configure Signal Source to play test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it 43 
receives a trigger signal from the CUSM-E that C-Plane messages have been sent. 44 
 Load C-Plane message sequence on Test Equipment O-RU (TER)  45 
 Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul messages  46 
 Launch test to simultaneously play RF uplink frame and C-Plane messages  47 
 Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the 48 
Antenna port  49 
 Extract IQ information  50 
 Extract Payload 51 
 Compare payload binary sequences  52 
 53 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  54 
1. The verdict is “Test pass” if payload binary sequences match between the uplink test frame sent to the DUT 55 
and the received U-Plane data from the DUT 56 
2. If any of the test conditions is not true, the verdict for the whole test is "Fail" 57 
3. If the DUT does not support initial conditions, the test verdict is "Inconclusive" 58 
 59 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       193 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended using reMask parameter 3GPP DL – 2 
Resource allocation 3 
A. Test Description and Applicability 4 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 5 
 6 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can accurately interpret C-Plane resource allocation messages 7 
with the reMask parameter set, transfer U-Plane data into the correct resource elements and transmit this data 8 
accurately in the downlink.  This test is applicable for  Category A and  Category B radios (No precoding is 9 
required).  The test will be conducted therefore there will be no channel distortion or interference.  It is 10 
mandatory the radio pass this test to be considered O-RAN conformant. 11 
 12 
This test requires non-zero data to populate all allocated resource blocks.  This data will be a PN23 sequence 13 
with a seed value of all ones.  This test is applicable for both  Category A and  Category B radios.  14 
 15 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 16 
 17 
 The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1 of this document.  The test bandwidth is 20 18 
MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 19 
 The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port to be connected to a signal analyzer.   20 
 The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 21 
 22 
C. Test Methodology 23 
 24 
a. Initial Conditions 25 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for 26 
operation using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.   27 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors under test and configure 28 
the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted 29 
signal.  30 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  31 
 32 
b. Procedure 33 
 Build an appropriate IQ signal described above in the CUSM-E.   34 
 Use the CUSM-E control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal.  35 
 Every symbol should be described by a single type 1 section (DL-SCH and DCI) except symbols#6 36 
which will be used for the reMask test. 37 
 The data in this section must be a PN23 sequence using an initial seed of all ones. The first bits of the 38 
PN23 will be in PRB1 and continue in consecutive resource elements to the end of PRB5. No section 39 
type zero messages will be used for this test. 40 
 Symbol number #6 should be stock data section type “D” as shown above.   41 
 This test will only be using PRBs 1 through 5.  The corresponding C-Plane message will contain a 42 
section IDs in a single C-Plane message describing symbol #6.  43 
 The startSymbolId in the application header will be symbol #6.  44 
 The C-Plane message will have one section with the reMask set to only the odd number resource 45 
elements.  The number of PRBs will be 5. The start PRB will be 1. 46 
 The corresponding U-Plane message will be a new PN23 Sequence (initial seed is all ones) in PRBs 1 47 
through 5 of symbol #6. 48 
 49 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  50 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 51 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 52 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should only contain the same PN23 signals that were sent in 53 
the U-Plane but only every other odd resource element. 54 
 55 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       194 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class With Precoding (WPR) TxD 1 
A. Test Description and Applicability 2 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 3 
 4 
The purpose of this test is to validate the correct implementation of transmit diversity of a Category B O-RU with 5 
two antenna ports.  TxD uses TM2 (transmission Mode 2).  For TxD, information for 2 layers are packed into a 6 
PRB for transmission from O-DU and are unpacked at the O-RU.  TxD precoding is applied based on the C Plane 7 
configuration before RF transmission.  8 
 9 
Using a standard E-TM1.1 test frame for FDD the CUSM-E (i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER described in section 10 
3.2.2) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on the downlink the standard 11 
E-TM1.1 signal.   12 
 13 
This test is applicable for  Category B radios only. 14 
 15 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 16 
 17 
 The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1 of this document.  The test bandwidth is 20 18 
MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 19 
 The O-RU must have two conducted antenna ports to be connected to a signal analyzer.   20 
 The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 21 
 The O-RU must support the Section Extension ExtType=3 parameter as notified by the M-Plane 22 
 23 
C. Test Methodology 24 
 25 
a. Initial Conditions 26 
 27 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 28 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.   29 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors under test and configure the 30 
analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted signal.  31 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  32 
 33 
b. Procedure 34 
 35 
 Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the E-TM1.1 signal described above in the CUSM-E.   36 
 Use the CUSM-E control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal.  37 
 Every symbol should be described by a single section (DL-SCH and DCI) using section type 1 messages. 38 
No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 39 
 The test configures two antenna ports hence two beamIDs needed (same beamID for user data and CRS 40 
REs).  For Antenna Port 0, the beamId is contained in the C-Plane data section header, while the Antenna 41 
Ports 1 (“beamIdAP1”) is contained in the ExtType=3 .  42 
 Configure different eAxCs are used for each layer 43 
 Configure following parameters in the Section Extension ExtType=3   44 
o codebookIndex - ‘00000000’ (invalid) 45 
o layerID (Layer ID for DL transmission) - layer ID that are used for DL transmission 46 
o txScheme (transmission scheme) - ’txD’ 47 
o numLayers (number of layers used for DL transmission) - 0001 (implies 2) 48 
o crsReMask (CRS resource element mask)  49 
o crsSymlNum (CRS symbol number indication) 50 
o crsShift (crsShift used for DL transmission) 51 
 Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 52 
described in section 3.2.3.4.   53 
 Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate 54 
and decode the test frame. 55 
 56 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  57 
 58 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       195 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 1 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 2 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 3 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 4 
3. The signal relation between antenna ports or TAB connectors under test should match the expected result for 5 
Tx Diversity transmission as specified in 3GPP TS 36.141 Section 4.5.1.1. 6 
 7 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class With Precoding (WPR) SM 8 
A. Test Description and Applicability 9 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 10 
 11 
The purpose of this test is to validate the correct implementation of TM3/4 Spatial Multiplexing transmission mode 12 
for a Category B O-RU with two antenna ports.  For TM3/4 Spatial Multiplexing, information for 2 layers are 13 
packed into a PRB for transmission from O-DU and are unpacked at the O-RU, subsequently TM3/4 based 14 
precoding is applied based on the C Plane configuration before over the air transmission.  15 
 16 
Using a standard E-TM1.1 test frame for FDD the CUSM-E (i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER described in section 17 
3.2.2) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on the downlink the standard 18 
E-TM1.1 signal.   19 
 20 
This test is applicable for  Category B radios only. 21 
 22 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 23 
 24 
 The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1 of this document.  The test bandwidth is 20 25 
MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 26 
 The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 27 
 The O-RU must support the Section Extension ExtType=3 parameter as notified by the M-Plane 28 
 The O-RU must have at least two conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be connected to a signal 29 
analyzer. 30 
 The TER with connections to the O-RU must be calibrated. 31 
 32 
C. Test Methodology 33 
 34 
a. Initial Conditions 35 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 36 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.   37 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors under test and configure the 38 
analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted signal.  39 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  40 
 41 
b. Procedure 42 
 Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the E-TM1.1 signal described above in the CUSM-E.   43 
 Use the CUSM-E control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal.  44 
 Every symbol should be described by a single section (DL-SCH and DCI) using section type 1 messages. 45 
No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 46 
 The test configures two antenna ports.  Therefore, two beamIDs are needed.  The same beamID is used for 47 
user data and CRS REs.   48 
o For Antenna Port 0, the beamId is contained in the C-Plane data section header, while the 49 
Antenna Ports 1 (“beamIdAP1”) is contained in the ExtType=3   50 
 Configure following parameters in the Section Extension ExtType=3 as defined in CUS Plane Specification 51 
[2].  52 
o codebookIndex - indices of the precoder codebook that are used for precoding 53 
o layerID (Layer ID for DL transmission) - layer ID that are used for DL transmission 54 
o txScheme (transmission scheme) – set to Spatial multiplexing (no CDD) 55

o numLayers (number of layers used for DL transmission) – set to 0001 (implies 2) 1 
o crsReMask (CRS resource element mask)  2 
o crsSymlNum (CRS symbol number indication) 3 
o crsShift (crsShift used for DL transmission) 4

 Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 6 
described in section 3.2.3.4.   7

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Section Type 3 (ST3) 20 
This section will specify the test scenarios to validate the correct decoding of C-Plane messages with section type 3. 21 
The required test setup is shown in 2.1, where only a stimulus RF signal is applied. 22 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class ST3 Test #1: NR PRACH 23 
A. Test Description and Applicability {MANDATORY} 24 
This test is MANDATORY. 25 
This test will validate the correct decoding of C-Plane messages containing section type 3 in 5G NR scenario by 26 
testing the correct detection of a PRACH signal.  27 
TER will setup the signal generator with a PRACH test waveform according to TS 38.141-1 section 8.4.1 and A.6. 28 
The test waveform will contain the same preamble ID repeated by following the timing offset scheme specified in 29 
the figures 8.4.1.4.2-2 or 8.4.1.4.2-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected PRACH format. 30 
This is an example for FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3, at each occasion the time offset of the 31 
same preamble index (selected according to table A.6-1 TS 38.141.1) is incremented by 100nsec starting from 0 up 32 
to 800nsec (9 occasions per frame). Each PRACH occasion is at the beginning of the first nine used sub-frames. 33 
The scheme is repeated every frame. 34 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       197 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
 2 
Figure 3.2.3.8-1 FR1 SCS 30Kz 100MHz Format A3 3 
 4 
According to the PRACH waveform setting, the TER will generate a corresponding sequence of C-Plane messages 5 
with section type 3. By the corresponding U-Plane messages in the uplink direction, the TER will try to detect the 6 
presence of the corresponding preamble at the expected timing offset and calculate the probability of detection Pd 7 
according to the definition in TS38.141-1 section 8.4.1.1.  8 
The signal will be exercised at only one O-RU port without adding any external AWGN power level or multipath 9 
fading profile and at a power level avoiding detection errors due to poor SNR (rule described in the sub-section C 10 
of this scenario class). 11 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 12 
O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (FR1) or TAB connector. 13 
By the M-plane, TER will detect all the supported SCSs, FFT sizes and carrier bandwidths by the O-RU. To test 14 
the correct interpretation of section type 3, it is assumed that only one combination of the three above parameters 15 
supported by the O-RU is enough to validate the test. TER shall generate C-Plane messages according to one of the 16 
PRACH formats in table A.6-1 TS 38.141. TER will choose the format either according to the manufacturer 17 
declaration item D.103 “PRACH format and SCS” in TS 38.141-1 or according to the format information obtained 18 
by the M-plane in case O-RU implements this feature. If more formats are claimed, only one shall be selected to 19 
reduce the test time, preference will be given to a format specified in Table A.6.1 TS 38.141. It is assumed that the 20 
O-RU manufacturer will support at least one in that table. For the case of long preambles, it is assumed format 0 is 21 
always supported since the only one shown in the table A.6-1 TS 38.141.  22 
C. Test Methodology 23 
a. Initial Conditions 24 
The O-RU is synchronized using G.8275.1. The signal generator is connected to the antenna port under test and 25 
synchronized to the same frequency reference of the O-RU. CUSM-E has completed the activation of one carrier on 26 
the O-RU port and enabled one endpoint supporting section type 3. The endpoint is configured with no data 27 
compression.  28 
b. Procedure 29 
1. Set signal generator power by the following method: 30 
d. Select SNR from the scenario with two RX antennas and AWGN propagation condition in table 8.4.1.5-31 
1, 8.4.1.5-2 or 8.4.1.5-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected SCS and PRACH format. 32 
e. Select the AWGN power level according to the configured SCS and channel bandwidth in table 33 
8.4.1.4.2-1 TS 38.141-1and38.141-1and multiply by the PRACH signal bandwidth.  34 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       198 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
f. The output power will be given by the formula (SNR+Noise power – 3dB) rounded to the first decimal 1 
digit. Extra 3dB are to compensate that SNR and noise power are selected from the two RX ports test 2 
case and this test procedure requires only one O-RU port. 3 
 4 
For example, for the FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3 SNR is -13.5dB and noise level 5 
is -70.1dBm/98.28MHz. signal generator power = -13.5dB -70.1dBm/98.28MHz*(139*30 KHz)-3dB 6 
=-19.5dBm.  7 
2. Set signal generator frequency offset to the central carrier frequency. PRACH will be mapped over frequency 8 
according to msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter equal to 0. PRACH format is set according to what TER 9 
has selected from the manufacturer declarations. 10 
3. Start PRACH waveform generation on the signal generator. 11 
4. Configure CUSM-E to generate C-Plane section type 3 messages according to the PRACH occasions 12 
described in subsection A and by the following approach: 13 
a. In case of a PRACH format not including preamble repetitions, only one C-Plane message with one 14 
section ID is generated per PRACH occasion. O-DU emulator will set “cpLength” field according to 15 
table 6.3.3.1-2 or table 6.3.3.1-1 TS 38.211 and to the format specified in section 5.4.4.14 in [2] 16 
“timeOffset” field will be set according to the PRACH occasion position inside the slot and by 17 
following the format value specified section 5.4.4.12 CUS plane specification.  18 
b. In case of a PRACH format with preamble repetitions, the implementation can be achieved by one C-19 
Plane message with one section ID or by N number of C-Plane messages with one section ID 20 
corresponding to the single PRACH repetition as described in section 5.3.2 CUS plane specification. 21 
TER shall exercise both approaches and perform them in two separate test sessions by repeating steps 4 22 
and 5. 23 
c. In both scenarios “filterIndex” field is setup based on the PRACH format and according to table 5.9 24 
of [2]and “beamId” field will set to 0 (no beamforming). 25 
5. TER will perform PRACH detection per each PRACH occasion and compare the result with the expected 26 
preamble ID and the expected timing offset. Since the external AWGN and fading generator are not present the 27 
time error tolerance should be low, TER will use the time error tolerance in table 8.4.1.1-1 for AWGN case 28 
according to the corresponding PRACH format and PRACH SCS. A counter of successful detections is 29 
incremented at every matching. The probability of detection is given by the ratio between that counter and the 30 
number of the expected received PRACH occasions within the test time. 31 
6. Repeat the test procedure by setting msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter to the right edge of the 32 
configured carrier bandwidth in order to exercise a different frequency offset number in section type 3. 33 
D. Pass/Fail Criteria (expected result) 34 
1. Test is pass if the probability of detection is 100%. 35 
 36 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class ST3 Test #2: LTE PRACH 37 
A. Test Description and Applicability  38 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 39 
This test will validate the correct decoding of C-Plane messages containing section type 3 in LTE scenario by 40 
testing the correct detection of a PRACH signal.  41 
TER will setup the signal generator with a PRACH test waveform according to TS 36.141 section 8.4.1 and A.6. 42 
The test waveform will contain the same preamble ID repeated by the timing offset scheme specified in the figure 43 
8.4.1.4.2-2 and section 8.4.1.4.2 TS 36.141. 44 
According to the PRACH waveform setting, TER will generate a corresponding sequence of C-Plane messages with 45 
section type 3. By the corresponding U-Plane messages in the uplink direction, TER will try to detect the presence 46 
startRAn
startRAn

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       199 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
of the corresponding preamble at the expected timing offset and calculate the probability of detection Pd according 1 
to the definition in TS36.141 section 8.4.1.1.  2 
The signal will be exercised at only one O-RU port without adding any external AWGN power level or multipath 3 
fading profile and at a power level avoiding detection errors due to poor SNR (rule described in the sub-section C of 4 
this scenario class). 5 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 6 
O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (FR1) or TAB connector. 7 
By the M-plane, TER will detect all the supported SCSs, FFT sizes and carrier bandwidths by the O-RU. To test the 8 
correct interpretation of section type 3, it is assumed that only one combination of the three above parameters 9 
supported by the O-RU is enough to validate the test. TER will choose the PRACH format according to the 10 
manufacturer declarations or according to the format information obtained by the M-plane in case O-RU implements 11 
this feature. If more formats are claimed, only one shall be selected to reduce the test time.  12 
C.   Test Methodology 13 
a. Initial Conditions 14 
O-RU is synchronized using G.8275.1. signal generator is connected to the antenna port under test and 15 
synchronized to the same frequency reference of the O-RU. CUSM-E has completed the activation of one carrier 16 
on the O-RU port and enabled one endpoint supporting section type 3. The endpoint is configured with no data 17 
compression.  18 
b. Procedure 19 
1. Set signal generator power by the following method: 20 
a. Select SNR from the scenario with two RX antennas and AWGN propagation condition in table 8.4.1.5-21 
1 TS 36.141 depending on the selected PRACH format. 22 
b. Select the AWGN power level according to the configured channel bandwidth in table 8.4.1.4.2-1 TS 23 
36.141 and multiply by the PRACH signal bandwidth.  24 
c. The output power will be given by the formula (SNR+Noise power – 3dB) rounded to the first decimal 25 
digit. Extra 3dB are to compensate that SNR and noise power are selected from the two RX ports test 26 
case and this test procedure requires only one O-RU port. 27 
For example, for the LTE 20MHz – Format 0 SNR is -13.9dB and noise level is -77.4dBm/18MHz. signal 28 
generator power = -13.9dB -77.4dBm/18MHz*(839*1.25kHz)-3dB =-21.5dBm.  29 
2. Set signal generator frequency offset to the central carrier frequency. PRACH will be mapped over frequency 30 
according to prach-FrequencyOffset (RAoffset PRBn ) parameter equal to 0. PRACH format is set according to what 31 
TER has selected from the manufacturer declarations. 32 
3. Start PRACH waveform generation on the signal generator. 33 
4. Configure CUSM-E to generate C-Plane section type 3 messages according to the PRACH occasions 34 
described in subsection A and by the following approach: 35 
a. In case of a PRACH format not including preamble repetitions, only one C-Plane message with one 36 
section ID is generated per PRACH occasion. O-DU emulator will set “cpLength” field according to table 37 
6.3.3.1-2 or table 6.3.3.1-1 TS 38.211 and to the format specified in section 5.4.4.14 in [2].  The 38 
timeOffset” field will be set according to the PRACH occasion position inside the slot and by following 39 
the format value specified section 5.4.4.12 in [2].  40 
b. In case of a PRACH format with preamble repetitions, the implementation can be achieved by one C-41 
Plane message with one section ID or by N number of C-Plane messages with one section ID 42 
corresponding to the single PRACH repetition as described in section 5.3.2 in [2].  TER shall exercise 43 
both approaches and perform them in two separate test sessions by repeating steps 4 and 5 44 
c. In both scenarios “filterIndex” field is setup based on the PRACH format and according to table 5.9 of [2] 45 
and “beamId” field will set to 0 (no beamforming). 46 
5. The TER will perform PRACH detection per each PRACH occasion and compare the result with the expected 47 
preamble ID and the expected timing offset. Since the external AWGN and fading generator are not present, the 48 
time error tolerance should be low.  The TER will use the time error tolerance defined in section 8.4.1.1 TS 49 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       200 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
36.141 for AWGN (1.04usec).  On the TER, a counter is incremented for each successful preamble detection. 1 
The probability of detection is given by the ratio between that counter and the number of the expected received 2 
PRACH occasions within the test time. 3 
6. Repeat the test procedure by setting RAoffset PRBn  parameter of PRACH to the right edge of the configured carrier 4 
bandwidth in order to exercise a different frequency offset number in section type 3. 5 
D.  Pass/Fail Criteria (expected result) 6 
1. Test is pass if the probability of detection is 100%. 7 
 8 
3.2.4 FR1 FDD Non-conducted OTA Signal Tests 9 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class NR testing Generic (NRG) 10 
The generic tests for FR1 FDD Non-conducted OTA are the same as the tests described in section 3.2.3 FR1 FDD 11 
Conducted-Signal Tests.  Only the setup for the tests are different reflecting the difference between non-conductive and 12 
conductive mode testing.  13 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming (BFM)  14 
This section describes the beamforming conformance testing for ORAN fronthaul interface. The tests do not aim to test 15 
the O-RU beamforming performance or capabilities but to test that the O-RU under test focuses the RF energy or 16 
sensitivity into a specific direction and with a specific granularity following the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface 17 
of the TER described in section 2.1) C-Plane messages.  18 
Unless stated otherwise in a test case, the following statements apply to all the test cases defined in this section: 19 
 It is based on Over-the-Air (OTA) testing with a setup such as described in Section 2.1 and it may be applied to 20 
any O-RU DUTs, whether the O-RU DUTs have conducted antenna ports or TAB connectors or not. 21 
 22 
 It applies to  Category A and  Category B O-RU DUTs. 23 
 24 
 It applies to LTE and/or 5G New Radio O-RU DUTs.  In both cases, precoding is not required in any test case.   25 
 26 
 If O-RU DUT supports Analog Beamforming (i.e. time domain beamforming), all the U-Plane test frames are 27 
defined by segmenting the Stock Test A: 1 section per symbol.  The definition of this Stock Test A can be 28 
found in Figure 3.2.1.1-2 and the description accompanying this figure.  Each slot shall include multiple 29 
sections (one per symbol within the slot) and only one beam at a time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore 30 
only one beam can be tested per slot. 31 
 32 
 If O-RU DUT supports Digital Beamforming (i.e. frequency domain beamforming), all the U-Plane test frames 33 
are defined by segmenting the Stock Test B: 2 sections per symbol definition as shown in Figure 3.2.1.1-2.  34 
Each slot shall include multiple sections (two per symbol within the slot) and only one beam per section at a 35 
time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore up to two different beams can be tested per slot. 36 
 37 
 If O-RU DUT supports multiple polarizations, it is up to the TER to determine if the testing is carried out for 38 
each polarization separately or multiple polarizations at the same time. In any case, it is important to guarantee 39 
that the correct eAxC_ID for the correct polarization (or polarizations) is exercised.  40 
 41 
 For O-RU DUT that support LTE:  42 
o Downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP E-TM1.1 test frame for FDD (Section 6.1.1.1 TS 36.141) with 43 
20MHz bandwidth (100 RB) as shown in Figure 3.2.4.2-1. 44 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       201 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
Figure 3.2.4.2-1 E-TM1.1 FDD 20 MHz 100RB 2 
If 20MHz is not supported by the O-RU DUT, then it will use the highest bandwidth supported by the O-3 
RU DUT. 4 
o Uplink test will use a standard 3GPP UL FRC Configuration definition for FDD (TS36.521-1) and power 5 
levels at least 30dB above Reference Sensitivity power level with 20MHz bandwidth (100 RB) as shown 6 
in Figure 3.2.4.2-2. 7 
 8 Figure 3.2.4.2-2 UL FRC FDD 20 MHz 100 RB 9 
If 20MHz is not supported by the O-RU DUT, then it will use the highest bandwidth supported by the O-10 
RU DUT. 11 
 12 
 For O-RU DUT that support 5G NR:  13 
o Downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 test frame for FDD in [19] (Section 4.9.2 14 
TS138.141-1) of the Conducted Transmitter Characteristic Test section (Section 6 TS138.141-1) as 15 
described in section 3.2.1.1. The test numerology will be preferably 30KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 16 
MHz Bandwidth. If not supported, then it will use any other supported subcarrier spacing and the 17 
highest bandwidth of the O-RU DUT. 18 
  19 
o Uplink tests will use a standard 3GPP G-FR1-A1-5 Reference Sensitivity level definition (Section 7.2 20 
and Annex A TS138.141-1) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 21 
38.141) and power levels at least 30dB above Reference Sensitivity power level as described in section 22 
3.2.1.1.  The test numerology will be preferably 30kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth, if 23 
supported. Otherwise, it will use any available subcarrier space and the highest bandwidth supported 24 
by the O-RU DUT. 25 
  26 
 Radiated tests coordinate system is based on the coordinate system defined in section 10.5.1. of  [2]. 27 
 28 
 The O-RU DUT must: 29 
o support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.2 of this document. 30 
o have installed current release of shipping software.  31 
o be fully calibrated up to Radiated Interface Boundary (RIB). It is expected to be calibrated by O-RU 32 
vendor prior to testing.  33 
 34 
 35 
 The TER must: 36 
o be capable of carrying out any signal processing required to generate and demodulate 3GPP compliant 37 
waveforms. 38 
o be able to calculate or extract the beam direction via OTA measurements. 39 
o be able to generate and deliver signals with the required beam direction at the RIB point.  40 
o be fully calibrated up to the interface where it interacts with the DUT’s RIB. For that, a known test signal 41 
might be either injected by the TER into the O-RU DUT, or internally generated by the O-RU DUT, and 42 
the O-RU DUT must not apply any digital or analog beam direction to the known test signal.  One possible 43 
method to perform calibration uses injected C-Plane and U-Plane signals from TER into the O-RU and 44 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       202 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
using C-Plane messages with beamID=0. Alternatively, calibration methods for radiated test setups that are 1 
described in 3GPP TR37.941 can be used. 2 
 3 
 4 
 The O-DU emulator of the TER must: 5 
o be capable of generating and sending U-Plane messages containing 3GPP test frames following the 6 
corresponding Stock sectioning defined above, as well as be capable of capturing U-Plane messages and 7 
extracting 3GPP test frames (i.e. IQ data) from the captured U-Plane messages. 8 
o be capable of generating the C-Plane messages for, receiving, extracting and demodulating the 3GPP test 9 
frames following the corresponding Stock sectioning defined above. 10 
 11 
 The TER might have a single test antenna if a single beam direction and polarization is measured at a time, or 12 
multiple test antennas if multiple beam directions and/or polarizations are measured at the same time. 13 
 14 
 It is up to the TER on how to extract the beam direction and beam properties at the DUT’s RIB in 15 
order to match it with the manufacturer’s declaration. 16 
 17 
 The user payload will be generated as PN23 with a seed of all ones. 18 
 19 
 It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections: 20 
 Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 21 
 Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 22 
 Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 23 
 Section 10 for beamforming guidelines. 24 
 Annex J for beamforming methods description.  25 
 26 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – No Beamforming 27 
B. Test Description and Applicability 28 
This test is MANDATORY. 29 
 30 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 31 
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 32 
 33 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 34 
 Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of beam directions when O-RU DUT is operating with no 35 
beamforming.  36 
 37 
C. Test Methodology 38 
 39 
a. Initial Conditions 40 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 41 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  42 
 Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  43 
 Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and configure 44 
the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted 45 
signal. 46 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 47 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 48 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  49 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  50 
 51 
b. Procedure 52 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 53 
emulator.   54 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 55 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-SCH 56 
and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 57 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       203 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 1 
windows described in section 3.2.1.1.2.   2 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 3 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 4 
e. Measure any metric/s that allows for extracting the transmitted beam direction from a single measurement, 5 
i.e. transform-based techniques, or take as many measurements of any metric/s from multiple angles, by 6 
for example rotating the O-RU, that allows for extracting beam direction from multiple measurement, i.e. 7 
beam scanning. 8 
 9 
 10 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  11 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer at the expected transmitted beam direction should satisfy a basic 12 
3GPP signal performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 13 
2. The test frame received at the expected transmitted beam direction by the signal analyzer should be the same as 14 
the signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 15 
3. The extracted beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were measured (i.e. best EVM, 16 
power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction for the expected no beamforming within a 17 
tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  18 
 19 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – No Beamforming 20 
A. Test Description and Applicability 21 
This test is MANDATORY. 22 
 23 
 24 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 25 
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 26 
 27 
 28 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 29 
 Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of beam directions when O-RU DUT is operating with no 30 
beamforming.  31 
 32 
C. Test Methodology 33 
 34 
a. Initial Conditions 35 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 36 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  37 
 Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  38 
 Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and configure 39 
the signal source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test signal. 40 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 41 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 42 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  43 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  44 
 45 
b. Procedure 46 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  47 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial beam direction. This initial beam 48 
direction could be the boresight direction of the receiver antenna array. 49 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 50 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-51 
SCH) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 52 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.2 while 53 
also triggering the signal source.   54 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 55 
plane messages to the O-DU. 56 
f. Allow the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload and to measure and extract any required 57 
metric/s from the received signal that will be used later to determine what is the best received direction. 58 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       204 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
g. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different beam direction when injecting the test signal 1 
into the O-RU. Repeating the process for a number of different beam directions will exercise the reception 2 
of the test signal from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing 3 
the sensitivity to the correct beam direction. 4 
 5 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  6 
1. The test frame received at the expected beam direction by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal 7 
described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 8 
2. The extracted beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were measured (i.e. best EVM, 9 
power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction for the expected no beamforming within a 10 
tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  11 
 12 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam 13 
Beamforming 14 
A. Test Description and Applicability 15 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 16 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with predefined-beams 17 
beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 18 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each indexed beam required in this measurement, see below. The 19 
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction is defined 20 
by extracting the beam direction. 21 
 22 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 23 
 24 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam Beamforming conformance test 25 
might include multiple test that the O-RU must comply: 26 
a. “Coarse” beamIds test:  27 
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that are defined as coarse granularity (coarse beamIds) to the O-DU 28 
emulator, the test should include the following beams: 29 
1. A beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 30 
2. A beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 31 
3. A beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 32 
4. A beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 33 
5. A beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 34 
 35 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured. 36 
 37 
 38 
 39 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 40 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of beam indices and their associated beam directions with antenna array 41 
characteristics. 42 
 43 
C. Test Methodology 44 
 45 
a. Initial Conditions 46 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 47 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  48 
 Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  49 
 Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and configure 50 
the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted 51 
signal. 52 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 53 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 54 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  55 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       205 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  1 
   2 
b. Procedure 3 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 4 
emulator.   5 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 6 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-7 
SCH and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this 8 
test. 9 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 10 
windows described in section 3.2.1.1.2.   11 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 12 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 13 
e. Measure any metric/s that allows for extracting the transmitted beam direction from a single 14 
measurement, i.e. transform-based techniques, or take as many measurements of any metric/s from 15 
multiple angles, by for example rotating the O-RU, that allows for extracting beam direction from 16 
multiple measurement, i.e. beam scanning. 17 
 18 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  19 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer at the expected transmitted beam direction should satisfy a basic 20 
3GPP signal performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 21 
2. The test frame received at the expected transmitted beam direction by the signal analyzer should be the same as 22 
the signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 23 
3. The extracted beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were measured (i.e. best EVM, 24 
power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction for the beam under test within a tolerance 25 
defined by the manufacturer.  26

 32

beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  34 
 35 
The same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 1.1.1.1.3 applies, but 36 
instead it is related to the uplink direction.  37

characteristics. 42

a. Initial Conditions 46

coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  54 
Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range 55 
b. Procedure 56 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  57 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       206 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial beam direction. This initial beam 1 
direction could be the boresight direction of the receiver antenna array. 2 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 3 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-4 
SCH) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 5

plane messages to the O-DU. 9

metric/s from the received signal that will be used later to determine what is the best received direction. 11 
g. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different beam direction when injecting the test signal 12 
into the O-RU. Repeating the process for a number of different beam directions will exercise the reception 13 
of the test signal from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing 14 
the sensitivity to the correct beam direction. 15
