 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic 24 
Beamforming 25 
A. Test Description and Applicability 26 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 27 
 28 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with weight-based dynamic 29 
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  30 
 31 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each weighted beam required in this measurement, see below. The 32 
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction is defined 33 
by extracting the beam direction. 34 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 35 
 36 
 37 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic Beamforming conformance 38 
test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 39 
a. A weight-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 40 
b. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 41 
(θ). 42 
c. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 43 
(θ). 44 
d. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 45 
(θ). 46 
e. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 47 
(θ). 48 
 49 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured. 50 
 51 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight—based Dynamic Beamforming 52 
conformance test should also evaluate the following compression methods for each of the supported beams 53 
described above (a. to e.) for the O-RU to comply: 54 
a. No compression method applied to the beamforming weights.  55 
b. Block floating point compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit mantissa. 56 
c. Block scaling compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit scaler. 57 
d. μ-law compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit fixed width. 58 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       207 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
e.  Depending on what type of Beamspace compression the DUT supports, either  Beamspace compression 1 
method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit scaler. or Beamspace compression method applied to 2 
the beamforming weights with 14-bit mantissa. 3 
 4 
If the O-RU does not support all the compression methods described above, fewer than 5 compression methods will 5 
be measured. 6 
 7 
 8 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 9 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of frequency domain (ϕ) and/or time domain (θ) weights and their associated beam 10 
directions with antenna array characteristics 11 
 12 
C. Test Methodology 13 
 14 
a. Initial Conditions 15 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 16 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 17 
 Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  18 
 Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and configure 19 
the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted 20 
signal. 21 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 22 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 23 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  24 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   25 
 26 
b. Procedure 27 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 28 
emulator.   29 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 30 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (DL-SCH and DCI) 31 
using section type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension 32 
extType=0x01 to convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 1 33 
since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 34 
should be 0x0. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 35 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 36 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   37 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 38 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 39 
e. Measure any metric/s that allows for extracting the transmitted beam direction from a single measurement, 40 
i.e. transform-based techniques, or take as many measurements of any metric/s from multiple angles, by for 41 
example rotating the O-RU, that allows for extracting beam direction from multiple measurement, i.e. beam 42 
scanning. 43 
 44 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  45 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer at the expected transmitted beam direction should satisfy a basic 46 
3GPP signal performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 47 
2. The test frame received at the expected transmitted beam direction by the signal analyzer should be the same as 48 
the signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 49 
3. The extracted beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were measured (i.e. best EVM, 50 
power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction for the beam under test within a tolerance 51 
defined by the manufacturer.  52 
 53

Beamforming 55 
A. Test Description and Applicability 56 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 57

                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with weight-based beamforming 1 
and with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  2 
 3 
The same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.5 but applies to 4 
the uplink direction.  5

directions with antenna array characteristics. 9

 12 
a. Initial Conditions 13 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 14 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  15

direction could be the boresight direction of the receiver antenna array. 28 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 29 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (UL-SCH) using section 30 
type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension extType=0x01 to 31

beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0. No 33 
section type zero messages will be used for this test. 34 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.2 while also 35 
triggering the signal source.   36 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 37 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 38 
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different beam direction when injecting the test signal 39 
into the O-RU. Repeating the process for a number of different beam directions will exercise the reception 40 
of the test signal from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the 41 
sensitivity to the correct beam direction. 42 
 43

1. The test frame received at the expected beam direction by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal 45 
described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 46 
2. The extracted beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were measured (i.e. best EVM, 47 
power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction for the beam under test within a tolerance 48 
defined by the manufacturer.  49

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Attribute-based Dynamic 52 
Beamforming 53 
A. Test Description and Applicability 54 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 55 
 56 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       209 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with attributed-based dynamic 1 
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  2 
 3 
If the O-RU DUT supports Attribute based Dynamic Beamforming, this test is mandatory for the O-RU DUT to be 4 
O-RAN conformant.   5 
The transmitted beam direction and attributes are measured for each attributed beam required in this measurement, 6 
see below. The measured transmitted direction and attributes, i.e. pointing azimuth and elevation angles, 7 
beamwidths and sidelobe suppression, is compared to manufacturer-designated direction and attributes. 8 
Transmitted direction and beam attributes are defined extracting the beam properties. 9 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in Section 10.4.1.1 of [2]. 10 
 11 
 12 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Attribute-based Dynamic Beamforming 13 
conformance test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 14 
a. An attribute-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles with any beamwidth and sidelobe 15 
suppression supported by the O-RU under this beam direction. 16 
b. An attribute-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 17 
(θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction. 18 
c. An attribute-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 19 
(θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction. 20 
d. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 21 
(θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction. 22 
e. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 23 
(θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction. 24 
 25 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles and attribute 26 
configurations will be measured. 27 
 28 
 29 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 30 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of supported beam attributes that are supported by the O-RU and/or their 31 
associated beam directions with antenna array characteristics. 32 
 33 
C. Test Methodology 34 
 35 
a. Initial Conditions 36 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 37 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  38 
 Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  39 
 Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and configure 40 
the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted 41 
signal. 42 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 43 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 44 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  45 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   46 
 47 
b. Procedure 48 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 49 
emulator.   50 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 51 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (DL-SCH and DCI) 52 
using section type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension 53 
extType=0x02 to convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 2 54 
since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot.  If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 55 
should be 0x0. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 56 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 57 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   58 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       210 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 1 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 2 
e. Measure any metric/s that allows for extracting the transmitted beam attributes from a single measurement, 3 
i.e. transform-based techniques, or take as many measurements of any metric/s from multiple angles, by for 4 
example rotating the O-RU, that allows for extracting beam attributes from multiple measurement, i.e. 5 
beam scanning. 6 
 7 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  8 
1. The signal measured at the expected beam direction by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal 9 
performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 10 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 11 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 12 
3. The extracted beam attributes are referenced from the measured beam direction where the best metric/s were 13 
measured (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction and attributes for 14 
the beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  15 
 16 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Attribute-based Dynamic 17 
Beamforming 18 
A. Test Description and Applicability 19 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 20 
 21 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with attribute-based 22 
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 23 
 24 
Same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.7 but considering 25 
uplink direction.  26 
 27 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 28 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of supported beam attributes that are supported by the O-RU and/or their 29 
associated beam directions with antenna array characteristics. 30 
 31 
C. Test Methodology 32 
 33 
a. Initial Conditions 34 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 35 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 36 
 Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  37 
 Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and configure 38 
the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted 39 
signal. 40 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 41 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 42 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  43 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   44 
 45 
b. Procedure 46 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  47 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial beam direction. This initial beam 48 
direction could be the boresight direction of the receiver antenna array. 49 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 50 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (UL-SCH) using section 51 
type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension extType=0x02 to 52 
convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 2 since the same 53 
beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0. No 54 
section type zero messages will be used for this test. 55 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.12. while 56 
also triggering the signal source.   57 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       211 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 1 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 2 
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different beam direction when injecting the test signal 3 
into the O-RU. Repeating the process for a number of different beam directions will exercise the reception of 4 
the test signal from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the 5 
sensitivity to the correct beam direction with the correct beam attributes. 6 
 7 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  8 
1. The test frame received at the expected beam direction by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal 9 
described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 10 
2. The extracted beam attributes are referenced from the measured beam direction where the best metric/s were 11 
measured (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction and attributes for 12 
the beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  13 
 14 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based 15 
Beamforming 16 
A. Test Description and Applicability 17 
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 18 
 19 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with channel-information-based 20 
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU-MIMO). 21 
 22 
For Category A radios, the test is for each polarization separately and consequently either different or same channel 23 
models can be defined for each of the polarization. For Category B, same channel might be used for both 24 
polarizations and the test might measure each polarization separately. 25 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each scenario required in this measurement.  The measured 26 
transmitted direction is extracted from the decoded received signal in the TER. Transmitted direction is defined by 27 
properly receiving a data transmission between the O-RU and the target User Equipment while destroying or 28 
heavily attenuating the data transmission between the O-RU and the other User Equipment. 29 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based Beamforming 30 
conformance test should evaluate the following scenarios for the O-RU to comply and will rely on TER Channel 31 
Emulation capabilities as shown in Figure 3.2.4.2-3.  32 
 33 
 34 
 35 Figure 3.2.4.2-3 TER with Channel Emulation Capability antennas representing multiple UEs 36 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       212 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
b. A scenario where two spatial streams, or eAxC flows, are generated for two users (one layer each) with M 2 
antennas ports or TAB connectors. The O-DU will report to the O-RU via C plane messages an channel 3 
estimate 𝐻 ≜  [ℎଵଵ, . . . , ℎଵெ, ℎଶଵ, . . . , ℎଶெ] ∈ ℂଶ௫ெ, which is the effective channel as seen by the antennas 4 
representing the multiple UEs, which are spaced sufficiently such that the O-RU can effectively equalize out 5 
the interference between the users.. The O-RU will calculate and apply the beamweight matrix 𝐺 ≜6 
 [𝑔ଵଵ, . . . ,𝑔ଵெ,𝑔ଶଵ, . . . ,𝑔ଶெ] ∈ ℂெ௫ଶ in such that the received signal at the users is the same as the generated in the 7 
O-DU. It is up to the O-RU on how to calculate the beamforming weights, for example Zero-forcing, 8 
regularized zero-forcing / MMSE, etc.   9 
 10 
If O-RU supports Analog Beamforming (Time Domain Beamforming), the test should not apply any analog 11 
beamforming or time domain beamforming. In this case, M is not the number of antennas ports or TAB connectors 12 
but the number of TRX channels supported by the O-RU. 13 
 14 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 15 
 16 
 The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with radiating antennas. 17 
 The TER equipment must include 2 antennas with sufficient separation to emulate the 2 users such that the O-18 
RU can equalize out the mutual interference of the users due to the effective MU-MIMO channel. 19 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antennas are connected to each TRX chain.  20 
 21 
C. Test Methodology 22 
 23 
a. Initial Conditions 24 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 25 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  26 
 Ensure that the test antennas and TER equipment are calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  27 
 Place the test antennas within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 with sufficient separation for 28 
effective MU-MIMO beamforming and configure the analyzer ports with any setup information needed to 29 
synch and demodulate the MU-MIMO transmitted signal 30 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 31 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 32 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  33 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   34 
 35 
b. Procedure 36 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 37 
emulator, with the data symbols for user 1 and user 2 fully overlapping in time and frequency, but with user 38 
data initialized using different seeds for the PN23 sequence.  .   39 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 40 
and the scenario under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-SCH and 41 
DCI) using section type 5 and 6 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 42 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 43 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1. 44 
d. Capture the test signals and pass them through a channel emulator or apply the signal processing required 45 
to emulate the channel under test using the 2 test antennas.   46 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 47 
demodulate and decode the test frames for the 2 users. 48 
 49 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  50 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer for each of the expected UE – layer - should satisfy a basic 3GPP 51 
signal performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 52 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer for each of the expected UE – layer - should be the same as the 53 
signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 54 
 55 
 56 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       213 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Channel-Information-based 1 
Beamforming 2 
A. Test Description and Applicability 3 
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 4 
 5 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with channel-information-based 6 
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU-MIMO).  7 
 8 
Same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.10 but considering 9 
the uplink direction.  10 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 11 
 12 
 The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with radiating sensing antennas. 13 
 The TER equipment must include 2 antennas with sufficient separation to emulate the 2 users such that the O-14 
RU can equalize out the mutual interference of the users due to the effective MU-MIMO channel. 15 
 The TER equipment must have at least two probe transmitting antennas to radiate the test signals to the O-RU. 16 
 The TER equipment must either include a channel emulator between the signal generator and the probe 17 
transmitting antennas or the signal generator be capable of applying the required channel matrix being 18 
emulated between the users and the O-RU.  19 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antennas are connected to each TRX chain.  20 
 21 
C. Test Methodology 22 
 23 
a. Initial Conditions 24 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 25 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  26 
 Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  27 
 Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 with sufficient 28 
separation for effective MU-MIMO beamforming and configure the generator with any set-up information 29 
needed to transmit the signals from the 2 UEs. 30 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 31 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 32 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  33 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  34 
  35 
b. Procedure 36 
a. Build an appropriate test signals for each of the 2 users as described above in the signal sources of the TER 37 
using a different seed to initialize the PN23 data for each user. 38 
b. Inject the test signals through a channel emulator or apply the required signal processing to emulate the 39 
channel under test.  40 
c. Radiate the resulting test signals over the air into the antennas of the O-RU. 41 
d. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 42 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-SCH) using 43 
section type 5 and 6. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 44 
e. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 2.4. while also 45 
triggering the signal source.   46 
f. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 47 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload for each of 48 
the users. 49 
 50 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  51 
The test frame received by the TER/O-DU for each of the expected User – layer - should be the same as the signal 52 
described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 53 
 54

This test is  CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 10 
  11 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame using the default parameters in 12 
section 3.2.1.1.1 of this document except for only one spatial stream on one antenna will be used.   13 
 14 
This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios (No precoding is required).   15 
As per E-TM1.1 all user data in this test will be zeros.  The test will be conducted.   16 
 17

MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 20 
 The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 21 
 22

signal. 30

coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  33

 Use the CUSM-E control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal. 1

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP DL – Resource Allocation 16 
The test description, execution and pass criteria is the same as described in section 3.2.3.7.2. The only difference is that 17 
the test setup is as described in 3.2.1.1.2 with a single signal analyzer setup as described above in Figure 3.2.4.7-1. 18 
A. Test Description and Applicability 19 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 20 
 21 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can accurately interpret C-Plane resource allocation messages, 22 
transfer U-Plane data into the correct resource blocks and transmit this data accurately in the downlink.   23 
 24 
This test requires non-zero data to populate all allocated resource blocks.  This data will be a PN23 sequence with a 25 
seed value of all ones. 26 
 27 
This test is applicable for both Category A and Category B radios.  28 
 29 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 30 
 The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1 of this document.  The test bandwidth is 20 31 
MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 32 
 The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 33 
 34 
C. Test Methodology 35 
 36 
a. Initial Conditions 37 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 38 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.   39 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  40 
 Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  41 
 Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and configure 42 
the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted 43 
signal. 44 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 45 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 46 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  47 
 48 
b. Procedure 49 
 Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the E-TM1.1 signal described above in the CUSM-E.  50 
 Use the CUSM-E control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal. Every 51 
symbol should be described by a single section (DL-SCH and DCI) using section type 1 messages.  52 
 The data in the sections must be a PN23 sequence using an initial seed of all ones.  53 
 No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  54

Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       217 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 1 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal 2 
analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame. 3 
 4 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  5 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 6 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 7 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above.  It contains 8 
all the same PRB assignments and data the test passes. 9 
 10 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP UL – Resource Allocation 11 
The test description, execution and pass criteria is the same as described in section 3.2.3.7.3.  The only difference is that 12 
the test setup is as described in section 3.2.1.1.2 Non-conducted OTA FDD tests for FR1 radios with a single signal 13 
analyzer setup as described above in Figure 3.2.4.7-1. 14 
A. Test Description and Applicability 15 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 16 
 17 
The purpose of this test is to validate correct uplink operation of the O-RU using 3GPP Reference Sensitivity level 18 
definition (Section 7.2 TS 36.141) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 36.104) and 19 
power levels at least 30 dB above Reference Sensitivity power Level described in E-TM1.1.  This is to improve the 20 
likelihood that all data will be received by the radio correctly since we are not interested in testing receiver 21 
sensitivity but only the O-RAN protocol compliance.  22 
 23 
Under those conditions, 3GPP compliant O-RU should deliver uplink U-Plane information that matches with the 24 
uplink signal.  25 
 26 
The TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) generates an uplink signal on the signal generator which is then transmitted over 27 
the air via the test antenna, together with the corresponding C-Plane messages on the Fronthaul interface. The TER 28 
will capture the U-Plane messages generated by the DUT and validate if the payload matches with the uplink 29 
signal.  30 
 31 
This test is applicable for both  Category A and  Category B radios. 32 
 33 
It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections 34 
 Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 35 
 Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 36 
 Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 37 
 38 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 39 
 40 
 The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1 of this document.  The test bandwidth is 20 41 
MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 42 
 The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 43 
 44 
C. Test Methodology 45 
 46 
a. Initial Conditions 47 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 48 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.   49 
 Configure the source to transmit the required 3GPP test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from the 50 
CUSM-ECUSM-E.  The signal source power level should be adjusted to setting used in the 3GPP receiver 51 
sensitivity test. 52 
 Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  53 
 Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and 54 
configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 55 
transmitted signal. 56 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 57 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       218 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 1 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  2 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  3 
 4 
b.  Procedure 5 
 Load uplink test waveform (A1-1) on the RF Signal Source. Number of allocated RB is 6 as in A1-1 and 6 
the data content is a PN23 sequence. 7 
 Configure Signal Source to play test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it receives a 8 
trigger signal from the CUSM-E that C-Plane messages have been sent. 9 
 Load C-Plane message sequence on Test Equipment O-RU (TER)  10 
 Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul messages  11 
 Launch test to simultaneously play RF uplink frame and C-Plane messages  12 
 Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the Antenna 13 
port  14 
 Extract IQ information  15 
 Extract Payload 16 
 Compare payload binary sequences  17 
 18 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  19 
a. The verdict is “Test pass” if payload binary sequences match between the uplink test frame sent to the 20 
DUT and the received U-Plane data from the DUT 21 
b. If any of the test conditions is not true, the verdict for the whole test is "Fail" 22 
c. If the DUT does not support initial conditions, the test verdict is "Inconclusive" 23 
 24 
 25 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended using reMask parameter 3GPP DL – 26 
Resource allocation 27 
The test description, execution and pass criteria is the same as described in section 3.2.3.7.4.  The only difference is that 28 
the test setup is as described in section 3.2.1.1.2 Non-conducted OTA FDD tests for FR1 radios with a single signal 29 
analyzer setup as described above in Figure 3.2.4.7-1. 30 
A. Test Description and Applicability 31 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 32 
 33 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can accurately interpret C-Plane resource allocation messages with 34 
the reMask parameter set, transfer U-Plane data into the correct resource elements and transmit this data accurately 35 
in the downlink.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios (No precoding is required).  The test 36 
will be conducted therefore there will be no channel distortion or interference.  It is mandatory the radio pass this 37 
test to be considered O-RAN conformant. 38 
 39 
This test requires non-zero data to populate all allocated resource blocks.  This data will be a PN23 sequence with a 40 
seed value of all ones.  This test is applicable for both  Category A and  Category B radios.  41 
 42 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 43 
 44 
 The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1 of this document.  The test bandwidth is 20 45 
MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 46 
 The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 47 
 48 
C. Test Methodology 49 
 50 
a. Initial Conditions 51 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 52 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.   53 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors under test and configure the 54 
analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted signal.  55 
 Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  56 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       219 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and 1 
configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 2 
transmitted signal. 3 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 4 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the 5 
declared coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  6 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  7 
 8 
b. Procedure 9 
 Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the E-TM1.1 signal described above in the CUSM-E.   10 
 Use the CUSM-E control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal.  11 
 Every symbol should be described by a single type 1 section (DL-SCH and DCI) except symbols#6 12 
which will be used for the reMask test. 13 
 The data in this section must be a PN23 sequence using an initial seed of all ones. The first bits of the 14 
PN23 will be in PRB1 and continue in consecutive resource elements to the end of PRB5. No section 15 
type zero messages will be used for this test. 16 
 Symbol number #6 should be stock data section type “D” as shown above.   17 
 This test will only be using PRBs 1 through 5.  The corresponding C-Plane message will contain a 18 
section IDs in a single C-Plane message describing symbol #6.  19 
 The startSymbolId in the application header will be symbol #6.  20 
 The C-Plane message will have one section with the reMask set to only the odd number resource 21 
elements.  The number of PRBs will be 4. The start PRB will be 1. 22 
 The corresponding U-Plane message will be a new PN23 Sequence (initial seed is all ones) in PRBs 1 23 
through 5 of symbol #6. 24 
 25 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  26 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 27 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 28 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should only contain the same PN23 signals that were sent in the 29 
U-Plane but only every other odd resource element. 30 
 31 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class With Precoding (WPR) TxD 32 
The test description, execution and pass criteria is the same as described in section 3.2.3.7.5.  The only difference is that 33 
the test setup is as described in section 3.2.1.1.2 Non-conducted OTA FDD tests for FR1 radios with two signal 34 
analyzers setup as described above in Figure 3.2.4.7-2. 35 
A. Test Description and Applicability 36 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 37 
 38 
The purpose of this test is to validate the correct implementation of transmit diversity of a Category B O-RU with 39 
two antennas.  TxD uses TM2 (transmission Mode 2).  For TxD, information for 2 layers are packed into a PRB for 40 
transmission from O-DU and are unpacked at the O-RU.  TxD precoding is applied based on the C Plane 41 
configuration before RF transmission.  42 
 43 
Using a standard E-TM1.1 test frame for FDD the CUSM-E (i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER described in section 44 
3.2.2) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on the downlink the standard 45 
E-TM1.1 signal.   46 
 47 
This test is applicable for Category B radios only. 48 
 49 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 50 
 51 
 The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1 of this document.  The test bandwidth is 20 52 
MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 53 
 The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with radiating antennas. 54 
 The TER equipment must include 2 antennas with sufficient separation. The TER equipment must have at least 55 
two probe receiving antennas to receive each individual layer. 56 
 The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 57 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       220 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 The O-RU must support the Section Extension ExtType=3 parameter as notified by the M-Plane 1 
 2 
C. Test Methodology 3 
 4 
a. Initial Conditions 5 
 6 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 7 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.   8 
 Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  9 
 Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and configure 10 
the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted 11 
signal. 12 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 13 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 14 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  15 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  16 
 17 
b. Procedure 18 
 19 
 Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the E-TM1.1 signal described above in the CUSM-E.  the data 20 
content is a PN23 sequences starting with an initial seed of ones.   21 
 Use the CUSM-E control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal.  22 
 Every symbol should be described by a single section (DL-SCH and DCI) using section type 1 messages. 23 
No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 24 
 The test configures two antenna ports hence two beamIDs needed (same beamID for user data and CRS 25 
REs).  For Antenna Port 0, the beamId is contained in the C-Plane data section header, while the Antenna 26 
Ports 1 (“beamIdAP1”) is contained in the ExtType=3 .  27 
 Configure different eAxCs are used for each layer 28 
 Configure following parameters in the Section Extension ExtType=3   29 
o codebookIndex - ‘00000000’ (invalid) 30 
o layerID (Layer ID for DL transmission) - layer ID that are used for DL transmission 31 
o txScheme (transmission scheme) - ’txD’ 32 
o numLayers (number of layers used for DL transmission) - 0001 (implies 2) 33 
o crsReMask (CRS resource element mask)  34 
o crsSymlNum (CRS symbol number indication) 35 
o crsShift (crsShift used for DL transmission) 36 
 Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 37 
described in section 3.2.3.4.   38 
 Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate 39 
and decode the test frame. 40 
 41 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  42 
 43 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 44 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 45 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 46 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 47 
3. The signal relation between received signal analyzer or channels of the signal analyzer should match the 48 
expected result for Tx Diversity transmission as specified in 3GPP TS 36.141 Section 4.5.1.1. 49 
 50 
 51 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class With Precoding (WPR) SM 52 
The test description, execution and pass criteria is the same as described in section 3.2.3.7.6. The only difference is that 53 
the test setup is as described in section 3.2.1.1.2 Non-conducted OTA FDD tests for FR1 radios with two signal 54 
analyzers setup as described above in Figure 3.2.4.7-2. 55 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       221 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
A. Test Description and Applicability 1 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 2 
 3 
The purpose of this test is to validate the correct implementation of TM3/4 Spatial Multiplexing transmission mode 4 
for a Category B O-RU with two antennas.  For TM3/4 Spatial Multiplexing, information for 2 layers are packed 5 
into a PRB for transmission from O-DU and are unpacked at the O-RU, subsequently TM3/4 based precoding is 6 
applied based on the C Plane configuration before over the air transmission.  7 
 8 
Using a standard E-TM1.1 test frame for FDD the CUSM-E (i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER described in section 9 
3.2.2) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on the downlink the standard 10 
E-TM1.1 signal.   11 
 12 
This test is applicable for Category B radios only. 13 
 14 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 15 
 16 
 The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1 of this document.  The test bandwidth is 20 17 
MHz Bandwidth as described by E-TM1.1. 18 
 The signal analyzer must have the ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 19 
 The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with radiating antennas. 20 
 The TER equipment must include 2 antennas with sufficient separation. The TER equipment must have at least 21 
two probe receiving antennas to receive each individual layer. 22 
 The TER with connections to the O-RU must be calibrated. 23 
 24 
C. Test Methodology 25 
 26 
a. Initial Conditions 27 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 28 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.   29 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU TAB connectors under test and configure the analyzer with any 30 
set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted signal.  31 
 Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  32 
 Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2 and configure 33 
the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted signal. 34 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2. 35 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 36 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.2.  37 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  38 
 39 
b. Procedure 40 
 Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the E-TM1.1 signal described above in the CUSM-E.  .  The data 41 
content is a PN23 sequences starting with an initial seed of ones.   42 
 The codeword -to-layer mapping follows table 6.3.3.2-1 of TS 36.211 with one codeword to two layer 43 
mapping, but does not restrict to use two codeword to two layer mapping.   44 
 Use the CUSM-E control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal.  45 
 Every symbol should be described by a single section (DL-SCH and DCI) using section type 1 messages. 46 
No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 47 
 The test configures two antenna ports.  Therefore, two beamIDs are needed.  The same beamID is used for 48 
user data and CRS REs.   49 
o For Antenna Port 0, the beamId is contained in the C-Plane data section header, while the 50 
Antenna Ports 1 (“beamIdAP1”) is contained in the ExtType=3   51 
 Configure following parameters in the Section Extension ExtType=3 as defined in CUS Plane Specification 52 
[2].  53 
o codebookIndex - indices of the precoder codebook that are used for precoding 54 
o layerID (Layer ID for DL transmission) - layer ID that are used for DL transmission 55 
o txScheme (transmission scheme) – set to Spatial multiplexing (no CDD) 56 
o numLayers (number of layers used for DL transmission) – set to 0001 (implies 2) 57

Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       222 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
o crsReMask (CRS resource element mask)  1 
o crsSymlNum (CRS symbol number indication) 2 
o crsShift (crsShift used for DL transmission) 3 
 4 
 Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 5 
described in section 3.2.3.4.   6 
 Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate 7 
and decode the test frame. 8 
 9 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  10 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 11 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 12 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 13 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23. 14 
3. The signal relation between the two signal analyzers or two channels of the signal analyzer should match the 15 
expected result for MIMO transmission as specified in 3GPP TS 36.141 Section 4.5.1.1. 16

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Section Type 3 (ST3) 20 
The Section Type 3 tests for FR1 FDD Non-conducted OTA are the same as the tests described in section 3.2.3.8 .  21 
Only the setup for the tests are different reflecting the difference between non-conductive and conductive mode testing.  22

Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.

3.2.5 FR1 TDD Conducted Signal Tests 1 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class NR testing Generic (NRG)  2 
All TDD tests described in this section will be combined UL and DL tests (i.e., a single test frame describing 3 
bothuplink anddownlink). The default test frame used in this section is described in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document. 4 
There are several variations on this test signal depending on the capabilities of the radio.  If the radio does not support 5 
the numerology used in the example tests as reported in the M-plane it will be up to the test developer to modify their 6 
tests to adapt to the radio.  This can usually be accomplished by using stock test patterns described above.  The test is 7 
expected to follow the same spirit as the tests in this document but things like symbol numbers, number of PRBs, etc. 8 
may have to be changed. 9 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Base 3GPP DL/UL 10 
A. Test Description and Applicability 11 
This test is MANDATORY. 12 
 13 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can meet the most basic uplink and downlink requirements for O-14 
RAN fronthaul using a TDD signal.  Subsequent tests will build on this to exercise additional capabilities of the 15 
Fronthaul. 16 
 17 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the 18 
TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on 19 
thedownlink and uplink the default signal.   20 
 21 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit and receive  a basic 3GPP, TDD test frame using the 22 
default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.5 of this document (or a similar 3GPP waveform) except only one spatial 23 
stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios (No precoding is 24 
required).  As per section 3.2.1.1.3 this test requires all-zero data to populate all allocated resource blocks.  This 25 
configuration corresponds to stock data section A in all symbols that do not contain PDCCH channels. 26 
 27 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 28 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document.  The test numerology will be 29 
30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described by TM-FR1-TM1.1 in downlink direction and 30 
G-FR1-A1-5 (SCS30k_51RB) in the uplink direction. If the O-RU does not support this bandwidth another 3GPP 31 
FRC can be selected. In the test frame, all PDSCH data is set to all zeros and PUSCH is set to all zeros.  It will be 32 
for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. 33 
 34 
The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (or TAB connector) to be connected to a signal analyzer and signal 35 
source.  It must also support the default parameters defined in section 3.2.1.1.3 above. 36 
 37 
C. Test Methodology 38 
a. Initial Conditions 39 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 40 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer and 41 
signal source to the O-RU antenna ports and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to 42 
allow it to synch and demodulate the transmitted signal.   43 
b. Procedure 44 
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the signal described above in section 3.2.1.1.3 in the CUSM 45 
emulator.  Built the appropriate test frame (uplink slots) for the signal source. Use the CUSM emulator 46 
control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal. Every symbol other 47 
than the ones used in the test should either be allocated with user data or left unallocated (empty). If 48 
allocated with user data, they be described by either a single or multiple sections (DL-SCH that are used for 49 
the test, DMRS and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for 50 
this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages for downlink slots only. Play those messages to the 51 
O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.3.  Repeat the entire frame the number of 52 
times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame.  It will be 53 
the responsibility of the TER’s signal analyzer and source to coordinate downlink and uplink TDD 54 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       224 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of the TER is responsible for receiving uplink U-Plane messages, 1 
extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which can be compared to those sent by the signal source. 2 
 3 
 4 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  5 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 6 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 7 
2. The test frame received in downlink direction by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described 8 
above.  If it contains all the same PRB assignments and all zero data, the test passes. 9 
3. The test frame received in uplink direction by the TER should be the same as the signal described above.  If it 10 
contains all the same PRB assignments and PN23 sequence data, the test passes. 11 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP DL/UL – Resource Allocation 12 
A. Test Description and Applicability 13 
This test is MANDATORY. 14 
 15 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can meet the extended uplink and downlink requirements for O-RAN 16 
fronthaul using a TDD signal.  This test modifies the previous test by using a PN23 sequence in all test PDSCH 17 
sections. 18 
 19 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the 20 
TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on 21 
thedownlink and uplink the default signal.   22 
 23 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit and receive  an extended 3GPP TDD test frame using 24 
the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document (or a similar 3GPP waveform) except only one spatial 25 
stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios (No precoding 26 
is required).  All downlink user data in this test will be a PN23 sequence and all uplink user data will also be a 27 
PN23 sequence. 28 
 29 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 30 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document.  The test numerology will be 31 
30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described by TM-FR1-TM1.1.  It will be for 5G New 32 
Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. 33 
 34 
The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (or TAB connector) to be connected to a signal analyzer and signal 35 
source.  It must also support the default parameters defined in section 3.2.1.1.1 above. 36 
 37 
C. Test Methodology 38 
a. Initial Conditions 39 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 40 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the 41 
O-RU antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 42 
demodulate the transmitted signal.   43 
b. Procedure 44 
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the signal described above in section 3.2.1.1.3 in the CUSM 45 
emulator. In this case use a PN23 sequence for the downlink shared channel.  Build the appropriate test 46 
frame (uplink slots) for the signal source. Use the CUSM emulator control interface to build the appropriate 47 
C-Plane messages that describe the uplink and downlink signals. Every symbol used in the test should be 48 
described by a single section (DL-SCH that are used for the test, DMRS and DCI) using section type 1 49 
messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane 50 
messages for downlink slots only. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described 51 
in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and 52 
allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame.  It will be the responsibility of the TER’s signal analyzer 53 
and source to coordinate downlink and uplink TDD transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of the TER is 54 
responsible for receiving uplink U-Plane messages, extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which can be 55 
compared to those sent by the signal source. 56 
 57 
 58 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       225 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  1 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 2 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 3 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above.  If it contains 4 
all the same PRB assignments and PN23 sequence data, the test passes. 5 
 6 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended using RB parameter 3GPP DL/UL – 7 
Resource Allocation 8 
A. Test Description and Applicability 9 
This test is MANDATORY. 10 
 11 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can accurately interpret C-Plane resource allocation messages with 12 
the rb parameter set, transfer U-Plane data into the correct resource blocks and transmit this data accurately in the 13 
downlink and interpret and capture the correct resource blocks in the uplink with the rb parameter set.    This test 14 
uses a PN23 sequence in all test PDSCH sections. 15 
 16 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the 17 
TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on 18 
thedownlink and uplink the specified signal using the rb bit in both uplink and downlink.   19 
 20 
Only one spatial stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios 21 
(No precoding is required).  All downlink user data in this test will be a PN23 sequence and all uplink user data 22 
will also be a PN23 sequence. 23 
 24 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 25 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document.  The test numerology will be 26 
30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section 3.2.1.1.3.  It will be for 5G New 27 
Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. 28 
 29 
The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (or TAB connector) to be connected to a signal analyzer.  It must 30 
also support the default parameters defined in section 3.2.1.1.1 above. 31 
 32 
C. Test Methodology 33 
a. Initial Conditions 34 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 35 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the 36 
O-RU antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 37 
demodulate the transmitted signal.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna port and configure it as 38 
described below. 39 
b.  Procedure 40 
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the signal described above in section 3.2.1.1.3 in the CUSM 41 
emulator. In this case use a PN23 sequence for the downlink shared channel.  Build the appropriate test 42 
frame (uplink slots) for the signal source. Use the CUSM emulator control interface to build the appropriate 43 
C-Plane messages that describe the uplink and downlink signals. Every symbol used in the test should be 44 
described by a single section (DL-SCH that are used for the test, DMRS and DCI) using section type 1 45 
messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane 46 
messages for downlink slots only. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described 47 
in section 3.2.1.1.3.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and 48 
allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame.  It will be the responsibility of the TER’s signal analyzer 49 
and source to coordinate downlink and uplink TDD transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of the TER is 50 
responsible for receiving uplink U-Plane messages, extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which can be 51 
compared to those sent by the signal source. 52 
 53 
For the downlink slots and symbols:  54 
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU emulator.  55 
Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal.  56 
If symbols other than the ones under test are allocated with user data, every allocated (see below) symbol 57

should be described by sections (DL-SCH and DCI) using section type 1 messages.  No section type zero 1 
messages will be used for this test.  Symbol #3 of each slot should be Stock data section “D”  as shown in 2 
section 3.2.1.1.5 above. The control plane for symbol #3 will only include PRBs number 5 through 23. C-3 
Plane messages will have the rb bit set to one for this section. All other DL-SCH symbols and PRBs other 4 
than PRBs 5-23 will not contain data.  There are two ways to conduct the test: 5 
1. A single data section with the rb bit set and a PN23 sequence sent as shown below: 6 
 7 
 8 
A new PN23 sequence will be started but every other PRB will contain only the odd parts of the PN23 9 
sequence (as shown in green).  The other PRBs (shown in orange) will not contain data and will not be sent to 10 
the O-RU.  Thus, a single data section will be used, and the corresponding U-Plane message will only contain 11 
data for the odd PRBs as shown above.  The parts of the PN23 sequence not used (shown marked with an X) 12 
will be discarded. 13 
2. Two data sections one containing the odd parts of the PN23 sequence and the other containing the even 14 
parts as shown below: 15 
 16

Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       227

 1 
A new PN23 sequence will be started but every other PRB in one section will contain only the odd parts of 2 
the PN23 sequence (as shown in green).  The second data section will contain the even parts of the PN23 3 
sequence.  The C-Plane messages for both sections will use the rb bit. The U-Plane messages 4 
corresponding to the first data section will contain only the odd parts of the PN23 sequence, the U-Plane 5 
message corresponding to the second data section will only contain the even parts.  Thus, a continuous 6 
PN23 sequence will be sent only in PRBs 5 through 23. 7 
Additional sections should be included to describe the DCI symbols as well as Reference Signals described 8 
in 38.141-1 as well as if DL-SCH is allocated for all the symbols other than the one under test (Symbol #3 9 
Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the 10 
entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and 11 
decode the test frame.  12 
 13 
 For the uplink sections and symbols: Load uplink test waveform (G-FR1-A1-5 : 14 
SCS30k_51RB) on the RF Signal Source.  Note this signal has a PN23 sequence as user data.  15 
Configure the Signal Source to play the  TDD test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting 16 
when it receives a trigger signal from the O-DU emulator that all C-Plane messages have been 17 
sent.  Ensure the O-RU and source are synchronized so downlink slots do not conflict with uplink 18 
slots. Load C-Plane message sequence on Test Equipment O-RU (TER) – In this test only symbol 19 
number 6 will be used and all 51 PRBs will be used.  Symbol number 6 will be a guard symbol in 20 
the flexible slot if the TDD configuration according to table 3.2.1.1 is used, so only 2 uplink slots 21 
per frame are possible. If needed, another symbol than symbol number 6 can be selected.  All 22 
other symbols may either contain user data or may be left unallocated except for required DRMS 23 
signals which may be used to synchronize test equipment. There are two options for conducting 24 
this test: 25 
1. A single data section with the rb bit set and a PN23 sequence sent as shown below: 26

 1 
A new PN23 sequence will be started but every other PRB will contain only the odd parts of 2 
the PN23 sequence (as shown in orange).  The other PRBs (shown in  blue and white) may 3 
either have allocated user data and will be sent to the O-RU or may be left unallocated and 4 
will not be sent to the O-RU.  A single data section will be used for symbol #6, and the 5 
corresponding U-Plane message will only contain data for the odd PRBs as shown above.  6
