the PN23 sequence (as shown in green).  The second data section will contain the even parts of the PN23 3 
sequence.  The C-Plane messages for both sections will use the rb bit. The U-Plane messages 4 
corresponding to the first data section will contain only the odd parts of the PN23 sequence, the U-Plane 5 
message corresponding to the second data section will only contain the even parts.  Thus, a continuous 6 
PN23 sequence will be sent only in PRBs 0 through 51 7 
 8 
 9 
Steps: 10 
 Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  11 
 Launch test to play the C-Plane messages and the downlink U-Plane messages and trigger the 12 
source to play the RF signal on a frame boundary.  13 
 Play messages to the O-RU respecting the timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat 14 
the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 15 
demodulate and decode the frame. 16 
 Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the 17 
Antenna port  18 
 Extract IQ information from the captured U-Plane messages 19 
 Extract IQ information from the signal analyzer for downlink slots 20 
 Extract Payload for both signals 21 
 Compare payload binary sequences  22 
 23 
 24 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       230 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  1 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 2 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 3 
2. The signal extracted by the U-Plane messages (uplink) should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance 4 
requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 5 
3. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above.  If it contains 6 
all the same PRB assignments andPN23 sequence data, the downlink test passes. 7 
4. The test frame extracted from the uplink U-Plane messages should be the same as the uplink signal described 8 
above.  If it contains all the same PRB assignments and PN23 sequence data, the uplink test passes. 9 
 10 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended using SymInc parameter 3GPP DL/UL – 11 
Resource Allocation 12 
A. Test Description and Applicability 13 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 14 
 15 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can accurately interpret C-Plane resource allocation messages with 16 
the SymInc parameter set, transfer U-Plane data into the correct resource blocks and transmit this data accurately in 17 
the downlink and interpret and capture the correct resource blocks in the uplink with the SymInc parameter set.    18 
This test uses a PN23 sequence in all test PDSCH sections. 19 
 20 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the 21 
TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on 22 
thedownlink and uplink the specified signal using the SymInc bit in both uplink and downlink.   23 
 24 
Only one spatial stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios 25 
(No precoding is required).  All downlink user data in this test will be a PN23 sequence and all uplink user data 26 
will also be a PN23 sequence. 27 
 28 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 29 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document.  The test numerology will be 30 
30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section 3.2.1.1.3.  It will be for 5G New Radio 31 
only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. 32 
 33 
The radio must support the SymInc Parameter as notified by the M-Plane.  The Signal Analyzer must have the 34 
ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 35 
 36 
 37 
C. Test Methodology 38 
a. Initial Conditions 39 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 40 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the 41 
O-RU antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 42 
demodulate the transmitted signal.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna port and configure it as 43 
described below. 44 
b. Procedure 45 
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the signal described above in section 3.2.1.1.3 in the CUSM 46 
emulator. In this case use a PN23 sequence for the downlink shared channel.  Build the appropriate test 47 
frame (uplink slots) for the signal source. Use the CUSM emulator control interface to build the appropriate 48 
C-Plane messages that describe the uplink and downlink signals. Every symbol other than the ones used in 49 
the test should either be allocated with user data or left unallocated (empty). If allocated with user data, 50 
they may be described by either a single or multiple sections (DL-SCH that are used for the test, DMRS 51 
and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  52 
Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages for downlink slots only. Play those messages to the O-RU 53 
respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.3.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times 54 
required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame.  It will be the 55 
responsibility of the TER’s signal analyzer and source to coordinate downlink and uplink TDD 56 
transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of the TER is responsible for receiving uplink U-Plane messages, 57 
extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which can be compared to those sent by the signal source. 58 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       231 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
 2 
For the downlink slots and symbols: If the symbols other than the ones under test (symbols #5 and #6) 3 
have user data allocated, these Every symbols should be described by a single or multiple type 1 section 4 
(DL-SCH and DCI) except symbols #5 and #6 which will be used for the SymInc test. The data in these 5 
sections must be a PN23 sequence using an initial seed of all ones. Each symbol should be a new PN23 6 
sequence, that is PRB 0 should contain the data from a new PN23 sequence for each symbol. Symbols 7 
number 5 and 6 should be stock data sections type “E” as shown above.  This stock data section consists of 8 
two adjacent symbols each containing two sections.  The corresponding C-Plane message will contain 4 9 
section IDs in a single C-Plane message describing symbols #5 and #6.  The startSymbolId in the 10 
application header will be symbol #5. The third section ID for symbol #6 will have the SymInc bit set 11 
informing the O-RU that this section will begin describing symbol #6. The corresponding U-Plane 12 
messages will be a new PN23 Sequence for each symbol (5 and 6). Additional sections should be included 13 
to describe the DCI symbols as well as Reference Signals described in 38.141-1.  14 
 15 
For the uplink sections and symbols: Load uplink test waveform (G-FR1-A1-5 : SCS30k_51RB, 100 16 
MHz) on the RF Signal Source.  Note this signal has a PN23 sequence as user data.  Configure the source 17 
to generate a new PN23 sequence in symbols #5 and #6.  Configure the Signal Source to play test 18 
waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it receives a trigger signal from the O-DU emulator 19 
that all C-Plane messages have been sent.  Ensure the O-RU and source are synchronized so downlink slots 20 
do not conflict with uplink slots.  Load C-Plane message sequence on Test Equipment O-RU (TER) – Only 21 
symbols #5 and #6 in each slot will be used in this test. Symbol number 6 will be a guard symbol in the 22 
flexible slot if the TDD configuration according to table 3.2.1.1 is used, so only 2 uplink slots per frame are 23 
possible. If needed, another symbol than symbol number 6 can be selected.  All other symbols will might 24 
either contain either reference signals only or data and reference signals but will not be considered part of 25 
the test.  These two symbols will be used to determine whether the radio properly increments the current 26 
symbol ID when the SymInc bit is set. The C-Plane message for symbol #6 should have the SymInc bit set.  27 
This message should have a third section describing symbol #6 (using the SymInc mechanism).  All PRBs 28 
in each symbol will be requested (In the example waveform 51 PRBs). 29 
 30 
Steps: 31 
 Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  32 
 Launch test to play the C-Plane messages and the downlink U-Plane messages and trigger the 33 
source to play the RF signal on a frame boundary.  34 
 Play messages to the O-RU respecting the timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat 35 
the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 36 
demodulate and decode the frame. 37 
 Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the 38 
Antenna port  39 
 Extract IQ information from the captured U-Plane messages 40 
 Extract IQ information from the signal analyzer for downlink slots 41 
 Extract Payload for both signals 42 
 Compare payload binary sequences  43 
 44 
 45 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  46 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 47 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 48 
2. The signal extracted by the U-Plane messages (uplink) should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance 49 
requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 50 
3. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above.  If it contains 51 
all the same PRB assignments and the correct PN23 data, the downlink test passes. 52 
4. The test frame extracted from the uplink U-Plane messages should be the same as the uplink signal described 53 
above.  If it contains all the same PRB assignments and correct PN23 data, the uplink test passes. 54 
 55

Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       232

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended using reMask parameter 3GPP DL/UL – 1 
Resource Allocation 2 
A. Test Description and Applicability 3 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 4 
 5 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can accurately interpret C-Plane resource allocation messages with 6 
the reMask parameter set, transfer U-Plane data into the correct resource blocks and transmit this data accurately in 7 
the downlink and interpret and capture the correct resource blocks in the uplink with the reMask parameter set.    8 
This test uses a PN23 sequence in all test PDSCH sections. 9 
 10 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the 11 
TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on 12 
thedownlink and uplink the specified signal using the reMask bit in both uplink and downlink.   13 
 14 
Only one spatial stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios 15 
(No precoding is required).  All downlink user data in this test will be a PN23 sequence and all uplink user data 16 
will also be a PN23 sequence. 17 
 18 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 19 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document.  The test numerology will be 20 
30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section 3.2.1.1.3.  It will be for 5G New Radio 21 
only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. 22 
 23 
The radio must support the reMask Parameter as notified by the M-Plane.  The Signal Analyzer must have the 24 
ability to decode the downlink shared channel. 25 
 26 
C. Test Methodology 27 
a. Initial Conditions 28 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 29 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the 30 
O-RU antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 31 
demodulate the transmitted signal.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna port and configure it as 32 
described below. 33 
b. Procedure 34 
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the signal described above in section 3.2.1.1.3 in the CUSM 35 
emulator and modified as described below. In this case use a PN23 sequence for the downlink shared 36 
channel.  Build the appropriate test frame (uplink slots) as described below for the signal source. Use the 37 
CUSM emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the uplink and 38 
downlink signals. Every symbol other than the ones used in the test should either be allocated with user 39 
data or left unallocated (empty). If allocated with user data, they will be described by either a single or 40 
multiple sections (DL-SCH that are used for the test, DMRS and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No 41 
section type zero messages will be used for this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages for 42 
downlink slots only. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 43 
3.2.1.1.3.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 44 
demodulate and decode the test frame.  It will be the responsibility of the TER’s signal analyzer and source 45 
to coordinate downlink and uplink TDD transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of the TER is responsible for 46 
receiving uplink U-Plane messages, extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which can be compared to those 47 
sent by the signal source. 48 
 49 
For the downlink slots and symbols:  50 
Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 51 
signal as described below. If the symbols other than the ones under test (symbol #2) have user data 52 
allocated, these Every symbols should be described by a single or multiple type 1 sections (DL-SCH 53 
and DCI).   Only symbol #2 will be used for the reMask test. The data in this section must be a PN23 54 
sequence using an initial seed of all ones. The first bits of the PN23 will be in PRB1 and continue in 55 
consecutive resource elements to the end of PRB5. No section type zero messages will be used for this 56 
test.  The PN23 sequence will be interleaved with DMRS signals as shown below: 57 
 58

Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V.

 1  2 
Symbol number 2 should be stock data section type “D” as shown above.  This test will only be using 3 
PRBs 1 through 5.  The corresponding C-Plane message will contain two section IDs in a single C-4 
Plane message describing symbol #2.  The startSymbolId in the application header will be symbol #2. 5 
The C-Plane message will have one section with the reMask set to 101010101010b and another section 6 
with the reMask set to all ones.  The first section (reMask = 101010101010b) will be for PRB 1 only, 7 
the second section will be for PRBs 2-5 and will have an reMask value of all ones.  The two sections 8 
will have different section IDs. 9 
 10 
The corresponding U-Plane messages will be a new PN23 Sequence (initial seed is all ones) in PRBs 1 11 
through 5 of symbol #2 alternated with the DMRS signals.  The first U-Plane message will correspond 12 
to sectionID with reMask set to 101010101010b and will contain one PRB with user data and DMRS 13 
signals as shown.  The second U-Plane message will correspond to PRBs 2-5 and will containing the 14 
same alternate data. The purpose of the section ID containing valid data is to ensure the radio sends a 15 
signal to synchronize the signal analyzer. 16 
 17 
 18

be left unallocated (unused).  However other symbols containing reference signals may be used to ensure 22 
the O-RU can synchronize with the TER.    The format of symbol #2 used in this test will be: 23 
 24 
 25  26 
The TER will not request any other symbols from the O-RU in this test unless they are needed by the 27 
TER for synchronization.  The C-Plane message describing symbol #2 should contain two sections with 28 
different section IDs.  Only PRBs 1-5 will be used.  The first section should only describe PRB 1 and 29

have an reMask of 101010101010b.  The second section should describe PRBs 2-5 and have an reMask 1 
of all ones.  The two sections should have different section IDs. 2

Steps: 5 
 Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  6 
 Launch test to play the C-Plane messages and the downlink U-Plane messages and trigger the 7

D. Test Requirement (expected result)  21 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 22 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 23 
2. The signal extracted by the U-Plane messages (uplink) should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance 24 
requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 25 
3. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should only contain the same PN23 signals that were sent in the 26 
U-Plane only for PRBs 2-5.  only DMRS signals should be in PRB1. 27 
4. The test frame extracted from the uplink U-Plane messages should be the same as the uplink signal described 28 
above.  In particular the U-Plane messages for PRBs 2-5 should contain user data as well as DMRS signals 29 
while PRB1 should only contain DMRS signals. 30

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended using Non-contiguous PRB Allocation 33 
Section Extension 3GPP DL/UL – Resource Allocation 34 
A. Test Description and Applicability 35 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 36 
 37 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can accurately interpret C-Plane resource allocation messages with 38 
section extension 6, transfer U-Plane data into the correct resource blocks and transmit this data accurately in the 39 
downlink and interpret and capture the correct resource blocks in the uplink with section extension 6.    This test 40 
uses a PN23 sequence in all test PDSCH sections. 41 
 42 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the 43 
TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on 44 
thedownlink and uplink the specified signal using section extension 6 in both uplink and downlink.   45 
 46 
In this test stock data section definition C will be used to exercise the non-contiguous RB allocation, all 273 PRBs 47 
(51 in the uplink slots)or the max number of PRBs per symbol for the highest numerology the radio supports will 48 
be used in this test. 49 
 50 
Only one spatial stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios 51 
(No precoding is required).  All downlink user data in this test will be a PN23 sequence and all uplink user data 52 
will also be a PN23 sequence. 53 
 54 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 55 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document.  The test numerology will be 56 
30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section 3.2.1.1.3.  It will be for 5G New Radio 57 
only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. 58 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       235 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
The radio must support section extension 6 as notified by the M-Plane.  The Signal Analyzer must have the ability 2 
to decode the downlink shared channel. 3 
 4 
C. Test Methodology 5 
a. Initial Conditions 6 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 7 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the 8 
O-RU antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 9 
demodulate the transmitted signal.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna port and configure it as 10 
described below. 11 
b. Procedure 12 
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the signal described above in section 3.2.1.1.3 in the CUSM 13 
emulator. In this case use a PN23 sequence for the downlink shared channel.  Build the appropriate test 14 
frame (uplink slots) for the signal source. Use the CUSM emulator control interface to build the appropriate 15 
C-Plane messages that describe the uplink and downlink signals. Every symbol other than the ones used in 16 
the test should either be allocated with user data or left unallocated (empty). If allocated with user data, 17 
they may be described by either a single or multiple sections  (DL-SCH that are used for the test, DMRS 18 
and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  19 
Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages for downlink slots only. Play those messages to the O-RU 20 
respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times 21 
required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame.  It will be the 22 
responsibility of the TER’s signal analyzer and source to coordinate downlink and uplink TDD 23 
transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of the TER is responsible for receiving uplink U-Plane messages, 24 
extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which can be compared to those sent by the signal source. 25 
 26 
 27 
For the downlink slots and symbols: Only symbols number 6 and 7 will be used in each slot.  Other 28 
symbols may be used in this test or be left unallocated (unused).  However other symbols containing 29 
reference signals may be used to ensure the O-RU can synchronize with the TER.  The starting PRB will be 30 
zero and number of PRBs will be chosen from one or more columns in Table 3.2.5.1-2 below.  The 31 
resource block group size will be 16 based on 3GPP 38.214 Table 5.1.2.2.1-1 as shown in Table 3.2.5.1-1 32 
below using configuration 2.   33

 37 
Using the calculations in the O-RAN fronthaul specification [2] section 5.4.7.6 for the test waveform 38 
described above, the ID of the last RBG will be 17, f(0) will be 16, f(n) will be 16 and f(lastRbgID) will be 39 
1 (17 total RBGs).  StartPrbc will be zero and numPrbc will be 273.  If the radio does not support this 40 
numerology the following table will apply.  The number of PRBs correspond to Table 3.2.5.1-2. 41

 2 
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU emulator.  3 
Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal. If 4 
the symbols other than the ones under test (symbol #6 and #7) have user data allocated, these symbols should 5 
be described by a single or multiple type 1 section (DL-SCH and DCI) except symbols 6 
#6 and #7 which will be used for the section extension 6 test. The data in symbol #6 should be a new PN23 7 
sequence starting in the first PRB and continuing to PRB 273 (RBG number 17).  Symbol #7 should be 8 
identical to symbol #6.  The rbgMask value should be set to 0000000000111111111111111101b and the 9 
symbolMask value should be set to 00000011000000b.  No section type zero messages will be used for this 10 
test. 11 
 12 
The O-DU emulator will build a U-Plane message containing the PN23 IQ data for the first 16 PRBs (RBG 0), 13 
this message will have the section ID used in the C-Plane message described above.  Another U-Plane message 14 
will be created using the same section ID but with the PN23 data for RBGs 2-17 in it.  The same U-Plane 15 
messages will be used for symbol #7. 16 
 17 
For the uplink sections and symbols: For this test symbols number 6 and 7 will be used in each slot.  The 18 
starting PRB will be zero and number of PRBs will be 51.  The resource block group size will be 8.  Using the 19 
calculations in the O-RAN fronthaul specification section 5.4.7.6 the ID of the last RBG will be 6, f(0) will be 8, 20 
f(n) will be 8 and f(lastRbgID) will be 3.   21 
Every symbol should be described by a single type 1 section (DL-SCH and DCI) except symbols #6 and #7 22 
which will be used for the section extension 6 test. Symbol number 6 will be a guard symbol in the flexible slot 23 
if the TDD configuration according to table 3.2.1.1 is used, so only 2 uplink slots per frame are possible. If 24 
needed, another symbol than symbol number 6 can be selected.  The data in symbol #6 is expected to be a new 25 
PN23 sequence starting in the first PRB and continuing to PRB 51 (RBG number 6).  Symbol #7 should be 26 
identical to symbol #6.  The rbgMask value should be set to 00000011000000b  and the symbolMask value 27 
should be set to 00000011000000b.  No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  If the radio only 28 
supports another numerology see the tables above in the downlink sections and symbols for appropriate 29 
modifications. 30 
 31 
Steps: 32 
 Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  33 
 Launch test to play the C-Plane messages and the downlink U-Plane messages and trigger the 34 
source to play the RF signal on a frame boundary.  35 
 Play messages to the O-RU respecting the timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat 36 
the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 37 
demodulate and decode the frame. 38 
 Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the 39 
Antenna port  40 
 Extract IQ information from the captured U-Plane messages 41 
 Extract IQ information from the signal analyzer for downlink slots 42 
 Extract Payload for both signals 43 
 Compare payload binary sequences  44 
 45 
 46 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       237 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  1 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 2 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 3 
2. The signal extracted by the U-Plane messages (uplink) should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance 4 
requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 5 
3. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above.  If it contains 6 
all the same PRB assignments and the correct PN23 sequence as data, the downlink test passes. 7 
4. The test frame extracted from the uplink U-Plane messages should be the same as the uplink signal described 8 
above.  If it contains all the same PRB assignments and the correct PN23 sequence as data, the uplink test 9 
passes. 10 
 11 
 12 
 13 
 UC- Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP DL/UL – Resource Allocation – 14 
Coupling C and U plane via time and frequency 15 
A. Test Description and Applicability 16 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 17 
 18 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can meet the extended uplink and downlink requirements for O-RAN 19 
fronthaul using a TDD signal.  This test uses time and frequency to couple C-Plane and U-Plane messages. 20 
 21 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the 22 
TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on 23 
thedownlink and uplink the default signal.   24 
 25 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit and receive  an extended 3GPP TDD test frame using 26 
the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document (or a similar 3GPP waveform) except only one spatial 27 
stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios (No precoding 28 
is required).  All downlink user data in this test will be a PN23 sequence and all uplink user data will also be a 29 
PN23 sequence. The radio must report over the M-Plane that it supports C and U plane coupling via time and 30 
frequency. 31 
 32 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 33 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document.  The test numerology will be 34 
30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described by TM-FR1-TM1.1.  It will be for 5G New 35 
Radio only. The radio must report over the M-Plane that it supports C and U plane coupling via time and 36 
frequency. 37 
 38 
The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (or TAB connector) to be connected to a signal analyzer and signal 39 
source.  It must also support the default parameters defined in section 3.2.1.1.1 above. 40 
 41 
C. Test Methodology 42 
a. Initial Conditions 43 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 44 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the 45 
O-RU antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 46 
demodulate the transmitted signal.   47 
b. Procedure 48 
Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the signal described above in section 3.2.1.1.3 in the CUSM 49 
emulator. In this case use a PN23 sequence for the downlink shared channel.  Build the appropriate test 50 
frame (uplink slots) for the signal source. Use the CUSM emulator control interface to build the appropriate 51 
C-Plane messages that describe the uplink and downlink signals. Every symbol used in the test should be 52 
described by a single section (DL-SCH that are used for the test, DMRS and DCI) using section type 1 53 
messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane 54 
messages for downlink slots only. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described 55 
in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and 56 
allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame.  It will be the responsibility of the TER’s signal analyzer 57 
and source to coordinate downlink and uplink TDD transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of the TER is 58 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       238 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
responsible for receiving uplink U-Plane messages, extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which can be 1 
compared to those sent by the signal source.  All section IDs in C-Plane messages and downlink U-Plane 2 
messages must be 4095. 3 
 4 
C-Plane and Downlink U-Plane messages sent by the TER will have valid values in the following fields: 5 
 EAxC ID 6 
 Datadirection bit  7 
 Frame ID, subframeID, slotID, startsymbolID, and NumSymbol 8 
 SectionID must have a value 4095 9 
 SymInc, rb reMask and section extension #6 are not used in this test 10 
 11 
It is the responsibility of the TER to properly arrange uplink U-Plane messages using only time and 12 
frequency resources. 13 
 14 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  15 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 16 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 17 
2. All received U-Plane messages must have section ID equal to 4095 18 
3. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above.  If it contains 19 
all the same PRB assignments and PN23 sequence data, the test passes. 20 
 21 
 UC- Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended 3GPP DL/UL – Coupling C and U plane via 22 
Time and Frequency and Section Description Priorities 23 
A. Test Description and Applicability 24 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 25 
 26 
The purpose of this test is to test whether the radio can implement coupling U and C plane via time and frequency 27 
and section description priorities requirements for O-RAN fronthaul using a TDD signal.  This test combines the 28 
FDD, uplink and downlink tests for these same features.  Note, there are two versions of this feature: coupling C 29 
and U plane messages via frequency and time and Section Description Priorities and coupling C and U plane 30 
messages via frequency and time and Section Description Priorities (optimized).  This test requires both tests to be 31 
performed if the radio supports both methods otherwise only one test is to be performed in the radio only supports 32 
one of these methods.  These methods are listed under test methodology below. 33 
 34 
Starting with the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface 35 
of the TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit 36 
on thedownlink and uplink the signals described below.   37 
 38 
Only one spatial stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios 39 
(No precoding is required).  All downlink user data in this test will be a PN23 sequence and all uplink user data 40 
will also be a PN23 sequence. 41 
 42 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 43 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document and those specified below.  44 
The test numerology will be 30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described by TM-FR1-45 
TM1.1.  It will be for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB 46 
connectors.  It will be a TDD signal. 47 
 48 
The O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (or TAB connector) to be connected to a signal analyzer and signal 49 
source.  It must also support the default parameters defined in section 3.2.1.1.1 above. 50 
 51 
C. Test Methodology 52 
a. Initial Conditions 53 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 54 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the 55 
O-RU antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 56 
demodulate the transmitted signal.   57 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       239 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
b. Procedure for Coupling C and U plane messages via frequency and time with section priorities 1 
Build an appropriate C and U plane signals for the signals described below in the CUSM emulator. Every 2 
slot used in the test should be described by a single C-Plane message with multiple sections (DL-SCH that 3 
are used for the test, DMRS and DCI) using a section type 1 message. No section type zero messages will 4 
be used for this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages for downlink slots only. Play those 5 
messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame 6 
the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test 7 
frame.  It will be the responsibility of the TER’s signal analyzer and source to coordinate downlink and 8 
uplink TDD transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of the TER is responsible for receiving uplink U-Plane 9 
messages, extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which can be compared to those sent by the signal source. 10 
 11

Table 3.2.5.1-3  Time and Frequency Coupling with Priority TDD DL 14 
 15 
In this test the section configuration will be as shown in Table 3.2.5.1-3above.  The 6 sections will comprise 16 
one slot and this slot will be repeated continuously in the downlink slots in the TDD frame to synchronize the 17 
TER signal analyzer.  The six sections will be sent on one C-Plane message using C and U plane coupling 18 
via time and frequency.  The configuration above follows the example given in the CUSM specification. 19 
The section numbers in the above table do not represent SectionID numbers but individual sections. Sections 20 
#1 and #2 describe hypothetical DMRS signals sent in symbols #2 and #11 in each slot.  These signals have 21 
every other subcarrier masked by reMask. This is the same as shown above in the standard NR-FR1-TM1.1 22 
test signal shown above. The DMRS signals in symbol #2 have beam ID 1 and symbol #11 have beam ID 2.  23 
These sections use section extension 6 and contain a higher priority than all other sections.  24 
Section #3 describes PN23 data sent to hypothetical UE #1 it overlaps REs in sections #1 and #2 but has a 25 
lower priority so sections #1 and #2 are valid.  Since section #3 has contiguous symbols section extension 6 26 
is not needed. 27 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       240 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
Section #4 is for hypothetical UE #2. It occupies the same symbols as the DMRS signals but uses a different 1 
reMask.  Since the symbols are not contiguous it uses sections extension 6 but the priority is set to the default 2 
0. 3 
Section #5 is for hypothetical UE #3 and uses a contiguous set of symbols so section extension 6 is not 4 
needed.  It does not overlap any other signals.  This section is optional because it does not test Section 5 
Description Priority. 6 
Section #6 is a hypothetical special channel using only one symbol and does not require section extension 6.  7 
This section is also optional. 8 
U-Plane messages will contain: 9 
 DMRS signals for every odd resource element as described by section #1 for symbol #11 10 
 DMRS signals for every odd resource element as described by section #2 for symbol #2 11 
 A new PN23 sequence in each of the first 5 symbols as described in section #3.  Note that for 12 
symbol #2 the PN sequence will be pierced by the DMRS signals. 13 
 A new PN23 sequence for symbol #6 as described by section #4 as well as a new PN sequence for 14 
symbol #11.  These sequences are only 32 PRBs long and start in PRB 15. The sequence in symbol 15 
#11 will be pierced by DMRS signals. 16 
 The user data for sections number #5 and #6 are standard PN23 sequences only for these symbols 17 
and PRBs described in the table above. 18

 1 
In this test the section configuration will be as shown in Table 3.2.5.1-4 above.  The 6 sections will comprise 2 
one slot and this slot will be repeated to fill the entire frame (i.e., 20 times).  The six sections will be sent on 3 
one C-Plane message using C and U plane coupling via time and frequency.  The configuration above 4 
follows the example given in the CUSM specification. 5 
o The section numbers in the above table do not represent SectionID numbers but individual sections. 6 
Sections #1 and #2 describe hypothetical DMRS signals sent in symbols #2 and #11 in each slot.  7 
These signals have every other subcarrier masked by reMask. This is the same as shown above in 8 
the standard G-FR1-A1-5 test signal shown above with the exception that the DMRS signals 9 
continue for all 273 RBs. The DMRS signals in symbol #2 have beam ID 1 and symbol #11 have 10 
beam ID 2.  These sections use section extension 6 and contain a higher priority than all other 11 
sections.  12 
o Section #3 describes PN23 data sent to hypothetical UE #1 it overlaps REs in sections #1 and #2 13 
but has a lower priority so sections #1 and #2 are valid.  Since section #3 has contiguous symbols 14 
section extension 6 is not needed.  Note it starts in PRM 64 (RBG 4) and continues for the 15 
remainder of the 273 RBs. 16 
o Section #4 is for hypothetical UE #2. It occupies the same symbols as the DMRS signals but uses a 17 
different reMask.  Since the symbols are not contiguous it uses sections extension 6 but the priority 18 
is set to the default 0.  It also starts in RBG 4 (RB 64) and continues to the rest of the 273 RBs. 19 
o Section #5 is for hypothetical UE #3 and uses a contiguous set of symbols so section extension 6 is 20 
not needed.  It does not overlap any other signals.  This section is optional because it does not test 21 
Section Description Priority. 22 
o Section #6 is a hypothetical special channel using only one symbol and does not require section 23 
extension 6.  This section is also optional. 24 
 Load the following waveform into the signal source: 25 
o DMRS signals for every odd resource element as described by section #1 for symbol #11 26 
o DMRS signals for every odd resource element as described by section #2 for symbol #2 27 
o A new PN23 sequence in each of the first 5 symbols as described in section #3.  Note that for 28 
symbol #2 the PN sequence will be pierced by the DMRS signals. 29 
o A new PN23 sequence for symbol #6 as described by section #4 as well as a new PN sequence for 30 
symbol #11.  These sequences start in PRB 64 and continue to PRB 273. The sequence in symbol 31 
#11 will be pierced by DMRS signals. 32 
o The user data for sections number #5 and #6 are standard PN23 sequences only for these symbols 33 
and PRBs described in the table above. 34 
 Configure Signal Source to play test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it receives a 35 
trigger signal from the O-DU emulator that C-Plane messages have been sent. 36 
 Load C-Plane message described above on Test Equipment O-RU (TER). The C-Plane message will 37 
contain valid values in the following fields: 38 
 EAxC ID 39 
 Datadirection bit (Uplink) 40 
 Frame ID, subframeID, slotID, startsymbolID, and NumSymbol 41 
 SectionID must have a value 4095 42 
 Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  43 
 Launch test to play the RF uplink frame after the C-Plane messages have been sent honoring timing 44 
windows  45 
 Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the Antenna 46 
port  47 
 TER will arrange U-Plane messages according to time and frequency 48 
 Extract IQ information  49 
 Extract Payload 50 
 Compare payload binary sequences  51 
 52 
c. Procedure for Coupling C and U plane messages via frequency and time with section priorities 53 
(optimized) 54 
This test will be identical to the above test with the following exceptions: 55 
 There will be two C-Plane messages describing the uplink and downlink signals to be sent. 56 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       242 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 The first two sections listed in the table above (those with higher priorities) will be repeated in both C-1 
Plane messages and will have a section ID equal to a value between 0 and “max-highest-priority-2 
sections-per-slot” as sent on the M-Plane. 3 
 The other sections will be divided between the two C-Plane messages and not repeated. 4 
 The repeated C-plane message will have the “repetition” bit set to one. 5 
 6 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  7 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 8 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 9 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer must be the same as the signal described above.  It must contain 10 
all the same PRB assignments and PN23 sequences. 11 
3. The data received from the O-RU on the uplink U-Plane must match the uplink signal sent to the DUT 12 
including all the same PRB assignments and PN23 sequences. 13 
4. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 14 
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 15 
declaration of the beam under test.  The procedures for test case 3.2.3.2.4 (UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class 16 
Beamforming 3GPP UL – Predefined-beam Beamforming) and test case 3.2.3.2.3 (UC-Plane O-RU Scenario 17 
Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam Beamforming) should be used. 18 
5. These expected results are applicable for either or both forms of this test. 19 
6. If all of the above results are observed the test passes. 20 
 21 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended using Non-contiguous PRB Allocation 22 
Section Extension using section extension 12 3GPP DL/UL – Resource Allocation 23 
A. Test Description and Applicability 24 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 25 
 26 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can accurately interpret C-Plane resource allocation messages with 27 
section extension 12, transfer U-Plane data into the correct resource blocks and transmit this data accurately in the 28 
downlink and interpret and capture the correct resource blocks in the uplink with section extension 12.    This test 29 
uses a PN23 sequence in all test PDSCH sections. 30 
 31 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the 32 
TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on 33 
thedownlink and uplink the specified signal using section extension 12 in both uplink and downlink.   34 
 35 
In this test stock data section definition C will be used to exercise the non-contiguous RB allocation, all 273 PRBs 36 
(48 of the 51 in the uplink slots) or the max number of PRBs per symbol for the highest numerology the radio 37 
supports will be used in this test. 38 
 39 
Only one spatial stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios 40 
(No precoding is required).  All downlink user data in this test will be a PN23 sequence and all uplink user data 41 
will also be a PN23 sequence. 42 
 43 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 44 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document.  The test numerology will be 45 
30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section 3.2.1.1.3.  It will be for 5G New Radio 46 
only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. 47 
 48 
The radio must support section extension 12 as notified by the M-Plane.  The Signal Analyzer must have the ability 49 
to decode the downlink shared channel. 50 
 51 
C. Test Methodology 52 
a. Initial Conditions 53 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 54 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the 55 
O-RU antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 56 
demodulate the transmitted signal.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna port and configure it as 57 
described below. 58 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       243 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
b. Procedure 1 
Build an appropriate IQ signal as described above in section 3.2.1.1.3 in the CUSM emulator. In this case 2 
use a PN23 sequence for the downlink shared channel.  Build the appropriate test frame (uplink slots) for 3 
the signal source. Use the CUSM emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that 4 
describe the uplink and downlink signals. Every symbol used in the test should be described by a single 5 
section (DL-SCH that are used for the test, DMRS and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section 6 
type zero messages will be used for this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages for downlink 7 
slots only. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  8 
Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 9 
demodulate and decode the test frame.  It will be the responsibility of the TER’s signal analyzer and source 10 
to coordinate downlink and uplink TDD transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of the TER is responsible for 11 
receiving uplink U-Plane messages, extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which can be compared to those 12 
sent by the signal source. 13 
 14 
 15 
For the downlink slots and symbols: Only symbols number 6 and 7 will be used in each slot.  Other 16 
symbols may contain data including reference signals to ensure test equipment can synchronize with the 17 
signal.  The starting PRB will be zero and number of PRBs will be chosen from one or more columns in 18 
Table 3.2.5.1-6 below.  The resource block group size will be 16 based on 3GPP 38.214 Table 5.1.2.2.1-1 19 
as shown in Table 3.2.5.1-5 below using configuration 2.   20

1 – 36 2 4

145 – 275 16 16

described above, the ID of the last RBG will be 17, f(0) will be 16, f(n) will be 16 and f(lastRbgID) will be 26 
1 (17 total RBGs).  StartPrbc will be zero and numPrbc will be 273.  If the radio does not support this 27 
numerology the following table will apply.  The number of PRBs correspond to Table 3.2.5.1-6. 28

Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU emulator.  1 
Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal. 2 
Every symbol should be described by a single type 1 section (DL-SCH and DCI) except symbols 3 
#6 and #7 which will be used for the section extension 12 test. The data in symbol #6 should be a new PN23 4 
sequence starting in the first PRB and continuing to PRB 273 (RBG number 17).  Symbol #7 should be 5 
identical to symbol #6.  The symMask value should be set to 00000011000000b.  No section type zero 6 
messages will be used for this test.  The relevant parameters for the downlink C-Plane message are shown in 7 
Figure 3.2.5.1-1 below: 8 
 9 Figure 3.2.5.1-1 Downlink C-Plane Parameters 10 
The O-DU emulator will build a U-Plane message containing the PN23 IQ data for the first 16 PRBs (RBG 0), 11 
this message will have the section ID used in the C-Plane message described above.  Another U-Plane message 12 
will be created using the same section ID but with the PN23 data for RBGs 2-17 in it.  The same U-Plane 13 
messages will be used for symbol #7. 14 
 15 
For the uplink sections and symbols: For this test symbols number 6 and 7 will be used in each slot.  The 16 
starting PRB will be zero and number of PRBs will be 48.  The resource block group size will be 16.  Using the 17 
calculations in the O-RAN fronthaul specification section 5.4.7.6 the ID of the last RBG will be 17, f(0) will be 18 
16, f(n) will be 16 and f(lastRbgID) will be 1.   19 
Every symbol should be described by a single type 1 section (DL-SCH and DCI) except symbols #6 and #7 20 
which will be used for the section extension 6 test. The data in symbol #6 is expected to be a new PN23 21 
sequence starting in the first PRB and continuing to PRB 48 (RBG number 2).  Symbol #7 should be identical to 22 
symbol #6.  The symMask value should be set to 00000011000000b.  No section type zero messages will be 23 
used for this test.  If the radio only supports another numerology see the tables above in the downlink sections 24 
and symbols for appropriate modifications.  The relevant parameters for the uplink C-Plane message are shown 25 
in Figure 3.2.5.1-2 below:  26

Steps: 3 
 Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  4 
 Launch test to play the C-Plane messages and the downlink U-Plane messages and trigger the 5 
source to play the RF signal on a frame boundary.  6 
 Play messages to the O-RU respecting the timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat 7 
the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 8 
demodulate and decode the frame. 9 
 Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the 10 
Antenna port  11 
 Extract IQ information from the captured U-Plane messages 12 
 Extract IQ information from the signal analyzer for downlink slots 13 
 Extract Payload for both signals 14 
 Compare payload binary sequences  15

D. Test Requirement (expected result)  18 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 19 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 20 
2. The signal extracted by the U-Plane messages (uplink) should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance 21 
requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 22 
3. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above.  If it contains 23 
all the same PRB assignments and the correct PN23 sequence as data, the downlink test passes. 24 
4. The test frame extracted from the uplink U-Plane messages should be the same as the uplink signal described 25 
above.  If it contains all the same PRB assignments and the correct PN23 sequence as data, the uplink test 26 
passes. 27

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Static SRS Allocation UL – Resource Allocation 1 
A. Test Description and Applicability 2 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 3 
 4 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the O-RU can support static SRS configuration through the M-Plane.  This is an 5 
uplink only test so there is no corresponding downlink test for TDD.  The O-RU must report through the M-Plane 6 
that it supports static configuration of SRS. 7 
 8 
This test will use the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.  The test will have the CUSM emulator 9 
configure the O-RU, through the M-Plane, with a section of time/frequency resources reserved for static uplink 10 
SRS, these will be limited to the uplink slots of the TDD frame.  The signal source will be programmed to send 11 
simulated SRS signals in a subset of those resources.  The O-RU should receive this SRS signals and pass them 12 
through to the CUSM emulator using U-Plane messages.  Note, there will be no C-Plane messages sent from the 13 
CUSM emulator and the O-RU.  The signal generator will signal power levels at least 30 dB above Reference 14 
Sensitivity power Level described in TS 138.141-1 Table 7.2.5-1.  This is to improve the likelihood that all data will 15 
be received by the radio correctly since we are not interested in testing receiver sensitivity but only the O-RAN 16 
protocol compliance.  The placement of the time frequency resources is not specified in this test so it may be placed 17 
in any uplink slots of the TDD frame. 18 
 19 
The TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) generates an uplink SRS signal on the antenna connector or TAB connector. The 20 
TER will capture the U-Plane messages generated by the DUT and validate whether the payload matches the uplink 21 
signal as well as beam characteristics. The metric used to validate that the signal received by the CUSM emulator 22 
matches the signal sent by the signal generator will be EVM as described in Annex H.7 of 3GPP 38.141.  While 23 
some 3GPP test documents (e.g., TS 38.521 section 6.4.2.1.3) suggest treating the EVM requirements for physical 24 
Zadoff-Chu sequences such as PRACH the same as QPSK for EVM requirements, this document will decrease the 25 
required EVM to the level specified for 64 QAM.  The purpose of this is to ensure that there is no chance of false 26 
positives where a random, mistaken signal sent by the O-RU closely mimics the test signal used by the TER.  Since 27 
there are no impairments made to the uplink SRS signal this should be well within the capabilities of the O-RU. 28 
 29 
 30 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 31 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document.  The O-RU must indicate it 32 
supports static SRS allocation. The test numerology will be 30 kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth.  33 
It will be for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. Note 34 
this signal may be changed to any of the 3GPP sensitivity test signals in 3GPP TS 138.141-1 if the radio does not 35 
support the numerology and bandwidth used in this test.  The test signal described in this section will be used if 36 
the radio supports that numerology and bandwidth.  37 
 38 
C. Test Methodology 39 
a. Initial Conditions 40 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-41 
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 42 
port and configure the source to transmit the required SRS test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from the 43 
CUSM-E.  The signal source power level should be adjusted to at least 30 dB above the setting used in the 44 
3GPP receiver sensitivity test. 45 
Implicit in this Initial set up is statically configuring O-RU with a section of time/frequency resources for static 46 
SRS signals. 47 
.   48 
b. Procedure 49 
 Build an SRS signal in the signal generator that fits in the preconfigured time frequency resources set in the 50 
initial configuration. 51 
 Load the waveform into the signal source: 52 
 Configure Signal Source to play test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it receives a 53 
trigger signal from the O-DU emulator that signals the start of a frame boundary. 54 
 Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  55 
 Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the Antenna port 56 
connected 57 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       247 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 TER will arrange U-Plane messages according to time and frequency 1 
 Extract IQ information  2 
 Calculate EVM of the SRS signal received by the CUSM emulator to the ideal signal generated by the 3 
signal source. Use the method described in TS 38.141 Annex H.7 to perform the calculation. 4 
 5 
 6 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  7 
1. The verdict is “Test pass” if the calculated EVM is less than 8%. 8 
2. If any of the test conditions are not true, the verdict for the whole test is "Fail" 9 
 10 
 11 
 12 
 UC Plane O-RU Base Class TDD Test UL – Static PRACH allocation 13 
A. Test Description and Applicability 14 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 15 
 16 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the O-RU can support static PRACH configuration through the M-Plane.  This 17 
is an uplink only test so there is no corresponding downlink test for downlink slots.  The O-RU must report through 18 
the M-Plane that it supports static configuration of PRACH.  The concept is to repeat the spirit of test 3.2.3.8.1 19 
(5GNR  PRACH test) without sending any C-Plane type 3 messages and configuring the O-RU using only the M-20 
Plane. 21 
 22 
TER will setup the signal generator with a PRACH test waveform according to TS 38.141-1 section 8.4.1 and A.6. 23 
The test waveform will contain the same preamble ID repeated by following the timing offset scheme specified in 24 
the figures 8.4.1.4.2-2 or 8.4.1.4.2-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected PRACH format. 25 
This is an example for FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3 configuration index 132 (From Table 26 
6.3.3.2-3, unpaired spectrum), at each occasion the time offset of the same preamble index (selected according to 27 
table A.6-1 TS 38.141.1) is incremented by 100nsec starting from 0 up to 800nsec (9 occasions per frame). Each 28 
PRACH occasion is at the beginning of the first nine used sub-frames. The scheme is repeated every frame. The test 29 
must be conducted using a PRACH format and configuration index the radio has reported it supports 30 
 31 
 32 
Figure 3.2.5.1-3 FR1 SCS 30Kz 100MHz Format A3, Unpaired Spectrum, configuration index 132 33 
 34 
According to the PRACH waveform setting, the TER will generate a corresponding sequence of M-Plane messages 35 
which include the following parameters (According to the M-Plane specification and the PRACH configuration index 36 
supported): 37 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       248 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
• grouping static-prach-configuration  1 
• leaf pattern-period - "Period after which static PRACH patterns are repeated. Unit: number of 2 
frames." 3 
• leaf guard-tone-low-re - "Number of REs occupied by the low guard tones." 4 
• leaf num-prach-re - "Number of contiguous PRBs per data section description“ 5 
• leaf guard-tone-high-re - "Number of REs occupied by the high guard tones.“ 6 
• leaf sequence-duration - "Duration of single sequence of the PRACH. Sequence may be considered as 7 
'single PRACH symbol’” 8 
• list prach-patterns - key prach-pattern-id - "Provides a PRACH pattern. Each record in the list 9 
represents a single PRACH occasion. Number of list entries cannot exceed max-prach-patterns“ 10 
• leaf prach-pattern-id - "Supplementary parameter acting as key for prach-pattern list.“ 11 
• leaf number-of-repetitions - "This parameter defines number of PRACH repetitions in 12 
PRACH occasion, to which the section control is applicable 13 
• leaf number-of-occasions - "This parameter informs how many consecutive PRACH 14 
occasions is described by the PRACH Pattern” 15 
• leaf re-offset – “Offset between the start of the lowest-frequency RE of the lowest frequency 16 
PRB and the start of the lowest frequency RE belonging to the PRACH occasion.  The re-17 
offset is configured as number of PRACH REs. 18 
• list occasion-parameters – “list of cp-lengths, gp-lengths and beam-ids applicable per each 19 
PRACH occasion in PRACH pattern. Note: the number of records in this list MUST be equal 20 
to value of parameter number-of-occasions.“ 21 
• leaf occasion-id - "Supplementary parameter acting as key in 'occasion-parameters' 22 
list“ 23 
• leaf cp-length - "Cyclic prefix length. See CUS-plane specification for detailed 24 
description.“ 25 
• leaf gp-length - "Guard period length.“ 26 
• leaf beam-id  - "This parameter defines the beam pattern to be applied to the U-27 
Plane data. beamId = 0 means no beamforming operation will be performed." 28 
• leaf frame-number - "This parameter is an index inside the pattern-length, such that PRACH 29 
occasion is happening for SFN which fulfills following equation: [SFN mod pattern-length = 30 
frame-id]“ 31 
• leaf sub-frame-id - "Identifier of sub-frame of the PRACH occasion. Value is interpreted in 32 
the same way as subframeId field in a section description of a C-Plane message.“ 33 
• leaf time-offset - "This parameter defines the time-offset from the start of the sub-frame to 34 
the start of the first Cyclic Prefix of PRACH pattern" 35 
 36 
By the corresponding U-Plane messages in the uplink direction, the TER will try to detect the presence of the 37 
corresponding preamble at the expected timing offset and calculate the probability of detection Pd according to the 38 
definition in TS38.141-1 section 8.4.1.1.  39 
The signal will be exercised at only one O-RU port without adding any external AWGN power level or multipath 40 
fading profile and at a power level avoiding detection errors due to poor SNR (rule described in the sub-section C of 41 
this scenario class). 42 
The test will have the CUSM emulator configure the O-RU, through the M-Plane, with a section of time/frequency 43 
resources reserved for static uplink PRACH.  The default is the PRACH configuration described in 3GPP above, but the 44 
test may be conducted with changes if the radio does not support those exact configurations.  The signal source will be 45 
programmed to send simulated PRACH signals in those resources.  The O-RU should receive this PRACH signal and 46 
pass them through to the CUSM emulator using U-Plane messages.  Note, there will be no C-Plane messages sent from 47 
the CUSM emulator and the O-RU. 48 
 49 
 50 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 51 
O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (FR1) or TAB connector. 52 
By the M-plane or by manufacturer declaration, TER will detect all the supported SCSs, FFT sizes and carrier 53 
bandwidths by the O-RU. It is assumed that only one combination of the three above parameters supported by the O-54 
RU is enough to validate the test. TER shall generate M-Plane messages according to one of the PRACH formats in 55 
table A.6-1 TS 38.141. TER will choose the format either according to the manufacturer declaration item D.103 56 
“PRACH format and SCS” in TS 38.141-1 or according to the format information obtained by the M-plane in case O-57 
RU implements this feature. If more formats are claimed, only one shall be selected to reduce the test time, preference 58 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       249 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
will be given to a format specified in Table A.6.1 TS 38.141. It is assumed that the O-RU manufacturer will support at 1 
least one in that table. For the case of long preambles, it is assumed format 0 is always supported since this is the only 2 
one shown in the table A.6-1 TS 38.141. 3 
 4 
C. Test Methodology 5 
  6 
a: Initial Conditions 7 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-8 
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 9 
port and configure the source to transmit the required PRACH test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from 10 
the CUSM-E.   11 
Implicit in this Initial set up is statically configuring O-RU with a section of time/frequency resources for static 12 
PRACH signals. 13 
b: Procedure 14 
 Set signal generator power by the following method: 15 
g. Select SNR from the scenario with two RX antennas and AWGN propagation condition in table 8.4.1.5-16 
1, 8.4.1.5-2 or 8.4.1.5-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected SCS and PRACH format. 17 
h. Select the AWGN power level according to the configured SCS and channel bandwidth in table 18 
8.4.1.4.2-1 TS 38.141-1 and 38.141-1and multiply by the PRACH signal bandwidth.  19 
i. The output power will be given by the formula (SNR+Noise power – 3dB) rounded to the first decimal 20 
digit. Extra 3dB are to compensate that SNR and noise power are selected from the two RX ports test 21 
case and this test procedure requires only one O-RU port. 22 
 23 
For example, for the FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3 SNR is -13.5dB and noise level 24 
is -70.1dBm/98.28MHz. signal generator power = -13.5dB -70.1dBm/98.28MHz*(139*30 KHz)-3dB 25 
=-19.5dBm.  26 
 Set signal generator frequency offset to the central carrier frequency. PRACH will be mapped over 27 
frequency according to msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter equal to 0. PRACH format is set according 28 
to what TER has selected from the manufacturer declarations. 29 
 Start PRACH waveform generation on the signal generator.  Ensure the test frame is repeated enough times 30 
to generate a statistically significant number of PRACH occasions.  That is at least 10 occasions. 31 
 TER will perform PRACH detection per each PRACH occasion in each frame sent and compare the result 32 
with the expected preamble ID and the expected timing offset. Since the external AWGN and fading 33 
generator are not present the time error tolerance should be low, TER will use the time error tolerance in 34 
table 8.4.1.1-1 for AWGN case according to the corresponding PRACH format and PRACH SCS. A counter 35 
of successful detections is incremented at every matching. The probability of detection is given by the ratio 36 
between that counter and the number of the expected received PRACH occasions within the test time. 37 
 Repeat the test procedure by setting msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter to the right edge of the 38 
configured carrier bandwidth in order to exercise a different frequency offset number 39 
  40 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  41 
a. Test is pass if the probability of detection is 100%. 42 
 43 
 44 
 UC Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended using section extension 13 for frequency 45 
hopping UL/DL – Resource Allocation 46 
A. Test Description and Applicability 47 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 48 
 49 
The purpose of this test is to validate the capability of the O-RU to correctly interpret section extension 13, 50 
frequency hopping, for the uplink.  Note, since frequency hopping is only used in uplink in 5G NR this test will be   51 
limited to the uplink slots of the basic TDD signal. 52 
startRAn
startRAn
