Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       250 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface of the 2 
TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to transmit on the 3 
downlink and uplink of the specified signal using section extension 13 for the uplink.  The downlink portion of the 4 
test is not part of this test and may be any signal or no downlink signal at all. 5 
 6 
In this test stock data section definition C will be used to exercise the non-contiguous RB allocation, all 273 PRBs 7 
(48 of the 51 in the uplink slots) or the max number of PRBs per symbol for the highest numerology the radio 8 
supports will be used in this test. 9 
 10 
Only one spatial stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios 11 
(No precoding is required). 12 
 13 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 14 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 of this document.  The test numerology will be 15 
30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section 3.2.1.1.3.  It will be for 5G New Radio 16 
only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. 17 
 18 
The radio must support section extension 13 as notified by the M-Plane.  The Signal Analyzer must have the ability 19 
to decode the downlink shared channel. 20 
 21 
C. Test Methodology 22 
a. Initial Conditions 23 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 24 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the 25 
O-RU antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 26 
demodulate the transmitted signal.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna port and configure it as 27 
described below. 28 
b. Procedure 29 
Build an appropriate IQ signal as described above in section 3.2.1.1.3 in the CUSM emulator. In this case 30 
use a PN23 sequence for the downlink shared channel.  Build the appropriate test frame (uplink slots) for 31 
the signal source. Use the CUSM emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that 32 
describe the uplink and downlink signals. Every symbol used in the test should be described by a single 33 
section (DL-SCH that are used for the test, DMRS and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section 34 
type zero messages will be used for this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages for downlink 35 
slots only. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  36 
Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 37 
demodulate and decode the test frame.  It will be the responsibility of the TER’s signal analyzer and source 38 
to coordinate downlink and uplink TDD transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of the TER is responsible for 39 
receiving uplink U-Plane messages, extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which can be compared to those 40 
sent by the signal source. 41 
 42 
 43 
For the downlink slots and symbols: Any signal may be used if needed by the TER or no downlink signal 44 
may be used. 45 
 46 
For the uplink sections and symbols: Load uplink test waveform (G-FR1-A1-5 : SCS130k_51RB) on the 47 
RF Signal Source.  Note this signal should contain a new PN23 sequence as user data in PRBs 0 through 50 48 
for symbol 6 and PRBs 100 through 151 for symbol 7.  This will be copied for all uplink slots. The 49 
remainder of the test waveform is as described in 3GPP.  Configure Signal Source to play test waveforms 50 
on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it receives a trigger signal from the O-DU emulator that C-Plane 51 
messages have been sent.  Load a C-Plane message on Test Equipment O-RU (TER) – Use the O-DU 52 
emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane message that describes this uplink signal. This 53 
section should have startSymbolId = 6, numPrbc = 51, and section extension 13 attached.  The section 54 
extension should have nextSymbolId = 7 and nextStartPrbc = 100. 55 
 56 
Steps: 57 
 Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  58 
 Launch test to play the C-Plane messages and the downlink U-Plane messages (if needed) and 59 
trigger the source to play the RF signal on a frame boundary.  60 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       251 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Play messages to the O-RU respecting the timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat 1 
the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 2 
demodulate and decode the frame. 3 
 Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the 4 
Antenna port  5 
 Extract IQ information from the captured U-Plane messages 6 
 Extract IQ information from the signal analyzer for downlink slots (if needed) 7 
 Extract Payload for both signals 8 
 Compare payload binary sequences  9 
 10 
 11 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  12 
1. The signal extracted by the U-Plane messages (uplink) should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance 13 
requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 14 
2. The verdict is “Test pass” if the test frame received by the signal analyzer contains two U-Plane messages for 15 
this section ID one containing the PN23 sequence for the first 51 PRBs in symbol 6 and PRBs 100 through 151 16 
for symbol #7 containing the PN23 sequence sent by the signal source for those PRBs. 17 
 18 
 19 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming (BFM)  20 
This section describes the beamforming conformance testing for ORAN fronthaul interface. The tests do not aim to test 21 
the O-RU beamforming performance or capabilities but to test that the O-RU under test focuses the RF energy or 22 
sensitivity into a specific direction and with a specific granularity following the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface 23 
of the TER described in section 2.1) C-Plane messages.  24 
Unless stated otherwise in a test case, the following statements apply to all the test cases defined in this section: 25 
 It is based on conducted testing with a setup such as described in Section 2.1 and it only applies to O-RU DUTs 26 
that have conducted antenna ports or TAB connectors. 27 
 28 
 It applies to  Category A and  Category B O-RU DUTs. 29 
 30 
 It applies to LTE and/or 5G New Radio O-RU DUTs.  In both cases, precoding is not required in any test case.   31 
 32 
 If O-RU DUT supports Analog Beamforming (i.e. time domain beamforming), all the U-Plane test frames are 33 
defined by segmenting the Stock Test A: 1 section per symbol.  The definition of this Stock Test A can be 34 
found in Figure 3.2.1.1-2 and the description accompanying this figure.  Each slot shall include multiple 35 
sections (one per symbol within the slot) and only one beam at a time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore 36 
only one beam can be tested per slot. 37 
 38 
 If O-RU DUT supports Digital Beamforming (i.e. frequency domain beamforming), all the U-Plane test frames 39 
are defined by segmenting the Stock Test B: 2 sections per symbol definition as shown in Figure 3.2.1.1-2.  40 
Each slot shall include multiple sections (two per symbol within the slot) and only one beam per section at a 41 
time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore up to two different beams can be tested per slot. 42 
 43 
 If O-RU DUT supports multiple polarizations, it is up to the TER to determine if the testing is carried out for 44 
each polarization separately or multiple polarizations at the same time. In any case, it is important to guarantee 45 
that the correct eAxC_ID for the correct polarization (or polarizations) is exercised.  46 
 47 
 For O-RU DUT that support TDD:  48 
 The tests may use any combination of Downlink and Uplink standard 3GPP LTE test frames found in 49 
Section 6.1.1.1 of TS 36.141-1. 50 
 For example, the following TDD test waveform could be used for this test: 51 
o 20MHz bandwidth with 100 RBs assigned 52 
o Uplink/Downlink Configuration set to 3 53 
o Special Subframe Configuration set to 8 54 
o DwPTS Length set to 11 Symbols 55 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       252 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
o GP lengths set to 1 Symbol 1 
o UpPTS Length set to 2 Symbols. 2 
 The full test radio frame is shown in Figure 3.2.5.2-1. 3 
 4 Figure 3.2.5.2-1 Combined DL and UL TDD 20 MHz 100 RB 5 
If 20MHz is not supported by the O-RU DUT, then it will use the highest bandwidth supported by the O-6 
RU DUT. 7 
 8 
 For O-RU DUT that support 5G NR:  9 
o The tests will use a combination of Downlink and Uplink standard 3GPP 5G NR test frames. See 10 
figure . 11 
o The Downlink part of the radio frame will use a standard 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 test frame for TDD in 12 
[19] (Section 4.9.2 TS138.141-1) of the Conducted Transmitter Characteristic Test section (Section 6 13 
TS138.141-1) as described in section 3.2.1.1. The test numerology will be preferably 30KHz 14 
subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth. If not supported, then it will use any other supported 15 
subcarrier spacing and the highest bandwidth of the O-RU DUT. 16 
o The Uplink part of the radio frame will use a standard 3GPP Reference Sensitivity level definition 17 
(Section 7.2 and Annex A TS138.141-1) of the Conducted Receiver Characteristic Test section 18 
(Section 7 TS 38.141) and power levels at least 30dB above Reference Sensitivity power level as 19 
described in section 3.2.1.1.  The test numerology will be preferably 30kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 20 
MHz Bandwidth, if supported. Otherwise, it will use any available subcarrier space and the highest 21 
bandwidth supported by the O-RU DUT. 22 
o The Downlink symbols are allocated at slots 0 to 7 and 10 to 17.  23 
o The Uplink symbols are allocated at slots 7 to 9 and 17 to 19. 24 
o Note that slots 7 and 17 have symbols allocated for Downlink, symbols 0 to 5, some other symbols 25 
assigned as Guard Period where no signal is transmitted or expected to be received, symbols 6 to 9, 26 
and finally some other symbols allocated for Uplink, symbols 10 to 13. 27 
 28 
 The O-RU DUT must: 29 
o support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.1 of this document. 30 
o have installed current release of shipping software.  31 
o have at least two conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be connected to a signal analyzer. 32 
Likewise, it must have at least two conducted antenna ports or TAB connectors to be connected to a signal 33 
generator. 34 
o be fully calibrated up to the antenna ports or (TAB connectors) (if needed). It is expected to be calibrated 35 
by O-RU vendor prior to testing.  36 
 37 
 38 
 The TER must: 39 
o be capable of carrying out any signal processing required to generate and demodulate 3GPP compliant 40 
waveforms. 41 
o be able to calculate or extract beamweights (or magnitude and phase relations) between antenna ports or 42 
TAB connectors. Alternatively, and if the O-RU DUT manufacturer provides the list of beam directions 43 
supported by the O-RU DUT, TER might calculate or extract the beam direction instead of the 44 
beamweights. 45 
o be able to generate and deliver signals with the required beamweights (or magnitude and phase relations) at 46 
the antenna ports or TAB connectors.  47 
o be fully calibrated up to the interfaces where is connected to the O-RU DUT antenna ports (or TAB 48 
connectors). For that, a known test signal might be either injected by the TER into the O-RU DUT, or 49 
internally generated by the O-RU DUT, and the O-RU DUT must not apply any digital or analog 50 
beamweights to the known test signal.  One possible method to perform calibration uses injected C-Plane 51 
and U-Plane signals from TER into the O-RU and using C-Plane messages with beamID=0.   52 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       253 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
 2 
 The O-DU emulator of the TER must: 3 
o be capable of generating and sending U-Plane messages containing 3GPP test frames following the 4 
corresponding Stock sectioning defined above, as well as be capable of capturing U-Plane messages and 5 
extracting 3GPP test frames (i.e. IQ data) from the captured U-Plane messages. 6 
o be capable of generating the C-Plane messages for, receiving, extracting and demodulating the 3GPP test 7 
frames following the corresponding Stock sectioning defined above. 8 
 9 
 The TER might have less testing ports than the O-RU DUT conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) if 10 
testing is carried out sequentially; or as many antenna ports as the number of conducted antenna ports (or TAB 11 
connectors) under test if testing is carried out simultaneously. 12 
 13 
 It is up to the TER on how to extract the beamweights (or magnitude and phase relation) between the antenna 14 
ports or TAB connectors, or the beam direction / properties, in order to match it with the manufacturer’s 15 
declaration. 16 
 17 
 The user payload will be generated as PN23 with a seed of all ones. 18 
 19 
 It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections: 20 
 Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 21 
 Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 22 
 Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 23 
 Section 10 for beamforming guidelines. 24 
 Annex J for beamforming methods description.  25 
 26 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – No Beamforming 27 
A. Test Description and Applicability 28 
This test is MANDATORY. 29 
 30 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 31 
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 32 
 33 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 34 
 Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of magnitude and phase relation (or beamweights) between 35 
antenna ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics when O-RU DUT 36 
is operating with no beamforming.  37 
 38 
C. Test Methodology 39 
 40 
a. Initial Conditions 41 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 42 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  43 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 44 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.  45 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 46 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 47 
transmitted signal.   48 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  49 
 50 
b. Procedure 51 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal described above in the O-DU emulator.   52 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 53 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two sections (DL-SCH 54 
and DCI) using section type 1 messages.  Section type zero messages will be used to signal Guard Period 55 
resources in the test waveform. 56 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 57 
windows described in section3.2.1.1.1.   58 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       254 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 1 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 2 
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam direction from the measured 3 
signal. 4 
 5 
 6 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  7 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 8 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 9 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 10 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 11 
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 12 
connectors, or the extracted beam direction, should match the expected relation, or beam direction, for the 13 
expected no beamforming within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  14 
 15 
 16 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – No Beamforming 17 
A. Test Description and Applicability 18 
This test is MANDATORY. 19 
 20 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 21 
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 22 
 23 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 24 
 Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of magnitude and phase relation (or beamweights) between antenna 25 
ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics when O-RU DUT is 26 
operating with no beamforming.  27 
 28 
C. Test Methodology 29 
 30 
a. Initial Conditions 31 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 32 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 33 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 34 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.  35 
 Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 36 
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 37 
signal.  38 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   39 
 40 
b. Procedure 41 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  42 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 43 
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 44 
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test. For 45 
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming). 46 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 47 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-48 
SCH) using section type 1 messages. 49 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 50 
also triggering the signal source.   51 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 52 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 53 
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or phase relation between 54 
all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O-RU. For example, 55 
repeating the process for a number of different beamweights will simulate the reception of the test signal 56 
from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the sensitivity to 57 
the correct beam direction. 58 
 59 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       255 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  1 
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should 2 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 3 
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 4 
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 5 
declaration of the phase relation expected for no beamforming. 6 
 7 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam 8 
Beamforming 9 
A. Test Description and Applicability 10 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 11 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with predefined-beams 12 
beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 13 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each indexed beam required in this measurement, see below. The 14 
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction could be 15 
defined by the phase relation between the antenna ports or TAB connectors under test, or directly by extracting the 16 
beam direction. 17 
Depending on the O-RU beamforming capabilities regarding the ability to generate “coarse”, “fine” and/or “beam 18 
groups”, as defined in [2] Section 10.4.1.1. 19 
 20 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 21 
 22 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam Beamforming conformance test 23 
might include multiple test that the O-RU must comply: 24 
 25 
a. “Coarse” beamIds test:  26 
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that are defined as coarse granularity (coarse beamIds) to the O-DU 27 
emulator, the test should include the following beams: 28 
1. A coarse beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 29 
2. A coarse beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 30 
3. A coarse beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 31 
4. A coarse beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 32 
5. A coarse beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 33 
 34 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured. 35 
 36 
b.  “Fine” beamIds test:  37 
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that are defined as fine granularity (fine beamIds) to the O-DU 38 
emulator, the test should include the following beams: 39 
1. A fine beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 40 
2. A fine beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 41 
3. A fine beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 42 
4. A fine beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 43 
5. A fine beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 44 
 45 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth or elevation angle, fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured. 46 
 47 
c.  “beam-group” beamIds test:  48 
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that belong to same and different beam-groups to the O-DU emulator, 49 
the test should include the following beams: 50 
1. All beams that belong to a beam-group with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) or elevation (θ) angles. 51 
2. All beams that belong to a beam-group with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ). 52 
3. All beams that belong to a beam-group with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ). 53 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       256 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
4. All beams that belong to a beam-group with maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 1 
5. All beams that belong to a beam-group with minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 2 
 3 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth or elevation angle, fewer than 5 beam-groups will be measured. 4 
 5 
 6 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 7 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of beam indices and their associated magnitude and phase relation between antenna 8 
ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics. 9 
 10 
C. Test Methodology 11 
 12 
a. Initial Conditions 13 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 14 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  15 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 16 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   17 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 18 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 19 
transmitted signal.  20 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range. 21 
   22 
b. Procedure 23 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal described above in the O-DU emulator.   24 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 25 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two sections (DL-SCH and 26 
DCI) using section type 1 messages.   27 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 28 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   29 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to demodulate 30 
and decode the test frame. 31 
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam direction from the measured 32 
signal. 33 
 34 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  35 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 36 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 37 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 38 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 39 
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 40 
connectors, or the extracted beam direction, should match the expected relation, or beam direction, 41 
corresponding to the beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  42 
 43 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Predefined-beam 44 
Beamforming 45 
A. Test Description and Applicability 46 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 47 
 48 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with predefined-beams 49 
beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  50 
 51 
The same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.3 applies, but 52 
instead it is related to the uplink direction.  53 
 54 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 55 
 56

 Manufacturers’ defined list of beam indices and their associated magnitude and phase relation between antenna 1 
ports or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics. 2 
  3 
C. Test Methodology 4 
 5 
a. Initial Conditions 6 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 7 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 8 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 9 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.    10 
 Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 11 
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 12 
signal.  13 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   14 
 15 
b. Procedure 16 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER. 17 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 18 
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 19 
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test. For 20 
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).   21 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 22 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-23 
SCH) using section type 1 messages.  24 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 25 
also triggering the signal source.   26 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 27 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 28 
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or phase relation between 29 
all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O-RU. For example, 30 
repeating the process for a number of different beamweights will simulate the reception of the test signal 31 
from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the sensitivity to 32 
the correct beam direction. 33 
 34 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  35 
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain 36 
all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 37 
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 38 
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 39 
declaration of the beam under test. 40 
 41 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic 42 
Beamforming 43 
A. Test Description and Applicability 44 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 45 
 46 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with weight-based dynamic 47 
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  48 
 49 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each weighted beam required in this measurement, see below. The 50 
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted direction could be 51 
defined by the phase relation between the antenna ports or TAB connectors under test, or by directly extracting the 52 
beam direction. 53 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 54 
 55 
 56 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       258 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic Beamforming conformance 1 
test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 2 
 3 
a. A weight-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 4 
b. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation 5 
angle (θ). 6 
c. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 7 
(θ). 8 
d. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 9 
(θ). 10 
e. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 11 
(θ). 12 
 13 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured. 14 
 15 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight—based Dynamic Beamforming 16 
conformance test should also evaluate the following compression methods for each of the supported beams 17 
described above (a. to e.) for the O-RU to comply: 18 
a. No compression method applied to the beamforming weights.  19 
b. Block floating point compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit mantissa. 20 
c. Block scaling compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit scaler. 21 
d. μ-law compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit fixed width. 22 
e. . Depending on what type of Beamspace compression the DUT supports, either  Beamspace compression 23 
method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit scaler. or Beamspace compression method 24 
applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit mantissa 25 
 26 
If the O-RU does not support all the compression methods described above, fewer than 5 compression methods will 27 
be measured. 28 
 29 
 30 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 31 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of frequency domain (ϕ) and or time domain (θ) weights for each supported beam, 32 
or alternatively, list of gain and phase relation, or complex beam weights, between antenna ports or TAB 33 
connectors for each supported beam . Also, the O-RU needs to report to the O-DU the antenna array 34 
characteristics. 35 
 36 
C. Test Methodology 37 
 38 
a. Initial Conditions 39 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 40 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 41 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 42 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.    43 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 44 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 45 
transmitted signal.  46 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   47 
 48 
b. Procedure 49 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal described above in the O-DU emulator.   50 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 51 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (DL-SCH and DCI) 52 
using section type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension 53 
extType=0x01 to convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 1 54 
since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 55 
should be 0x0.  56 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 57 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   58 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 59 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 60 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       259 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam direction from the measured 1 
signal. 2 
 3 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  4 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for 5 
this radio category (i.e., EVM). 6 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 7 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 8 
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 9 
connectors, or the extracted beam direction, should match the expected relation, or beam direction, 10 
corresponding to the beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  11 
 12 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Weight-based Dynamic 13 
Beamforming 14 
A. Test Description and Applicability 15 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 16 
 17 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with weight-based beamforming 18 
and with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  19 
 20 
The same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.5 but applies to 21 
the uplink direction.  22 
 23 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 24 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of frequency domain (ϕ) and or time domain (θ) weights for each supported beam, 25 
or alternatively, list of gain and phase relation, or complex beam weights, between antenna ports or TAB 26 
connectors for each supported beam . Also, the O-RU needs to report to the O-DU the antenna array 27 
characteristics 28 
 29 
C. Test Methodology 30 
 31 
a. Initial Conditions 32 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 33 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  34 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 35 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   36 
 Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 37 
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 38 
signal.  39 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   40 
 41 
b. Procedure 42 
 43 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  44 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 45 
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 46 
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test. For 47 
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).   48 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 49 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (UL-SCH) using section 50 
type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension extType=0x01 to 51 
convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 1 since the same 52 
beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0.  53 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 54 
also triggering the signal source.   55 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       260 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 1 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 2 
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or phase relation between 3 
all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O-RU. For example, 4 
repeating the process for a number of different beamweights will simulate the reception of the test signal 5 
from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the sensitivity to the 6 
correct beam direction. 7 
 8 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  9 
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain 10 
all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 11 
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 12 
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 13 
declaration of the beam under test. 14 
 15 
 16 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Attribute-based Dynamic 17 
Beamforming 18 
A. Test Description and Applicability 19 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 20 
 21 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with attributed-based dynamic 22 
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  23 
 24 
If the O-RU DUT supports Attribute based Dynamic Beamforming, this test is mandatory for the O-RU DUT to be 25 
O-RAN conformant.   26 
The transmitted beam direction and attributes are measured for each attributed beam required in this measurement, 27 
see below. The measured transmitted direction and attributes, i.e. pointing azimuth and elevation angles, 28 
beamwidths and sidelobe suppression, is compared to manufacturer-designated direction and attributes. 29 
Transmitted direction and beam attributes are defined by the magnitude and phase relation between the antenna 30 
ports or TAB connectors under test, or by directly extracting the beam properties. 31 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in Section 10.4.1.1 of [2]. 32 
 33 
 34 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Attribute-based Dynamic Beamforming 35 
conformance test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 36 
a. An attribute-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles with any beamwidth and 37 
sidelobe suppression supported by the O-RU under this beam direction. 38 
b. An attribute-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation 39 
angle (θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam 40 
direction. 41 
c. An attribute-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation 42 
angle (θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam 43 
direction. 44 
d. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation 45 
angle (θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam 46 
direction. 47 
e. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation 48 
angle (θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam 49 
direction. 50 
 51 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles and attribute 52 
configurations will be measured. 53 
 54 
 55 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 56

 Manufacturers’ defined list of supported beam directions (azimuth ϕ and elevation θ angles) attributes that are 1 
supported by the O-RU and their associated gain and phase relation, or complex weight, between antenna ports 2 
or TAB connectors and/or beam directions with antenna array characteristics. 3

C. Test Methodology 5 
 6 
a. Initial Conditions 7 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 8 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  9 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 10 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   11 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under 12 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 13 
transmitted signal.  14 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   15 
 16 
b. Procedure 17 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 18 
emulator.   19 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 20 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (DL-SCH and DCI) 21 
using section type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension 22 
extType=0x02 to convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 2 23 
since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot.  If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 24 
should be 0x0.  25 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 26 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   27 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 28 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 29 
e. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam properties from the measured 30 
signal. 31 
 32 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  33 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 34 
radio category (i.e., EVM). 35 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 36 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 37 
3. The signal relation (i.e. beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation) between antenna ports or TAB 38 
connectors, or the extracted beam properties, should match the expected beam properties corresponding to the 39 
beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  40 
 41

C. Test Methodology 1 
 2 
a. Initial Conditions 3 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 4 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 5 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 6 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.    7 
 Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the beam under test 8 
and configure the source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 9 
signal.  10 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   11 
 12 
b. Procedure 13 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  14 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial set of beamweights, or equivalently 15 
magnitude and phase relation, between all the TER ports connected to the antenna ports (or TAB 16 
connectors) to emulate the phase and magnitude difference “seen” by the antenna elements under test. For 17 
example, initial beamweights could be set to be “all equal” (i.e. no beamforming).   18 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 19 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (UL-SCH) using section 20 
type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension extType=0x02 to 21 
convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 2 since the same 22 
beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0.  23 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while also 24 
triggering the signal source.   25 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 26 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 27 
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different set of beamweights or magnitude and phase 28 
relation between all the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) when injecting the test signal into the O-RU. For 29 
example, repeating the process for a number of different sets of beamweights will simulate the reception of 30 
the test signal from different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really focusing the 31 
sensitivity to the correct beam properties. 32 
 33 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  34 
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain 35 
all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 36 
2. The beamweights or magnitude and phase relation at the antenna ports (or TAB connectors) of the test signal 37 
that achieves the highest performance (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) should match with the manufacturer’s 38 
declaration of the beam under test. 39 
 40 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based 41 
Beamforming 42 
A. Test Description and Applicability 43 
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 44 
 45 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with channel-information-based 46 
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU-MIMO). 47 
 48 
For Category A radios, the test is for each polarization separately and consequently either different or same channel 49 
models can be defined for each of the polarization. For Category B, same channel might be used for both 50 
polarizations and the test might measure each polarization separately. 51 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each scenario required in this measurement.  The measured 52 
transmitted direction is extracted from the decoded received signal in the TER. Transmitted direction is defined by 53 
properly receiving a data transmission between the O-RU and the target User Equipment while destroying or 54 
heavily attenuating the data transmission between the O-RU and the other User Equipment. 55 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       263 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based Beamforming 1 
conformance test should evaluate the following scenarios for the O-RU to comply and will rely on TER Channel 2 
Emulation capabilities as shown in Figure 3.2.5.2-2.  3 
 4 
 5 Figure 3.2.5.2-2 TER with Channel Emulation Capability 6 
 7 
A scenario where two spatial streams, or eAxC flows, are generated for two users (one layer each) with M antenna 8 
ports or TAB connectors. The O-DU will report to the O-RU via C plane messages an emulated channel estimate 9 
𝐻 ≜  [ℎଵଵ, . . . , ℎଵெ, ℎଶଵ, . . . , ℎଶெ] ∈ ℂଶ௫ . The emulated channel  𝐻  shall model a static channel, with rank not lower 10 
than the number of spatial streams, and it shall not be a block-diagonal channel. As an example, a Butler channel 11 
model could be implemented as emulated channel. The O-RU will calculate and apply the beamweight matrix 𝐺 ≜12 
 [𝑔ଵଵ, . . . , 𝑔ଵெ, 𝑔ଶଵ, . . . , 𝑔ଶெ] ∈ ℂெ௫ଶ in such that the received signal at the users is the same as the generated in the O-13 
DU. It is up to the O-RU on how to calculate the beamforming weights, for example Zero-forcing, regularized 14 
zero-forcing / MMSE, etc.   15 
 16 
If O-RU supports Analog Beamforming (Time Domain Beamforming), the test should not apply any analog 17 
beamforming or time domain beamforming. In this case, M is not the number of antenna ports or TAB connectors 18 
but the number of TRX channels supported by the O-RU. 19 
 20 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 21 
 22 
 The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be 23 
connected to a signal analyzer. 24 
 The TER equipment must either include a channel emulator between the O-RU antenna ports and the signal 25 
analyzer or the signal analyzer be capable of applying the required channel matrix being emulated between the 26 
O-RU and the users.  27 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antenna ports or TAB connectors are 28 
connected to each TRX chain.  29 
 30 
C. Test Methodology 31 
 32 
a. Initial Conditions 33 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 34 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  35 
 Ensure that the RF connections and cables are calibrated so there is phase coherence between the antenna 36 
ports (or TAB connectors) within acceptable tolerance.   37

Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       264 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Connect the signal analyzer to the O-RU antenna ports or TAB connectors that belong to the scenario under 1 
test and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 2 
transmitted signal.  3 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   4 
 5 
b. Procedure 6 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal described above in the O-DU emulator.   7 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 8 
and the scenario under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-SCH and 9 
DCI) using section type 5 and 6 messages.  10 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 11 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1. 12 
d. Capture the test signals and pass them through a channel emulator or apply the signal processing required 13 
to emulate the channel under test.   14 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 15 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 16 
 17 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  18 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 19 
radio category (i.e., EVM). 20 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 21 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 22

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Channel-Information-based 25 
Beamforming 26

generator or the signal generator be capable of applying the required channel matrix being emulated between 40

connected to each TRX chain. 43

signal.  54

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression (CMP) 16 
Validate the correct implementation and interpretation of mandatory and optional IQ data compression formats 17 
described in [2]. Also, evaluate the consistency in U-Plane signaling. 18 
It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections in [2]: 19 
 Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 20 
 Section 5.4.4.10 for applicability of "udCompHdr" and "reserved" fields 21 
 Section 6.3.3.15/16/17 for applicability of udCompParam 22 
 Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 23 
 Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 24 
 Table 8-2 for mandatory/optional capabilities. 25 
 Annex A.6 Selective RE sending Compression 26 
 27 
The objective is primarily to test the protocol, prior to the compression algorithms performance. 28 
Signalling: IQ Compression related fields in UC-Plane messages include:  29 
 U-Plane IQ data field  30 
 C-Plane udCompHdr (per section 5.4.4.10 of [2]) 31 
 U-Plane udComphdr (per section 6.3.3.13 of [2]) 32 
 U-Plane udCompParam (per section 6.3.3.15 of [2]) 33 
 Modulation compression parameters used in the Section Extension Type =4 34 
 csf (constellation shift flag)  35 
 modCompScaler (modulation compression scaler value) 36 
 37 
Compression: Current specification includes 7 compression modes, including uncompressed mode (fixed point).  Tests 38 
should cover each one of these modes   39 
 fixed-point 40 
 block floating-point 41 
 block scaling 42 
 mu-law 43 
 modulation compression 44 
 Block Floating Point + selective RE sending 45 
 Modulation Compression + selective RE sending 46 
 47 
IQ Bit Width: For fixed-point, block floating point, block scaling and mu-law compression, IQ information can be 48 
represented using different bit width (1-16 bits). To optimize test time, tests should be performed on a subset of bit 49 
widths  50 
 9 bits 51 
 14 bits  52 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       266 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Overview of Compression Test Methodology 1 
A common test methodology and structure will be used across all compression test cases. Each one of the test cases will 2 
be defined with specific input parameters and expected output values.  3 
To minimize influence of the Radio’s RF performance to the test results, the test methodology will be based on a 4 
relative comparison between modulated signal measurements performed on a TDD test frame with uncompressed IQ 5 
(fixed 16 bits) and measurements on the same test frame using compressed IQ. The test will verify that the difference 6 
between measurements fits within an acceptable range for the test to pass. 7 
For downlink test, the modulated signal measurement is performed by a signal analyzer on the antenna port of the O-8 
RU.  9 
For uplink measurement, the modulated signal measurement is performed with the IQ extracted from the Uplink U-10 
Plane data sent by the O-RU on the O-RAN interface.  11 
The following paragraphs in this overview section outline the details of these common test methodologies.  12 
3.2.5.3.1.1 Test Frame 13 
TDD test methodology for compression will combine similar downlink and uplink test patterns used for FDD test. The 14 
main difference is that uplink and downlink tests are performed simultaneously for TDD.  15 
The test frames used for compression conformance test will be referred in this document as “NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-16 
TST-DL” TDD Downlink Standard Compression Test frame and “NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-UL” TDD Uplink 17 
Standard Compression Test frame. They are 5G NR frames based on the description in section 3.2.1.1.3 For scenario #3 18 
(Conducted TDD Tests for FR1 Radios) with specific attributes described below. 19 
The Downlink UC-Plane test stimulus file includes the C-Plane and U-Plane messages that require the O-RU to 20 
transmit on the downlink the NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-DL test frame.  21 
The Uplink C-Plane test stimulus file includes the C-Plane messages that require the O-RU to provide the uplink U-22 
Plane messages according to the NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-UL test frame received by the O-RU on its antenna port. 23 
Signalling and IQ information will be based on various compression schemes 24

3.2.5.3.1.2 Test Frame Power  3 
To ensure that the compressed IQ exponent value is properly tested, each symbol of the test frame will include 3 4 
sections with different power levels.  The Power levels are relative powers to the first group of PRBs transmitted.  Any 5 
valid 3GPP power level may be used for the first set of PRBs as long as the power levels of the remaining PRBs are 6 
also valid.  Figure 3.2.5.3-1 below shows PRB power relative to the first set of PRBs. 7 
    0 dB for the bottom third of total PRBs in the symbol (referred as PDSCH0) 8 
 -10 dB for the middle third of total PRBs in the symbol (referred as PDSCH1) 9 
 -20 dB for the upper third of total PRBs in the symbol (referred as PDSCH2) 10 
 11 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       269 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
The spectrum representation of the frame shown in Figure 3.2.5.3-1 below highlights the various power levels for each 1 
group of PRBS within a symbol.  2 
 3 
Figure 3.2.5.3-1 PRB Spectrum Power Visualization 4 
 5 
3.2.5.3.1.3 Test Frame User data  6 
To validate that user data has not been impacted by compression, the test payload for the 3 sections is each based on an  7 
individual PN23 sequence that will be measured and compared by the test apparatus.   8 
3.2.5.3.1.4 Test Frame Modulation Scheme 9 
To maximise coverage on the compressed IQ mantissa value, the test frame will use the highest possible modulation 10 
(256 QAM modulation for downlink).  An example measurement is show in Table 3.2.5.3-3. 11 
 12 
Table 3.2.5.3-3 Example User Data Modulation Validation 13 
 14 
3.2.5.3.1.5 Summary of Required Measurements for Compression Tests 15 
3 measurements types will be required for downlink tests and 4 measurements will be required for uplink tests.  16 
 Power level:  Using the test frames (NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-DL and NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL) 17 
sent twice with both compressed and uncompressed IQ data, power level measurements are performed to 18 
validate compression algorithms influence on Exponent (udCompParam).  19 
The Power level measurements are called: 20 
For downlink 21 
 22 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH0 in dBm 23 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH0 in dBm 24 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH1 in dBm 25 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH1 in dBm 26 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH2 in dBm 27 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH2 in dBm 28 
 29 
For Uplink 30 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-UL-PUSCH0 in dBm 31 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-UL-PUSCH0 in dBm 32 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-UL-PUSCH1 in dBm 33 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-UL-PUSCH1 in dBm 34 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-UL-PUSCH2 in dBm 35 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-UL-PUSCH2 in dBm 36 
 37 
For the test to pass, the difference between compressed and uncompressed measurements should be within an 38 
acceptable range, called 39 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       270 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
o ACC_PWR_PDSCH0 = ± 1dB 1 
o ACC_PWR_PDSCH1 = ± 1dB 2 
o ACC_PWR_PDSCH2 = ± 1dB 3 
o  4 
 EVM:  Using a common test frame sent twice with both compressed and uncompressed IQ data, EVM 5 
measurements comparisons between uncompressed IQ and compressed IQ will help validate acceptable 6 
compression influence on signal quality.  7 
 8 
For downlink these 6 EVM measurements required: 9 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH0 in % 10 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH0  in % 11 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH1  in % 12 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH1  in % 13 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH2  in % 14 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH2  in % 15 
 16 
For uplink these 6 EVM measurements required: 17 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PUSCH0 in % 18 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PUSCH0  in % 19 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PUSCH1  in % 20 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PUSCH1  in % 21 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PUSCH2  in % 22 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PUSCH2  in % 23 
 24 
For the test to pass, the difference between the compressed and uncompressed measurements for the same 25 
PDSCH signal must be within the following range: 26 
o ACC_EVM_PDSCH0 ≤ 4 percentage points 27 
o ACC_EVM_PDSCH1 ≤ 4 percentage points 28 
o ACC_EVM_PDSCH2 ≤ 4 percentage points 29 
 30 
An example measurement showing both power and EVM is shown below in Figure 3.2.5.3-2 31 
Example Compression EVM Measurement. 32 
 33 
  
Figure 3.2.5.3-2 Example Compression EVM Measurement 34 
 35 
 Payload Data Integrity:  comparing user data between the O-RAN test frame and the RF measurement to 36 
validate that compression does not influence user data.  The User data measurements are called: 37 
For Downlink 38 
 39 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-DL-PDSCH0  40 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-DL-PDSCH1  41 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-DL-PDSCH2  42 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-DL-PDSCH0  43 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-DL-PDSCH1  44 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-DL-PDSCH2  45 
 46 
For Uplink 47

o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-UL-PUSCH2  4 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-UL-PUSCH0  5 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-UL-PUSCH1  6 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-UL-PUSCH2  7 
 8 
For the data integrity test to pass, the comparison between stimulus payload and the measured payload should 9 
be free of any errors (i.e. BER=0).  10 
 11 
 Presence/Absence of U-Plane Header measurements (uplink only): to validate that in the U-Plane PRB 12 
header, the udCompHeader, “reserved” and udCompParam fields are correctly absent for Static compression 13 
mode or present for other compression modes.  14 
 15

3.2.5.3.1.7 Results Analysis 2 
In general, for each specific Compression Test in this conformance test document, the test will pass if the following 3 
conditions are met: 4 
 Power measurement differences between Uncompressed and Compressed are within acceptable range  5 
 EVM measurement difference between Uncompressed and Compressed are within acceptable range  6 
 Data integrity measurements show no data corruption 7 
 Uplink U-Plane Header measurements exclude fields for static compression 8 
 9 
These test criteria and expected results are summarized below in Table 3.2.5.3-6 Compression Test Acceptance 10 
Threshold Criteria. 11

Table 3.2.5.3-6 Compression Test Acceptance Threshold Criteria 1

 TDD UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Static Format (SF) Fixed-Point 3 
(FP)  4 
A. Test Description and Applicability 5 
This test is CONDITIONALMANDATORY and shall be performed if the O-RU supports this compression format. 6 
 7 
The purpose of this test is to: 8 
 Validate correct encoding of IQ data under the following conditions.  9 
o RU Static compression configurations 10 
o Fixed point IQ data format 11 
o Selection of 2 supported bit width: 9 bits, 14 bits  12 
o Uplink / downlink 13 
 Validate that in the U-Plane PRB header, the udCompHeader, “reserved” and udCompParam fields are 14 
not present  15 
 16 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 17 
The test uses the setup and methodology described in section 3.2.5.3.1. 18 
 19 
 20 
C. Test Methodology 21 
a.  Initial Conditions 22 
 The O-RU is started 23 
 Fronthaul Ethernet interface configured for communication between TER and the DUT. 24 
 O-RU synchronized with TER using S-Plane 25 
 Communication established between TER and the DUT such that it is possible to exchange U-Plane and 26 
C-Plane messages  27 
 Signal Analyzer connected to DUT’s antenna port and setup according to DUT RF output configuration 28 
 Signal Source connected to DUT’s antenna port and setup according to DUT RF input configuration 29 
 30 
b.  Procedure 31 
For each supported bit width (9 bits, 14 bits), the following tests need to be performed: 32 
  33 
1. Launch Uncompressed Test  34 
 Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, put the O-RU into a static configuration with the downlink 35 
and uplink configured as follows: no compression, (16 bits) 36 
 Arm Signal Analyzers and Signal Source 37 
o Arm Signal analyzer to capture the next Frame  38 
o Arm Signal Source to generate the Frame NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL 39 
 Arm the CUSM emulator to send the TDD O-RAN test frame, including 40 
o Downlink: CU-plane of “uncompressed” NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-UNC-16B test stimulus 41 
file to the DUT 42 
o Uplink: C-plane of “uncompressed” NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-UL-UNC-16B test stimulus file 43 
to the DUT 44 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       276 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 ARM CUSM-E to capture the Uplink U-Plane Data from the DUT 1 
 Launch the test until: 2 
o RF Signal Analyzer has captured the downlink frame 3 
o CUSM-E has captured the uplink U_plane data  4 
2. Uncompressed Downlink Measurements  5 
 With the RF Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 power measurements  6 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH0 in dBm 7 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH1 in dBm 8 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-DL PDSCH2 in dBm 9 
 With the RF Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 EVM measurements  10 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH0 in % 11 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH1 in % 12 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH2 in % 13 
 With the RF Signal Analyzer, check Data integrity measurements  14 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-DL-PDSCH0  15 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-DL-PDSCH1  16 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-DL-PDSCH2 17 
3. Uncompressed Uplink Measurements  18 
 Extract IQ information from Capture U-Plane trace of the CUSM-E 19 
 Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 power measurements  20 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH0 in dBm 21 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH1 in dBm 22 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH2 in dBm 23 
 24 
 Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 EVM measurements  25 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH0 in % 26 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH1 in % 27 
o CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH2 in % 28 
 29 
 Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform Data integrity measurements  30 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-UL-PDSCH0  31 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-UL-PDSCH1  32 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-UL-PDSCH2 33 
4. Launch “compressed” Test  34 
 Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, put the O-RU into a static configuration with the downlink 35 
and uplink configured as follows: Fixed point, 9-bit (then 14 bits) 36 
 Arm Signal Analyzers and Signal Sources 37 
o Arm Signal analyzer to capture the next Frame  38 
o Arm Signal Source to generate the Frame NR-FR1-CMP-TST-FRAME-UL 39 
 Arm the CUSM emulator to send the TDD O-RAN test frame, including 40 
o Downlink: CU-plane of the “Compressed” NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-FPF-9B (then 14B) 41 
test stimulus file to the DUT 42 
o Uplink: CU-plane of the “Compressed” NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-UL-FPF-9B (then 14B) test 43 
stimulus file to the DUT 44 
 ARM CUSM-E to capture the Uplink U-Plane Data from the DUT 45 
 Launch the test until: 46 
o RF Signal Analyzer has captured the downlink frame 47 
o CUSM-E has captured the uplink U_plane data 48 
5. Compressed Downlink Measurements  49 
 With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 power measurements  50 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH0 in dBm 51 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH1 in dBm 52 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH2 in dBm 53 
 With the Signal Analyzer, perform the 3 EVM measurements  54 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH0 in % 55 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH1 in % 56 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH2 in % 57 
 With the Signal Analyzer, check Data integrity measurements  58 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-DL-PDSCH0  59 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-DL-PDSCH1  60

Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       277 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-DL-PDSCH2 1 
6. Validate Downlink conformance conditions  2 
 Power measurements within acceptable range  3 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH0 and CMP-Compressed-4 
Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH0 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH0 range 5 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH1 and CMP-Compressed-6 
Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH1 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH1 range 7 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH2 and CMP-Compressed-8 
Measured-Power-DL-PDSCH2 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH2 range 9 
 EVM measurements within acceptable range  10 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH0 and CMP-Compressed-11 
Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH0 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH0 12 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH1 and CMP-Compressed-13 
Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH1 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH1 14 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH2 and CMP-Compressed-15 
Measured-EVM-DL-PDSCH2 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH2 16 
 BER Measurements show no errors  17 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-DL-PDSCH0 =0 18 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-DL-PDSCH1 =0 19 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-DL-PDSCH2 =0 20 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-DL-PDSCH0 =0 21 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-DL-PDSCH1 =0 22 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-DL-PDSCH2 =0 23 
7. Compressed Uplink Measurements  24 
 Extract IQ information from Capture U-Plane trace 25 
 Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 power measurements  26 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH0 in dBm 27 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH1 in dBm 28 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH2 in dBm 29 
 Using the Signal Analyzer software, perform the 3 EVM measurements  30 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH0 in % 31 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH1 in % 32 
o CMP-Compressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH2 in % 33 
 Using the Signal Analyzer software, check Data integrity measurements  34 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-UL-PDSCH0  35 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-UL-PDSCH1  36 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-UL-PDSCH2 37 
8. Validate Uplink conformance conditions  38 
 Validate correct U-Plane PRB header structure  39 
o U-Plane udComphdr (per section 6.3.3.13 of [2]) 40 
o U-Plane udCompParam (per section 6.3.3.15 of [2]) 41 
 Validate that the power measurements within acceptable range  42 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH0 and CMP-Compressed-43 
Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH0 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH0 range 44 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH1 and CMP-Compressed-45 
Measured-Power-UL_PDSCH1 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH1 range 46 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-Power-UL-PDSCH2 and CMP-Compressed-47 
Measured-Power-UL PDSCH2 is within ACC_PWR_PDSCH2 range 48 
 Validate EVM measurements within acceptable range  49 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH0 and CMP-Compressed-50 
Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH0 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH0 51 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH1 and CMP-Compressed-52 
Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH1 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH1 53 
o Difference between CMP-Uncompressed-Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH2 and CMP-Compressed-54 
Measured-EVM-UL-PDSCH2 is less than ACC_EVM_PDSCH2 55 
 Validate that the BER Measurements show no errors  56 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-UL-PDSCH0 = 0 57 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-UL-PDSCH1 = 0 58 
o CMP-Uncompressed-BER-UL-PDSCH2 = 0 59 
o CMP-Compressed-BER-UL-PDSCH0 = 0 60

 TDD UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression Static Format (SF) Modulation-23 
Compressed Format 24 
A. Test Description and Applicability 25 
This test is CONDITIONALMANDATORY and shall be performed if the O-RU supports this compression format. 26 
 27 
This modulation compression format scenario is a static format scenario, based on 3.2.5.3.2 with some important 28 
differences 29 
 The purpose is to validate Radio Unit’s correct interpretation of the Modulation compression parameters 30 
used in the Section Extension Type =4  31 
 The test will only verify DL correct encoding of IQ information, as the Modulation Compression model is 32 
not applicable for uplink 33 
 As the Modulation Compression model does not require IQ bit width to be setup, there is no need to run 34 
multiple compression tests for various IQ bit width.  35 
 The CUSM_E must generate:  36 
 37 
Stimulus File Name Description 
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-UNC-16B Static Downlink Uncompressed (CU-plane) 
NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-MC Static Downlink Modulation Compression  
Table 3.2.5.3-7 SFM Modulation Compression 38 
 39 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 40 
Same as 3.2.5.3.2. 41 
 42 
C. Test Methodology 43 
Same as 3.2.5.3.2 with Static Modulation Compression test patterns 44 
 NR-FR1-TDD-CMP-TST-ST-DL-MC 45 
 46 
Via the M-Plane or another suitable mechanism, put the O-RU into a static configuration with the downlink 47 
configured as follow: Modulation Compression   48 
 Validation only of the downlink measurements  49
