Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       307 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Static SRS Allocation UL – Resource Allocation 1 
A. Test Description and Applicability 2 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 3 
 4 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the O-RU can support static SRS configuration through the M-Plane.  This is an 5 
uplink only test so there is no corresponding downlink test for TDD.  The O-RU must report through the M-Plane 6 
that it supports static configuration of SRS. 7 
 8 
This test will use the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4  for FR2.  The test 9 
will have the CUSM emulator configure the O-RU, through the M-Plane, with a section of time/frequency resources 10 
reserved for static uplink SRS, these will be limited to the uplink slots of the TDD frame.  The signal source will be 11 
programmed to send simulated SRS signals in a subset of those resources.  The O-RU should receive this SRS 12 
signals and pass them through to the CUSM emulator using U-Plane messages.  Note, there will be no C-Plane 13 
messages sent from the CUSM emulator and the O-RU.  The signal generator will signal power levels at least 30 dB 14 
above Reference Sensitivity power Level described in TS 138.141-1 Table 7.2.5-1.  This is to improve the 15 
likelihood that all data will be received by the radio correctly since we are not interested in testing receiver 16 
sensitivity but only the O-RAN protocol compliance.  The placement of the time frequency resources is not 17 
specified in this test so it may be placed in any uplink slots of the TDD frame. 18 
 19 
The TER (Test Equipment, O-RU) generates an uplink SRS signal on the antenna connector or TAB connector. The 20 
TER will capture the U-Plane messages generated by the DUT and validate whether the payload matches the uplink 21 
signal as well as beam characteristics. The metric used to validate that the signal received by the CUSM emulator 22 
matches the signal sent by the signal generator will be EVM as described in Annex H.7 of 3GPP 38.141.  While 23 
some 3GPP test documents (e.g., TS 38.521 section 6.4.2.1.3) suggest treating the EVM requirements for physical 24 
Zadoff-Chu sequences such as PRACH the same as QPSK for EVM requirements, this document will decrease the 25 
required EVM to the level specified for 64 QAM.  The purpose of this is to ensure that there is no chance of false 26 
positives where a random, mistaken signal sent by the O-RU closely mimics the test signal used by the TER.  Since 27 
there are no impairments made to the uplink SRS signal this should be well within the capabilities of the O-RU. 28 
 29 
 30 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 31 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4 for FR2 of this document.  32 
The O-RU must indicate is supports static SRS allocation. The test numerology will be 30 kHz subcarrier spacing 33 
and 100 MHz Bandwidth for FR1 and 120 kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth for FR2.  It will be 34 
for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. Note this signal 35 
may be changed to any of the 3GPP sensitivity test signals in 3GPP TS 138.141-1 if the radio does not support the 36 
numerology and bandwidth used in this test.  The test signal described in this section will be used if the radio 37 
supports that numerology and bandwidth.  38 
 39 
C. Test Methodology 40 
a. Initial Conditions 41 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-42 
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 43 
port and configure the source to transmit the required SRS test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from the 44 
CUSM-E.  The signal source power level should be adjusted to at least 30 dB above the setting used in the 45 
3GPP receiver sensitivity test. 46 
Implicit in this Initial set up is statically configuring O-RU with a section of time/frequency resources for statis 47 
SRS signals. 48 
.   49 
b. Procedure 50 
 Build an SRS signal in the signal generator that fits in the preconfigured time frequency resources set in the 51 
initial configuration. 52 
 Load the waveform into the signal source: 53 
 Configure Signal Source to play test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it receives a 54 
trigger signal from the O-DU emulator that signals the start of a frame boundary. 55 
 Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  56 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       308 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the Antenna port 1 
connected 2 
 TER will arrange U-Plane messages according to time and frequency 3 
 Extract IQ information  4 
 Calculate EVM of the SRS signal received by the CUSM emulator to the ideal signal generated by the 5 
signal source. Use the method described in TS 38.141 Annex H.7 to perform the calculation. 6 
 7 
 8 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  9 
3. The verdict is “Test pass” if the calculated EVM is less than 8%. 10 
4. If any of the test conditions are not true, the verdict for the whole test is "Fail" 11 
 12 
 13 
 14 
 UC Plane O-RU Base Class TDD Test UL – Static PRACH allocation 15 
A. Test Description and Applicability 16 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 17 
 18 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the O-RU can support static PRACH configuration through the M-Plane.  This 19 
is an uplink only test so there is no corresponding downlink test for downlink slots.  The O-RU must report through 20 
the M-Plane that it supports static configuration of PRACH.  The concept is to repeat the spirit of test 3.2.3.8.1 21 
(5GNR  PRACH test) without sending any C-Plane type 3 messages and configuring the O-RU using only the M-22 
Plane. 23 
 24 
TER will setup the signal generator with a PRACH test waveform according to TS 38.141-1 section 8.4.1 and A.6. 25 
The test waveform will contain the same preamble ID repeated by following the timing offset scheme specified in 26 
the figures 8.4.1.4.2-2 or 8.4.1.4.2-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected PRACH format. 27 
This is an example for FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3 configuration index 132 (From Table 28 
6.3.3.2-3, unpaired spectrum), at each occasion the time offset of the same preamble index (selected according to 29 
table A.6-1 TS 38.141.1) is incremented by 100nsec starting from 0 up to 800nsec (9 occasions per frame). Each 30 
PRACH occasion is at the beginning of the first nine used sub-frames. The scheme is repeated every frame. The test 31 
must be conducted using a PRACH format and configuration index the radio has reported it supports 32 
 33 
 34 
Figure 3.2.6.1-3 FR1 SCS 30Kz 100MHz Format A3, Unpaired Spectrum, configuration index 132 35 
 36 
According to the PRACH waveform setting, the TER will generate a corresponding sequence of M-Plane messages 37 
which include the following parameters (According to the M-Plane specification and the PRACH configuration index 38 
supported): 39 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       309 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
grouping static-prach-configuration  1 
• leaf pattern-period - "Period after which static PRACH patterns are repeated. Unit: number of 2 
frames." 3 
• leaf guard-tone-low-re - "Number of REs occupied by the low guard tones." 4 
• leaf num-prach-re - "Number of contiguous PRBs per data section description“ 5 
• leaf guard-tone-high-re - "Number of REs occupied by the high guard tones.“ 6 
• leaf sequence-duration - "Duration of single sequence of the PRACH. Sequence may be considered as 7 
'single PRACH symbol’” 8 
• list prach-patterns - key prach-pattern-id - "Provides a PRACH pattern. Each record in the list 9 
represents a single PRACH occasion. Number of list entries cannot exceed max-prach-patterns“ 10 
• leaf prach-pattern-id - "Supplementary parameter acting as key for prach-pattern list.“ 11 
• leaf number-of-repetitions - "This parameter defines number of PRACH repetitions in 12 
PRACH occasion, to which the section control is applicable 13 
• leaf number-of-occasions - "This parameter informs how many consecutive PRACH 14 
occasions is described by the PRACH Pattern” 15 
• leaf re-offset – “Offset between the start of the lowest-frequency RE of the lowest frequency 16 
PRB and the start of the lowest frequency RE belonging to the PRACH occasion.  The re-17 
offset is configured as number of PRACH REs. 18 
• list occasion-parameters – “list of cp-lengths, gp-lengths and beam-ids applicable per each 19 
PRACH occasion in PRACH pattern. Note: the number of records in this list MUST be equal 20 
to value of parameter number-of-occasions.“ 21 
• leaf occasion-id - "Supplementary parameter acting as key in 'occasion-parameters' 22 
list“ 23 
• leaf cp-length - "Cyclic prefix length. See CUS-plane specification for detailed 24 
description.“ 25 
• leaf gp-length - "Guard period length.“ 26 
• leaf beam-id  - "This parameter defines the beam pattern to be applied to the U-27 
Plane data. beamId = 0 means no beamforming operation will be performed." 28 
• leaf frame-number - "This parameter is an index inside the pattern-length, such that PRACH 29 
occasion is happening for SFN which fulfills following equation: [SFN mod pattern-length = 30 
frame-id]“ 31 
• leaf sub-frame-id - "Identifier of sub-frame of the PRACH occasion. Value is interpreted in 32 
the same way as subframeId field in a section description of a C-Plane message.“ 33 
• leaf time-offset - "This parameter defines the time-offset from the start of the sub-frame to 34 
the start of the first Cyclic Prefix of PRACH pattern" 35 
 36 
By the corresponding U-Plane messages in the uplink direction, the TER will try to detect the presence of the 37 
corresponding preamble at the expected timing offset and calculate the probability of detection Pd according to the 38 
definition in TS38.141-1 section 8.4.1.1.  39 
The signal will be exercised at only one O-RU port without adding any external AWGN power level or multipath 40 
fading profile and at a power level avoiding detection errors due to poor SNR (rule described in the sub-section C of 41 
this scenario class). 42 
The test will have the CUSM emulator configure the O-RU, through the M-Plane, with a section of time/frequency 43 
resources reserved for static uplink PRACH.  The default is the PRACH configuration described in 3GPP above, but the 44 
test may be conducted with changes if the radio does not support those exact configurations.  The signal source will be 45 
programmed to send simulated PRACH signals in those resources.  The O-RU should receive this PRACH signal and 46 
pass them through to the CUSM emulator using U-Plane messages.  Note, there will be no C-Plane messages sent from 47 
the CUSM emulator and the O-RU. 48 
 49 
 50 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 51 
O-RU must have a conducted antenna port (FR1) or TAB connector. 52 
By the M-plane or by manufacturer declaration, TER will detect all the supported SCSs, FFT sizes and carrier 53 
bandwidths by the O-RU. It is assumed that only one combination of the three above parameters supported by the O-54 
RU is enough to validate the test. TER shall generate M-Plane messages according to one of the PRACH formats in 55 
table A.6-1 TS 38.141. TER will choose the format either according to the manufacturer declaration item D.103 56 
“PRACH format and SCS” in TS 38.141-1 or according to the format information obtained by the M-plane in case O-57 
RU implements this feature. If more formats are claimed, only one shall be selected to reduce the test time, preference 58 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       310 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
will be given to a format specified in Table A.6.1 TS 38.141. It is assumed that the O-RU manufacturer will support at 1 
least one in that table. For the case of long preambles, it is assumed format 0 is always supported since this is the only 2 
one shown in the table A.6-1 TS 38.141. 3 
 4 
C. Test Methodology 5 
  6 
a: Initial Conditions 7 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using M-8 
Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna 9 
port and configure the source to transmit the required PRACH test signal upon receiving a trigger signal from 10 
the CUSM-E.   11 
Implicit in this Initial set up is statically configuring O-RU with a section of time/frequency resources for static 12 
PRACH signals. 13 
b: Procedure 14 
 Set signal generator power by the following method: 15 
a. Select SNR from the scenario with two RX antennas and AWGN propagation condition in table 8.4.1.5-16 
1, 8.4.1.5-2 or 8.4.1.5-3 TS 38.141-1 depending on the selected SCS and PRACH format. 17 
b. Select the AWGN power level according to the configured SCS and channel bandwidth in table 18 
8.4.1.4.2-1 TS 38.141-1 and 38.141-1and multiply by the PRACH signal bandwidth.  19 
c. The output power will be given by the formula (SNR+Noise power – 3dB) rounded to the first decimal 20 
digit. Extra 3dB are to compensate that SNR and noise power are selected from the two RX ports test 21 
case and this test procedure requires only one O-RU port. 22 
 23 
For example, for the FR1 – SCS=30 KHz – BW=100MHz – Format A3 SNR is -13.5dB and noise level 24 
is -70.1dBm/98.28MHz. signal generator power = -13.5dB -70.1dBm/98.28MHz*(139*30 KHz)-3dB 25 
=-19.5dBm.  26 
 Set signal generator frequency offset to the central carrier frequency. PRACH will be mapped over 27 
frequency according to msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter equal to 0. PRACH format is set according 28 
to what TER has selected from the manufacturer declarations. 29 
 Start PRACH waveform generation on the signal generator.  Ensure the test frame is repeated enough times 30 
to generate a statistically significant number of PRACH occasions.  That is at least 10 occasions. 31 
 TER will perform PRACH detection per each PRACH occasion in each frame sent and compare the result 32 
with the expected preamble ID and the expected timing offset. Since the external AWGN and fading 33 
generator are not present the time error tolerance should be low, TER will use the time error tolerance in 34 
table 8.4.1.1-1 for AWGN case according to the corresponding PRACH format and PRACH SCS. A counter 35 
of successful detections is incremented at every matching. The probability of detection is given by the ratio 36 
between that counter and the number of the expected received PRACH occasions within the test time. 37 
 Repeat the test procedure by setting msg1-FrequencyStart ( ) parameter to the right edge of the 38 
configured carrier bandwidth in order to exercise a different frequency offset number 39 
  40 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  41 
a. Test is pass if the probability of detection is 100%. 42 
 43 
 44 
 UC Plane O-RU Scenario Class Extended using section extension 13 for frequency 45 
hopping UL/DL – Resource Allocation 46 
A. Test Description and Applicability 47 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 48 
 49 
The purpose of this test is to validate the capability of the O-RU to correctly interpret section extension 13, 50 
frequency hopping, for the uplink.  Note, since frequency hopping is only used in uplink in 5G NR this test will be   51 
limited to the uplink slots of the basic TDD signal. 52 
startRAn
startRAn

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       311 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
Using the standard TDD test frame described in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4  for FR2 the O-DU emulator 2 
(i.e., O-RAN interface of the TER described in section 2.1) will generate C-Plane and U-Plane messages that 3 
require the O-RU to transmit on thedownlink and uplink the specified signal using section extension 13 in just the 4 
uplink downlink.  The downlink portion of the test is not part of this test and may be any signal or no downlink 5 
signal at all. 6 
 7 
In this test stock data section definition C will be used to exercise the non-contiguous RB allocation, all 273 PRBs 8 
(48 of the 51 in the uplink slots) or the max number of PRBs per symbol for the highest numerology the radio 9 
supports will be used in this test. 10 
 11 
Only one spatial stream on one antenna will be used.  This test is applicable for Category A and Category B radios 12 
(No precoding is required).  All uplink user data will be a PN23 sequence. 13 
 14 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 15 
The O-RU must support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4  for FR2 of this document.  16 
The test numerology will be 30 KHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth as described in section 3.2.1.1.3 17 
for FR1 and 120 kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz bandwidth as described in section 3.2.1.1.4 for FR2.  It will 18 
be for 5G New Radio only. The radio must have conducted antenna ports (FR1) or TAB connectors. 19 
 20 
The radio must support section extension 13 as notified by the M-Plane.  The Signal Analyzer must have the ability 21 
to decode the downlink shared channel. 22 
 23 
C. Test Methodology 24 
a. Initial Conditions 25 
Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 26 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  Connect the signal analyzer to the 27 
O-RU antenna port and configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and 28 
demodulate the transmitted signal.  Connect the signal source to the O-RU antenna port and configure it as 29 
described below. 30 
b. Procedure 31 
Build an appropriate IQ signal as described above in section 3.2.1.1.3 for FR1 or 3.2.1.1.4 for FR2 in the 32 
CUSM emulator. In this case use a PN23 sequence for the downlink shared channel.  Build the appropriate 33 
test frame (uplink slots) for the signal source. Use the CUSM emulator control interface to build the 34 
appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the uplink and downlink signals. Every symbol used in the test 35 
should be described by a single section (DL-SCH that are used for the test, DMRS and DCI) using section 36 
type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test.  Encapsulate the IQ data in U-37 
Plane messages for downlink slots only. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 38 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal 39 
analyzer and allow it to demodulate and decode the test frame.  It will be the responsibility of the TER’s 40 
signal analyzer and source to coordinate downlink and uplink TDD transmissions.  The CUSM Emulator of 41 
the TER is responsible for receiving uplink U-Plane messages, extracting IQ and decoding it to bits which 42 
can be compared to those sent by the signal source. 43 
 44 
 45 
For the downlink slots and symbols: Any signal may be used if needed by the TER or no downlink signal 46 
may be used. 47 
 48 
For the uplink sections and symbols: Load uplink test waveform (G-FR1-A1-5: SCS30k_51RB for FR1 49 
or G-FR2-A3-1: SCS120k_66RB for FR2) on the RF Signal Source.  Note this signal should contain a new 50 
PN23 sequence as user data in PRBs 0 through 50 for symbol 6 and PRBs 100 through 151 for symbol 7.  51 
This will be copied for all uplink slots. The remainder of the test waveform is as described in 3GPP.  52 
Configure Signal Source to play test waveforms on 10ms frame boundaries starting when it receives a 53 
trigger signal from the O-DU emulator that C-Plane messages have been sent.  Load a C-Plane message on 54 
Test Equipment O-RU (TER) – Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane 55 
message that describes this uplink signal. This section should have startSymbolId = 6, numPrbc = 51, and 56 
section extension 13 attached.  The section extension should have nextSymbolId = 7 and nextStartPrbc = 57 
100. 58 
 59 
Steps: 60

Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       312 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Arm Test Equipment O-RU (TER) to capture DUT fronthaul Messages  1 
 Launch test to play the C-Plane messages and the downlink U-Plane messages (if needed) and 2 
trigger the source to play the RF signal on a frame boundary.  3 
 Play messages to the O-RU respecting the timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1.  Repeat 4 
the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 5 
demodulate and decode the frame. 6 
 Record U-Plane messages from DUT for a complete frame and the eAxC corresponding to the 7 
Antenna port  8 
 Extract IQ information from the captured U-Plane messages 9 
 Extract IQ information from the signal analyzer for downlink slots (if needed) 10 
 Extract Payload for both signals 11 
 Compare payload binary sequences  12 
 13 
 14 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  15 
1. The signal extracted by the U-Plane messages (uplink) should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance 16 
requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 17 
2. The verdict is “Test pass” if the test frame received by the signal analyzer contains two U-Plane messages for 18 
this section ID one containing the PN23 sequence for the first 51 PRBs in symbol 6 and PRBs 100 through 151 19 
for symbol #7 containing the PN23 sequence sent by the signal source for those PRBs. 20

________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       313 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming (BFM)  1 
This section describes the beamforming conformance testing for ORAN fronthaul interface. The tests do not aim to test 2 
the O-RU beamforming performance or capabilities but to test that the O-RU under test focuses the RF energy or 3 
sensitivity into a specific direction and with a specific granularity following the O-DU emulator (i.e., O-RAN interface 4 
of the TER described in section 2.1) C-Plane messages.  5 
Unless stated otherwise in a test case, the following statements apply to all the test cases defined in this section: 6 
 It is based on Over-the-Air (OTA) testing with a setup such as described in Section 2.1 and it may be applied to 7 
any O-RU DUTs, whether the O-RU DUTs have conducted antenna ports or TAB connectors or not.  8 
 Section 3.2.1.1.2 for scenario #2 non-conducted OTA FDD FR1 radios contains a description of test setups, as 9 
mentioned by 3GPP TS 37.843 defines various radiated test systems. If not explicitly mentioned, scenario #4 10 
non-conducted OTA TDD tests for FR1 and FR2 radios will inherit those descriptions.  11 
 12 
 It applies to  Category A and  Category B O-RU DUTs. 13 
 14 
 It applies to LTE and/or 5G New Radio O-RU DUTs.  In both cases, precoding is not required in any test case.   15 
 16 
 If O-RU DUT supports Analog Beamforming (i.e. time domain beamforming), all the U-Plane test frames are 17 
defined by segmenting the Stock Test A: 1 section per symbol.  The definition of this Stock Test A can be 18 
found in Figure 3.2.1.1-2 and the description accompanying this Figure.  Each slot shall include multiple 19 
sections (one per symbol within the slot) and only one beam at a time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore 20 
only one beam can be tested per slot. 21 
 22 
 If O-RU DUT supports Digital Beamforming (i.e. frequency domain beamforming), all the U-Plane test frames 23 
are defined by segmenting the Stock Test B: 2 sections per symbol definition as shown in Figure 3.2.1.1-2.  24 
Each slot shall include multiple sections (two per symbol within the slot) and only one beam per section at a 25 
time (i.e. one beamId at a time) and therefore up to two different beams can be tested per slot. 26 
 27 
 If O-RU DUT supports multiple polarizations, it is up to the TER to determine if the testing is carried out for 28 
each polarization separately or multiple polarizations at the same time. In any case, it is important to guarantee 29 
that the correct eAxC_ID for the correct polarization (or polarizations) is exercised.  30 
 31 
 For O-RU DUT that support LTE:  32 
o Downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP E-TM1.1 test frame for TDD, based on uplink/downlink 33 
configuration 3 and special subframe configuration 8  (Section 6.1.1.1 TS 36.141) with 20MHz bandwidth 34 
(100 RB) as shown in Figure 3.2.6.2-1. 35 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       314 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
Figure 3.2.6.2-1 E-TM1.1 TDD 20 MHz 100RB 2 
If 20MHz is not supported by the O-RU DUT, then it will use the highest bandwidth supported by the O-3 
RU DUT. 4 
o Uplink test will use a standard 3GPP UL RMC Configuration definition for TDD (TS36.521-1 Annex 5 
A.2.3) and power levels at least 30dB above Reference Sensitivity power level with 20MHz bandwidth 6 
(100 RB) as shown in Figure 3.2.6.2-2. 7 
o  8 
 9 
Figure 3.2.6.2-2 UL RMC TDD 20 MHz 100 RB. TS 36.521-1 A.2.3.1.1 10 
If 20MHz is not supported by the O-RU DUT, then it will use the highest bandwidth supported by the O-11 
RU DUT. 12 
 13 
 For O-RU DUT that support 5G NR:  14 
o NR FR1 test models described in TS 38.141-1 are also applicable for BS type 1-O conformance testing. 15 
FR1 TDD downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP NR-FR1-TM1.1 test frame for TDD.  16 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       315 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
o FR2 TDD downlink tests will use a standard 3GPP NR-FR2-TM1.1 test frame for TDD in (Section 1 
4.9.2 TS 38.141-2) of the Radiated Transmitter Characteristic Test section (Section 6 TS 38.141-2) as 2 
described in section 3.2.1.1. The test numerology will be preferably 120KHz subcarrier spacing and 3 
100 MHz Bandwidth, or lower depending on DUT capability. If not supported, then it will use any 4 
other supported subcarrier spacing and the highest bandwidth of the O-RU DUT. 5 
o NR FR1 test models described in TS 38.141-1 are also applicable for BS type 1-O conformance testing. 6 
FR1 TDD uplink tests will use a standard 3GPP G-FR1_A1-5_SCS30kHz_51RB test frame for TDD.  7 
 8 
o FR2 TDD uplink tests will use a standard 3GPP Reference Sensitivity level definition (Section 7.2 and 9 
Annex A TS 38.141-2) of the Radiated Receiver Characteristic Test section (Section 7 TS 38.141-2). 10 
The O-RU manufacturer declares a minimum EIS level for the considered OTA sensitivity direction 11 
declaration. The power levels inclining from the angle of arrival that should be tested (RoAoA) is at 12 
least 30dB above the OSDD EIS Reference Sensitivity power level. The test numerology will be 13 
preferably 120kHz subcarrier spacing and 100 MHz Bandwidth based on G-FR2-A1-3 in TS 38.141-2,  14 
or lower depending on DUT capability. Otherwise, it will use any available subcarrier spacing and the 15 
highest bandwidth supported by the O-RU DUT. 16 
 17 
  Radiated tests coordinate system is based on the coordinate system defined in section 10.5.1. of  [2]. 18 
 19 
 20 
 The O-RU DUT must: 21 
o support the default parameters in section 3.2.1.1.2 of this document. 22 
o have installed current release of shipping software.  23 
o be fully calibrated up to Radiated Interface Boundary (RIB) as defined in 3GPP TS 38.141-2. It is expected 24 
to be calibrated by O-RU vendor prior to testing.  25 
 26 
 27 
 The TER must: 28 
o be capable of carrying out any signal processing required to generate and demodulate 3GPP compliant 29 
waveforms. 30 
o be able to calculate or extract the spherical beam direction via OTA measurements. 31 
o be able to generate and deliver signals with the required beam direction at the RIB point.  32 
o be fully calibrated up to the interface where it interacts with the DUT’s RIB. For that, a known test signal 33 
might be either injected by the TER into the O-RU DUT, or internally generated by the O-RU DUT, and 34 
the O-RU DUT must not apply any digital or analog beam forming to apply a directional characteristic to 35 
the known test signal.  One possible method to perform calibration uses injected C-Plane and U-Plane 36 
signals from TER into the O-RU and using C-Plane messages with beamID=0.  Alternatively, calibration 37 
methods for radiated test setups that are described in 3GPP TR37.941 can be used. 38 
o    39 
o  40 
 41 
 42 
 The O-DU emulator of the TER must: 43 
o be capable of generating and sending U-Plane messages containing 3GPP test frames following the 44 
corresponding Stock sectioning defined above, as well as be capable of capturing U-Plane messages and 45 
extracting 3GPP test frames (i.e. IQ data) from the captured U-Plane messages. 46 
o be capable of generating the C-Plane messages for, receiving, extracting and demodulating the 3GPP test 47 
frames following the corresponding Stock sectioning defined above. 48 
 49 
 The TER might have a single test antenna if a single beam direction and polarization is measured and an 50 
optional positioning method to perform directional radiation measurements sequentially, or multiple test 51 
antennas to perform directional radiation measurements and/or polarizations at the same time. 52 
 53 
 It is up to the TER on how to extract the beam direction and beam properties at the DUT’s RIB in order to 54 
match it with the manufacturer’s declaration. 55 
 56 
 The user payload will be generated as PN23 with a seed of all ones. 57 
 58 
 It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections: 59 
 Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 60 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       316 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Section 6.3.2 for U-Plane message layout 1 
 Section 6.3.3 for coding of applicable Information Elements 2 
 Section 10 for beamforming guidelines. 3 
 Annex J for beamforming methods description.  4 
 5 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – No Beamforming 6 
A. Test Description and Applicability 7 
This test is MANDATORY. 8 
 9 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 10 
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 11 
 12 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 13 
 Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of beam directions when O-RU DUT is operating with no 14 
beamforming. This list serves as indication of the expected transmitted beam direction in below evaluation.   15 
 16 
C. Test Methodology 17 
 18 
a. Initial Conditions 19 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 20 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  21 
 Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  22 
 Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4 and 23 
configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 24 
transmitted signal. 25 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4. 26 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 27 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.  28 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  29 
 30 
b. Procedure 31 
f. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 or NR-FR2-TM1.1 signal described above 32 
in the O-DU emulator.   33 
g. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 34 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-SCH 35 
and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 36 
h. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 37 
windows described in section 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.   38 
i. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 39 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 40 
j. Measure any metric/s that allows for extracting the transmitted beam direction from a single measurement, 41 
i.e. transform-based techniques, or take as many measurements of any metric/s from multiple angles, by 42 
for example rotating the O-RU, that allows for extracting beam direction from multiple measurement, i.e. 43 
beam scanning. 44 
 45 
 46 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  47 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer at the contemplated transmitted beam direction should satisfy a 48 
basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 49 
2. The test frame received at the contemplated transmitted beam direction by the signal analyzer should be the 50 
same as the signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 51 
data. 52 
3. The extracted or measured beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were measured (i.e. 53 
best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected transmitted beam direction for the expected no 54 
beamforming within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  55 
 56 
 57 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       317 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – No Beamforming 1 
A. Test Description and Applicability 2 
This test is MANDATORY. 3 
 4 
 5 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with no beamforming 6 
(beamId=0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 7 
 8 
 9 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 10 
 Manufacturers’ declaration that defines list of beam directions when O-RU DUT is operating with no 11 
beamforming. This list serves as indication of the expected receive beam direction in below evaluation.   12 
  13 
 14 
C. Test Methodology 15 
 16 
a. Initial Conditions 17 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 18 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  19 
 Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  20 
 Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4 and 21 
configure the signal source with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and generate the test 22 
signal. 23 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4. 24 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 25 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.  26 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  27 
 28 
b. Procedure 29 
a. Build an appropriate test signal described above in the signal source of the TER.  30 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial beam direction. This initial beam 31 
direction could be the boresight direction of the receiver antenna array, corresponding to the 32 
manufacturers declaration of the expected receive direction. 33 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 34 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-35 
SCH) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 36 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4 37 
while also triggering the signal source.   38 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 39 
plane messages to the O-DU. 40 
f. Allow the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload and to measure and extract any required 41 
metric/s from the received signal that will be used later to determine what is the best received direction. 42 
g. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different beam direction when injecting the test signal 43 
into the O-RU. Repeating the process for a number of different beam directions will exercise the reception 44 
of the test signal from different receive beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-RU is really 45 
focusing the sensitivity to the correct expected receive beam direction. 46 
 47 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  48 
1. The test frame received at the contemplated receive beam direction by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the 49 
signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 50 
2. The extracted or measured receive beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were 51 
measured (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected receive beam direction for the 52 
expected no beamforming within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  53 
 54 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam 55 
Beamforming 56 
A. Test Description and Applicability 57 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 58 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       318 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with predefined-beams 1 
beamforming (beamId≠0x000) and with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 2 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each indexed beam required in this measurement, see below. The 3 
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted beam direction is 4 
defined by extracting the beam direction from directional measurement samples. , e.g. spherical scan. 5 
Depending on the O-RU beamforming capabilities regarding the ability to generate “coarse”, “fine” and/or “beam 6 
groups”, as defined in [2] Section 10.4.1.1. 7 
 8 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 9 
 10 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Predefined-beam Beamforming conformance test 11 
might include multiple test that the O-RU must comply: 12 
a. “Coarse” beamIds test:  13 
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that are defined as coarse granularity (coarse beamIds) to the O-DU 14 
emulator, the test should include the following beams: 15 
1. A coarse beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 16 
2. A coarse beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 17 
3. A coarse beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 18 
4. A coarse beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 19 
5. A coarse beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 20 
 21 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured. 22 
 23 
b.  “Fine” beamIds test:  24 
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that are defined as fine granularity (fine beamIds) to the O-DU 25 
emulator, the test should include the following beams: 26 
1. A fine beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 27 
2. A fine beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 28 
3. A fine beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 29 
4. A fine beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 30 
5. A fine beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 31 
 32 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth or elevation angle, fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured. 33 
 34 
c.  “beam-group” beamIds test:  35 
If O-RU supports and reports beamIds that belong to same and different beam-groups to the O-DU emulator, 36 
the test should include the following beams: 37 
1. All beams that belong to a beam-group with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) or elevation (θ) angles. 38 
2. All beams that belong to a beam-group with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ). 39 
3. All beams that belong to a beam-group with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ). 40 
4. All beams that belong to a beam-group with maximum supported elevation angle (θ). 41 
5. All beams that belong to a beam-group with minimum supported elevation angle (θ). 42 
 43 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth or elevation angle, fewer than 5 beam-groups will be measured. 44 
 45 
 46 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 47 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of beam indices and their associated beam directions with antenna array 48 
characteristics. This list serves as indication of the expected transmitted beam direction in below evaluation.   49 
 50 
C. Test Methodology 51 
 52 
a. Initial Conditions 53 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 54 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  55

Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       319 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  1 
 Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4 and 2 
configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 3 
transmitted signal. 4 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4. 5 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 6 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.  7 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  8 
   9 
b. Procedure 10 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 11 
emulator.   12 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the 13 
signal and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-SCH 14 
and DCI) using section type 1 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 15 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing 16 
windows described in section 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.   17 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 18 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 19 
e. Measure any metric/s that allows for extracting the transmitted beam direction from a single measurement, 20 
i.e. transform-based techniques, or take as many measurements of any metric/s from multiple angles, by 21 
for example rotating the O-RU, that allows for extracting beam direction from multiple measurement, i.e. 22 
beam scanning. 23 
 24 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  25 
The signal measured by the signal analyzer at the contemplated transmitted beam direction should satisfy a basic 26 
3GPP signal performance requirement for this radio category (i.e., EVM). 27 
1. The test frame received at the contemplated transmitted beam direction by the signal analyzer should be the 28 
same as the signal described above and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 29 
data. 30 
2. The extracted or measured transmit beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were 31 
measured (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected transmit beam direction for the 32 
beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer.  33

 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic 34 
Beamforming 35 
A. Test Description and Applicability 36 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 37 
 38 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with weight-based dynamic 39 
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  40 
 41 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each weighted beam required in this measurement, see below. The 42 
measured transmitted direction is compared to manufacturer-designated direction. Transmitted beam direction is 43 
obtained by directly extracting the beam direction from the directional samples. 44 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in [2] Section 10.4.1.1: 45 
 46 
 47 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight-based Dynamic Beamforming conformance 48 
test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 49 
a. A weight-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles. 50 
b. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 51 
(θ). 52 
c. A weight-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 53 
(θ). 54 
d. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 55 
(θ). 56 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       321 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
e. A weight-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 1 
(θ). 2 
 3 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles will be measured. 4 
 5 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Weight—based Dynamic Beamforming 6 
conformance test should also evaluate the following compression methods for each of the supported beams 7 
described above (a. to e.) for the O-RU to comply: 8 
a. No compression method applied to the beamforming weights.  9 
b. Block floating point compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit mantissa. 10 
c. Block scaling compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit scaler. 11 
d. μ-law compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit fixed width. 12 
e. Beamspace compression method applied to the beamforming weights with 14-bit scaler.  13 
 14 
If the O-RU does not support all the compression methods described above, fewer than 5 compression methods will 15 
be measured. 16 
 17 
 18 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 19 
Manufacturers’ defined list of frequency domain (ϕ) and/or time domain (θ) weights and their associated beam 20 
directions with antenna array characteristics 21 
 22 
C. Test Methodology 23 
 24 
a. Initial Conditions 25 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 26 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1. 27 
 Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  28 
 Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4 and 29 
configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 30 
transmitted signal. 31 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4. 32 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 33 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.  34 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   35 
 36 
b. Procedure 37 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 or NR-FR2-TM1.1 signal described above in 38 
the O-DU emulator.   39 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 40 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (DL-SCH and DCI) 41 
using section type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension 42 
extType=0x01 to convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 1 43 
since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 44 
should be 0x0. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 45 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 46 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   47 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 48 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 49 
 50 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  51 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 52 
radio category (i.e., EVM). 53 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 54 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 55 
3. The extracted or measured transmit beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were 56 
measured (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction for the beam under 57 
test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer  58 
 59

Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       322 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Weight-based Dynamic 1 
Beamforming 2 
A. Test Description and Applicability 3 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 4 
 5 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with weight-based beamforming 6 
and with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  7 
 8 
The same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.5 but applies to 9 
the uplink direction.  10 
 11 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 12 
Manufacturers’ defined list of frequency domain (ϕ) and/or time domain (θ) weights and their associated beam 13 
directions with antenna array characteristics. 14 
 15 
 16 
C. Test Methodology 17 
 18 
a. Initial Conditions 19 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 20 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  21 
 Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  22 
 Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4 and 23 
configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 24 
transmitted signal. 25 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4. 26 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 27 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.  28 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   29 
 30 
b. Procedure 31 
 32 
a. Build an appropriate test signal related to either FR1 or FR2 described above in the signal source of the 33 
TER.  34 
b. Inject the test signal into the O-RU with the application of an initial beam direction as fulfilling the 35 
expected spherical  RoAoA .For example, initial beam direction could be the boresight of the receive 36 
antenna array.   37 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 38 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (UL-SCH) using section 39 
type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension extType=0x01 to 40 
convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 1 since the same 41 
beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0. No 42 
section type zero messages will be used for this test. 43 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while 44 
also triggering the signal source.   45 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 46 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 47 
f. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different inclining beam direction or RoAoA. For 48 
example, repeating the process for a number of different beam directions. This allows to determine if the O-49 
RU is really focusing the sensitivity to the correct beam direction. 50 
 51 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  52 
1. The test frame received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signal described above and should contain 53 
all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 54 
2. The extracted or measured receive beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were 55 
measured (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected receive beam direction for the beam 56 
under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer 57 
 58 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       323 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Attribute-based Dynamic 2 
Beamforming 3 
A. Test Description and Applicability 4 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 5 
 6 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with attributed-based dynamic 7 
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC).  8 
 9 
If the O-RU DUT supports Attribute based Dynamic Beamforming, this test is mandatory for the O-RU DUT to be 10 
O-RAN conformant.   11 
The transmitted beam direction and attributes are measured for each attributed beam required in this measurement, 12 
see below. The measured transmitted direction and attributes, i.e. pointing azimuth and elevation angles, 13 
beamwidths and sidelobe suppression, is compared to manufacturer-designated direction and attributes. 14 
Transmitted direction and beam attributes are defined by the magnitude and phase relation between the antenna 15 
ports or TAB connectors under test, or by directly extracting the beam properties. 16 
The elevation θ and azimuth Φ angles are defined as in Section 10.4.1.1 of [2]. 17 
 18 
 19 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Attribute-based Dynamic Beamforming 20 
conformance test should evaluate the following beams for the O-RU to comply: 21 
a. An attribute-based beam with 0 degrees azimuth (Φ) and elevation (θ) angles with any beamwidth and sidelobe 22 
suppression supported by the O-RU under this beam direction. 23 
b. An attribute-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 24 
(θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction. 25 
c. An attribute-based beam with maximum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 26 
(θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction. 27 
d. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and maximum supported elevation angle 28 
(θ) with the widest beamwidth and lowest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction. 29 
e. An attribute-based beam with minimum supported azimuth angle (Φ) and minimum supported elevation angle 30 
(θ) with the narrowest beamwidth and highest sidelobe suppression supported for this specific beam direction. 31 
 32 
If the O-RU only supports one azimuth (Φ) or elevation angle (θ), fewer than 5 beam angles and attribute 33 
configurations will be measured. 34 
 35 
 36 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 37 
Manufacturers’ defined list of frequency domain (ϕ) and/or time domain (θ) weights and their associated beam 38 
directions with antenna array characteristics. 39 
 40 
C. Test Methodology 41 
 42 
a. Initial Conditions 43 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 44 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  45 
 Ensure that the test antenna/s and TER equipment is calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  46 
 Place the test antenna/s to a defined position within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4 and 47 
configure the analyzer with any set-up information needed to allow it to synch and demodulate the 48 
transmitted signal. 49 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4. 50 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 51 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.4.  52 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   53 
 54 
b. Procedure 55 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       324 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 or NR-FR2-TM1.1 signal described above in 1 
the O-DU emulator.   2 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 3 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (DL-SCH and DCI) 4 
using section type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension 5 
extType=0x02 to convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 2 6 
since the same beam IDs will not change along the slot.  If O-RU does not support a field, then its value 7 
should be 0x0. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 8 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 9 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1.   10 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 11 
demodulate and decode the test frame. 12 
a. Extract either the beamweights, or magnitude and phase relation, or beam properties from the measured 13 
signal. the beam direction from the measured samples. Measure any metric/s that allows for extracting the 14 
transmitted beam attributes from a single measurement, i.e. transform-based techniques, or take as many 15 
measurements of any metric/s from multiple angles, by for example rotating the O-RU, that allows for 16 
extracting beam attributes from multiple measurement, i.e. beam scanning. 17 
 18 
 19 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  20 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 21 
radio category (i.e., EVM). 22 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer should be the same as the signal described above and should 23 
contain all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 24 
3. The extracted or measured transmit beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were 25 
measured (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected beam direction for the beam under 26 
test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer 27 
 28 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Attribute-based Dynamic 29 
Beamforming 30

 33 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with attribute-based 34 
beamforming with one spatial stream (single eAxC). 35 
 36 
Same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.7 but considering 37 
uplink direction.  38

directions with antenna array characteristics. 42

 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   1 
 2 
b. Procedure 3 
a. Build an appropriate test signal either related to FR1 or FR2, described above in the signal source of the 4 
TER.  5 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 6 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by one or two sections (UL-SCH) using section 7 
type 1 messages, the sections in the first symbol of the slot will contain section extension extType=0x02 to 8 
convey the beam weights, it is not required that the next sections contain extension type 2 since the same 9 
beam IDs will not change along the slot. If O-RU does not support a field, then its value should be 0x0. No 10 
section type zero messages will be used for this test. 11 
c. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 3.2.1.1.1. while also 12 
triggering the signal source.   13 
d. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U 14 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload. 15 
e. Repeat the previous steps but now in step b apply a different inclining beam direction or RoAoA. For 16 
example, repeating the process for a number of different beam directions. This allows the tester to determine 17 
if the O-RU is really focusing the sensitivity to the correct beam direction. 18 
 19

all the same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data. 22 
2. The extracted or measured receive beam direction is defined as the direction where the best metric/s were 23 
measured (i.e. best EVM, power, SNR, etc.) and should match the expected receive beam direction for the 24 
beam under test within a tolerance defined by the manufacturer 25 
 26 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based 27 
Beamforming 28 
A. Test Description and Applicability 29 
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 30 
 31 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can transmit a basic 3GPP test frame with channel-information-based 32 
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU-MIMO). 33 
 34 
For Category A radios, the test is for each polarization separately and consequently either different or same channel 35 
models can be defined for each of the polarization. For Category B, same channel might be used for both 36 
polarizations and the test might measure each polarization separately. 37 
The transmitted beam direction is measured for each scenario required in this measurement.  The measured 38 
transmitted direction is extracted from the decoded received signal in the TER. Transmitted direction is defined by 39 
properly receiving a data transmission between the O-RU and the target User Equipment while destroying or 40 
heavily attenuating the data transmission between the O-RU and the other User Equipment. 41 
The UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP DL – Channel-Information-based Beamforming 42 
conformance test should evaluate the following scenarios for the O-RU to comply and will rely on TER Channel 43 
Emulation capabilities as shown in Figure 3.2.6.2-3.  44 
 45 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       326 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 Figure 3.2.6.2-3 TER with antennas representing multiple UEs 2 
 3 
c. A scenario where two spatial streams, or eAxC flows, are generated for two users (one layer each) with M 4 
antennas ports or TAB connectors. The O-DU will report to the O-RU via C plane messages the channel 5 
estimate 𝐻 ≜  [ℎଵଵ, . . . , ℎଵெ, ℎଶଵ, . . . , ℎଶெ] ∈ ℂଶ௫ெ, which is the effective channel as seen by the antennas 6 
representing the multiple UEs, which are spaced sufficiently such that the O-RU can effectively equalize out 7 
the interference between the users. The O-RU will calculate and apply the beamweight matrix 𝐺 ≜8 
 [𝑔ଵଵ, . . . , 𝑔ଵெ, 𝑔ଶଵ, . . . , 𝑔ଶெ] ∈ ℂெ௫  in such that the received signal at the users is the same as the generated in the 9 
O-DU. It is up to the O-RU on how to calculate the beamforming weights, for example Zero-forcing, 10 
regularized zero-forcing / MMSE, etc.   11 
 12 
If O-RU supports Analog Beamforming (Time Domain Beamforming), the test should not apply any analog 13 
beamforming or time domain beamforming. In this case, M is not the number of antennas ports or TAB connectors 14 
but the number of TRX channels supported by the O-RU. 15 
 16 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 17 
 18 
 The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with radiating antennas  19 
 The TER equipment must include 2 antennas with sufficient separation to emulate the 2 users such that the O-20 
RU can equalize out the mutual interference of the users due to the effective MU-MIMO channel. 21 
 Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antennas are connected to each TRX chain 22 
 23 
C. Test Methodology 24 
 25 
a. Initial Conditions 26 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation using 27 
M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  28 
 Ensure that the test antennas and TER equipment are calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  29 
 Place the test antennas within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.4  with sufficient separation for 30 
effective MU-MIMO beamforming and configure the analyzer ports with any setup information needed to 31 
synch and demodulate the MU-MIMO transmitted signal 32 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.4. 33 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 34 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.4.  35 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.   36 
 37 
b. Procedure 38 


 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       327 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
a. Build an appropriate IQ signal describing the NR-FR1-TM1.1 signal described above in the O-DU 1 
emulator, with the data symbols for user 1 and user 2 fully overlapping in time and frequency, but with user 2 
data initialized using different seeds for the PN23 sequence.   3 
b. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 4 
and the scenario under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (DL-SCH and 5 
DCI) using section type 5 and 6 messages. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 6 
c. Encapsulate the IQ data in U-Plane messages. Play those messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows 7 
described in section 3.2.1.1.1. 8 
d. Capture the test signals and pass them through a channel emulator or apply the signal processing required 9 
to emulate the channel under test using the 2 test antennas.   10 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the signal analyzer and allow it to 11 
demodulate and decode the test frames for the 2 users. 12 
 13 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  14 
1. The signal measured by the signal analyzer should satisfy a basic 3GPP signal performance requirement for this 15 
radio category (i.e., EVM). 16 
2. The test frame received by the signal analyzer for the 2 users should be the same as the signal described above 17 
and should contain all the same PRB assignments and all the respective  PN23 data. 18 
 19 
 20 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP UL – Channel-Information-based 21 
Beamforming 22 
A. Test Description and Applicability 23 
This Test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 24 
 25 
The purpose of this test is to ensure the radio can receive a basic 3GPP test frame with channel-information-based 26 
beamforming with multiple spatial streams from multiple users (i.e. MU-MIMO).  27 
 28 
Same description and criteria for selecting the beams to be tested applies as in section 3.2.3.2.103.2.6.2.9 but 29 
considering the uplink direction.  30 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 31 
 32 
 The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with radiating sensing antennas  33 
 The TER equipment must include 2 antennas with sufficient separation to emulate the 2 users such that the O-34 
RU can equalize out the mutual interference of the users due to the effective MU-MIMO channel. 35 
 The O-RU must have at least two TRX chains with conducted antenna ports (or TAB connectors) to be 36 
connected to a signal generator. 37 
 The TER equipment must include 2 antennas with sufficient separation to emulate the 2 users the O-RU need 38 
to be able to equalize out the mutual interference of the users due to the effective MU-MIMO channel. 39 
Manufacturers’ defined list of number of TRX chains and what antennas are connected to each TRX chain. 40 
 41 
C. Test Methodology 42 
 43 
a. Initial Conditions 44 
 Configure the O-RU which includes collecting O-RU capabilities, configuring the O-RU for operation 45 
using M-Plane commands, and synchronizing the O-RU using G.8275.1.  46 
 Ensure that the test antennas and TER equipment are calibrated within acceptable tolerance.  47 
 Place the test antennas within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.4 with sufficient separation for 48 
effective MU-MIMO beamforming and configure the generator ports with any setup information needed to 49 
transmit the signals from the 2 UEs 50 
 Place the O-RU into a test calibrated point within the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.4. 51 
 Align the O-RU to a default initial position, i.e. align the O-RU to the origin of coordinates of the declared 52 
coordinate reference point and orientation in the OTA chamber as defined in 3.2.1.1.4.  53 
 Let the DUT and TER to warm to the normal operating temperature within specified range.  54 
  55 
b. Procedure 56 
a. Build the appropriate test signals for each of the 2 users as described above in the signal source of the TER 57 
using a different seed to initialize the PN23 data for each user. 58 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       328 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
b. Transmit the test signals over the air with sufficient transmit power according to  3.2.1.1.4 1 
c. Use the O-DU emulator control interface to build the appropriate C-Plane messages that describe the signal 2 
and the beam under test. Every symbol should be described by either one or two  sections (UL-SCH) using 3 
section type 5 and 6. No section type zero messages will be used for this test. 4 
d. Play the C plane messages to the O-RU respecting timing windows described in section 2.4. while also 5 
triggering the signal source.   6 
e. Repeat the entire frame the number of times required to synch the DUT, allow it to create and send the U-7 
plane messages to the O-DU and for the O-DU to demodulate, decode and extract the payload for each of 8 
the users. 9 
 10 
D. Test Requirement (expected result)  11 
The test frames received by the TER/O-DU should be the same as the signals described above and should contain all the 12 
same PRB assignments and all the original PN23 data of the 2 users. 13 
 14 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Compression (CMP) 15 
The compression tests for FR1 and FR2 TDD Non-conducted OTA are the same as the tests described in section 3.2.5.3 16 
for FR1.  For FR2, similar test frames with 120 KHz SCS shall be used in the test  Only the setup for the tests are 17 
different reflecting the difference between non-conductive and conductive mode testing.  18 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Delay Management (DLM) 19 
The delay management tests for FR1 and FR2 TDD Non-conducted OTA are the same as the tests described in section 20 
3.2.5.4 for FR1.  For FR2, similar test frames with 120 KHz SCS shall be used in the test.  Only the setup for the tests 21 
are different reflecting the difference between non-conductive and conductive mode testing.  22 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Transport (TRN) 23 
This test is for future study. 24 
 25 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class LAA (LAA) 26 
The LAA tests for FR1TDD Non-conducted OTA are the same as the tests described in section 3.2.5.6.  Only the setup 27 
for the tests are different reflecting the difference between non-conductive and conductive mode testing.  Note that 28 
LAA tests are not applicable for the FR2 spectrum.  29 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class LTE (LTE) 30 
This test is for future study. 31 
 UC-Plane O-RU Scenario Class Section Type 3 (ST3) 32 
The Section Type 3 tests for FR1 and FR2 TDD Non-conducted OTA are the same as the tests described in section 33 
3.2.5.8 for FR1.  For FR2, similar test frames with 120 KHz SCS shall be used in the test.  Only the setup for the tests 34 
are different reflecting the difference between non-conductive and conductive mode testing.  35
