                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
3.3 S-Plane Conformance Tests 2 
This section describes tests that are used to validate S-Plane functional and performance conformance of network 3 
elements using the O-RAN WG4 fronthaul interface defined in [2] and the O-RAN WG4 M-Plane interface defined in 4 
[3].  This version of the conformance specification defines both O-DU and O-RU conformance tests.  Future versions of 5 
this specification will describe additional S-Plane functional and performance conformance tests of other clocks used in 6 
the front haul, e.g. PRTC/T-GM, etc.  7 
S-Plane functionality of the O-RU is determined based on status retrieved from the O-RU using the M-Plane or SMO as 8 
appropriate, whereas, S-Plane performance is determined by over-the-air (OTA) or conductive (i.e. a cabled electrical 9 
connection to the DUT’s radio interface) measurements of O-RU synchronization signal.  10 
S-Plane functionality of the O-DU is determined based on status retrieved from the O-DU using the SMO. As M-plane 11 
specification in WG5 become available, retrieval of O-DU status based on M-plane will be considered for functional 12 
tests, as well.  13 
The performance of O-DU is determined by time/frequency error measurements on output signals (such as 1PPS, or 14 
fronthaul SyncE+PTP master ports in LLS-C1 and LLS-C2).  When applicable, O-DU tests are based on ITU-T 15 
G.8275.1 profile. ITU-T G.8275.2 is not specifically supported in this document version because this standard does not 16 
specify performance criteria and is left for further study.   17 
O-DU tests consider both local and remote PRTC connections, as shown in Figure 3.3.1-1. The connection type is 18 
relevant for performance tests because the input conditions applied to DUT depends on connection types supported: 19 
  An embedded PRTC (e.g. using embedded GNSS receiver, Figure 3.3.1-1a) has no exposed direct O-DU 20 
interface, so test stimulus is applied to the Time Reference input (e.g. GNSS RF). 21 
  A local PRTC is collocated with the O-DU and may communicate to O-DU via either a 1PPS and serial link 22 
(e.g. ITU-T G.8271 or similar interface), Figure 3.3.1-1b, or an Ethernet interface (PTP and PLFS, Figure 23 
3.3.1-1c).  24 
 A remote PRTC is located anywhere in the network (backhaul or fronthaul) and communicates to O-DU via an 25 
Ethernet interface (PTP and PLFS, Figure 3.3.1-1d). 26 
 27 
 28 
Figure 3.3.1-1 Methods to connect PRTC to O-DU  29 
 30 
Both functional and performance tests require the provision of a test equipment i.e. provision of a test setup that 31 
includes a CUSM-E which delivers the necessary stimuli as described in section 3.3.1. 32 
DUT(O-DU)DUT(O-DU)G.703,  G.8271 Annex A, or ProprietaryDUT(O-DU)Direct Ethernet  with PTP/SyncESwitched/ Routed NetworkEthernet with PTP/SyncE(b)Local PRTC using 1PPS/10MHz/ToD interface(c)Local PRTC using direct Ethernet connection (d)Remote PRTC using networked Ethernet connection DUT(O-DU)PRTCTime Reference (e.g. GNSS)(a)Embedded PRTCPRTCPRTC + T/GMPRTC + T/GMTime Reference (e.g. GNSS)Time Reference (e.g. GNSS)Time Reference (e.g. GNSS)No exposed timing interface

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       330 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
The S-Plane conformance test suite assumes that the vendor’s equipment is conformant and has been tested to meet the 1 
requirements of G.8275.1 and IEEE1588v2 and other relevant S-Plane standards. Therefore, this document does not 2 
attempt to duplicate tests for these standards.    3 
The below sections of bullets summarize the test scope in order to validate conformance to the synchronization plane 4 
specification referenced by [2] section 9.  5 
 General points which apply to testing of both functional and performance aspects of the O-DU and O-RU: 6 
 The tests apply to both 4G (LTE/E-UTRA) and 5G (NR) and are applicable to all O-RAN IOT profiles listed 7 
in Annex A 8 
 A CUSM-E is needed to generate the necessary M-plane or SMO and S-Plane traffic that includes PTP and 9 
possibly SyncE SSM over ESMC. It is synchronized to a time reference. For the O-RU testing a CUSM-E 10 
must also generate CU-Plane background traffic. 11 
 Shall be done in the lab at constant temperature  12 
 The CUS specification [2] may in the future support different kinds of Physical Layer Frequency Support 13 
(PLFS), however the only fully specified PLFS by the current edition of [2] is SyncE. Thus, these S-Plane tests 14 
are defined to include SyncE when required. 15 
 Testing of SyncE is optional and is only valid when the SyncE device which can be driven by a master (e.g. O-16 
RU) makes use of it. Therefore, the related SyncE test cases are optional. 17 
 18 
 The following bulleted points apply specifically to functional tests of the O-RU in addition to the general points 19 
above, 20 
 For validation of S-Plane, the following are used: 21 
o A CUSM-E sends and receives synchronization information over the fronthaul interface.  22 
o A Measurement Equipment to perform frequency/phase/time measurements from any available 23 
synchronization interface.  24 
o DUT’s S-Plane reports its state over M-Plane. 25 
 The acceptance criterion for these tests is to comply with specification [2]. 26 
 27 
 The following bullets points apply specifically to functional test of the O-DU in addition to the general points 28 
above: 29 
 On its input ports, O-DU end application like O-RU may optionally use SyncE along with PTP. However, in 30 
the case of an LLS-C1/C2 O-DU acting as G.8275.1 SyncE+PTP master, SyncE emission is mandatory on the 31 
fronthaul for validation of S-plane: 32 
o DUT reports its S-Plane state over SMO (and in future WG5 M-plane). 33 
 The acceptance criterion for these tests is to comply with specification [2]. 34 
 The CUSM-E also provides local time source input signals to the O-DU: 35 
o GNSS RF signals, delivered by a GNSS generator referenced to the local time reference 36 
o PRTC output signals (1PPS + serial link)  37 
 The following bulleted points apply specifically to performance tests for O-RU and O-DU in addition to the general 38 
points above. 39 
 These tests are not defined to fully stress the DUT. Rather they are intended to stress the DUT enough to 40 
determine that it can properly operate via the defined front haul protocol.    41 
o The thermal profile is not defined. The tests are defined to be run at a constant temperature, but the 42 
thermal profile choice and range is left as a decision for the vendor.  43 
o The variable C/U-Plane profile (for example similar to test case 13 shown in figure VI.11 of ITU-T 44 
G.8261 [10]) will be defined as part of the work on the future performance tests.  45 
o All performance tests described in this section assume the following two components in the procedure (test 46 
methodology sections): 47 
o Establishing the necessary M-plane session to bring up the O-RU or O-DU and make it ready for 48 
transmission of a measurement signal. For the O-DU, the establishment of an M-plane session can be done 49 
when the WG5 M-plane is available. In the interim, the O-DU shall be configured using SMO.  50 
o For the O-RU in addition to the M-plane session, the transmission of a test signal necessitates the 51 
provision of a CU plane test vector. The test vector needs to have enough information to set up a 52 
synchronization channel within the radio frame transmitted over the air.  53 
o For O-DU performance tests the test cannot be executed unless the O-DU provides an Ethernet port with 54 
sync master function and/or a 1PPS output signal.  55 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       331 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 The acceptance criterion for the performance tests is to satisfy the 3GPP OTA TAE limits specified in 3GPP 1 
TS 36.141 [18] for 4G (LTE) and 38.141-2 [20] for 5G (NR), and summarized in eCPRI [11] and ITU-T 2 
G.8271 [7]. The conditions applicable to each test will be set out in the relevant sections below (future work 3 
item). OTA TAE limits for MIMO/Tx Diversity is outside the scope of this document because they apply 4 
between endpoints belonging to the same O-RU. 5 
 The CUS Specification [2] which follows eCPRI and IEEE802.1 CM recommendation, defines two examples 6 
of O-RU types, but these are not strict classes like the T-BC classes specified in ITU-T G.8273.2. 7 
3.3.1 Test Environment 8 
The following describes the necessary functions and capabilities of the test equipment in order to perform O-RU or O-9 
DU conformance tests. A diagram of the O-RU test set up shown in Figure 3.3.1-2, and a similar diagram of the O-DU 10 
test set up is shown in Figure 3.3.1-3.  11 
Referring to Figure 3.3.1-2, the stimulus is applied to the O-RU via an Ethernet interface which simulates an ORAN 12 
CUS-Plane protocols by using equipment to generate an O-DU and/or front haul time reference. This interface carries 13 
the PTP and SyncE stimulus to test the O-RU and carries M-Plane information to configure DUT and as needed C-14 
Plane and U-Plane information to generate a test signal to measure time accuracy.  Performance measurements are 15 
made at the radio output.  These measurements can be made either over the air (called a non-conductive measurement), 16 
or via a cable connection from the radio interface (called conductive measurement).  If the O-RU has a 1PPS (One 17 
Pulse Per Second) output, which has been correlated to the radio output, the measurements can be made using the 1PPS 18 
output.  19 
Figure 3.3.1-2 applies to LLS-C1/C2/C3 topologies.  LLS-C4 topology is for further study. 20 
 21 
CUSM-Plane Emulator (CUSM-E)1PPS out (optional)Radio Interface Optional SMOTime Ref-erencePerformance MeasurementDirect Front Haul Ethernet Test Port extract 1PPS & extract freq.Synchronization/Reference Clock1PPS out, 10MHz out, and/or PTPO-RAN Protocol DUT (O-RU)Clock/Time ReferenceRFPTP/SyncE pathSignal Extractor/AnalyzerPTP/SyncE Gen. (T-GM)
RU Test Equipment, (R-TE)
 22 
Figure 3.3.1-2 O-RU C1/C2/C3 Conformance Test Set Up 23 
As shown in Figure 3.3.1-3, the O-DU the setup is similar to the O-RU. In addition to the option to supply timing using 24 
PTP via Ethernet (like the O-RU), the input stimulus may be applied to the DUT from a directly connected Time 25 
Reference which delivers frequency (e.g. SyncE, 10MHz, 1PPS), phase (e.g.1PPS, 10ms frame boundary) and time 26 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       332 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
(e.g. ToD, PTP) signals.  Directly connecting the Time Reference time via a Local Sync Port simulates topology with 1 
an O-DU using a Local PRTC Time Reference. Using PTP via an Ethernet Test Port simulates a topology using a 2 
Remote PRTC. 3 
For the O-DU performance tests the quality of the DUTs timing output is measured via the DUT’s Master Ethernet Port 4 
(again, if available) which propagates the time and optionally frequency information from the DUT using PTP, and 5 
optionally SyncE, or 1PPS output (if available). If no master ethernet port or 1PPS output are available, then 6 
performance test cannot be executed. 7 
 Typically, in LLS-C1/C2, using a spare Ethernet Master Port offers the most accurate interface 8 
 Typically, in LLS-C3/C4, using a 1PPS measurement interface may avoid having to configure an Ethernet port 9 
as PTP master for measurement purpose. 10

Figure 3.3.1-3  O-DU C1/C2/C3/C4 Conformance Test Set Up with an a) Embedded PRTC, b) Local Sync Port 12 
PRTC, c) PRTC over PTP/SyncE 13 
 14 
CUSM-Plane Emulator: This function implements various planes (C, U, S, M) to simulate a front haul/transport 15 
network connecting to DUT (i.e. O-RU, O-DU). It should be capable of testing S-Plane performance under stress with 16 
various noise profiles. S-Plane signals sent to DUT and measurement equipment are traceable to reference signals 17 
received from the master time reference. Emulator should generate noise free reference signal for Measurement 18 
Equipment and (when required) a noise profile for the DUT. The CUSM-Plane emulator may be composed of multiple 19 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       333 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
components or could be a single component containing all the capabilities listed below. When O-RU is the DUT UC-1 
Plane is needed for O-RU to generate a radio information required to measure timing.  For O-DU, CU-Plane 2 
functionality is not used since timing is measured directly from an Ethernet or 1PPS test port.  3 
 Time Reference/S-Plane: This equipment is the frequency and time reference. It delivers frequency (e.g. 4 
SyncE, 10MHz, 1PPS), phase (e.g.1PPS, 10ms frame boundary) and time (e.g. ToD, PTP) signals to the Sync 5 
Tester equipment and to the various simulators/generators listed below. PRTC specified by ITU-T G.8272 is 6 
one example in terms of performance. The level of performance for these reference signals should be 7 
significantly (by an order of magnitude) better than the 3GPP synchronization requirements when absolute 8 
limits are measured against the reference clock. The time reference function with the CUSM-Plane emulator is 9 
traceable to UTC. The time output is used to synchronize the Signal Analyzer or Test Equipment performing 10 
time error measurements. The phase output is used to synchronize the Signal Analyzer or Test Equipment 11 
performing time error measurements. 12 
 PRTC/T-GM: for testing an O-DU from either local or remote PRTC over Ethernet. It includes a PTP master 13 
clock and, when applicable, a SyncE master function that propagate the Time reference and allow adding 14 
configured noise patterns. 15 
 GNSS Emulator: for testing an O-DU with integrated local PRTC. The GNSS emulator will provide an RF 16 
signal to the O-DU. The RF signal emulates a signal received by a GNSS antenna and allows adding 17 
configured noise patterns. As an alternative to a GNSS emulator following case is acceptable: the test 18 
environment provides the capability to access a GNSS antenna mounted at a suitable location inside the 19 
building with line of sight to sufficient number of GNSS satellites (>4).  20 
 PRTC Emulator: for testing an O-DU with integrated T-GM, but without an integrated local PRTC: in this 21 
case, the test setup needs to provide the following signals to the O-DU: 1PPS (according to ITU G.703), 22 
10MHz, and serial link carrying ToD and PRTC status. There are different ToD formats such as ITU-T G.8271 23 
Annex A and NMEA. The ToD format of the test setup needs to deliver the ToD format supported by the O-24 
DU. This interface allows adding configured noise patterns. 25 
 SMO: Responsible for configuring CUSM Plane emulator to send configuration to DUT for the defined 26 
conformance tests. 27 
 M-Plane: Translate the SMO configuration into the proper M-Plane messages to correctly configure and 28 
report status from the DUT.  For O-RU testing this is implemented using WG4 M-Plane protocol.  For O-DU 29 
this is implemented by either using a Network Management System (SMO) which is compatible with the DUT 30 
or using a WG5 M-Plane emulator. 31 
 UC-Plane: S-Plane tests require the transmission of UC-Plane traffic over the fronthaul, the emulator shall 32 
implement the O-RAN UC-Plane protocol and shall send a stock data frame defined in Section 3.2.1.1.5 and 33 
shown in Figure Figure 3.2.1.1-2 as UC-Plane messages to DUT O-RU. 34 
The emulator shall merge all traffic types for transmission over the fronthaul without degrading performance of S-35 
Plane. 36 
O-DU Input Time Source Topology and Master Output Time

Table 3.3.1-1 O-DU C1/C2/C3 Input Source and Output Source Options  37 
Measurement Equipment: This equipment is responsible for extracting the desired synchronization information from 38 
the test signal transmitted by the DUT, and then measuring this information to determine if the performance is within 39 
limits. This could be a single piece of test equipment containing all the capabilities listed below, or it may be created by 40 
interconnecting a separate signal analyzer and performance measurement system.  41 
For O-RU testing the following measurement equipment is needed. 42 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       334 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Signal Extractor/Analyzer: This equipment demodulates the time reference signal from the O-RU’s 1 
downlink radio interface. It receives RF signals from the DUT’s air or preferably coaxial interface. This 2 
equipment should be connected to Synchronization/Reference Clock to be able to lock on the correct 3 
synchronization channel of the O-RU RF output signal. 4 
 Performance Measurement Equipment: This equipment performs error measurements of the 1pps and 5 
10MHz signals from DUT or from Signal Extractor.  It uses standard metrics to validate if measured signal 6 
meets the defined limits. It is recommended to use a ≥2 GHz sampling on 1pps signals (for 1 ns sampling 7 
accuracy)  8 
For O-DU testing the following measurement equipment is used. 9 
 PTP/SyncE/1pps Measurement Equipment: This equipment is responsible for extracting the desired 10 
synchronization information from the master Ethernet port (e.g. decoding the PTP and/or SyncE sent from 11 
DUT’s master port) or 1PPS output from the DUT. Then measuring this information to determine if the 12 
performance of the DUT is within limits. 13 
3.3.2 Functional test of O-RU using ITU-T G.8275.1 profile (LLS-C1/C2/C3) 14 
A. Test Description and Applicability 15 
This test is MANDATORY. 16 
The purpose of this test is to validate that an O-RU is correctly synchronizing to a CUSM Emulator delivering both 17 
PTP and (optionally) SyncE using ITU-T G.8275.1 [5] profile and that the O-RU correctly reports its status to the 18 
CUSM Emulator based on the nominal or degraded synchronization conditions generated by CUSM Emulator.  19 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 20 
O-RU is connected to CUSM Emulator directly.  21 
O-RU must be operating with the respective SMO or M-Plane properly. (as defined in 3.2.1.1.53.2.1.1.5). 22 
C. Test Methodology 23 
a. Initial Conditions 24 
This test uses the O-RU (DUT), a CUSM-Plane emulator with SMO features to generate stimulus for the O-25 
RU (DUT) and signal analyzer to measure the radio interface timing. 26 
b. Procedure 27 
Three conditions must be tested: 28 
Startup: CUSM-Plane Emulator is configured to act as a clock, with PTP and SyncE ports in passive state (no 29 
messages sent) 30 
Nominal: CUSM-E is configured to start acting as a PTP master compliant with the ITU-T G.8275.1 [5] 31 
profile advertising LOCKED status with nominal clockClass and clockAccuracy. If SyncE is to be tested 32 
CUSM-Plane Emulator is configured to act as a clock, with SyncE ports in master state, compliant to ITU-T 33 
G.8264 profile advertising nominal SSM value as specified by ITU-T G.8275.1 [5]. 34 
Degraded: There are two levels of degraded conditions for both PTP and SyncE that can be configured to the 35 
CUSM-Emulator. 36 
 The first degradation level is where the CUSM-E is configured to act as a clock, with PTP and SyncE 37 
ports in master state, compliant to ITU-T G.8275.1 profile, and sending configured clockClass and/or 38 
SSM values within the O-RU’s configured accepted limits via the M-plane.  39 
 The second degradation level is where the same clockClass and/or SSM values are sent by CUSM-E 40 
outside the O-RU’s configured accepted limits via the M-plane. 41 
To cover the all the relevant scenarios the test sequence listed in Table 3.3.2-1  steps through the 42 
Startup/Nominal/Degraded states in a sequence. The steps in this table and Table 3.3.2-2 are intended to be 43 
exercised in sequential order.  Since SyncE is optional, there are two columns, one for PTP status and a second 44 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       335 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
for SyncE.  Each of the status items corresponds the conditions defined above. 1 
 2 
Step PTP Status:  SyncE Status (if applicable): SSM 
1. Startup: no clockclass Startup: no SSM/QL 
2. Nominal clockclass=6 Nominal QL= (see Note 1) 
3. Degraded clockclass but within the O-RU’s 
configured accepted range. 
Nominal QL= (see Note 1) 
4. Degraded clockclass outside the O-RU’s 
configured accepted range. 
Nominal QL= (see Note 1) 
5. Degraded clockclass outside the O-RU’s 
configured accepted range. 
Degraded QL outside the O-RU’s configured accepted 
range. 
6. Nominal clockclass=6 Nominal QL= (see Note 1) 
7. Nominal clockclass=6 Degraded QL but within the O-RU’s configured 
accepted range. 
8. Nominal clockclass=6 Degraded QL outside the O-RU’s configured accepted 
range. 
9. Nominal clockclass=6 Nominal QL = (see Note1) 
10. S-Plane lost, no message S-Plane lost, no message 
Note 1: For SyncE, Nominal QL is what is determined as the best acceptable configured value by the O-RU 3 
Table 3.3.2-1  O-RU C1/C2/C3 Functional Conformance Test Steps 4 
D. Pass Fail Criteria (expected results) 5 
The acceptance criterion is that the status reported by the O-RU for the steps defined in above procedure matches 6 
the results described in Table 3.3.2-.   The left column indicates the steps defined in Table 3.3.2-1 . The second 7 
column summarizes the O-RU status from Table 3.3.2-1 .  The right two columns list the M-plane clock status 8 
parameters that are queried from the test O-RU and their desired value. For PTP clockClass and optional SyncE 9 
SSM quality level, the “Received Value” is the one received by the O-RU (except in Startup mode when there is no 10 
such received value and the default one is reported).  11 
The O-RU Sync-state, PTP lock state, PTP state, PTP clock-class, SyncE lock-state, SyncE state, SyncE quality-12 
level are defined in the M-Plane specification [3] (chapter 13 Synchronization Aspects) and relevant YANG 13 
models.  14

3.3.3 Performance test of O-RU using ITU-T G.8275.1 Profile (LLS-C1/C2/C3) 11 
A. Test Description and Applicability 12 
This test is MANDATORY.   13 
This test validates that an O-RU is synchronizing from a CUSM-plane Emulator delivering configured (ideal and 14 
normal operating conditions) PTP and (optionally) SyncE. Frequency and time error generated by the O-RU must 15 
be within specified limits.  16 
This test focuses on LLS-C1.  In this edition of the document this test can provisionally apply to LLS-C2, but some 17 
details related to frequency error require further study.  LLS-C3 will be addressed in a future version. 18 
CUS -plane spec lists two classes of O-DU (class A has ±15 ppb frequency error limit; class B has ±5 ppb limit). 19 
This test applies to the strictest one from O-RU prospective and therefore considers class A O-DU. 20 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       337 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 1 
O-RU is connected to CUSM-Plane Emulator via direct fiber link(s).  2 
Conformance Functional test 2.5.2 is successfully passed. 3 
It is the vendor’s responsibility to make sure that limits defined in the test are also met in worse-case field 4 
conditions.  Thermal testing, PTP PDV tolerance and SyncE jitter/wander tolerance are beyond the scope of this 5 
test. 6 
O-RU must be operating with the respective SMO or M-Plane properly. (as defined in 3.2.1.1.5) 7 
C. Test Methodology 8 
a. Initial Conditions 9 
These tests use the O-RU DUT and a CUSM-Plane emulator with SMO features.   10 
Frequency and time error are measured on the Air interface at the O-RU output. 11 
CUSM-Plane Emulator is configured to act as a clock, with PTP ports in master state, compliant to ITU-T 12 
G.8275.1 profile advertising LOCKED status with nominal clockClass and clockAccuracy. 13 
CUSM-Plane Emulator is configured to act as a clock, with SyncE ports in master state, compliant to ITU-T 14 
G.8264 profile advertising nominal SSM value.  15 
The DUT shall have achieved frequency and phase lock prior to starting the test. 16 
b. Procedure:  17 
Unlike the functional test defined in section 3.3.2, where start-up / nominal / degraded scenarios are tested, 18 
only nominal scenarios with ideal and normal operation input noise are tested in this section. 19 
1. Ideal: PTP and SyncE (if used) provide “ideal” O-RU input synchronization with no added noise. 20 
2. Normal Operation: PTP and SyncE (if used) provide “Within normal operating limits” O-RU inputs as 21 
specified in CUS-Plane Specification [1], simultaneously meeting two limits:  22 
a. Maximum time error: ± 1420 ns,  23 
b. Maximum frequency error (0.1Hz low pass filtered): ±15 ppb  24 
Notes applicable to this Normal Operation condition test: 25 
 The CUSM-Plane Emulator may be configured to generate the time and frequency error of PTP and SyncE, 26 
either simultaneously or sequence.  27 
 CU and M plane messages do not need to be modified. It has no impact if they are delayed by the time and 28 
frequency error applied in this test. 29 
 The time error added to the input signal shall follow a sinusoidal waveform with amplitude (A) and frequency 30 
(f). Three such signal frequencies are specified for the test, but intermediate ones can be used for testing, as 31 
long as the following relationship between amplitude and frequency: A[ns] = 15[ppb]/(2*pi*f[Hz]) is 32 
maintained and simultaneously meets the 2a and 2b conditions above. An additional constant time error may 33 
be added to the sinusoidal waveform for each frequency, so that the maximum time error reaches the 34 
maximum value of 1420 ns: cTE[ns] = 1420[ns] - A[ns]. 35 
 Based on ITU-T analysis it is considered that the time error budget comprises both constant and dynamic 36 
errors. Because of this the time error budget is proposed to be split so that the constant time error represents at 37 
least half of the total budget. This is approximately consistent with ITU-T 8271.1. 38 
 Testing any higher frequency input noise than the ITU cut-off frequency (0.1Hz) would require using limits 39 
that are defined by vendor-specific parameters (CUS spec provides an example for a 75 MHz low pass filtering 40 
and 18ppb frequency noise generation O-RU). It is therefore outside the scope of this document and such 41 
performance must be validated by vendors and documented in test reports. 42 
 The following table and graph show the three sinusoidal time error waveforms to be used for testing: 43 
 44 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       338 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
Frequency 
[Hz] 
Dynamic Time Error  
Amplitude [ns] 
Constant Time  
Error [ns] Test duration [s] 
0.003362 710 710 595 (2 periods) 
0.010 239 1181 500 (5 periods) 
0.100 24 1396 50 (5 periods) 
Table 3.3.3-1 Time Error Limits for Test Signal 1 
 2 
  3 
Figure 3.3.3-1 Graph of Time Error Limits for Test Signal 4 
 5 
D. Pass/Fail Criteria (expected results)  6 
The results as measured for conducted or non-conducted (OTA) on the Air interface from the two conditions 7 
specified above shall be less than or equal to these values:  8 
1. Ideal Case:  9 
a. ±35 ppb maximum frequency error  10 
(3GPP limit 50 ppb - 15ppb = 35 ppb, where 15ppb is the error of a class A O-DU (worst-case)) 11 
b. +/-80ns maximum time error 12 
(3GPP limit 1500 ns – CUS spec 1420ns = 80 ns, where 1420ns is the error allocated to the O-DU for 13 
LLS-C1).   14 
c. As multiple O-RUs are not tested, there is no distinction between relative and absolute time error 15 
measurement. 16 
2. Normal Operation Case:  17 
a. ±50 ppb maximum frequency error  18 
(3GPP limit) 19 
b. ±1500ns maximum time error 20 
(3GPP limit).  21 
As multiple O-RUs are not tested, there is no distinction between relative and absolute time error measurement. 22 
Note: This test as currently defined does not provide any allowances for measurement error. It is left to the tester to 23 
factor in any errors based on the test equipment used. Defining the allowed measurement error is for future study. 24 
 25 
3.3.4 Performance test of O-RU using LLS-C4 26 
Testing of the O-RU in an LLS-C4 topology is for future study.  27 
 28

3.3.5 Functional test of O-DU Synchronized from ITU-T G.8275.1 profile 1 
PRTC/T-GM (LLS-C1/C2/C3/C4) 2 
A. Test Description and Applicability 3 
This test is MANDATORY. 4 
The purpose of this test is to validate that an O-DU is correctly synchronizing to a timing reference delivering by 5 
PTP (and optionally SyncE) when using ITU-T G.8275.1 [5] profile and that the O-DU correctly reports its status 6 
to the SMO or WG5 M-Plane controller based on the nominal or degraded synchronization conditions generated by 7 
CUSM Emulator.  8 
This test covers all cases where O-DU is synchronized using the Ethernet interface, whether the PRTC/T-GM is: 9 
 Local (direct link from a co-located equipment): case c in figure 3.3.1-1 10 
 Remote (network connection from a distant equipment): case d in figure 3.3.1-1 11 
These O-DU functional tests do not consider configurations which have multiple sources. It is assumed the O-DU 12 
has only a single synchronization source. Multiple sources such as a Multiport PTP/SyncE are for further study. 13 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 14 
O-DU is connected to the sync stimuli directly as shown in Figure 3.3.1-3 via the Ethernet Test Port.  15 
O-DU must be properly operating with the respective SMO or M-Plane (when WG5 M-Plane specification is 16 
available and implemented). (as described in 3.3.1). 17 
C. Test Methodology 18 
a. Initial Conditions 19 
This test uses the O-DU (DUT), a sync tester setup and SMO features to generate stimulus for the O-DU 20 
(DUT) and retrieve its sync status. For LLS-C1/C2 the fronthaul ports must be enabled as ITU-T G.8275.1 21 
synchronization master.  22 
b. Procedure 23 
Three conditions must be tested: 24 
Startup: The CUSM-E is configured to act as a clock, with PTP and SyncE ports in passive state (no messages 25 
sent). 26 
Nominal: The CUSM-E is configured to start acting as either a PTP master compliant with the ITU-T 27 
G.8275.1 [5] profile advertising LOCKED status with nominal clockClass and clockAccuracy. If SyncE 28 
is to be tested CUSM-E is configured to act as a clock, with SyncE ports in master state, compliant to 29 
ITU-T G.8264 profile advertising nominal SSM value as specified by ITU-T G.8275.1 [5]. 30 
Degraded: There are two levels of degraded conditions for both PTP and SyncE that the CUSM-E can be 31 
configured to. 32 
 The first degradation level is where the CUSM-E is configured to act as a clock, with PTP and SyncE 33 
ports in master state, compliant to ITU-T G.8275.1 profile, and sending configured clockClass and/or 34 
SSM values within the O-DU’s configured accepted limits via the M-plane.  35 
 The second degradation level is where the same clockClass and/or SSM values are sent by CUSM-E 36 
outside the O-DU’s configured accepted limits via the SMO (or M-plane). 37 
To cover the all the relevant PTP functional scenarios the test sequence listed in Table 3.3.5-1 steps through 38 
the Startup/Nominal/Degraded states in a sequence.  Since SyncE is optional, there are two columns, one for 39 
PTP status and a second for SyncE.   In this table each of the status items (Startup, Nominal, Degraded) 40 
correspond to the conditions defined above. 41 
 42

Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       340 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
Step PTP Status:  SyncE Status (if applicable): SSM 
1. Startup: no clockclass Startup: no SSM/QL 
2. Nominal clockclass=6 Nominal QL= (see Note 1) 
3. Degraded clockclass but within the O-DU’s 
configured accepted range. 
Nominal QL= (see Note 1) 
4. Degraded clockclass outside the O-DU’s 
configured accepted range. 
Nominal QL= (see Note 1) 
5. Degraded clockclass outside the O-DU’s 
configured accepted range. 
Degraded QL outside the O-RU’s configured accepted 
range. 
6. Nominal clockclass=6 Nominal QL= (see Note 1) 
7. Nominal clockclass=6 Degraded QL but within the O-DU’s configured 
accepted range. 
8. Nominal clockclass=6 Degraded QL outside the O-DU’s configured accepted 
range. 
9. Nominal clockclass=6 Nominal QL = (see Note1) 
10. S-Plane lost, no message S-Plane lost, no message 
Note 1: For SyncE, Nominal QL is what is determined as the best acceptable configured value by the O-DU 1 
Table 3.3.5-1 O-DU Functional Conformance Test Steps with PTP and SyncE Reference 2 
 3 
D. Pass Fail Criteria (expected results) 4 
The acceptance criterion is that the status reported by the O-DU for the steps defined in above procedure 5 
matches the results described in the 2 tables which follow, Table 3.3.5-2 and Table 3.3.5-3. The tables cover 2 6 
different use cases.  1) PTP without SyncE, and 2) PTP with SyncE. The test engineer should choose the 7 
appropriate table(s) based on the equipment’s intended application(s).    8 
Each of the tables are formatted similarly.  The left two columns indicate the procedural steps as defined in 9 
Table 3.3.2-1 . The right columns list the O-DU status parameters that are defined in the M-Plane specification 10 
[3] (chapter 13 Synchronization Aspects) and relevant YANG models. These parameters are queried from the 11 
test O-DU and their values should match those listed in the tables.  12 
When an O-DU’s selected time source is PTP and optional SyncE, the parameters to be checked are: Sync-13 
state, PTP sync-source-status, PTP clock-class, SyncE sync-source-status, SyncE quality-level. 14 
In LLS-C1 and LLS-C2 and regardless of the selected time source, the PTP Master sync-source-status, PTP 15 
Master clock class, SyncE Master sync-source-status, and SyncE Master Quality Level shall also be 16 
monitored. Specifically, for LLS-C1 configuration the emission of SyncE by O-DU is only mandatory if the O-17 
RU requires it. 18 
For PTP master clock-class, optional SyncE quality-level and master quality-level, the “Rcvd Value” table 19 
entry indicates that the value read should be the same as the one received by the O-DU (except in Startup and 20 
Disconnected modes when there is no such received value and the default one is reported).  21 
In case of local failure in the O-DU then O-DU should use FREERUN mode. 22 
These tests do not consider configurations which have multiple sources. This is for further study.  23

3.3.6 Functional test of O-DU Synchronized from Embedded or Local non-PTP 1 
PRTC (LLS-C1/C2/C3/C4) 2 
A. Test Description and Applicability 3 
This test is CONDITIONAL-MANDATORY. This test is mandatory if the DUT contains: 4 
 Either an O-DU with an embedded local PRTC using a GNSS receiver (see case a in figure 3.3.1-1) 5 
 Or an O-DU connected by a 1PPS + serial interface (e.g. ITU-T G.8271, see case b in figure 3.3.1-1) to a co-6 
located PRTC provided by the test setup. 7 
The purpose of this test is to validate that an O-DU is correctly synchronizing to a non-PTP local time source and 8 
that the O-DU correctly reports its status to the SMO or WG5 M-Plane controller based on the nominal or degraded 9 
synchronization conditions generated by CUSM Emulator.  10 
This O-DU functional test does not consider configurations which have multiple time sources.  11 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 12 
O-DU is connected to the time sync stimuli directly as shown in Figure 3.3.1-3 via the GNSS RF signal or local 13 
PRTC output signals.  14 
O-DU must be properly operating with the respective SMO or M-Plane (when WG5 M-Plane specification is 15 
available and implemented) emulator components. (as described in 3.3.1). 16 
C. Test Methodology 17 
a. Initial Conditions 18 
This test uses a time reference, synchronization tester setup and SMO/M-Plane functions to generate stimulus 19 
for the O-DU (DUT) and then retrieves the O-DU’s sync status. For LLS-C1/C2 the fronthaul ports must be 20 
enabled as an ITU-T G.8275.1 synchronization master.  21 
b. Procedure 22 
Three conditions must be tested: 23 
Startup: The CUSM-E is configured to act as a clock, with its output signals (either GNSS RF or PRTC ones) 24 
not started sending time information to DUT. 25 
Nominal: The CUSM-E is configured to start delivering output signals (either GNSS RF or PRTC ones) in 26 
LOCKED status with optimal time and state information.  27 
Degraded: The degraded conditions for GNSS receiver’s or PRTC output are not well defined.  There are no 28 
defined “slightly degraded” or “severely degraded” signal indications. Thus, the indication of a 29 
degraded state may be implementation specific.  Further, a degraded GNSS scenario is the only 30 
condition which causes the O-DU to lose its locked status.  31 
For GNSS RF signals, one proposal is to simulate the reception of a single satellite with a low signal level. 32 
However, all GNSS receivers may not offer the same sensitivity and robustness to this scenario. 33 
For GNSS-based PRTC output signals, one proposal is to advertise an alarm on poor signal status, but every 34 
protocol may have its own alarm mapping 35 
To cover the all the relevant functional scenarios the test sequence listed in Table 3.3.6-1 steps through the 36 
Startup/Nominal/Degraded states in order.  In this table each of the status items corresponds to the conditions 37 
defined above. 38 
 39 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       344 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
Step GNSS RF or PRTC output Status 
1. Startup Status (and GNSS Acquiring Mode if implemented) Note 1. 
2. Nominal 
3. Degraded, 
4. Nominal 
5. Failed (no signal) 
Note 1: After a power cycle it may take some time for GNSS receiver or PRTC to complete self-survey and 1 
progress to Nominal mode.  2 
Table 3.3.6-1 O-DU Functional Conformance Test Steps with GNSS Reference 3 
D. Pass Fail Criteria (expected results) 4 
The acceptance criterion when the O-DU uses GNSS is that the status reported by the O-DU for the steps 5 
defined in the above procedure in Table 3.3.6-1 matches the results described in Table 3.3.6-2.  The left 6 
column of this table indicates the procedural step numbers as defined in Table 3.3.2-8. The second column 7 
summarizes the O-DU status for each step.  The right 7 columns list the O-DU status parameters as they are 8 
defined in the M-Plane specification [3] (chapter 13 Synchronization Aspects) and relevant YANG models. 9 
These columns show the required values of the parameters queried from the test O-DU under test.  10 
When an O-DU’s selected time source is GNSS and optional SyncE, the input parameters to be queried are: 11 
Sync-state, GNSS sync-source-status, GNSS sync-status. 12 
Regardless of the selected time source the output parameters which are monitored are the PTP Master sync-13 
source-status, PTP Master clock-class, SyncE Master sync-source-status, and SyncE Master quality-level. 14 
Specifically, for LLS-C1 configuration the emission of SyncE by O-DU is only mandatory if O-RU requires it. 15 
SyncE assistance for GNSS is not considered in this test case and is left for future study. 16 
 17

Note 2: After HOLDOVER (relying on local oscillator) expires, then O-DU goes to FREERUN. In CUS-Plane 19 
specification the FREERUN state is defined to occur at start up prior to O-DU acquiring LOCK, and 20 
it also occurs when O-DU is in HOLDOVER and the reference is no longer within specification. 21

an O-DU acting as a Grandmaster clock. 23

 1 
3.3.7 Performance test of O-DU Synchronized from either Local or Remote PRTC 2 
using ITU-T G.8275.1 PTP Profile (LLS-C1/C2/C3/C4) 3 
A. Test Description and Applicability 4 
This test scope is relevant to LLS-C1 to LLS-C4. 5 
This test is CONDITIONAL-MANDATORY for O-DUs which support LLS-C1, LLS-C2 and do not only derive 6 
their timing information from an embedded PRTC.   7 
This test is OPTIONAL for O-DUs that only support LLS-C3 or LLS-C4 topology and is dependent on the 8 
availability of a measurement point.  For equipment that only supports LLS-C3 or LLS-C4, if the measurement 9 
point is not available, then the O-DU shall document that this conformance test cannot be performed. 10 
This test validates that an O-DU correctly synchronizes to incoming S-Plane timing information, from a CUSM-11 
plane Emulator which is emulating: 12 
 Either a local PRTC (using 1PPS+ serial link interface, e.g. ITU-T G.8271, see case b in figure 3.3.1-1) or 13 
local PRTC/T-GM (PTP and optionally SyncE, see case c in figure 3.3.1-1) and meeting ITU-T G.8271.1 14 
reference point B network limits. 15 
 Or a remote PRTC/T-GM (PTP and optionally SyncE, see case d in figure 3.3.1-1) meeting ITU-T G.8271.1 16 
reference point C network limits. The CUSM-E may be configured to inject either ideal or normal operating 17 
condition noise into the S-Plane timing information. Frequency and time error measured at the output of the O-18 
DU must be within specified limits, which may differ between LLS-C1-C4 configurations.  19 
As an example, the local reference link may use ITU-T G.8271 Annex A “1PPS+ToD” protocol. 20 
This test covers the two classes defined by CUS -plane spec for LLS -C1 and LLS -C2 (class A has ±15 ppb 21 
frequency error limit; class B has ±5 ppb limit).  22 
This test is defined assuming a Full Timing Support (FTS) profile used on all PTP ports of the O-DU.  Partial 23 
timing support is left for further study. 24 
The test intent is to exercise S-Plane performance under ideal and a typical/normal operating condition.  The test is 25 
not intended to exercise worst case conditions. It is the vendor’s responsibility to make sure that limits defined in 26 
the test are also met in worse-case field conditions.  Variable temperature, PTP PDV tolerance and SyncE 27 
jitter/wander tolerance, holdover and transients are beyond the scope of the CUS-Plane specification. 28 
 29 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 30 
Conformance Functional test 3.3.5 has successfully passed. 31 
O-DU is connected to CUSM-Plane Emulator’s time reference output interface.  32 
O-DU is connected to CUSM-E’s SMO or M-Plane function. (as defined in 3.3.1) 33 
C. Test Methodology 34 
a. Initial Conditions 35 
These tests configure the DUT (O-DU) using the CUSM-Plane emulator’s SMO or M-Plane features.  The O-36 
DU configuration depends on which LLS-C1-C4 topologies are to be tested and also it depends on whether the 37 
PRTC is local or remote.   38 
For LLS-C1 and LLS-C2 configuration, the test is set up to measure frequency and time error on one of the 39 
Ethernet master fronthaul ports of the DUT. 40 
For LLS-C3 and LLS-C4 configuration, the test is configured to measure time error on a measurement port of 41 
the O-DU, typically a 1PPS signal if available or an unused Ethernet port. 42 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       346 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
CUSM-Plane Emulator is configured to act as a clock, with PTP ports in master state, compliant to ITU-T 1 
G.8275.1 profile advertising LOCKED status with nominal clockClass and clockAccuracy. 2 
CUSM-Plane Emulator is configured to act as a clock, with SyncE ports in master state, compliant to ITU-T 3 
G.8264 profile advertising nominal SSM value.  4 
CUSM-Plane Emulator is configured to deliver 1PPS and act as a PRTC advertising LOCKED status over its 5 
serial link with nominal quality level (whatever protocol is used, ITU-T G.8271 or proprietary).  6 
Once the DUT has been configured, the DUT shall have achieved frequency and phase lock prior to starting 7 
the test. 8 
b. Procedure:  9 
Unlike the functional test defined in section 3.3.5 3.3.2, where start-up / nominal / degraded scenarios are 10 
tested, only nominal scenarios with ideal and normal operation input noise are tested in this section. 11 
1. Ideal Operation: The time source provides “ideal” O-DU synchronization input with no implicitly 12 
added dynamic or constant time error. This applies when testing with either a local or remote time 13 
source. 14 
2. Normal Operation: The time source provides an input stimulus with some added noise that is “within 15 
normal operating limits.” O-DU inputs as specified in CUS-Plane Specification [1]. The TEL stimulus is 16 
split between dynamic (|dTEL|) and constant (|cTE|) and is shown in Table 3.3.3-11The maximum time 17 
error (|TEL|) is  18 
 1100ns at ITU-T G.8271.1 section 7.3 reference point C (for remote PRTC/T-GM over PTP) . 19 
 100ns at ITU-T G.8271.1 section 7.2 reference point B (for both local PRTC/T-GM over PTP, and PRTC 20 
over 1PPS+ serial link interface) 21 
The TEL stimulus is split between dynamic (|dTEL|) and constant (|cTE|) and is shown in Table 3.3.7-1.  The 22 
time error added to the input signal shall follow a sinusoidal waveform with amplitude (A) and frequency (f) as 23 
specified in Table 3.3.7-1. Three such signal frequencies are specified for this test, but intermediate ones can 24 
be used for testing as well. 25 
 26 
Frequency 
[Hz] 
At Reference Point C At Reference Point B 
Test 
Duration [s] 
Dynamic 
Time Error  
Amplitude 
[ns] (Note 1) 
Constant 
Time  
Error [ns] 
Dynamic 
Time Error  
Amplitude 
[ns] (Note 2)

D. Pass/Fail Criteria (expected results)  4 
The measured results for Ideal and Normal Operation Cases shall be less than or equal to these values:  5 
a.  Maximum 0.1Hz low pass filtered frequency error for LLS-C1 and LLS-C2  6 
±15 ppb for class A O-DU 7 
±5 ppb for class B O-DU 8 
b. Maximum 0.1Hz low pass filtered time error (see note) 9 
±1420ns for LLS-C1. 10 
±1325ns for LLS-C2. 11 
±1500ns for LLS-C3 and LLS-C4. 12 
Note: This test as currently defined does not provide any allowances for measurement error. It is left to the tester to 13 
factor in any errors based on the test equipment used. Defining the allowed measurement error is for future study. 14 
 15 
3.3.8 Performance test of O-DU Synchronized from Embedded GNSS receiver 16 
(LLS-C1/C2/C3/C4) 17 
A. Test Description and Applicability 18 
This test scope is relevant to LLS-C1 to LLS-C4. 19 
This test is CONDITIONAL-MANDATORY. This test is mandatory if the DUT contains  an O-DU with an 20 
embedded local PRTC using a GNSS receiver (see case a in figure 3.3.1-1). 21 
This test validates that an O-DU correctly synchronizes to incoming timing information, from a CUSM-plane 22 
Emulator which is emulating a GNSS transmitter’s RF signal. The DUT shall contain a GNSS receiver, either 23 
embedded within the O-DU, or directly connected to the O-DU.  The CUSM-E may be configured to inject either 24 
ideal or normal operating condition noise into the timing information. Frequency and time error measured at the 25 
output of the O-DU must be within specified limits, which may differ between LLS-C1-C4 configurations.  26 
Note: Configuring the CUSM-E to inject normal operating condition noise is for further study. 27 
This test covers the two classes defined by CUS -plane spec for LLS -C1 and LLS -C2 (class A has ±15 ppb 28 
frequency error limit; class B has ±5 ppb limit).  29 
The test intent is to exercise S-Plane performance under ideal and a typical/normal operating condition.  The test is 30 
not intended to exercise worst case conditions. It is the vendor’s responsibility to make sure that limits defined in 31 
the test are also met in worse-case field conditions.  Variable temperature, degraded GNSS reception (degraded sky 32 
1901551402517121010010000.001 0.01 0.1Time Error (ns)Frequency (Hertz)O-DU Input Time Error Amplitude vs. FrequencyDynamic Time Error Point CDynamic Time Error Point B

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       348 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
view, multipath, jamming, spoofing etc.), holdover and transients are beyond the scope of the CUS-Plane 1 
specification. 2 
This test is defined assuming a Full Timing Support (FTS) profile on all PTP ports.  Partial timing support is left 3 
for further study. 4 
 5 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 6 
Conformance Functional test Error! Reference source not found. has successfully passed. 7 
O-DU is connected to CUSM-Plane Emulator’s GNSS time reference RF interface.  8 
O-DU is connected to CUSM-E’s SMO or M-Plane function. (as defined in 3.2.1.1.5) 9 
C. Test Methodology 10 
a. Initial Conditions 11 
These tests configure the DUT (O-DU) using the CUSM-Plane emulator’s SMO or M-Plane features.  The O-12 
DU configuration depends on which LLS-C1-C4 topologies are to be tested.   13 
For LLS-C1 and LLS-C2 configuration, the test is set up to measure frequency and time error on one of the 14 
Ethernet master fronthaul ports of the DUT. 15 
For LLS-C3 and LLS-C4 configuration, the test is configured to measure time error on a measurement port of 16 
the O-DU, typically a 1PPS signal if available or an unused Ethernet port configured as a PTP master. 17 
CUSM-Plane Emulator is configured to act as a GNSS transmitter, with time reference which is traceable to 18 
UTC. 19 
Once the DUT has been configured, the DUT shall have achieved frequency and phase lock prior to starting 20 
the test. 21 
b. Procedure:  22 
Unlike the functional test defined in section Error! Reference source not found.3.3.2, where start-up / 23 
nominal / degraded scenarios are tested, only nominal scenarios with ideal and normal operation input noise 24 
are tested. The test procedure is the same for both ideal and normal scenarios, the only difference is the noise 25 
settings for the timing source. 26 
3. Ideal Operation: The time source provides “ideal” O-DU synchronization input with no implicitly 27 
added dynamic or constant time error.  28 
4. Normal Operation: This test is for further study  29 
 30 
D. Pass/Fail Criteria (expected results)  31 
The measured results for Ideal and Normal Operation Cases shall be less than or equal to these values:  32 
a.  Maximum 0.1Hz low pass filtered frequency error for LLS-C1 and LLS-C2  33 
±15 ppb for class A O-DU 34 
±5 ppb for class B O-DU 35 
b. Maximum 0.1Hz low pass filtered time error  36 
±1420ns for LLS-C1. 37 
±1325ns for LLS-C2. 38 
±1500ns for LLS-C3 and LLS-C4. 39 
 40 
Note: This test as currently defined does not provide any allowances for measurement error. It is left to the tester to 41 
factor in any errors based on the test equipment used. Defining the allowed measurement error is for future study. 42 
 43 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       349 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
3.4 UC-Plane Measurements O-DU 1 
3.4.1 UC-Plane Tests 2 
This section describes conformance test scenarios for O-DU equipment implementing the U-Plane and C-Plane O-RAN 3 
option 7.2x protocols.  In these set of tests, the device under test (DUT) is either a stand-alone O-DU, or a combined O-4 
CU + O-DU from a single vendor.  Throughout this section, we may refer to the DUT generically as the O-DU for 5 
brevity, keeping in mind that there are these two potential DUT variants. 6 
3.4.2 UC-Plane Standard Test Definitions 7 
Section 2.2 outlines the test configuration for the O-DU tests in this section and provides an overview of the Test 8 
Equipment O-DU (TED) required to conduct the tests.  The following are the generic test steps to be used, although 9 
specific tests may deviate from this general procedure: 10 
1) Configure the Test Equipment, O-DU (TED) for test execution, which may include defining the specific test to 11 
execute. This includes configuring the various components comprising the TED:   12 
a. Configure the Core Emulator (and O-CU Emulator in the case of a stand-alone O-DU DUT) and the 13 
X2 signalling emulator for NSA mode such that it is ready to communicate with the DUT via the 14 
appropriate interfaces for the specific test scenario 15 
b. Configure the O-RU + UE Emulator such that it is ready to communicate to the DUT over the 16 
CUSM-planes of the open fronthaul interface for the specific test scenario, which may include 17 
configuring the O-RU emulator to emulate a certain type of O-RU, e.g. CAT-A, CAT-B, TDD, FDD; 18 
and configuring the UE emulator appropriately such that it can connect to the network for the specific 19 
test scenario      20 
2) Configure the O-DU DUT via the O1 (if available) or EMS interface to provision the DUT in order to place it 21 
into the appropriate modes to exercise the specific scenario and features under test.  Note that these should not 22 
be special test modes but are instead production modes that are used for provisioning the commercial O-DU to 23 
support various deployment configurations 24 
3) Instruct the UE Emulator to initiate a connection with the O-DU DUT through the O-RU emulator via the open 25 
fronthaul interface and on to the rest of the emulated network via the F1 interface 26 
4) Observe that the UE Emulator successfully attaches to the network and has successful data communications in 27 
both the downlink and uplink 28 
5) Perform detailed observation and analysis of the front haul data stream of the O-DU DUT in order to ascertain 29 
compliance to the specifications.   30 
 31 
3.4.3 Minimum Capabilities of the TED for U-Plane and C-Plane Tests 32 
Since many features of the O-RAN protocol rely on the O-DU instructing the O-RU to put data in specific resource 33 
blocks using a specific compression method it is imperative that the test equipment support features that allow detailed 34 
observation and analysis of the front haul data stream.  Furthermore, since the O-DU is meant to support various classes 35 
of O-RU with different feature sets, e.g. CAT-A or CAT-B, FR1 or FR2, different beamforming methods to multiple 36 
UEs, different compression schemes, etc.., it is important that the TED has the flexibility to effectively emulate the 37 
various scenarios in a robust and repeatable manner in order to test the various features.  As noted in Sec 2.2, this 38 
specification does not preclude the use of the commercial equivalent elements instead of emulators, but must support a 39 
level of configurability and repeatability to ensure that the required features in the O-DU front-haul are effectively and 40 
repeatably exercised.  With use of either node emulators or commercial equivalents, the required test outcomes and 41 
reports must be effectively and repeatably reproduced.  The rest of this section shall assume emulators are used for 42 
brevity of description.             43 
 Core + O-CU Emulator for Testing a Stand-alone O-DU DUT 44 
 Must have the capability of emulating and observing the appropriate signals at the F1 interface that enables the 45 
O-DU DUT to support connecting with the UE Emulator through the O-RU Emulator via the open front haul   46 
 Must have the capability of supporting the various modes that the O-DU DUT shall be provisioned to via the 47 
O1 or EMS interface for the various test cases and scenarios  48 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       350 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 Core Emulator for Testing a Combined O-CU + O-DU DUT 1 
 Must have the capability of emulating an EPC (NSA/LTE) or NGC (SA) and observing the appropriate signals 2 
at the NG (SA) or S1 (NSA) interface that enables the O-DU DUT to support connecting with the UE 3 
Emulator through the O-RU Emulator via the open front haul   4 
 Must have the capability of supporting the various modes that the O-DU DUT shall be provisioned to via the 5 
O1 or EMS interface for the various test cases and scenarios  6 
 X2 Signalling Emulator for NSA 7 
 Must have the capability of emulating the signalling over the X2 interface to the O-CU Emulator for the case 8 
of testing a Stand-alone O-DU DUT, or to the actual O-CU for the case of testing combined O-CU+O-DU 9 
DUT, in order to support an NSA connection 10 
 Must have the capability of supporting the various modes that the O-DU DUT shall be provisioned to via the 11 
O1 or EMS interface for the various test cases and scenarios  12 
 13 
 O-RU Emulator 14 
 Must have the capability of emulating various types of O-RUs in order to exercise the various features of the 15 
open front haul of the O-DU DUT 16 
 Must be able to be synchronized with the O-DU DUT to ensure proper timing of uplink C-Plane and U-Plane 17 
messages 18 
 Must be able to observe and analyze the front haul data stream of the O-DU DUT in order to ascertain 19 
compliance to the specifications of the specific test scenario 20 
 UE Emulator 21 
 Must have the capability of emulating a UE (or multiple UEs in the case of beamforming tests) that can 22 
successfully complete a connection with the O-DU DUT all the way through to the Core Emulator  23 
 Must be able to connect with the O-RU Emulator through a digital or RF interface 24 
 Must be able to observe and analyze the state of the connection and the uplink and downlink throughput in 25 
order to ascertain the successful connection with the network through the O-DU DUT  26 
 Test Configurator through O1 or EMS Interface 27 
 Must be able to interface with the O1 (if available) or EMS interface of the O-DU DUT 28 
 Must be able to setup test scenarios and coordinate the entities in the TED to perform the required test 29 
scenarios 30 
3.4.4 UC-Plane O-DU Test Scenarios  31 
 UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class NR testing Generic (NRG)  32 
The purpose of the tests in this section are to ensure that the O-DU DUT supports the mandatory open front haul 33 
features of the specification as defined in the Control, User and Synchronization Plane Specification [2] Table 8-2.   34 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       351 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Base CAT-A O-RU 1 
A. Test Description and Applicability 2 
This test is MANDATORY. 3 
 4 
The purpose of this test is to ensure that the O-DU can meet the most basic requirements of the O-RAN fronthaul to 5 
support connecting with a CAT-A O-RU with no beamforming and 16-bit fixed point IQ format.   6 
 7 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 8 
The O-DU DUT must be provisioned to connect with a CAT-A O-RU for 5G New Radio and be able to 9 
synchronize with the O-RU emulator of the TED.  The O-DU DUT could use any of the NR profiles for CAT-A O-10 
RU as specified in the Fronthaul Interoperability Test Specification [25] in Annex A.2 (except using 16-bit fixed 11 
point IQ format), or any other suitable profile that satisfies the test scenario.   12 
 13 
C. Test Methodology 14 
1. Initial Conditions 15 
Configure the O-DU DUT such that it is ready to accept a UE connection through its interfaces with 16 
the appropriate entities in the TED.  Configure the O-RU Emulator to be a CAT-A O-RU with no 17 
beamforming and 16-bit fixed point IQ format. 18 
2. Procedure 19 
i. Instruct the UE Emulator to initiate a connection with the O-DU DUT through the O-RU 20 
emulator  21 
ii. Initiate data transmission on both the downlink and uplink  22 
iii. Log and analyze the open front haul data stream between the O-DU DUT and O-RU 23 
Emulator including used section types and section extensions  24 
 25 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 26 
1. Non-zero data throughput in both uplink and downlink is observed 27 
2. Log of section types and section extensions successfully used  28 
 29 
 30 
 31 
 UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Base CAT-B O-RU 32 
A. Test Description and Applicability 33 
This test is MANDATORY. 34 
 35 
The purpose of this test is to ensure that the O-DU can meet the most basic requirements of the O-RAN fronthaul to 36 
support connecting with a CAT-B O-RU with beam-index based beamforming and 16-bit fixed point IQ format.   37 
 38 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 39 
The O-DU DUT must be provisioned to connect with a CAT-B O-RU for 5G New Radio and be able to 40 
synchronize with the O-RU emulator of the TED.  The O-DU DUT could use any of the NR profiles for a CAT-B 41 
O-RU as specified in the Fronthaul Interoperability Test Specification [25], e.g. Annex A.2 (except using 16-bit 42 
fixed point IQ format), or any other suitable profile that satisfies the test scenario.   43 
 44 
C. Test Methodology 45 
a. Initial Conditions 46 
Configure the O-DU DUT such that it is ready to accept a UE connection through its interfaces with 47 
the appropriate entities in the TED.  Configure the O-RU Emulator to be a CAT-B O-RU with beam-48 
index based beamforming and 16-bit fixed point IQ format. 49 
b. Procedure 50 
i. Instruct the UE Emulator to initiate a connection with the O-DU DUT through the O-RU 51 
emulator  52 
ii. Initiate data transmission on both the downlink and uplink  53 
iii. Log and analyze the open front haul data stream between the O-DU DUT and O-RU 54 
Emulator including used section types and section extensions  55 
 56 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 57
