1. Non-zero data throughput in both uplink and downlink is observed 1 
2. Log of section types and section extensions successfully used  2 
 3 
 UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Beamforming (BFM)  4 
This section describes beamforming conformance tests for O-RAN fronthaul interface on the O-DU. The tests do not 5 
aim to test the O-DU beamforming performance or general capabilities.   The conformance tests are designed to 6 
validate that the O-DU correctly describes the Beamforming methods via C-plane messages according to the O-RAN 7 
Fronthaul interface spec. The tests are configured following the outline in the section 2.2 description of the TED.  8 
As noted earlier in section 2.2, the O-DU is assumed to be a commercial product that may support a limited set of  9 
configurations.  Therefore, these beamforming tests will present a suggested method for evaluating protocol 10 
conformance.  The tester may choose other configurations which also clearly evaluate the conformance of the O-DU to 11 
the same protocol syntax and semantics.  12 
 13 
 UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP – Predefined-beam Beamforming 14 
 15 
A. Test Description and Applicability 16 
This test is MANDATORY. 17 
The purpose of this test is to validate the basic operation of the O-DU DUT when configured to use predefined-beams 18 
in a O-RU.  19 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 20 
The O-DU DUT must be provisioned to connect with an O-RU for 5G New Radio and be able to synchronize to a 21 
common sync source with the O-RU emulator of the TED.  The O-DU DUT could use any of the NR BF profiles for O-22 
RU as specified in the Fronthaul Interoperability Test Specification [25] in Annex A.2 (except using 16-bit fixed point 23 
IQ format), or any other suitable profile that satisfies the test scenario. 24 
 25 
The O-DU DUT must exercise at least two different beams to serve at least two SS Blocks (SSBs) and beam sweeping.  26 
The two beams under test, i.e. beam=A and beam=B, can have neither a vector size of one (i.e. only contains a single 27 
beam weight value) nor have identical beam weight values (i.e. no beamforming).   Additionally, O-DU DUT cannot 28 
assign beamId=0x0000 (i.e. no beamforming) to any of the two beams when sending beamforming information to the 29 
O-RU emulator. The O-DU might retrieve a list of O-RU beam capabilities to be able to generate beam weight vectors 30 
supported by the O-RU emulator. The O-DU DUT will use at least any two set of beam weight vectors to converge 31 
beamforming information to the O-RU emulator along with the test vectors (IQ data) containing SSB.    32 
 33 
The O-RU emulator must be configured to report support for weight-based beamforming in the M-Plane capabilities to 34 
allow the O-DU DUT to use weight-based beamforming.  It is assumed that the O-DU can be configured in some way 35 
to force the use of dynamic weight-based beamforming.   36 
 37 
C. Test Methodology 38 
a. Initial Conditions 39 
Configure the O-DU DUT such that it carries out the use of SSBs and beam sweeping through its interfaces 40 
with the appropriate entities in the TED.  Configure the O-RU Emulator with weight-based beamforming 41 
and 16-bit fixed point IQ format.  42 
b. Procedure 43 
i. O-DU DUT starts broadcasting procedure and beam sweeping 44 
ii. Log and analyze the open front haul data stream between the O-DU DUT and O-RU Emulator including 45 
used section types and section extensions 46 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 47 
a. Successful decoding of SSBs 48 
b. Log of at least two different assigned beamIds (i.e. beamId=A and beamId=B) are used and none of them are 49 
beamId=0x0000 50 
c. Log of at least two different assigned beam weight vectors are used for beam=A and beam=B. 51 
 52 
 53 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       353 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Beamforming 3GPP – Weight-based Beamforming 1 
A. Test Description and Applicability 2 
This test is CONDITIONAL MANDATORY. 3 
 4 
The purpose of this test is to ensure that the O-DU can meet the most basic requirements of the O-RAN fronthaul to 5 
support connecting with a O-RU emulator with weight-based beamforming. This test exercises the beamId field found 6 
in the C-plane section descriptions as well as section extension = 1 to converge beamforming information to the O-RU 7 
emulator of TED.   8 
 9 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 10 
The O-DU DUT must be provisioned to connect with an O-RU for 5G New Radio and is synchronized with the O-RU 11 
emulator of the TED.  The O-DU DUT could use any of the NR BF profiles for O-RU as specified in the Fronthaul 12 
Interoperability Test Specification [25] in Annex A.2 (except using 16-bit fixed point IQ format), or any other suitable 13 
profile that satisfies the test scenario. 14 
 15 
The O-DU must exercise at least two different DL beams. In matrix form, the column dimension of the beam weights, 16 
as defined in Section Extension Type 1, Section 5.4.7.1 of [2], corresponds to the number of beamIds, and the row 17 
dimension to the number of TRXs of the O-RU emulator. The number of beamIds must be greater than or equal to 2. 18 
Additionally, O-DU DUT cannot assign beamId=0x0000 (i.e. no beamforming) to any of the two beams when sending 19 
beamforming information to the O-RU emulator. 20 
 21 
The O-DU might retrieve a list of O-RU beam capabilities to be able to generate beam weight vectors (i.e., columns of 22 
the beam weight matrix) supported by the O-RU emulator. The O-DU DUT will use at least two beam weight vectors to 23 
convey beamforming information to the O-RU emulator along with the test vectors (IQ data).    24 
 25 
The O-RU emulator must be configured to report support for weight-based beamforming in the M-Plane capabilities to 26 
allow the O-DU DUT to use weight-based beamforming.  It is assumed that the O-DU can be configured in some way 27 
to force the use of dynamic weight-based beamforming.   28 
 29 
C. Test Methodology 30 
a. Initial Conditions 31 
Configure the O-DU DUT such that it carries out the broadcasting of common control channels (e.g., SSB) 32 
through its interfaces with the appropriate entities in the TED.  Configure the O-RU Emulator with weight-33 
based beamforming and 16-bit fixed point IQ format.  34 
b. Procedure 35 
i. O-DU DUT starts broadcasting procedure and beam sweeping 36 
ii. Log and analyze the open front haul data stream between the O-DU DUT and O-RU Emulator including 37 
used section types and section extensions 38 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 39 
a. Successful decoding of one or more SSBs 40 
b. Log of at least two different assigned beamIds (i.e. beamId=A and beamId=B) are used and none of them are 41 
beamId=0x0000 42 
c. Log of at least two different assigned beam weight vectors are used for beam=A and beam=B. 43 
 44 
 45 
 46 
 47 
 UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Compression (CMP)  48 
This section validates the correct implementation of mandatory and conditional mandatory IQ data compression formats 49 
in [2]. 50 
It applies to the following CUS fronthaul specification sections in [2]. 51 
 Section 5.4.2 for layout of C-Plane message, in particular Section Type 1 52 
 Section 5.4.4.10 for applicability of “udCompHdr” and “reserved” fields 53 
 Section 6.3.2 for layout of DL/UL Data 54 
 Section 6.3.3.13/14/15 for applicability of udCompParam 55 
 56 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       354 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
The objective is to test the mandatory and conditional mandatory compression capabilities of  a O-RAN compliant O-1 
DU. These include: 2 
 Mandatory: Static Fixed-Point Uncompressed 16-bit IQ 3 
 Conditional Mandatory: Static Block floating point compression – 9, 12 & 14-bit mantissa 4 
 5 
Overview of Compression Test Methodology 6 
For both downlink and uplink testing, the test will validate that non-zero user data throughput is achieved in both 7 
directions and that the section headers for CU plane in the downlink are consistent with the specification [2]. 8 
To maximise coverage on the compressed IQ mantissa value, the test frame will use the highest possible modulation 9 
supported by the O-DU.  The preferred value is 256 QAM modulation for downlink and uplink. 10 
Presence/Absence of CU-Plane Header measurements (downlink only): Validate that the fields udCompHdr, and 11 
“reserved” are absent in downlink U-Plane. For Static Block Floating Point Compression, only udCompParam is present 12 
in downlink U-Plane. For downlink C-Plane, validate that the udCompHdr is set to 0. 13 
 14 
 Static Format Fixed-Point (FP) Uncompressed 15 
A. Test Description and Applicability 16 
This test is MANDATORY. 17 
 18 
The purpose of this test is to: 19 
 Validate correct format of Control Plane Section Header 20 
o udCompHdr set to 0x0 21 
 Validate that in the data section header, udCompHdr, “reserved”, and udCompParam fields are not 22 
present 23 
 Validate correct encoding/decoding of IQ data 24 
o Fixed point 16 Bit IQ data format 25 
o Uplink / downlink 26 
 27 
The purpose of this test is to ensure that the O-DU can meet the mandatory requirements of the O-RAN fronthaul to 28 
support compression. 29 
 30 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 31 
The O-DU DUT must be provisioned to connect with a O-RU for 5G New Radio and be able to synchronize with the 32 
O-RU emulator or real O-RU.  The O-DU DUT could use any of the NR profiles as specified in the Fronthaul 33 
Interoperability Test Specification [25],  Annex A.2.  Compression is further adjusted as described below. 34 
 35 
C. Test Methodology 36 
a. Initial Conditions 37 
 Configure the O-DU DUT such that it is ready to accept a UE connection through its interfaces 38 
with the appropriate entities in the TED.  39 
 Configure O-DU for 16-bit fixed point IQ format. 40 
 Configure the O-RU Emulator with 16-bit fixed point IQ format. 41 
 42 
b. Procedure 43 
1. Instruct the UE Emulator or UE to initiate a connection with the O-DU DUT through the O-RU 44 
emulator or O-RU  45 
2. Initiate data transmission on both the downlink and uplink. 46 
3. Record the total throughput in each direction for comparison in additional test cases. 47 
4. Note any errors reported by the O-RU emulator for downlink compression.  Alternatively, using the 48 
log information from the O-RU emulator, analyze the open front haul data stream between the O-49 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       355 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
DU DUT and O-RU Emulator to confirm proper transmission of the downlink U-Plane data with 1 
16-bit fixed point format. 2 
5. Analyze any C-Plane errors reported by the O-RU emulator related to compression or sample the 3 
log file to validate compression header information.  4 
 5 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 6 
1. Validate that the Control Plane Section Header has udCompHdr set to 0x0 7 
2. Validate that udCompHdr, “reserved” and udCompParam fields are absent in Downlink Data Section Header 8 
3. Non-zero data throughput in both uplink and downlink is observed 9 
4. There are no errors in step 4 of the procedure 10 
 11 
 12 
 13 
 14 
 15 
 16 
 17 
 UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Compression (CMP) Static Format Block Floating 18 
Point 19 
A. Test Description and Applicability 20 
This test is CONDITIONALMANDATORY and shall be performed if the emulated O-RU or real O-RU supports 21 
this compression format. 22 
The static format test scenario for Block Floating Point Format will verify DL and UL correct encoding of IQ 23 
information for 3 supported bit widths: 9, 14 or 12 bits. 24 
 25 
The purpose of this test is to: 26 
 Validate correct format of Control Plane Section Header 27 
o udCompHdr set to 0x00 28 
 Validate that in the data section header, udCompHdr and “reserved” fields are not present 29 
 Validate correct encoding/decoding of IQ data 30 
o 9 bits IQ Data 31 
o 14 bits IQ Data 32 
o 12 bits IQ Data 33 
o Uplink / downlink 34 
 35 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       356 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
 1 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 2 
The O-DU DUT must be provisioned to connect with a O-RU for 5G New Radio and be able to synchronize with the 3 
O-RU emulator or real O-RU.  The O-DU DUT could use any of the NR profiles as specified in the Fronthaul 4 
Interoperability Test Specification [25],  Annex A.2.  Compression is further adjusted as described below. 5 
C. Test Methodology 6 
a. Initial Conditions 7 
 Configure the O-DU DUT such that it is ready to accept a UE connection through its interfaces 8 
with the appropriate entities in the TED.  9 
 10 
b. Procedure 11 
1. Configure O-DU for 14-bit Static Format BFP Compression. 12 
2. Configure the O-RU for 14-bit Static Format BFP Compression. 13 
3. Instruct the UE Emulator or UE to initiate a connection with the O-DU DUT through the O-RU 14 
emulator or O-RU  15 
4. Initiate data transmission on both the downlink and uplink.  16 
5. Record the total throughput in each direction and validate that user data throughput is non-zero.  17 
6. Note any errors reported by the O-RU emulator for downlink compression.  Alternatively, using 18 
the log information from the O-RU emulator, analyze the open front haul data stream between the 19 
O-DU DUT and O-RU Emulator to confirm proper transmission of the downlink U-Plane data. 20 
7. Analyze any C-Plane errors reported by the O-RU emulator related to compression or sample the 21 
log file to validate compression header information. 22 
8. Repeat steps 1- 7 with the configuration set to 9 bit Static Format Block Floating Point  23 
9. Repeat steps 1- 7 with the configuration set to 12 bit Static Format Block Floating Point  24 
 25 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 26 
a. Step 5 in each repetition meet the expected results 27 
b. Steps 6 and 7 for each repetition do not show any errors 28 
 29 
 UC-Plane O-DU Scenario Class Delay Management (DLM) 30 
 Delay Management On-time arrival 31 
A. Test Description and Applicability 32 
This test is MANDATORY. 33 
 34 
The purpose of this test is to ensure that the O-DU can meet basic requirements of the O-RAN fronthaul to support 35 
configured delay management parameters for transmissions from the O-DU to the O-RU for the C-Plane and U-36 
Plane protocol.  To exercise both the downlink O-DU adherence to the configured delay management and the 37 
required counters on the O-DU related to delay management in the uplink, a UE in connected mode is required.  38 
 39 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 40 
The O-DU DUT must be provisioned to connect with a O-RU for 5G New Radio and be able to synchronize with 41 
the O-RU emulator or real O-RU.  The O-DU DUT could use any of the NR profiles as specified in the Fronthaul 42 
Interoperability Test Specification [25],  Annex A.2.   The counters in table 7-1 of the CUS Fronthaul protocol 43 
specification [2] for on-time reception on the O-DU must be supported and accessible.  44 
 45 
C. Test Methodology 46 
d. Initial Conditions 47 
Configure the O-DU DUT such that it is ready to accept a UE connection through its interfaces with 48 
the appropriate entities in the TED.  Configure the O-RU emulator per the parameters of the chosen 49 
IOT profile. Using the M-Plane or other manual methods, configure the delay parameters in table 2-7 50 
to achieve proper timing on the O-RU emulator.  51 

 
________________________________________________________________________________________________ 
Copyright © 2022 by the O-RAN ALLIANCE e.V. 
Your use is subject to the terms of the O-RAN Adopter License Agreement in the Annex ZZZ.       357 
                                                                                        O-RAN.WG4.CONF.0-v05.00 
e. Procedure 1 
1. Clear the O-DU delay management receive counters or note the current value. 2 
2. Instruct the UE Emulator to initiate a connection with the O-DU DUT through the O-RU emulator 3 
3. Initiate data transmission on both the downlink and uplink  4 
4. Validate that the O-DU adheres to the downlink delay management parameters using the O-RU 5 
emulator receive counters for on-time, early and late arrival for the C-Plane and the U-Plane for 6 
each configured eAxC.   7 
5. Validate that the O-DU receive counters for on-time arrival for the C-Plane and the U-Plane for 8 
each configured eAxC increment as expected and that early and late counters remain unchanged 9 
(e.g. 0 if the test started with these counters at 0). 10 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 11 
1. O-DU receive (uplink) counters (RX_ON_TIME, RX_EARLY, RX_LATE, RX_ON_TIME) for each 12 
configured eAxC for the U-Plane are observed.  Only RX_ON_TIME should show non-zero values or 13 
changed values if the counters could not be cleared.  14 
2. O-RU emulator (downlink) receive counters report that only on-time PDUs are received. No early or late 15 
PDUs are received.  16 
 17 
 Delay Management Early Arrival and Late Arrival 18 
A. Test Description and Applicability 19 
This test is MANDATORY. 20 
 21 
The purpose of this test is to validate the operation of the O-DU delay management receive counters for the C-22 
Plane and U-Plane protocol .  To exercise these counters, a UE in connected mode is required. 23 
 24 
B. Test Entrance Criteria 25 
The O-DU DUT must be provisioned to connect with a O-RU for 5G New Radio and be able to synchronize with 26 
the O-RU emulator or real O-RU.  The O-DU DUT could use any of the NR profiles as specified in the Fronthaul 27 
Interoperability Test Specification [25], Annex A.2.   The counters in table 7-1 of the CUS Fronthaul protocol 28 
specification [2] for on-time reception on the O-DU must be supported and accessible.  29 
 30 
C. Test Methodology 31 
a. Initial Conditions 32 
Configure the O-DU DUT such that it is ready to accept a UE connection through its interfaces with the 33 
appropriate entities in the TED.  Configure the O-RU emulator per the parameters of the chosen IOT profile. 34 
Using the M-Plane or other manual methods, for the appropriate step below, configure the delay parameters 35 
in table 2-7 of [2] to force early or late PDU transmission of the U-Plane PDUs to the O-DU.  36 
b. Procedure 37 
1. Clear the O-DU delay management receive counters or note the current value 38 
2. Force the O-RU emulator to send U-Plane PDUs to the O-DU “early” such that they arrive at the O-DU 39 
outside the receive window.  40 
3. Instruct the UE Emulator to initiate a connection with the O-DU DUT through the O-RU emulator. 41 
4. Initiate data transmission on both the downlink and uplink  42 
5. Validate that the O-DU counters for RX_EARLY for U-Plane for each configured eAxC are 43 
incrementing.  44 
6. Clear the O-DU delay management receive counters or note the current value 45 
7. Force the O-RU emulator to send U-Plane PDUs to the O-DU “late” such that they arrive at the O-DU 46 
outside the receive window.  47 
8. Instruct the UE Emulator to initiate a connection with the O-DU DUT through the O-RU emulator. 48 
9. Initiate data transmission on both the downlink and uplink  49 
10. Validate that the O-DU counters for RX_LATE for U-Plane for each configured eAxC are 50 
incrementing.  51 
 52 
D. Test Requirement (expected result) 53 
Steps 5 and 10 show the expected counter(s) incremented 54 
  55

Annex ZZZ : O-RAN Adopter License Agreement 1 
BY DOWNLOADING, USING OR OTHERWISE ACCESSING ANY O-RAN SPECIFICATION, ADOPTER 2 
AGREES TO THE TERMS OF THIS AGREEMENT. 3 
This O-RAN Adopter License Agreement (the “Agreement”) is made by and between the O-RAN Alliance and the 4 
entity that downloads, uses or otherwise accesses any O-RAN Specification, including its Affiliates (the “Adopter”). 5 
This is a license agreement for entities who wish to adopt any O-RAN Specification. 6 
Section 1: DEFINITIONS 7 
1.1 “Affiliate” means an entity that directly or indirectly controls, is controlled by, or is under common control with 8 
another entity, so long as such control exists. For the purpose of this Section, “Control” means beneficial ownership of 9 
fifty (50%) percent or more of the voting stock or equity in an entity. 10 
1.2 “Compliant Implementation” means any system, device, method or operation (whether implemented in hardware, 11 
software or combinations thereof) that fully conforms to a Final Specification. 12 
1.3 “Adopter(s)” means all entities, who are not Members, Contributors or Academic Contributors, including their 13 
Affiliates, who wish to download, use or otherwise access O-RAN Specifications. 14 
1.4 “Minor Update” means an update or revision to an O-RAN Specification published by O-RAN Alliance that does 15 
not add any significant new features or functionality and remains interoperable with the prior version of an O-RAN 16 
Specification. The term “O-RAN Specifications” includes Minor Updates. 17 
1.5 “Necessary Claims” means those claims of all present and future patents and patent applications, other than design 18 
patents and design registrations, throughout the world, which (i) are owned or otherwise licensable by a Member, 19 
Contributor or Academic Contributor during the term of its Member, Contributor or Academic Contributorship; (ii) 20 
such Member, Contributor or Academic Contributor has the right to grant a license without the payment of 21 
consideration to a third party; and (iii) are necessarily infringed by a Compliant Implementation (without considering 22 
any Contributions not included in the Final Specification). A claim is necessarily infringed only when it is not possible 23 
on technical (but not commercial) grounds, taking into account normal technical practice and the state of the art 24 
generally available at the date any Final Specification was published by the O-RAN Alliance or the date the patent 25 
claim first came into existence, whichever last occurred, to make, sell, lease, otherwise dispose of, repair, use or operate 26 
a Compliant Implementation without infringing that claim. For the avoidance of doubt in exceptional cases where a 27 
Final Specification can only be implemented by technical solutions, all of which infringe patent claims, all such patent 28 
claims shall be considered Necessary Claims. 29 
1.6 “Defensive Suspension” means for the purposes of any license grant pursuant to Section 3, Member, Contributor, 30 
Academic Contributor, Adopter, or any of their Affiliates, may have the discretion to include in their license a term 31 
allowing the licensor to suspend the license against a licensee who brings a patent infringement suit against the 32 
licensing Member, Contributor, Academic Contributor, Adopter, or any of their Affiliates. 33 
Section 2: COPYRIGHT LICENSE 34 
2.1 Subject to the terms and conditions of this Agreement, O-RAN Alliance hereby grants to Adopter a nonexclusive, 35 
nontransferable, irrevocable, non-sublicensable, worldwide copyright license to obtain, use and modify O-RAN 36 
Specifications, but not to further distribute such O-RAN Specification in any modified or unmodified way, solely in 37 
furtherance of implementations of an ORAN 38 
Specification. 39 
2.2 Adopter shall not use O-RAN Specifications except as expressly set forth in this Agreement or in a separate written 40 
agreement with O-RAN Alliance. 41 
Section 3: FRAND LICENSE 42 
3.1 Members, Contributors and Academic Contributors and their Affiliates are prepared to grant based on a separate 43 
Patent License Agreement to each Adopter under Fair Reasonable And Non- Discriminatory (FRAND) terms and 44 
conditions with or without compensation (royalties) a nonexclusive, non-transferable, irrevocable (but subject to 45 
Defensive Suspension), non-sublicensable, worldwide patent license under their Necessary Claims to make, have made, 46 
use, import, offer to sell, lease, sell and otherwise distribute Compliant Implementations; provided, however, that such 47 
license shall not extend: (a) to any part or function of a product in which a Compliant Implementation is incorporated 48

grant to Members, Contributors and Academic Contributors, as set forth in Section 3.3. For the avoidance of doubt, the 2

Section 4: TERM AND TERMINATION 21 
4.1 This Agreement shall remain in force, unless early terminated according to this Section 4. 22 
4.2 O-RAN Alliance on behalf of its Members, Contributors and Academic Contributors may terminate this Agreement 23 
if Adopter materially breaches this Agreement and does not cure or is not capable of curing such breach within thirty 24 
(30) days after being given notice specifying the breach. 25 
4.3 Sections 1, 3, 5 - 11 of this Agreement shall survive any termination of this Agreement. Under surviving Section 3, 26 
after termination of this Agreement, Adopter will continue to grant licenses (a) to entities who become Adopters after 27 
the date of termination; and (b) for future versions of ORAN Specifications that are backwards compatible with the 28 
version that was current as of the date of termination. 29 
Section 5: CONFIDENTIALITY 30 
Adopter will use the same care and discretion to avoid disclosure, publication, and dissemination of O-RAN 31 
Specifications to third parties, as Adopter employs with its own confidential information, but no less than reasonable 32 
care. Any disclosure by Adopter to its Affiliates, contractors and consultants should be subject to an obligation of 33 
confidentiality at least as restrictive as those contained in this Section. The foregoing obligation shall not apply to any 34 
information which is: (1) rightfully known by Adopter without any limitation on use or disclosure prior to disclosure; 35 
(2) publicly available through no fault of Adopter; (3) rightfully received without a duty of confidentiality; (4) disclosed 36 
by O-RAN Alliance or a Member, Contributor or Academic Contributor to a third party without a duty of 37 
confidentiality on such third party; (5) independently developed by Adopter; (6) disclosed pursuant to the order of a 38 
court or other authorized governmental body, or as required by law, provided that Adopter provides reasonable prior 39 
written notice to O-RAN Alliance, and cooperates with O-RAN Alliance and/or the applicable Member, Contributor or 40 
Academic Contributor to have the opportunity to oppose any such order; or (7) disclosed by Adopter with O-RAN 41 
Alliance’s prior written approval. 42 
Section 6: INDEMNIFICATION 43 
Adopter shall indemnify, defend, and hold harmless the O-RAN Alliance, its Members, Contributors or Academic 44 
Contributors, and their employees, and agents and their respective successors, heirs and assigns (the “Indemnitees”), 45 
against any liability, damage, loss, or expense (including reasonable attorneys’ fees and expenses) incurred by or 46 
imposed upon any of the Indemnitees in connection with any claims, suits, investigations, actions, demands or 47 
judgments arising out of Adopter’s use of the licensed O-RAN Specifications or Adopter’s commercialization of 48 
products that comply with O-RAN Specifications. 49
